column2: Russia’s accession to the W.T.O. has been a key goal of the “reset” between Russia and the United States, a reconciliation whose future is uncertain amid political change.
A practice referred to in a criminal case against an aide in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s 2009 campaign has been associated for decades with efforts to suppress votes.
The buses from World Wide Travel, which operated the one that crashed in March, killing 15 people, were shifted to a new company, state officials said.
Killing the leader of a terrorist group is not the best way to weaken the organization.
The governor of New Jersey, who has ruled out a 2012 bid, calls political commentators who wrote about his weight the “most ignorant.”
Not one of 31 schools visited by officials was in full compliance with state guidelines, an audit by the city comptroller found.
The unusual circumstances under which a convicted killer lost his right to appeal are the subject of a Supreme Court hearing.
Why writing off debts may not necessarily increase economic growth; and why investors should be on the lookout for Apple’s new creative/destructive impacts.
After undergoing a $3 million renovation, the Center for Architecture in Greenwich Village has expanded again, inspiring other projects across the country.
The trial of Barbara Sheehan had accounts of upper-middle-class rituals alternated with stories of hellish brutality.
Insurgents in Afghanistan use tactics like controlling the hours of cellphone use, in addition to selected attacks and some new flexibility on matters like education.
Many major retailers plan to hire more workers during the lucrative holiday season, a reflection of statistics that show consumers just keep shopping despite the troubled economy.
The defendant was captured on a plane bound for Detroit from Amsterdam in 2009 and accused of trying to ignite a bomb hidden in his underwear.
Fiona Reid was chief financial officer of the 2009 Bloomberg re-election campaign, from which, prosecutors say, John F. Haggerty Jr. stole $1.1 million.
Mr. Porat opposed the removal of Jews from any land in exchange for peace with Israel’s neighbors.
At a meeting, leaders in Iraq agreed on the need to keep military trainers into 2012 but rebuffed a key American demand.
The price of a gallon of regular has fallen nearly a penny a day over the last four weeks, averaging $3.41 nationwide on Tuesday.
Déjà vu was back, with the Yanks relying upon an unlikely starter, A. J. Burnett, to get them back to the Bronx. This Motor City game of chicken had not happened for all of five years.
Mercedes-Benz has purchased the rights to rename the Superdome in New Orleans.
Chanel, Yves Saint Laurent, Valentino and Giambattista Valli show their spring 2012 collections in Paris.
Tens of thousands of boys under the age of 18 witnessed the brutality of the Civil War firsthand.
A resolution demanded the immediate end to all violence in Syria. European members of the Security Council had weakened references to sanctions in an attempt to prevent a veto, to no avail.
Readers respond to an article about nurses using the title of doctor.
Gene Monahan, the team’s trainer for 39 years and the man who memorializes baseballs used for Yankees achievements, will become a Nascar volunteer.
A reader responds to an article about potential reductions in the health and pension benefits of military retirees.
Commissioner David Stern announced the cancellation of the rest of the preseason and said that the first two weeks of the regular season would be canceled Monday.
Gender politics is displayed in the flesh in Fitzgerald & Stapleton’s work “The Smell of Want.”
Reflecting on the evolution of Napa cabernets at a tasting of 20 old vintages of Charles Krug Vintage Selection cabernet sauvignons, from the 1961 to 1991.
Mattel is using Monster High, the No. 3 fashion doll line behind Barbie and Disney Princess, to address school bullying.
Paula Wolfert, an American writer, and Mourad Lahlou, a chef from Casablanca who cooks in San Francisco, have both written new Moroccan cookbooks — from diametrically opposed perspectives.
A recipe for Moroccan Almond-Argan Butter.
A recipe for Moroccan pancakes (beghrir).
A recipe for Berber Skillet Bread.
Forty-five neuroscientists respond to a recent Op-Ed about using brain imaging to analyze our attachment to digital devices.
New films by Bela Tarr of Hungary and Nuri Bilge Ceylan of Turkey are landmarks at the New York Film Festival.
The president of Focus on the Family responds to a news article about companies under scrutiny for indirect funding of anti-gay religious groups.
Caorunn gin from Scotland offers herbal complexity, thanks to native botanicals like heather, rowan berry and dandelion.
In separate suits, New York’s attorney general and the United States attorney in Manhattan say the bank it overcharged customers almost $2 billion in foreign transactions.
Julia Child’s “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” is joining the e-book revolution.
“Benito Cereno” by Robert Lowell, is certainly poetic, and its questions concerning cruelty and civilized life are ripe for inquiry.
Martin Scorsese’s two-part documentary about George Harrison is an argument for Harrison’s essential role in the culture.
Events benefiting upstate New York farmers, and a bazaar at the new DeKalb Market.
Bruno Benzacken and François Athea have graduated from selling their spices and tears at street fairs to opening a store in Grand Central Market.
Mediterranean Snack Food Lentil Crackers come in three flavors: sea salt, cracked pepper and rosemary herb.
Kibo, a Japanese restaurant for which Joël Robuchon is consulting, opens on Monday; Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare and Eleven Madison Park get three Michelin stars.
Is affinage the fine art of ripening cheese, or is it a simple marketing ploy?
A look at the cheeses aging in the caves at Murray’s, Artisanal and the Cellars at Jasper Hill.
Adrian Beltre hit three home runs as Texas eliminated Tampa Bay, three games to one, in their American League division series.
Some analysts doubt that the European Central Bank will cut rates, but almost all say it will need to do something at its meeting on Thursday.
In “The Music of Elliott Carter Interpreted,” the ballet choreographers Emery LeCrone and Avi Scher have created different new works to the same music by Mr. Carter.
The avant-garde composer Anthony Braxton will be honored in the Tri-Centric Festival in Brooklyn.
A decision in Syria to ban imports of consumer goods sent prices soaring and provoked outrage among a business elite that has until now backed the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad.
Not even Egypt’s interim military rulers know when they plan to relinquish power to a new civilian government, the United States Ambassador to Egypt, Anne W. Patterson, said Tuesday.
A single-engine helicopter, with five people onboard, went down moments after it took off from a helipad at East 34th Street, the authorities said.
The Unesco-Obiang Prize was financed by Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, a leader with a brutal reputation who has ruled the tiny state of Equatorial Guinea since a 1979 coup.
Calvin Tomkins will be honored by the Whitney Museum of American Art for his artist profiles in The New Yorker.
The Moscow String Quartet’s interpretation of Borodin’s String Quartet No. 2 was enhanced by the Frick Collection’s elegant space.
Cassandra Wilson’s two-night engagement at the Rose Theater was a sort of career retrospective.
The Vikings’ proposal for building a $1.1 billion N.F.L. stadium on a Superfund site in Arden Hills, Minn., with the public paying about 60 percent of the cost, has faced stiff opposition.
Don Kelly, the only active major league player who has played all nine positions, played one to perfection in Game 3 against the Yankees.
Afghanistan officials signaled on Tuesday they had little interest, for now, in healing a rift with Pakistan, their eastern neighbor.
Seven Kosovars are accused of luring victims from Turkey and former Communist countries to Pristina to sell their kidneys with false promises of payments of up to €15,000, or nearly $20,000.
The House vote keeps the government operating through mid-November and ends the threat of a government shutdown — for now.

Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continent’s powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.
Tertulia, the chef Seamus Mullen’s gastropub in the West Village, sees its roots in northern Spain, and its success in a cuisine that is equal parts pork and seafood, garlic and smoked paprika.
Although the new phone is virtually indistinguishable from its predecessor on the outside, the company says the iPhone 4S is packed with better technical innards, including a more advanced camera.
With two layers of cookie surrounding a peanut butter filling, these treats will go fast.

Torture, watch lists and increased surveillance are among the ways that the government has infringed on human rights and the rule of law since 9/11, says an official of the A.C.L.U. Readers are invited to respond.
Ending a late flurry of indecision, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced on Tuesday that he had decided not to seek the presidency.

The Los Angeles Philharmonic, under leadership of the music director Gustavo Dudamel, is setting up a training program based on El Sistema, the Venezuelan-based movement that weds music teaching and social work.
The case of Mr. Olson caused a public uproar in the early 1980s after the authorities admitted paying him $100,000 to reveal the locations of his victims’ bodies.
It’s time for Republicans to start learning to love at least one of the candidates now running, since the field seems unlikely to change.

Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continent’s powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.
Activists were held in a nationwide sweep tied to an investigation of insurgent attacks.
A Chinese official said that a Senate bill, which threatens higher tariffs on some imports if China is found to be manipulating its currency, violated the rules of the World Trade Organization.
After decades of public mistrust, steps are being taken to combat dysfunction outlined in a Justice Department report.
“We are the epicenter of this global crisis,” Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Tuesday at the European Parliament.
Ben S. Bernanke told a Congressional committee that the Federal Reserve stood ready to do more to support growth, but said the rest of the government also needs to act.
Three brothers of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident writer who was given the Nobel Peace Prize last year, were allowed to visit him in a prison in northeast China.
Eight years after the NFL Network’s birth, Time Warner Cable still won’t show it.
Delta Airlines recently announced that it would probably drop or reduce air service to 24 smaller cities, but Hibbing officials say the flights are important to them.
A hopeful report on European banks prompted a late rally after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index officially traded in bear-market territory much of the day.
Three American-born scientists won the prize for their studies of exploding stars that revealed that the expansion of the universe is accelerating.
In a fresh blow to public confidence, a reactor in southern Japan went into automatic shutdown on Tuesday because of problems with its cooling system.
“Hell and Back Again,” a documentary by Danfung Dennis, follows Sgt. Nathan Harris, a Marine recovering from a shattered hip and leg.
Union workers at Ford will vote over the next two weeks on the agreement, which calls for the company to create 5,750 entry-level jobs.
Relatives of Meredith Kercher, the 21-year-old murdered in 2007, said Tuesday that the family was still awaiting the “full truth,” which they believe could emerge in the next phase of the case.
A blast in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, killed more than 50 people and possibly signaled a comeback for the Islamic militant group known as the Shabab.
The Dalai Lama had plans to attend an 80th birthday celebration for South Africa’s Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu but did not receive a visa to travel.
The Amanda Knox trial may be over, but the case has lost none of its power to polarize.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a bus in southwest Pakistan on Tuesday, killing at least 13 Shiite Muslims and wounding another seven, officials said.
The Bangladeshi restaurant Neerob, in the Bronx, is a de facto social center, partly for the genial atmosphere but principally for the food.
A recipe for Pork Katsu With Pickled Cucumbers and Shiso.
Japanese pork katsu is easy to make at home, especially if you borrow some techniques from schnitzel, its Austrian sibling.
Pears with radicchio and endive can accompany bubbly Gorgonzola crostini, hot from the oven.
A recipe for Gorgonzola Walnut Crostini With Pear Salad.

KILLIAN--Susan, Z.,died on September 26, 2011 at the age of 64. She was a resident of Westport, CT. Beloved wife of Laurence, mother of Sean and Matthew and grandmother of Kevon. Sister of Peter Zelter, Judith Zelter, Mary Beth John and Andrew Zelter. Susan was a loving mother and grandmother who alway put her family first. She was a college graduate who most recently worked for Pfizer. Family and friends will dearly miss her.

Madonna and the National Football League are discussing a deal under which the pop diva would perform at halftime during the Super Bowl in February, but the details have yet to be ironed out, a person familiar with the talks said. -Neither the N.F.L. nor Madonna's spokeswoman would comment on the talks. ''I can not announce that this is a done deal at this time,'' Madonna's spokeswoman, Liz Rosenberg, said in an e-mail. ''I can not give you an official confirmation.''

In the wake of another sizable drop in attendance, the Mets have announced that they were again cutting ticket prices. The Mets' attendance fell 7 percent in 2011, their second annual decline since moving to Citi Field, as the team logged its third consecutive fourth-place finish. That, with the continued weak economy, prompted the team to readjust prices for many of its season tickets in hopes of prompting fans to return.

KENNY--Peter J. on October 3, 2011 of Plandome, New York. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of James (Colleen), Patricia Anne Reilly (Timothy), Christine Goettelmann (George) and Kevin (JoAnne). Cherished grandfather of Brigid, Caitlyn, Casey, Sean, Ryan, Megan, Brendan, Brian, Tatum, Kelly, Patrick, Tommy, Teddy and Lilly. Brother of Gerard, Michael, Marianne and the late Bernard. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, New York, Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday 10am at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery Pt. Washington. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Autism Speaks, 1 East 33rd Street, 4th floor, New York, NY 10016 www.Autismspeaks.org

Any taxi-riding, bodega-shopping, laundromat-using New Yorker knows that immigrants own many of the businesses that make New York tick. Now a new study shows that while immigrants constitute just over a third of the city's population, they make up nearly half of the city's small-business owners. The study, published Monday by the Fiscal Policy Institute and based on census data, found that more than 69,000 New York City business owners - about 48 percent of the total - are foreign born. These immigrant entrepreneurs hail from around the world and run companies in every sector of the economy. But in certain lines of business, including dry cleaning, taxi services and grocery stores, the study shows that immigrant owners dominate.

As ''The Simpsons'' character Troy McClure once asked about that popular Fox cartoon family, ''Who knows what adventures they'll have between now and the time the show becomes unprofitable?'' That question didn't seem so funny on Tuesday, as a pay dispute between the ''Simpsons'' actors who provide the voices of Homer, Bart, Marge and company, and the studio that produces that long-lived animated comedy threatened the possibility of ending the series after more than 20 years on the air.

1:15 P.M. (IFC) CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER (2006) A cruel emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) and his secretive wife (Gong Li, above with Mr. Chow) plot each other's annihilation: he, by destroying her sanity with a rare fungus; she, by planning a bloody coup during a festival and persuading one of her three sons (Jay Chou) to join her revolt. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that this martial arts drama from the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, set in A.D. 928, ''achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.'' She added: ''Since his debut in 1987 with 'Red Sorghum' Mr. Zhang has made more controlled films but never one that's more fun. With 'Curse of the Golden Flower' he aims for Shakespeare and winds up with Jacqueline Susann. And a good thing too.'' 6 A.M. (Oxygen) A WALK ON THE MOON (1999) Diane Lane plays Pearl Kantrowitz, a housewife who each summer totes her ironing board, children and mother-in-law to a camp in the Catskills while her husband, Marty (Liev Schreiber), stays in New York City, repairing television sets. Viggo Mortensen is the hippie salesman who turns her life upside down in 1969, as the moon walk and Woodstock loom. Writing in The Times about this romance from Tony Goldwyn, Janet Maslin said, ''Even when it turns turbulent, the film sustains its warm summer glow, and makes itself a conversation piece about the moral issues it means to raise.''

COHEN--Max, M.D. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children and his entire family. Eric R. Marcus, M.D., Director CU Psychoanalytic Center Henry P. Schwartz, M.D., President, APM

8:23 p.m. | Updated The first batch of checks for eligible victims of Bernard L. Madoff's epic Ponzi scheme will go into the mail starting Wednesday, according to the trustee liquidating the Madoff estate in federal bankruptcy court.

There may not be two more distinctly different players in the league, but somehow, they play the same position. Wes Welker is one of the shortest, smallest players in the N.F.L. He was a star high school football player in Oklahoma, but he couldn't even get a scholarship from Tulsa. Despite a great career at Texas Tech, the 5-foot-9, 185-pound Welker was never invited to the N.F.L. scouting combine. He was not drafted. He was signed as a free agent by the Chargers, then cut after one game.

SAMUELS--Annette J.,the first African American woman to serve as a spokesperson in Jimmy Carter's Administration, died on Sept 26, 2011 in Camas, WA. Viewing 12pm-3pm, Service 3-4:30pm on Thursday, October 6, 2011 at Unity Funeral Chapel, 2352 8th Avenue, New York, NY 10027.

MYERS--Robert John, age 87, died in Palo Alto, CA on September 18, 2011. Born in Elkhart, Indiana on January 1, 1924, he attended DePauw University before joining the US Army in 1943. He was recruited into the OSS and went to China in 1945, assigned to the Eagle Project for Korean independence. In 1946, he returned to the University of Chicago, where he later obtained his PhD under Hans Morgenthau. He joined the CIA in 1949, assigned to Japan, Taiwan, Korea and Indonesia. He served as Cambodia station chief from 1960-62 and as Deputy Chief of the Far East Division 1963-1965. Upon his resignation from the CIA, he was awarded the Intelligence Medal. He was co-founder and publisher of The Washingtonian magazine in 1965. From 1968 through 1979, he was publisher of The New Republic. While in DC, he enjoyed writing fiction and political satire. From 1980-1994, he was president of the Carnegie Council for Ethics and International Affairs in New York. During his tenure, the Council developed dynamic programs examining questions of human rights, ethics and moral philosophy in partnership with diverse institutions throughout the world. Upon retirement, he and his wife Betty moved to California, where he was a fellow at the Hoover Institution from 1995-2007, completing two books; U.S. Policy in the 21st Century: The Relevance of Realism (1999) and Korea in the Cross Currents: A Century of Struggle and the Crisis of Reunification (2001). He enjoyed tennis and golf, was a White Sox fan and a jazz aficionado. Family, friends and colleagues benefited from his encouragement and ability to connect people through his wide-ranging interests and creativity. We will miss his wit and humor and incisive analyses. He was preceded in death by his wife, Elizabeth Watson Myers, in 1998, and a son, Timothy John Myers, in 2003. He is survived by his daughters, Holly Myers, of Portola Valley, CA and Lauchlin Myers, of Berkeley; his sons in law, Kirk Neely and Mark Liebman; and seven grandchildren.

Dr. Robert Feig, a retina specialist in Brooklyn and the Bronx, says he wants to save patients and Medicare money by treating eye diseases with a drug that costs $50 a dose, rather than one that costs $2,000 a dose. But three recent incidents around the country in which a total of 21 patients lost some or all vision in the affected eye after injections of the less expensive drug have made him fearful of a malpractice lawsuit, should something similar happen at his practice.

NBC, reacting quickly to the collapse of its Monday-night drama, ''The Playboy Club,'' announced a series of programming moves Tuesday, led by the cancellation of that 10 p.m. show (with Laura Benanti, above) and the addition of a newsmagazine hosted by its main news anchor, Brian Williams. ''Rock Center With Brian Williams'' had been rumored for weeks to be in rapid production mode to get ready to fill the slot where ''Playboy'' was languishing. On Tuesday NBC made the switch, announcing that the new program would occupy the 10 p.m. slot on Mondays beginning Oct. 31. The newsmagazine will feature Meredith Vieira, Harry Smith, Kate Snow, Ann Curry, Nancy Snyderman, Richard Engel and Matt Lauer as correspondents. As ''The Playboy Club'' was winning the trophy for first new series canceled this season, NBC also announced that it was ordering a full season of episodes of two new comedies, ''Up All Night'' and ''Whitney.''

BUCHBINDER--Mae. She recognized him as her blind date because he had a rose in his teeth. Her Norman recognized her for the tall stunningly elegant beauty who would share and enhance a long, often madcap life together. Heaven now has both halves of this classic pair. It is to their two lovely and loving daughters-Lori and Susan-and their husbands, Ray McDaniel and Bill Abramson, and their four children that we send our love. Donald Menzi and Jane Weprin-Menzi
ROSEN--Milt, founding Chair, Progressive Labor Party. Sunday, October 9, 2011, 1:30pm. Greenwood Baptist Church, Brooklyn, NY. 461 6th Street (at 7th Avenue).

KNOPF--Lucy, passed away on October 2, 2011. Born Lucia Cantarella on July 13, 1923. Beloved mother of Siegfried, mother-in-law of Dr. Nancy Needell and grandmother of Julian. Adored aunt of Mark, Ray, Glenn, Regina and Morgan Cantarella and great-aunt of Desiree, Brandon, Jeremy, Vanessa, Shauna, Jenna, Justin, Mandy, Erin, Karl, and Austin. Exuberant member of St Francis Xavier Church. Had careers in nursing, nursing research and dance in which she touched many lives. Avid ballroom dancer. Active in the Sacred Dance Guild. Longtime peace activist including Women in Black, Pax Christi. Viewing Thursday, October 6, 4-9pm at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., New York City; Service Saturday, October 8, 9am at Xavier, W. 16th St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mercy Center, Bronx, NY.

ZELTZER--George. The Board, Staff, Artists and Scholars of the Foundation for Jewish Culture express heartfelt condolences to the family of our founder, President, and longtime champion, George M. "Mike" Zeltzer, whose leadership & generosity nurtured Jewish culture and scholarship in Detroit & across the country for over 50 years. Mike, alongside his beloved Pearl, was prescient about the transformative role of culture in Jewish life. His strength of character and devotion to scholarship and the arts was a gift and will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Foundation for Jewish Culture

STEINMAN--Ralph M. The Rockefeller University community mourns with deep sadness the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Ralph Steinman. Dr. Steinman was an immunologist whose discovery of the dendritic cell expanded our understanding of the immune system and promises to revolutionize the way disease is treated. For this work, he was awarded the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. In addition to the Nobel Prize, he was honored with the Albert Lasker Basic Medical Research Award, the Albany Medical Center Prize and the Gairdner Foundation International Award, among many others. He was elected a member of the National Academy of Sciences and its Institute of Medicine. Dr. Steinman served the university with distinction for more than 40 years. He was the Henry Kunkel Professor and director of the Christopher H. Browne Center for Immunology and Immune Diseases, and he was a senior physician at The Rockefeller University Hospital. Dr. Steinman was a gifted teacher and mentor, and he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Claudia, his children, Adam, Alexis and Lesley, his mother, Nettie, and the entire Steinman family, as well as his many friends on campus. Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Paul Nurse and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti

HOSTILE JUDGE An unusually hostile ruling emerged from a Manhattan courtroom when a federal judge assailed the Securities and Exchange Commission for weak oversight. It was unusual, because its author was not Judge Jed S. Rakoff, who has made the S.E.C. a regular recipient of his wrath. Judge William H. Pauley III criticized the agency for failing to keep an eye on a private firm that it hired to dole out $25 million in settlement funds to investors in Zurich Financial Services. The judge took the S.E.C. to task for its ''unseemly'' oversight of the Garden City Group, which sought to collect its own steep $1 million fee. ''The question that occurs to this court, but apparently not to the S.E.C., is, was such an expensive notice program effective?'' Judge Pauley wrote.

VENTER--Josiah Barnum, 65, Director at Ingalls & Snyder in New York, died October 2, 2011 in New Haven. A Navy Vietnam veteran and avid sailor, Josh had a life-long commitment to the New Haven community. Devoted husband of Martha Reynolds and father of Molly and Josiah. Services, 2:30pm, Wednesday, Trinity Church on the Green, New Haven, CT.
Chelsea Clinton as a corporate director? Really? Ms. Clinton was appointed last week to the board of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet media conglomerate controlled by Barry Diller.

-Before he could react, George Bardwil had a gun pointed in his face. -It was Monday afternoon when Mr. Bardwil, a linen manufacturer, answered a call at his garden apartment on East 51st Street in Manhattan and was confronted by two robbers - one armed with a black semiautomatic handgun.

STEINMAN--Ralph. The Scientific Advisors and Board of Directors of the Lupus Research Institute extend a memorial tribute to Nobel Prize winner Dr. Ralph Steinman whose work revolutionized our understanding of the immune system. Dr. Steinman's discovery of dendritic cells and their essential role in activating the immune system paved the way for new vaccines and immunotherapies, including new treatments in development for autoimmune diseases such as lupus. The Lupus Research Institute and the entire lupus community is indebted to Dr. Steinman for his landmark contribution to immunology research.

Europe's biggest banks may finally be forced to own up to their losses. While bank executives and government leaders have been reluctant to acknowledge that the hundreds of billions of euros of Greek debt held by financial institutions is worth far less than its face value, they are slowly accepting the grim reality, as investors, clients and lenders grow increasingly wary.

LEVIN--Leona. Deepest condolences to Alisa and Chuck, Rhea, Lily and Sam and Tilly, on the loss of Leona Levin. Leona was a beautiful, strong, independent woman. Her worth was far above rubies. Foundation for Jewish Culture

An article on Friday about the French police interrogation of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, and a French writer who has accused him of trying to rape her eight years ago misstated the given name of one of his lawyers, who said after the interrogation that Mr. Strauss-Kahn had repeated his denial of the accusation, ''didn't apologize and had no reason to do so.'' The lawyer is Frédérique Beaulieu, not Frédé.

It may be the first time a foreword to a cookbook has confirmed hot restaurant news. In the introduction of the volume in question, ''The Eleven Madison Park Cookbook,'' Danny Meyer, the principal owner of the Manhattan restaurant that has been the cynosure of his empire, confirmed speculation on Eater.com that he intended to sell the restaurant to its executive chef and general manager - Daniel Humm and Will Guidara - and their financial backers.

BUCHBINDER--Mae. The entire staff of Buchbinder & Warren mourns the passing of Mae, the beloved wife of Norman and cherished mother of Lori and Susan Buchbinder. Mae's love and determination, with her boundless support for her family and their endeavors, really was the wind beneath their wings. Our deepest condolences to Lori, Susan, Ray, Bill, Jake, David, Jade and Mia. Services: Thursday, 10:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Bank of America's Web site continued to be troubled by sporadic problems for much of the day on Tuesday, as has been the case in four of the last five days. Visitors to the site were greeted with this message: ''We're sorry, our site is running slowly.''

Emanuel Litvinoff, an English-born Jewish poet known for his scathing verse indictment of T. S. Eliot's anti-Semitism -- and for reading it before an audience that happened to include Eliot -- died on Sept. 24 at his home in London. He was 96. His son Aaron confirmed the death.

An article last Wednesday about the United States Farmers and Ranchers Alliance, an agricultural industry promotional organization, described the National Milk Producers Federation, an alliance member, incorrectly. It is a lobbying group, not a marketing group. The article also misidentified the sponsor of the ''Got Milk?'' advertising campaign. It is the California Milk Processor Board, which is not an alliance member -- not the milk producers federation. The article also misidentified another alliance member. It is the American Meat Institute, not the American Meat Producers Association, which does not exist. And the article misstated the name of a Web site run by the institute. It is meatmythcrushers.com.

GRIFFITHS--Raymond Bert, died peacefully at home in New York City, October 3, 2011, at age 96, with pulmonary fibrosis. PhD (Biology) Princeton; MD Northwestern University. Captain, Army Medical Core, 1946 - 1948. Formally Executive Editor of The Journal of Cell Biology, Rockefeller University. Survived by his loving wife, Sylvia Preston, of 60 years, his daughter Wendy and son-in-law, Yuzuru Sadashige. Fondly remembered by his nieces, Janis Kerrick and Nancy Wood and brother-in-law, John Preston. Contributions in his memory may be sent to charity of your choice or VNSNY Hospice Care, 225 West 34th St., NY, NY 10122.

DETROIT - C. C. Sabathia has been a boon to the Yankees since he arrived in New York, going 59-23 with a 3.18 earned run average in three seasons, and leading the team, both on and off the field. In 2009, he repaid his huge contract by leading the Yankees all the way to a World Series championship. Sabathia says he loves pitching for the Yankees, but there is a small chance he threw his last pitch for them Monday night. In Game 3 of this American League division series, he started as the Yankees lost to the Detroit Tigers, 5-4, leaving them on the verge of elimination heading into Game 4 on Tuesday night.

Musicals with religious themes - as well as those with Andrew Lloyd Webber scores - are filling up Broadway theaters this season. The Stratford Shakespeare Festival's production of Mr. Lloyd Webber's ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' which has been an audience and critical favorite there since May, will transfer to Broadway and begin preview performances on March 1, 2012, at the Neil Simon Theater, the producers announced on Tuesday. The revival of the 1971 rock opera, which has lyrics by Tim Rice, will first move to the La Jolla Playhouse later this year. No casting was announced for the musical, about the last week of Jesus' life, but the positive response to the production (including from Mr. Lloyd Webber) has focused on the acting, particularly the leads playing Jesus, Judas, and Mary Magdalene.
BUCHBINDER--Mae. A deep friendship of the wives of partners for over 50 years. A beautiful lady of character and warmth. I will miss you all of my life. Mae, I love you. Gene

A picture on Tuesday with an obituary about the ballet dancer Alexander Grant was published in error. The photograph, supplied by Getty Images with incorrect identifications, showed the dancers Michael Somes and Violetta Elvin -- not Mr. Grant dancing with Margot Fonteyn.

Psychologists sometimes have a way of proving what you always suspected was true. A recent study of popular song lyrics done at the State University of New York in Albany shows not only that messages about sexual relationships dominate the songs at the top of the charts, but also that songs about sex sell better than other songs. Perhaps more surprising were the study's findings on the gaps between genres. The authors of the study, Dawn R. Hobbs and Gordon G. Gallup Jr., found a large difference between the ''reproductive messages'' embedded in country music and those found in pop and R&B. Successful country songs tended to have messages -- in descending order -- about long-term commitment to marriage, parenting children, break-ups and oaths of fidelity.

POPS--Martin Leonard, Professor of English at SUNY at Buffalo for over forty years, and author of books on Melville, Vermeer, and Albert Pinkham Ryder, died at his home in Buffalo on October 29 from complications of ALS. CHARLESTON, W.Va. - Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat, narrowly won a special election for governor on Tuesday, successfully defending himself against Republican attacks that tried to link him with President Obama and his health care overhaul. With about 94 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Tomblin led his Republican opponent, Bill Maloney, by about 3 percentage points, according to the Web site of the West Virginia Secretary of State.

The Houston Texans opened their game against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday with a 19-play touchdown drive that took 10 minutes 55 seconds. It was the longest drive by an N.F.L team since a New Orleans Saints march lasted 10:59 against the Oakland Raiders on Oct. 12, 2008. Houston's drive was a work of art, with Arian Foster rushing for 45 of his 155 yards and Matt Schaub completing five passes to a back or a tight end.

The company is set to report detailed third-quarter earnings on Oct. 25.

MYERS--Robert John. The Trustees and Staff of the Carnegie Council for Ethics in International Affairs mourn the death of Robert J. Myers, Council president 1980-1994. A man of extraordinary accomplishment he served his country and the world as a leading voice for ethics. Under his direction the Council developed creative educational programs for scholars, teachers, students and concerned citizens around the world. Bob's work emphasized the universality of ethical concern and the answers available to us through active reflection on world history and philosophy. His spirit continues to illuminate the Council's mission. We remain forever grateful. Joel H. Rosenthal, President

Dominique Strauss-Kahn has left New York for Paris, but the story of his sexual encounter with a hotel chambermaid, and the criminal case that developed and then was dropped, is just reaching book publishers. St. Martin's Press, part of Macmillan, said on Monday it had acquired a book by John Solomon, the Newsweek reporter who interviewed Nafissatou Diallo, the housekeeper who accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault in May. Mr. Solomon's book ''will report the inside story of how the DSK case was transformed from a slam-dunk, five-day indictment against Strauss-Kahn to a flat-out dismissal that turned the tables on his very accuser,'' a statement from the publisher said. The charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn -- who called the encounter ''an error'' and a ''moral failure'' but not a criminal act -- were dismissed in August after prosecutors said the accuser lacked credibility. Mr. Solomon is a former executive editor for The Washington Times and an investigative reporter for The Washington Post.

Morgan Stanley executives are battling a daily barrage of rumors and nay-saying to try to stem a sharp slide in the company's stock. It is a war that is being fought in large part in the shadows: against anonymous blogs and market whispers, but also against undefined fears about exposure to troubled European banks. While those worries are common to all the big Wall Street banks, Morgan Stanley, as the smallest, is perhaps the most vulnerable among them.

OLESKY--Edward Morris, passed away peacefully on October 4, 2011 in Basking Ridge, NJ at the age of 86. Edward was born in Rahway, NJ. He served his country proudly in World War II in the United States Navy, aboard the U.S.S. Ranger. For much of his life, Edward lived in Springfield, then Summit, New Jersey. He attended Syracuse University and worked in the garment industry his entire career, where he last served as President of B. Lippman, Inc. Throughout his life, Edward served in many community and public service positions including: an auxiliary policeman in Springfield, an Explorer Scout Advisor, a Democratic County Committeeman for Springfield, a member and chair of the Springfield Board of Adjustment, a founding member of Temple Sharey Shalom and a member of Temple Beth Ahm's Minionaires. He was also a volunteer with Meals on Wheels in Summit, the Rehab Center at Overlook Hospital and served as a teacher for the ESL-Connection at the Summit YMCA. He was an avid golfer and traveled extensively throughout the United States and Europe. His wife, Anne and his three children, Steven, Lisa and Jonathan, as well as nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren survive him. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Har Shalom, 104 Mount Horeb Road, Warren, NJ at 11:00am, Thursday, October 6, 2011, In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Sage Elder Care of Summit or Overlook Hospital.

When The Quad, the Times's college sports blog, put out a call for readers' recipes for tailgating parties, we honestly didn't expect much healthy eating. Of course, we've been surprised by some of the submissions. What should not have surprised us was that a recipe from a Southern city had an eye on calorie counting. We wouldn't expect that from Chicago, Green Bay or New York, where fans are pretty well bundled up for most of the season. This week's recipe is Buffalo chicken lettuce wraps, the spicy wing dish with a few of the calories lopped off. It's not too late to submit your own recipe for barbecue or chowder, or whatever makes your pregame feast tasty.

WEST HOMESTEAD, Pa. -- A long bike ride delivers you from one set of conditions to another. For almost a year -- well, O.K., 10 days, but it felt like a year -- I was riding in the damp and cold as a crummy weather front arrived over lower Michigan and Ohio and sat there. More than once I played the what-if game with myself: Would I trade a steady rain and a chilling wind for the heat and rolling hills of the Palouse in eastern Washington? How about for the endless prairie of Montana? A cyclist can appreciate all those challenges and enjoy meeting them, including the rain, but after a week or so of being soggy to the bone, the answer to every trade possibility was yes.

"100 Shoes" (The Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale, $25) is not a collection of fashion's most vertically daring heels, despite the Vivienne Westood platforms on the cover (and a preface by that stilt walker Sarah Jessica Parker). Instead it's a brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded: Moccasins were huge in Georgian England; American tango boots in the 1910s laced up like Grecian sandals; and that late-'60s prototype by Beth Levine - it kicks off the shoe slideshow above - seems to have come from a different planet.

"Basically they asked me, and I said O.K.," says the designer Gareth Pugh of his easy decision to collaborate with Melissa, the Brazilian shoe company best known for making synthetic vegan footwear with designers like Vivienne Westwood, Jason Wu and Jean Paul Gaultier. In fact, Pugh says that working with Melissa - a brand that took an early interest in his work (it helped sponsor his second fashion show back in 2006) - on his first-ever shoe collection and most mainstream venture yet feels "like a natural move." The six-piece Melissa + Gareth Pugh spring collection, which recently had its debut in Rio de Janeiro, was perfected via a steady stream of intercontinental e-mails in which Pugh would "tweak this, change that." "I'm a Virgo," he explains. "I'm very particular about how I want things to be." Here, Pugh's gothic-abstract aesthetic in Melissa's signature plastic: an exoskeletal sandal that inches over the ankle with a trio of vertebrae-like pieces in combinations of black, white and silver.

Mitt Romney's appearance before Christian conservatives this weekend is drawing some unwelcome attention because he is scheduled to appear right before someone known for making strident remarks on homosexuality, gay rights, Muslims and Mormons. The Values Voters Summit, a celebration of the political aims of the religious right, runs from Friday through Sunday in Washington, and is sponsored by the Family Research Council, the American Family Association and other evangelical Christian groups. The forum aims to energize social conservatives and test the fidelity of the candidates.

Denzel Washington has donated $2 million to his alma mater, Fordham University, to endow its first professorship in theater with the goal of attracting a well-known actor, director, playwright, designer or other artist to rotate into the position at the school's Lincoln Center theater program each fall, university officials announced on Tuesday. The Tony Award-winning stage and television actress Phylicia Rashad (''A Raisin in the Sun,'' ''The Cosby Show'') is the first to hold the endowed chair this fall; she is teaching an advanced acting course called ''Creating a Character.''

Her seven grandchildren adored her and relished the time they spent with Nana. The curtain has come down on a brilliant life. Bravo Marilyn.

PVBLIC, which has been making silk-screen T-shirts since 2002, has introduced a new collection inspired by Alaskan culture and folklore. Designed by Tara Ocello and Jayme Thaler, the line includes graphic tees and hoodies with Inuit coins and totem birds, but we like these leggings with a traditional tribal motif from ankle to thigh. Wear them with heels and an oversize button-down for evening, or dressed down with boots for daytime running around. ''The boots have to be low, though,'' Ms. Ocello advises, ''or you will lose half the print.'' Pvblic leggings, $90 at Eva New York, 355A Bowery; (212) 925-3890; farfetch.com.

An article on Saturday about efforts by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to reassure Jewish voters about President Obama's commitment to Israel gave an outdated role at Fox News for Dan Senor, who criticized the president's stance on Israel in a recent op-ed article for The Wall Street Journal. While Mr. Senor was under contract with Fox News at one point as a regular contributor, he now appears only as a guest on its programs, and therefore is not ''a Fox News commentator.''

Having survived Game 4 in Detroit, the Yankees will play the Tigers on Thursday night at Yankee Stadium in a deciding Game 5 of the American League division series. But while the Yankees are as much a part of October as Halloween, there is little precedent for them when it comes to playing at home in a do-or-die game in the first round. Since the wild-card format started in 1995, the Yankees have appeared in the division series in 15 out of 16 seasons, missing only once, when they failed to make the playoffs in 2008, Joe Girardi's first year as manager. Over all, the team is 9-6 in those series. Limiting the search to series that went five games cuts the total to five. Finding a series in which the Yankees had to win the deciding game at home leaves only 2001.

Adored aunt of Mark, Ray, Glenn, Regina and Morgan Cantarella and great-aunt of Desiree, Brandon, Jeremy, Vanessa, Shauna, Jenna, Justin, Mandy, Erin, Karl, and Austin. Exuberant member of St Francis Xavier Church. Had careers in nursing, nursing research and dance in which she touched many lives. Avid ballroom dancer. Active in the Sacred Dance Guild. Longtime peace activist including Women in Black, Pax Christi. Viewing Thursday, October 6, 4-9pm at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., New York City; Service Saturday, October 8, 9am at Xavier, W. 16th St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mercy Center, Bronx, NY.

The popular streaming video Web site Hulu is adding Spanish-language television shows for the first time. In a deal announced on Wednesday and to be carried out later this year, Hulu will have a selection of the Spanish-language soap opera dramas known as telenovelas and other shows from Univision, the leading Spanish language network in the United States.

WEIL--Leon J.,84, of NYC, on October 4, in Potomac MD, of complications following a heart attack. He now joins Mabel, his beloved wife of 59 years, who predeceased him by six months. Son of the late Lillian M. Rouse and Jerome L. Weil of NYC. Cherished father of Leon Jerome Jr, (Jerry), Kate and Cary, father-in-law of Gigi, Stuart and Rick. Adored grandfather of Ben, Harry, Lilly and Charlotte Weil, Emma Bauchner, and Jackson and Victoria Barnett. He graduated from Berkshire School and Princeton University. He served his country in the US Army Air Corps and the US Navy during WW II, and as US Ambassador to Nepal from 1984-87. He enjoyed a sixty year career as a trusted investment advisor, and was a partner or senior executive at several Wall Street firms including Steiner, Rouse and Co., Herzfeld and Stern, and Janney Montgomery Scott. He was an Exchange Official on the American Stock Exchange and served on various industry committees. A lifelong Republican and conservative, he was an enthusiastic fundraiser for many political campaigns, notably for James Buckley to the US Senate, and for President Ronald Reagan, who appointed him to the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports in 1981. He served as an official international election observer around the globe, and as special consultant to the UN Development Program, assisted in the development of capital market systems in Asia and Eastern Europe. A past governor of the Foreign Policy Association, he was at the time of his death a Director of the Council of American Ambassadors, International Foundation for Election Systems (IFES), Media Research Center, Parent's Television Council, Fund for American Studies, National Committee on American Foreign Policy, and American Himalayan Foundation, and an Advisor to Outward Bound. He was especially devoted to his alma mater, Berkshire School on whose Board he served for 33 years. Youthful and adventurous, he skied and played tennis with family and friends until his 80's, hiked throughout Nepal, Africa, Europe and the US, led Outward Bound trips for executives, ran the NYC Marathon, kayaked around Manhattan, climbed Kilimanjaro, and with Mabel, developed countless lasting friendships from Kitzbuhel to Kathmandu. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be sent to Leon Weil Fund c/o Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA 01257, or to any of the above organizations. Memorial service on October 19th at 1130am at the University Club, 1 W 54th St., NYC.

The first casualty of the new television season, ''The Playboy Club,'' which was canceled by NBC on Tuesday, was also one of the shows considered least likely to make it this season, according to players of The New York Times TV Ratings Game. Slightly more than a quarter of participants predicted the show would survive the season, and 12.3 percent of the participating readers correctly guessed that it would make it just three episodes. The only hourlong drama with poorer prospects than ''Playboy Club,'' according to readers, was ''Charlie's Angels.'' Only 5 percent of players had that ABC drama in their virtual prime-time lineups and 24.7 percent of the players thought the Angels would survive at least eight episodes.

MORGENSTERN--Robert, on October 4, 2011 in Del Ray Beach, FL at the age of 80. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Father of Dr. Eric (Dr. Sharon Scherl) and Ellen (Stephen Seckar). Cherished grandfather of Jacob, Randi and Jenna. Dr. Morgenstern practiced podiatry for 40 years in Queens and Brooklyn. Donations to: CURE PSP.

In a display of moxie worthy of Fanny Brice herself, the producers of the coming Los Angeles revival of ''Funny Girl'' said on Wednesday they would transfer that musical to the Imperial Theater on Broadway next April -- even though the show has yet to begin rehearsals. Ever since the producers disclosed in June 2010 that Bartlett Sher, a Tony Award winner for ''South Pacific,'' would direct a major revival of ''Funny Girl,'' Broadway theater owners and executives assumed that the show would eventually come their way - if Mr. Sher could first make it work out of town. That is no sure thing: ''Funny Girl'' has not been seen on Broadway in almost 50 years in part because of concerns that no actress could live up to Barbra Streisand, who played Fanny in the original 1964 production and won an Academy Award for best actress in 1969 for the film version. The producers announced in August that Lauren Ambrose, best known as Claire Fisher on the HBO series ''Six Feet Under,'' would play Fanny; the production will mark her Broadway debut in a musical.

An article on Sept. 29 about a man charged with plotting to attack the Pentagon and the United States Capitol with remote-controlled aircraft filled with plastic explosives misstated the means by which the man, Rezwan Ferdaus, acquired one such aircraft. He bought the aircraft with money that undercover F.B.I. agents provided to him; the agents did not provide him with the aircraft.
An obituary on Wednesday about Hanan Porat, a leader of Israel's religious settlement movement, misstated the number of children who survive him. It is 11, not four.

EVANS--William born Velvel Evenchik March 10, 1915 in Zembin Russia passed away on September 29 at the age of 96. As a young child Bill first migrated to Toronto Canada with his three brothers, two sisters and mother Rose. The family came to the United States when Bill was 15. He graduated from St. Johns University and then served in the U.S. Army during W.W. 11 stationed at the Panama Canal. Bill married Faye Furman, now deceased, in 1942. He was a fixture for over 50 years in the menswear manufacturing industry beginning as a salesman at Reliance Manufacturing company and ending as founder and vice president at Mens Wear International. Bill will be remembered for his 4:00 happy hour, his love of waffles and ice cream, but mostly for being the pillar of his family of siblings and many nieces and nephews. Bill was a most loving husband, father, grandfather, and great grandfather. He is survived by his children, Donald, Rene (Phil), Nina (Cary), his grandchildren, Dani (Jay), Casey (Spencer), Justen, Kyle, and his great grandchildren, Sammi, Avery, Alex, Ryan, and Zac. Papa Bill, we love you so very much and you will always be in our hearts.

SUBPRIME CARDS Two contrasting images of Capital One -- subprime credit card company or benevolent bank -- were presented Wednesday at a Federal Reserve hearing on its planned acquisition of ING Direct USA. To hear consumer advocates tell it, Capital One is an aggressive credit card company that preys on low-income borrowers. But Capital One argued that this was not the case. ''Responsible lending to these borrowers is not only acceptable, but also provides a source of credit and purchasing power for these customers,'' said its general counsel, John Finneran, above. But he did acknowledge that about a third of its credit card portfolio was subprime.

How quickly can you build a fish out of Legos? How about a ship, or a tree? Lego: Life of George, available in stores tomorrow, lets you test your pattern-matching skills under pressure, providing you have a camera-equipped iPhone or equivalent, and a free app called Life of George which is your blueprint, timer, progress tracker, and - most interestingly - your judge. The $30 kit includes 144 standard Legos blocks and a special cardboard grid that serves as a key for the app, required to help your camera see your work and grade your accuracy.

7:23 p.m. | Updated It was the Fourth of July weekend in 2008 at the Living Room Lounge in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, when a uniformed New York police officer issued a threat: No one, he said, ''messes with my cousin's place.'' The officer, Admir Kacamakovic, who was on duty at the time, would pepper-spray two patrons and handcuff one of them outside his cousin's lounge, federal prosecutors charged on Wednesday.

10 p.m. | Updated The operator of the Indian Point nuclear power complex has hired former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to vouch for the plant's safety in a new advertising campaign scheduled to begin next week. The campaign will include advertisements on cable television and in newspapers, a spokesman for the company, the Entergy Corporation, said Wednesday.

City and state officials on Wednesday agreed to a $73 million plan that would unlock an underutilized chunk of the Manhattan waterfront between East 38th and East 60th Streets, paving the way for a new United Nations office tower and esplanade along the East River. The deal would enable the city to plug in the largest remaining gap in the 32-mile Greenway around Manhattan as part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's effort to revitalize the city's waterfront for commercial, recreation and transportation purposes.

The Chicken Dance. The Electric Slide. And another of the songs Most Likely to Be Played at a Wedding, at least for theater fans, is ''Sunrise, Sunset,'' a ballad from the 1964 musical ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' Sung by Tevye and Golde during their daughter Tzeitel's wedding to the tailor Motel, the song is a melancholy look back at how time flies. But New York in 2011 is not a Russian shtetl. What if your boy is marrying a boy, or your girl is marrying a girl? Last Saturday, gay-friendly lyrics to ''Sunrise, Sunset,'' written by Sheldon Harnick, the ''Fiddler on the Roof'' lyricist, were sung at the nuptials of Richard Skipper and Daniel Sherman, in Tappan, N.Y. The actress Jana Robbins performed the number at the couple's wedding party. (Mr. Skipper and Mr. Sherman were officially married in July; Saturday's event was a reaffirmation of their vows for a larger group of family and friends.)

SATCHELS from the Cambridge Satchel Company, reminiscent of the school bags of 1950s England, made an emphatic appearance at New York Fashion Week. It's likely that most fans, including the stylist Brad Goreski (above left), are attracted to the unisex bags because of their fluorescent colors and friendly prices (around $150 to $250), but the bags' back story is good, too. Upon learning that her daughter was being bullied, Julie Deane, in Cambridge, England, set out to earn the money to send her children to private school. Reading the Harry Potter books with her family, she drew upon the bags that Harry and friends carried at Hogwarts. She made samples, bloggers got wind, and now she has a multimillion-dollar business, and starlets, like the enchanting Elle Fanning (right), toting her bags. They are available at cambridgesatchel.com, with custom embossing, if you like, and come November they will be at Bloomingdale's. P.S.: The kids are in private school.

The 1954 glass box at 510 Fifth Avenue is among the cultural heritage sites at risk, according to the annual list assembled by the World Monuments Fund, which was released on Wednesday. Noting that the controversial renovation of the building at 43rd Street, a branch of what was then the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, has been the subject of a court dispute, the fund said the case ''raises questions about the legality of recent alterations and the capacity of the New York City Landmarks Commission to enforce protective regulations.'' The Landmarks Preservation Committee has said it has made reasonable accommodations for a developer who needs to make the building economically viable but is otherwise restoring several of the building's historical elements.

J. Cole, a rapper signed to Jay-Z's record label, has taken the top spot on Billboard's album chart in a week when six new titles enter the Top 10. Mr. Cole, 26, is No. 1 with 218,000 sales of his debut studio album, ''Cole World: The Sideline Story'' (Roc Nation/Columbia), according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping last week's top seller, Tony Bennett's ''Duets II'' (Columbia), to No. 4 with 91,000 albums sold, a nearly 50 percent drop.

5:45 P.M. (Showtime) VALENTINO: THE LAST EMPEROR (2009) Matt Tyrnauer chronicles the life and times of the Italian designer Valentino Garavani, above, and the end of an era of haute couture. The film explores his fantasy vision for some of the world's most glamorous women (including Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis), his longtime romantic and business relationship with Giancarlo Giammetti, and his official retirement in 2007. The film offers ''only the sketchiest biography'' and few glimpses of his ''notoriously imperial lifestyle,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Still, ''watching the movie is a little like gorging on chocolate and Champagne until that queasy moment arrives when you realize you've consumed far too much.'' In ''Vidal Sassoon: The Movie'' (2011), at 7:30, Craig Teper examines the career of Mr. Sassoon, whose wash-and-wear philosophy changed the world of hairstyling. An ''extravagant verbal fusillade introduces a screen biography that sometimes feels like an infomercial,'' Mr. Holden wrote. Yes, ''it is all too much,'' he added. ''But in the documentary's defense, its upbeat tone, perky visual rhythm and sleek graphics capture the 'swinging '60s' aesthetic epitomized by Mr. Sassoon's major invention: the geometric 'five-point' haircut.'' 6 A.M. (Flix) BOEING BOEING (1965) Tony Curtis stars as Bernard Lawrence, a foreign correspondent in Paris who uses airline timetables -- and an understanding housekeeper (Thelma Ritter) -- to maintain relationships with three flight attendants (Dany Saval, Suzanna Leigh and Christiane Schmidtmer). Jerry Lewis is Robert Reed, his arch rival, who is intent on throwing the women off schedule.
STUART KING--Alix Elaine (Labouchere), died peacefully on 3rd October 2011. Beloved mother of Kathleen, Anne-Marie and Charles. Funeral service in London on October 10th at 11am.

UPDATE, 6:35 p.m.: Sarah Palin is not running for president. Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska, ended her inscrutable cat-and-mouse game with the political establishment on Wednesday afternoon by saying that she would not join the field of Republican candidates seeking her party's nomination, but would still work to oust President Obama.

FELLINI would have been spinning (cartwheels) in his grave had he witnessed the church-y proceedings on the runways of Paris this week. Taking in those shows, you might have suspected that some designers were reprising ''Roma,'' the director's 1972 cinematic tour of the Eternal City complete with a fashion show including priests on roller skates, robotic bishops in miters and stoles, and nuns in habits made of blinking Christmas lights. In Paris the references were mixed, of course. Some designers sought inspiration in ecclesiastical attire while others took their style cues from Cristóbal Balenciaga, whose own recently exhibited designs incorporated helmetlike veils, archangel shoulders, stiff peplums, loose blouses and billowing cloaks.

While the biggest rivals on Wall Street share a common disdain for new constraints on financial risk-taking, they're fighting over exactly how to tame the sprawling regulatory overhaul. Major industry lobbyists like the Chamber of Commerce and the American Bankers Association are split on crucial rules stemming from the Dodd-Frank Act, including restrictions on lending and the $600 trillion derivatives market, two areas at the center of the financial crisis. As federal officials flesh out some 300 new regulations, top companies and trade groups are squabbling over the fine print, each cheerleading for policies that suit their own businesses.

Trisha Brown, the modern dance choreographer, is to receive a ''Bessie'' award for lifetime achievement, the selection committee for the awards announced Tuesday. The Bessies, formally known as the New York Dance and Performance awards, and established in 1983 are named for the dance educator and mentor Bessie Schonberg. Ms. Brown's award is the first of what will become an annual honor for choreographers, Lucy Sexton, the director of the Bessies, said on Tuesday. Ms. Brown was cited by the selection committee for ''the influence of both her distinctive movement style and inquisitive choreographic drive'' throughout the world of dance. The award ceremony is to be held on Oct. 24 at the Apollo Theater and will be hosted by Bebe Neuwirth, with a performance by students from the Harlem School of the Arts.

The Rangers agitator Sean Avery cleared N.H.L. waivers on Wednesday, 24 hours after the Rangers placed him there. He was assigned to the team's American Hockey League affiliate in Hartford, the Connecticut Whale. It came as little surprise that Avery went unclaimed by another team, which would have had to pay him $2 million this season, high for a player who scored three goals last season.

She is survived by her children: Carol (Mrs. Owen E. Desmond III) of Princeton, NJ; James F. of Putney, VT; Charlotte (Mrs. John J. Kenney) of Bronxville, NY; Charles C. (Melissa M.) of Park Ridge, NJ; and Mary R. of Lexington, MA; grandchildren: Anne C. Desmond of Princeton; Owen E. (Ned) Desmond IV (Kristina H.) of Wellesley, MA; Alexander H. Kenney of New York, NY; Jennifer O'B Lacovara (Michael) of Greenwich, CT; and T. Christopher O'Brien of La Jolla, CA.; and great-grandchildren: Jack, Maja, and Tyler Desmond and Owen and Deirdre Ristic. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Saturday, October 8, 2011 at 11am at St. Paul's Church, 214 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ, with interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Anne Callan O'Brien Scholarship at Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 1200 Stuart Road, Princeton, NJ 08540.

An article on Tuesday about slime molds, in describing a species called Dictyostelium discoides, misstated the proportion of cells in a mass of the amoebas that die to form a stalk, allowing the survivors to climb up and form spores. It is 20 percent of the cells, not 80 percent.

DJ Shadow has lived for 15 years in the shadow of his own success. This disc jockey, from San Francisco, whose real name is Josh Davis, has put out just three full-length albums since the critically acclaimed ''Endtroducing'' in 1996, which helped define the genre of instrumental hip-hop. On Tuesday his new album, ''The Less You Know, the Better,'' on the Verve label, hit record stores real and virtual. Like his previous efforts the new tracks sample from heavy-metal bands and spoken-word performances to 1950s folk recordings and classic funk drum parts from the disco era.

BUCHBINDER--Mae, Our magnificent Queen, gorgeous, intelligent, elegant, humorous, charming, chic, unconditionally and forever loving mother of Lori and Susan, devoted and spectacular mother in law to Ray and Bill, wonderful "Mai Mai" to grandchildren Mia, Jade, Jake and David will be loved forever. We cannot imagine the world without your warm kisses, hugs, brilliant smile, wit and "I love you darling". We are consoled only by the fact that Norman will welcome you with that red rose between his teeth and hearing him say "Let's Go Mae" on your eternal adventure together. Our hearts ache with sadness.

6:28 p.m. | Updated One year into its tenure, the Mets' new front office is continuing to make emphatic moves. In recent weeks, the team announced that Terry Collins, who recently completed his first season as manager, would be kept on through the 2013 season, and revealed that major alterations to the dimensions of their home stadium, Citi Field, were likely to be forthcoming.

Federal regulators are planning to vote next week on plans to prohibit banks from making certain lucrative, yet risky trades, the latest step toward reining in risk-taking on Wall Street in the aftermath of the financial crisis. As the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation prepares Tuesday to vote on the so-called Volcker Rule, some clues have emerged on the details of the proposal. The American Banker on Wednesday published a document on its Web site that appeared to be the latest version of the proposed rules. The proposal spelled out the scope of the rule's ban on proprietary trading - and its broad exemptions for more routine business practices that can be mistaken for riskier trades.

WHIMSICAL and textural, the handcrafted knitwear of Daphne and Vera Correll, the identical twin sisters who design CorrellCorrell, is one sure way to set your layered look apart this season. Born and raised in southern Germany, the sisters grew up knitting and cultivated an early appreciation of textiles. (Their parents are collectors.) They began their line in 2006 while living in Berlin. Then, five years ago, they decamped to New York, where they work from a small studio on the Lower East Side. The line now includes vibrant knit vests, tanks and dresses, all dyed and stitched by hand. ''We love when you can tell a garment actually went through the designer's hands,'' Daphne Correll said. Sweatshirts like this one have intricately detailed knit fronts, to wear alone or layered under a tweed blazer. CorrellCorrell knit-front sweatshirt, $380 at Jumelle, 148 Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 388-9525; shopjumelle.com.

Search-engine map sites, like those from Bing, Google and Yahoo, can do more for trip planning than just calculating directions. All three have a setting that shows you the current traffic conditions along the planned route to avoid jams. Some sites are even more helpful. Bing, for example, has a link on its Maps page for its Maps Apps, like a distance calculator and a gasoline price finder. From the drop-down map menu in the upper right corner, Google Maps offers a list of informational layers you can add to the map--including weather conditions, feeds from nearby Webcams and bicycle paths.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - When The Kids were younger, I hired a teenager to babysit so I could get out of the house and have a coherent thought once a week. One evening, the teenager showed up wearing a T-shirt that had a picture of the plastic inserts we used to put into the large holes of 45 r.p.m. records so that we could play them on our turntables. Strictly out of curiosity (and not masochism, as some of you are no doubt thinking), I asked the 15-year-old if she could tell me what the object on her T-shirt was, and thoroughly enjoyed the fact that she could not. The closest she could get, being only 15, was that the picture on her shirt was "neat." To her credit, she knew that a turntable was something on which her Dad used to play records. Whatever those were.

In the latest salvo in publishing wars over exclusivity, Barnes & Noble said Friday that it was pulling 100 graphic novels from its shelves after the publisher of the books made a deal with Amazon to sell the digital editions exclusively.

When I got the job as editor of this magazine almost a year ago now, it was issues like this week's that I wished for. I am proud of everything we've published in the magazine over the last several months, but like many writers and editors, I am self-critical to the point that I can look at almost anything I've ever done and see only the mistakes and missed opportunities therein. But that should not happen with this week's issue. The mix of stories is the best we've assembled so far, starting with Jeffrey Gettleman's epic pirates tale. It is an exciting, dramatic work of narrative journalism overflowing with memorable moments like this: "Once the pirates were in control of the Lynn Rival, they ransacked it, flinging open cupboards, eating all of the Chandlers' cookies and stealing their money, watches, rings, electronics, their satellite phone and clothes." Yup, those mean pirates went right for the cookies. Awesome. Adding to the flair and intensity of Jeffrey's story are the excellent illustrations by Wesley Allsbrook, the first time she has been in the magazine.

"A T-shirt?" asked the Lanvin shopgirl on the other end of the receiver when I inquired about logo tees. "We sell blouses. Have you tried calling the outlets?" My recent sartorial scavenge was prompted by Céline's resort collection. I was already head over heels for the discreet French label, but then Phoebe Philo, its designer, showed an in-your-face Céline-tagged top, styled smartly beneath a bustier and a prim, tailored jacket. Only Philo could make blatant branding compulsively collectible so soon after we'd all stripped the initials (save our own) off our bags and sunglasses. "I've heard they keep them in the back," said a saleswoman at Jeffrey when I went there looking for logos. "That's the secret," he added. "You have to ask." A recent trip to Yves Saint Laurent confirmed this to be true. "We wouldn't be YSL if we didn't have an inscribed T-shirt, would we?" the sales associate coyly whispered to me before returning from the stockroom with a yummy stash of initialed tees in navy and magenta. "We'll always have them." Blouses, that is.

Meet the young German-Russian model from Tula City, Russia, Valeria S. With a wide-eyed, freckly face like Angela Lindvall, it's no wonder a talent scout followed the 5-foot-10-inch beauty on her way home from school one day. But Valeria, whose favorite labels are Chanel, YSL, Givenchy and Céline, is not one to let a little attention shift her focus. In this story, which was shot on the streets of Manhattan's West Village, the shy but easygoing 21-year-old found herself with yet another fan, an older passer-by who hammed it up in front of the camera with her for a while. "I think he was trying to outpose me!" says the former ballerina of the unusual situation. With an impressive résumé that, in addition to T, already lists spreads in British Elle, Wonderland and V Magazine - all hitting stands this month - we're pretty sure Valeria stole the stage.

A longtime resident of the Lower East Side, Michael Little had taken to riding his bike to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for a decent cup of coffee. Specifically, a cup of Blue Bottle coffee, the San Francisco-based cult favorite. Fortunately for his neighbors, Little got tired of making the trek. In August, he and his friend Chad Eggers opened Lost Weekend NYC, a lifestyle shop and coffee bar that carries, in addition to Blue Bottle, a selection of men's T-shirts, hoodies and board shorts from the clothing label Saltbox and products by the grooming gurus Malin+Goetz. The cafe, housed in a light-drenched former gallery space on a burgeoning stretch of Orchard Street, is already attracting a (dude-heavy) crowd.

I see some commenters reacting to the failure of major inflation to break out by insisting that inflation is defined as an increase in the monetary base -- that is, the bank reserves plus currency that are what increases when the Fed "prints money". As it happens, that's wrong: very old dictionaries defined inflation as a rise in money and/or credit, but the modern usage is, of course, a rise in prices.

Random House is expanding its publishing efforts tied to the 2012 election by teaming up with RealClearPolitics, a political Web site, to release a series of e-books during the campaign, the publisher said today. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said it would publish three short-form e-book originals, plus one full-length book, beginning Nov. 4. The books will be written by Thomas Bevan, co-founder and executive editor of RealClearPolitics, and Carl M. Cannon, the Washington editor for RealClearPolitics. The first e-book, "Election 2012," is expected to cost $1.99.

With Italian austerity measures looming and construction of the Mose Flood Barrier in full swing, little remains in Venice's budget to protect and restore its treasures. Which is why Save Venice Inc., a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the artistic heritage of the city, seems more relevant than ever. The organization is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year with the release of the monumental book "Save Venice Inc.: Four Decades of Restoration in Venice." The 500-page, self-published volume (hardcover edition, $200; soft cover $60; all proceeds go to Save Venice) serves as a retrospective on paper of the 400 works of art and architecture that the organization has adopted and restored.

Sundance has expanded its vaunted filmmaker labs program to include projects that focus on the convergence of film and new media technologies. (Think Matthew Barney.) The first New Frontier Story Lab will start Oct. 23 at Sundance's headquarters in the mountains outside Salt Lake City. Keri Putnam, executive director of the Sundance Institute, called the intersection of film and new media "a new and important field where we felt independent voices needed nurturing and resources." The inaugural New Frontier workshop, underwritten by Coca-Cola and McCann, will include 11 artists working on projects like "18 Days in Egypt," an interactive documentary project that will tell the story of the recent Egyptian revolution through a collage of videos, photos, tweets and other electronic media.

I dialed the host. Could I bring apples from my urban farm? Duck eggs? No, no; I was told that the guest chef Chris Kronner (formerly of Tartine) had all he needed. How about flowers? I had some beautiful Day of the Dead marigolds! "Novella, just bring yourself and Billy," the host, Jane White, ordered. She already had delicate baby yellow roses on the table. Suffice it to say that, in Japanese, Arashi Yanagawa's first name means "big storm." The son of a taxi driver, Yanagawa made a name for himself as a professional boxer over a four-year career that included winning the Japanese national championships. Having satisfied his father's deepest aspirations for his son, Yanagawa moved on to his new passion: fashion design. With no schooling or training, he simply started making clothes, founding the brand John Lawrence Sullivan (named after the Irish boxer) and learning as he went. Seven years later, JLS is one of the more respected men's-wear companies in Japan and Yanagawa maintains a solid reputation as an excellent designer. Now, he is turning his sights on men's-wear for women.

Aarrgghh! Yves Smith totally misreads what I was saying in today's column, which presumably means that I didn't write it very well. When I said that it was the job of policy intellectuals to fill in the details for the Occupy Wall Street protestors, I didn't mean "don't worry your pretty little heads about it, we'll work it out". I meant job literally as in responsibility: people like Joe Stiglitz and me have an obligation to work on this, helping to translate what justifiably angry citizens are saying into more fleshed-out proposals. That doesn't mean taking the public out of the loop; it means putting whatever expertise you have to work on the public's behalf.

There's something in the genetic makeup of every Indian which sparks nagging pangs for street food. On a late summer morning, as a strong breeze softened the stifling humidity, my husband Mahir and I had our cravings fulfilled on the Williamsburg waterfront. Our vado pav sandwich was a perfectly balanced mix of spicy, tangy, crispy and chewy, and took my husband back to his childhood in Mumbai, where he grew up spending his spare rupees on this snack.

A stage version of "The King's Speech," the film that won the Academy Award for best picture this year, is no longer on a fast track to Broadway, as its author and one of its producers had originally envisioned. The play by David Seidler, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay for the film, will have a world-premiere production in February in Guildford, England, and then tour theaters in five other British cities through mid-March, according to the producers. A London production of the play may follow, according to a spokesman for the show, and Broadway remains a possibility.

Packers (4-0) at Falcons (2-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Packers by 6.Tramon Williams's end-of-half interception return for the Packers against the Falcons in last year's playoffs may be remembered as a turning point in N.F.L. history. The Falcons were the better team entering the game, and while the Packers held a 21-14 lead before the play, the Falcons were driving and appeared likely to score. Williams's interception turned the game into a rout, and the Packers have been unbeatable ever since, while the Falcons have replaced them as the team with a young quarterback and lots of talent that cannot quite get its act together.Of course, for some that turning point arrived a little late. "I'm really surprised that it kind of took him so long," Brett Favre said of the three interminable years it took Aaron Rodgers to lead the Packers to the Super Bowl. Who knew that through all of those quasi-retirements, through his stints with the Jets and the Vikings, Favre was just impatiently waiting for Rodgers to close the deal? Favre did not sound as if  he was trying to insult Rodgers - he has simply lost the ability to compliment people who are not him - but teammates and analysts have rushed to Rodgers's defense, which he does not really need.It had been peaceful months since the last self-serving Favre rant. What took him so long? Pick: Packers
