RIDGWAY--Jane Akers, daughter of famed architect John Russell Pope and Sadie Jones Pope, died in Palm Beach, Florida, October 6, 2011. She was married to Anthony B. Akers, a P.T. boats war hero who later consulted on the Hollywood film "They Were Expendable". Mr. Akers also ran for Congress in New York's Silk Stocking District and later was Ambassador to New Zealand. Mr. Akers died in 1976. Mrs. Akers subsequently married Thomas Ridgway, Jr. who was a direct descendant of "Mad Anthony" Wayne. Mr. Ridgway died in 2005. Mrs. Ridgway had homes in New York City, Newport, Rhode Island and Palm Beach, Florida. She was predeceased by her daughter Andra Akers and is survived by her daughter Ellery Akers of San Francisco, California. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, October 12, 2011 at 1pm at Saint Columba Berkley Memorial Chapel, Portsmouth, Rhode Island.

The Public Theater's new production of ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' a one-man show that is at times sharply critical of Mr. Jobs and Apple, will undergo changes since Mr. Jobs died on Wednesday, but will begin performances as scheduled on Tuesday, according to its creator, Mike Daisey. In a telephone interview Mr. Daisey said that Mr. Jobs's death ''is of such importance that it absolutely has to be addressed because it heightens the importance of talking about his legacy.'' Mr. Daisey, an acclaimed monologist who performs his works extemporaneously, said that he did not plan to add a scene or epilogue but rather infuse the entire work with perspectives about the capacity of Mr. Jobs's influence to continue, even in death, through Apple products. While Mr. Daisey said he did not yet know exactly what he would say, he said he planned to deal with ''the culture of deification and the realities of nostalgia, as well as the fact that people have been expressing such tenderness and affection for this human being because of their connection to his devices.'' The production, directed by Jean-Michele Gregory, Mr. Daisey's wife, is scheduled to run through Nov. 13.

While ABC has conspicuously begun to celebrate the early jet age, the Port Authority has begun to tear it down. Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport - a crisp island of aesthetic tranquillity by the master architect I. M. Pei - is being demolished. The boarding gates are already piles of rubble. It's generally not a good sign when anyone in a horror movie wields a sharp instrument, but by taking some editing scissors to his film ''The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence),'' the director Tom Six has secured the right to show it in Britain as the British Board of Film Classification lifted its ban on the film. In June that board, the British equivalent to the Motion Picture Association of America, said that it would give no rating at all to ''The Human Centipede 2,'' Mr. Six's second entry in a series of shock films about madmen who kidnap people and sew them together from one end to the other. Explaining its decision at the time, which prevented the movie from being legally sold or shown in Britain, the board said the film was ''sexually violent,'' ''potentially obscene'' and posed ''a real, as opposed to a fanciful, risk'' to its audience; the board also said no amount of editing to the film could undo its decision. But on Thursday the board said it had certified ''The Human Centipede 2'' for viewers 18 and older after 2 minutes and 37 seconds of footage were removed. In a statement it said the film's British distributor ''was required to make 32 individual cuts to scenes of sexual and sexualized violence, sadistic violence and humiliation, and a child presented in an abusive and violent context.'' Among the scenes removed were the ''graphic sight of a man's teeth being removed with a hammer; graphic sight of lips being stapled to naked buttocks,'' and, well, quite a bit more. A version of ''The Human Centipede 2'' is scheduled to be released in the United States on Friday by IFC Films.

Four years ago, Chamath Palihapitiya, seemed poised for a long career on Sand Hill Road, the famed strip in Menlo Park, Calif., lined with Silicon Valley's most powerful venture capital firms. As a principal for the Mayfield Fund, one of the country's oldest venture firms, he wore the industry's unofficial uniform faithfully everyday, a buttoned-down shirt and pressed pants. Today, Mr. Palihapitiya shudders at the memory of khakis, favoring jeans and flip-flops. ''I'm trying to be as un-VC as possible,'' he said.

Adele may be the biggest-selling singer and songwriter to come out of Britain in years, but a newcomer to the British pop scene, Jessie J, below, swept the MOBO awards in Glasgow on Wednesday night, Billboard and other news agencies reported. That 23-year-old singer won best album for her debut effort, ''Who You Are,'' as well as best song, for ''Do It Like a Dude.'' She also took home awards for best newcomer and best British act. The raven-haired Jessie J, who has a penchant for eccentric costumes, had a great year, as her first album climbed to No. 11 on the Billboard 200 chart and she enjoyed a hit with the lead single ''Pricetag.'' Adele did receive one award: best R&B or soul act. Tinie Tempah took the award for best hip-hop act, while Rihanna won for best international act. The MOBO awards are 16 years old and were set up by Kanye King, an advocate for the poor, to honor the best ''music of black origin,'' hence the acronym.

News that an influential panel of experts is advising healthy men not to be screened for prostate cancer with a widely used test is certain to cause confusion and anxiety among men and their doctors, and reignites a debate about the benefits and risks of screening tests. The recommendations, to be officially announced on Tuesday by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, affect more than 44 million men age 50 and older who typically are candidates for a simple blood screen call the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.

PRESSMAN--David. Television and Broadway stage director, passed away on Monday, August 29th in his home in New York City. He was ninety seven years old. An acclaimed acting teacher, Mr. Pressman was head of The Neighborhood Playhouse School of Theater from 1957-1963, and started the Boston University acting program in the early 1950s. He was an original member of The Actors Studio. A successful director of early dramatic live television from 1947 until 1952, he fell victim to the McCarthy blacklist and was unable to work in television for almost twelve years. During that time he continued to teach and direct theater, including the acclaimed Broadway production of "The Disenchanted" starring Jason Robards in his first Broadway role. Mr. Pressman later directed the award winning play "Summertree" at Lincoln Center. He returned to directing television in the 1960s, with such shows as "The Defenders and NYPD". He went on to direct "One Life To Live", for which he won three Daytime Emmys. He continued directing until his retirement at the age of 85. A decorated World War II veteran with two Purple Hearts, Mr. Pressman saw combat for two years with the 45th Infantry Division in Italy, France and Germany. He was a beloved, kind and generous man, a loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed. He is survived by Sasha, his wife of 70 years; his three sons Gregory (husband of Emily), Michael and Eugene; grandchildren Joanna, Naomi, Joshua, Rachel and Brooks; and three great-grandchildren. A memorial to Mr. Pressman will take place at 11am on Saturday, October 22nd, 2011 at the Director's Guild of America, where he served on the Guild's Eastern Directors Council for many years. 110 West 57th Street, New York City. RSVP to 212-258-0807 or mleal@dga.org.

5:03 p.m. | Updated Craig A. Dubow, the chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, who had been on medical leave, resigned on Thursday for health reasons, the company said. Gracia C. Martore, the company's president and chief operating officer, was named president and chief executive by the Gannett board. Ms. Martore, who will also have a seat on the company's board, served as principal executive officer during Mr. Dubow's leave. Gannett, the country's largest newspaper publisher by circulation, also announced the appointment of Marjorie Magner as nonexecutive chairman. Ms. Magner, who was the chairwoman of Gannett's audit committee, is also a managing partner at the private equity firm.

Heard of Apple TV? A lot of people have not. That is because even though Steven P. Jobs helped upend so many businesses with a string of groundbreaking products in music, mobile phones, games and tablet computers, he barely made a dent in television. Under Mr. Jobs, Apple dipped its toe only slightly into the television business with Apple TV, a set-top box for accessing Internet video. That product has been one of the rare disappointments in its lineup, especially when compared with smashes like the iPhone and iPad.

An article on Tuesday about slime molds misidentified the university in Sydney, Australia, where Madeleine Beekman is a researcher. Dr. Beekman, who with colleagues recently documented the decision-making of the species Physarum polycephalum, is affiliated with the University of Sydney, not the University of New South Wales.

The On Hockey column on Thursday, about the beginning of the 2011-12 National Hockey League season, misstated the way in which the Washington Capitals were eliminated in the playoffs last season. They were swept by the Tampa Bay Lightning in four games; they did not blow a 3-1 series lead against Tampa Bay.

10 P.M. (MSNBC) 17 DAYS BURIED ALIVE On Aug. 5, 2010, 33 miners were trapped nearly a half-mile underground after a rockslide in the San José Mine near Copiapó, Chile. The men, above, survived there for 69 days, and after a riveting rescue mission they vowed not to reveal what had taken place during the first 17 days -- what they called ''the dark days'' -- when they didn't know if help would come. In this documentary from Ed Schultz, six of the miners break their silence to discuss their fears of never again seeing the light of day and their temptations to do things they never thought they would. The film will be shown at 2 p.m. on Saturday on Telemundo, hosted by Omar Germenos. 11:25 A.M. (Showtime 2) BIG FAN (2009) Patton Oswalt plays Paul Aufiero, a rabid New York Giants fan and radio talk-show caller whose brush with his favorite player, Quantrell Bishop (Jonathan Hamm), takes a dark turn. Reviewing this drama from Robert Siegel (who wrote the screenplay for ''The Wrestler'') in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote that the screenplay ''avoids sentimentality without abandoning sentiment.'' She added, ''Paul might make you squirm, but Mr. Siegel refuses to sell him out so you can feel more comfortable with his eccentricities, no small thing in contemporary independent cinema.''

After gaining their freedom following a nearly two-decade ordeal, the Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three are planning to attend a premiere screening for the latest entry in a documentary series that has helped keep their case in the public eye for more than 15 years. The men, Jason Baldwin, Damien Echols and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who were freed from prison in August after having been convicted in 1994 of the murders of three 8-year-old boys, are expected to be at the New York Film Festival on Monday evening for a screening of the film ''Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory,'' a nonfiction feature directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said. Throughout the three ''Paradise Lost'' films -- the first was released in 1996 -- Mr. Berlinger and Mr. Sinofsky have chronicled the case of the West Memphis Three, who were teenagers when convicted, and raised questions about the handling of their trials and the evidence and testimony presented. Though the new documentary was screened at the Toronto International Film Festival in September, the version shown at the New York Film Festival will include an updated ending with footage shot at the Aug. 19 hearing where, under a deal with Arkansas prosecutors, the men pleaded guilty to the murders but were set free. HBO, whose HBO Documentary Films division produced the ''Paradise Lost'' series, plans to show the movie next year.

BROWNSTEIN--Gladys, December 11, 1919 - October 3, 2011. Family and friends mourn her loss. Respects may be paid at the home of Honey Waldman, Saturday, 7pm-10pm; Sunday, 2-10pm; Monday-Thursday, 4-9pm.

STERN--Robert A. City Harvest mourns the passing of Robert A. Stern, a generous friend, mentor and committed partner of our work fighting hunger in New York City. Both Bob and his late wife Jean were sincerely dedicated to City Harvest's mission, and their generosity made a lasting difference in the lives of hundreds of thousands of hungry New Yorkers. We offer our deepest condolences to Rob, Peter and their families and friends and join them in mourning his loss. We were honored by Bob's partnership and will greatly miss his wonderful spirit. Jim Kallman, Chair Jilly Stephens, Executive Director

SCHWARTZ--Elayne P. Bernstein. It is difficult to write an obituary about someone who still lives. Elayne Polly Bernstein Schwartz passed away in Lenox, Massachusetts on October 4, 2011 from cancer. Born in the Bronx on October 29, 1924, she always liked to explain that she was conceived in China. Her parents, Jack Polly and Jean Morrison, returned from China to the U.S. to ensure Elayne's American citizenship. After spending her early years in China (where she learned lullabies she would later sing to her children), Elayne moved with her family to Brooklyn. After the death of her mother when Elayne was thirteen, her two aunts joined the household and jointly raised their children, including Elayne's older brother Sydney and her cousin Eileen, whom she regarded as a sister. From this experience, Elayne developed an unshakeable belief in the importance of family and extended family. Elayne was also a talented singer and actress. While at Erasmus Hall High School, she cut school one day in order to win the Betty Hutton Contest of Brooklyn. After graduation, she worked as a singer, performing on 52nd Street at the Zebra Club, and at the Onyx Club (she later called them "dens of iniquity") on the same bill with Lenny Bruce. After her marriage to high school sweetheart Harold Bernstein, Elayne moved to Great Neck, NY, in 1948, where she raised her five children. She served as a leader of the Free Nurses Institute of the Julia Bernstein League and was active in civic affairs, especially the effort to desegregate Great Neck Public Schools. Proud of her Jewish heritage, she was for many years an active member of both Temple Israel and Temple Beth El, starring in musical theater and singing in the High Holiday choirs. She proudly joined Beth El's first adult Bat Mitzvah class well after her five children had achieved this major milestone in their lives. And she was an ardent supporter of the Jewish Studies Program at Queens College. Her decision to enter Queens College as an adult mother of five was, she said, the most monumental one of her life, setting her on a path of education, inquiry and passionate engagement with the world of ideas, theater, art and music. She earned both a bachelor's and a master's degree (the latter magna cum laude), but her voracious appetite for education continued throughout her life and inspired her decades-long service as President of the Board of the Great Neck Public Library. She also privately supported the educational aspirations of disadvantaged children, enabling them to pursue successful careers in music and art. Her commitment to ORT led to the creation of the Elayne Bernstein Auditorium in Kiryat Yam, Israel to provide science and technology education to Ethiopian and Russian immigrant children. In conjunction with Peace Now, she sponsored two annual conferences in Lenox in which Palestinian and Israeli negotiators met to work on peace issues. Her sense of justice made her a truly righteous person. Elayne put her master's degree to work as an administrator at Queens College, where she was especially proud of organizing a 1985 conference on homosexuality and family life at the start of the AIDS epidemic, despite considerable disapproval. Most notably, she co-developed Backstage at the Berkshires, an adult education program at Queens designed to introduce the cultural treasures of the area to participants, with Shakespeare & Company as the crown jewel and the cultural/educational love of her life. Elayne supported Shakespeare productions everywhere she found them (becoming, for example, an ardent supporter of New York's Theater for a New Audience.) In Lenox Elayne served on the Board of Shakespeare and Company, working tirelessly to enable the organization to extend the reach of Shakespeare to everyone, especially young people. She was evangelical in her belief that Shakespeare speaks to us all. As a result of her devotion and support, Shakespeare and Company dedicated the Elayne P. Bernstein Theater (2009), the Bernstein Production Center, and, in 2011, Elayne's Corner, a garden that greets audience members on their way inside. Through her immersion in the cultural and artistic life of Lenox, Elayne met, fell in love with, and at age 80 married (in 2004) Sol Schwartz, and together they forged a joyous life of common interests in the arts, culture and education. Elayne is survived by her husband, Sol Schwartz; her cousin/sister Eileen Weinberg; her son and daughter-in-law Gene and Pamela Bernstein and their daughters, Jennifer Bernstein and Mindy Feinberg; her son and daughter-in-law Jay and Jill Bernstein and their children Julie Packin, Samantha Bernstein and Jamie Bernstein; her daughter Donna Bernstein and son Samuel Bernstein; her daughter and son-in-law Linda and Tony Rubin and their children Jacob and Gena Rubin; her son and daughter-in-law Matthew and Natalie Bernstein and their children Justin and Adam Bernstein; her grandsons-in-law Mark Feinberg and Ari Packin; her great-grandchildren Eliza and Jack Feinberg and Hallie Rose and Charlie Packin; and Sol Schwartz's children David and Risa Schwartz, and his grandson John. A memorial celebration will be held in the Elayne P. Bernstein Theater at Shakespeare & Company at 70 Kemble Street in Lenox, Massachusetts on Sunday, October 9, 2011 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, it was Elayne's wish that memorial contributions be made to Shakespeare & Company (70 Kemble Street, Lenox, MA, 01240) or to HospiceCare in the Berkshires, Inc. (877 South Street, Suite 1 West, Pittsfield, MA 01201. Everyone who met Elayne benefitted from her engaging smile, capacious heart, her superb ability to listen without judgment and provide wise advice, and her joyous sense of life. Many more benefited from her generosity without having the privilege of meeting her. To the very end of her life, she remained a woman of untrammeled honesty, integrity and hope. Her interests in the world and the people in it can only be described as all-encompassing, all-embracing and life affirming. It is for these many reasons that Elayne lives on.

SHAPIRO--Aaron. It is with great sadness that Baruch College marks the passing of Aaron Shapiro ('49, LHD [Hon.] 89), a longtime friend to the school whose devotion and munificence has helped generations of students. A past president of the Baruch College Fund, and a trustee from 1976 to 2002, Aaron served as a trustee emeritus since 2002. He was also a member of the Dean's Council of Baruch College's Weissman School of Arts and Sciences; his generosity funded the Joel Segall Great Works Reading Series at the College. Aaron received his LLD from Brooklyn Law School and was the founder of Shapiro Lobel LLP, a firm that has achieved international acclaim in its representation of clients in the entertainment industry. Over the years he received numerous tributes from Baruch College, including honorary membership in Beta Gamma Sigma, the accounting honor society; an honorary doctorate of humane letters; an Alumni Achievement Award; and the President's Medal. He has served on various committees of the New York State Society of CPAs and has lectured and taught at the NYU Tax Institute and at Fairleigh Dickinson University. His great appreciation for the performing arts was demonstrated by his service as treasurer of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and founding member of the Bob Fosse Theatre Scholarship Fund. He was also a member of the advisory board of the American Theatre Wing and a Tony Awards voter. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Elaine, and their family. He will be greatly missed by the Baruch community. Joel J. Cohen Baruch College Fund President Mitchel B. Wallerstein Baruch College President

The Philadelphia Orchestra said on Thursday that it had reached a tentative agreement with the union representing its musicians, an important step in emerging from bankruptcy. The lack of a contract had been a complicating issue in the orchestra's resort to Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April. The agreement requires approval of the musicians, the orchestra's board and the bankruptcy court, according to a joint statement by the two sides released by the orchestra. The parties will consider the deal early next week, the statement said. The Philadelphia Orchestra declined to release details of the pact or to comment further. A bankruptcy court judge, Stephen Raslavich, served as a mediator in the discussions involving orchestra and management representatives.

Contributions to the U.S. Naval Academy or Glen Rock Public Library.

MOUTOUX--Edgar J.,86, a longtime resident of New York City, passed away peacefully at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady following a short illness. Born and raised in New York City, he was a WWII Army veteran and recipient of the purple heart. Mr. Moutoux worked for the US Government in both the Central Intelligence Agency and Internal Revenue Service throughout his distinguished career. Edgar's ancestry is traced to Jacques Moutoux, who was one of the leaders in the Glorious Return by the Waldensians in 1689. He was of the Lutheran Faith. Survivors include his niece Janet Gramuglia (Vince) and nephew Robert Montoux as well as great-nieces and great-nephews. Graveside services, today, October 7 at 2pm at Woodlawn Cemetery, East 233rd St. at Webster Avenue, Bronx, NY with military honors. glenvillefuneralhome.com.

Fresh from a bruising battle to open a charter school on the Upper West Side, Eva S. Moskowitz, the former city councilwoman who runs a network of charters in New York City, is gearing up to expand into middle-class areas by opening a school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, next fall. The city has begun reaching out to neighborhood residents and leaders, continuing its push to turn charter schools into viable options for middle-class families whose neighborhood schools are too crowded or too weak to be attractive.

When the Yankees went into spring training in February, they took with them their annual goal of winning the World Series, even if many outside the team did not share that expectation. The Yankees had missed out on signing the free-agent pitcher Cliff Lee, and they carried serious concerns about their pitching rotation and the age of some of their core players. As the season progressed and many of the questions were answered, the Yankees ended up with the best record in the American League, stoking fans' hopes that a 28th World Series championship was in the offing.

LEE--Dorothy Chuan, 86, beloved wife of Booker Lee, died May 18 in Denver, after residing many years in NYC, Scarsdale, Greenwich, and Ft. Lauderdale. Born in Harbin, China, she graduated from Aurora College and Cornell University. A food editor at McCall's and later head of test kitchens at General Foods, she was a pioneer in teaching Chinese cooking as an art form and high cuisine. Left to cherish her memory are son Benjamin (Jianying Zha), daughter Victoria, granddaughter Siri; sisters, brother, beloved friends. Memorial service Sunday, October 16, 2:30pm, 2nd Congregational Church, 139 E. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donate to Visiting Nurse Assn (303-698-2121) or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr (212-639-2000).

ZAZZERA--Paul J.,age 56. At rest on October 5, 2011, loving husband of Maria Zazzera (nee Wujcik); beloved father of Kathryn and Charles Zazzera, dear brother of Robert Zazzera. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, he was a resident of Milltown, NY before moving to Summit, NJ 15 years ago. Mr. Zazzera earned his Bachelors and Masters Degrees from City College of New York in 1978 and 1980 respectively. He served as Vice President of Information Technology Strategy and Assessment with Warburg Pincus, LLC since 2008. Previously he worked with Time Warner Inc. and The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones & Co, all in New York. He was a member of the Union League Club of New York, and the Beacon Hill Club in Summit, NJ. Visitation Saturday, October 8, 7-9pm and Sunday, October 9, 2-4 and 7-9pm at William R. Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ, (908)273-2323. Funeral Mass Monday, October 10, 10:45am at St. Teresa of Avila R.C. Church, Summit. Private cremation will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to Rusty Staub Foundation, 100 Corp. Plaza, Suite 203, Peabody, MA 01960 would be appreciated.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - The quote immortalized in today's Acrostic puzzle is a confession of sorts, and a fascinating peek into the mind of a brilliant man. Walt Whitman, nineteenth century poet and essayist, admits readily that what the American people wanted to read was the sort of thing he wanted to read himself. His 1855 collection of poems, "Leaves of Grass," was considered immoral in its day for its honest portrayal of sensuality.

Ugly new term, but apparently the new thing; it refers to companies moving production back to America from China. The fact that such stories are being heard is support for those (including me) demanding action on the renminbi, because they show that there is indeed a margin at which changes in Chinese dollar costs move production back to the United States, and hence that the undervalued renminbi directly costs US jobs, as well as having the indirect effects I've written about recently.

The Springfield nuclear power plant will remain operational, and it won't be closing time at Moe's Tavern for at least two more years: on Friday night, Fox announced that it had renewed its hit animated comedy ''The Simpsons,'' television's longest running prime-time scripted series, for two additional seasons, following a contract dispute with its voice cast that had threatened to end the show altogether. ''The Simpsons,'' which began as a series of cartoon shorts on Fox's ''Tracey Ullman Show,'' has been on the air as a continuous series since 1989, and has become a billion-dollar business for the network and the 20th Century Fox television studio, which produces it. But earlier this week, the studio acknowledged that it was in a standoff with the ''Simpsons'' voice actors, including Dan Castellaneta (who plays Homer Simpson), Julie Kavner (Marge) and Nancy Cartwright (Bart), who each now earn about $8 million a year for their work on the show, and whose salaries the studio was looking to cut by 45 percent. On Tuesday the studio said, ''We believe this brilliant series can and should continue, but we cannot produce future seasons under its current financial model.''

The presidents of the universities in the Big East Conference participated in an hour-long conference call Friday morning, but no immediate decisions were made about the future of the league. A league official with direct knowledge of the call said that invitations to potential new members would be handed out soon, perhaps as early as next week. Little has changed in terms of the universities the Big East is targeting, with Navy, Air Force, Temple, Central Florida and East Carolina the main candidates. No final determinations have been made over which will be invited to join or when they would be approached. A small portion of the conversation Friday revolved around the issue of how much the league's exit fee should be, a tricky topic as it now has just six universities that play at the Football Bowl Subdivision level, and some of them are contemplating leaving.

A sense of dread is creeping over Philadelphia. It is flowing through the streets, covering all of the dried-up previous layers of dread. This year's dread is different. In the past, the Eagles have been failures, teases, doomed underdogs, strife-racked self-destructors and punchy palookas. But they have never been a laughingstock. They have never called attention to themselves so demandingly, only to pratfall so comically. The Eagles are 1-3, and they are so tragically flawed, so bumbling and inept at football basics, that they are easy prey for those who choose to mock the latest so-called Dream Team.

The last collaboration between the actor Fred Melamed and the filmmaker Ethan Coen yielded one of the silkiest screen villains in recent years: Sy Ableman, the gently bearish widower in ''A Serious Man'' (2009), who seduces the wife of the main character and then keeps explaining the logic of the cuckolding to him. (Sy: ''Such a thing, such a thing - you know, Larry, the way we handle ourselves in this situation is so important.'') But their latest outing together, in the Broadway production ''Relatively Speaking,'' has not gone as smoothly: He left the show after the matinee on Sunday. In a telephone interview on Thursday, Mr. Melamed said that he and the producers had come to a mutual decision that he would depart ''Relatively Speaking'' - a set of one-act plays by Mr. Coen, Woody Allen and Elaine May - so he could fulfill a commitment for Sacha Baron Cohen's new movie, ''The Dictator,'' as well as pursue another movie opportunity. (Mr. Melamed is a veteran of several Woody Allen movies and familiar to fans of ''The Good Wife'' and ''Curb Your Enthusiasm.'')

SCHWARTZ--Elayne P. Bernstein. It is difficult to write an obituary about someone who still lives. Elayne Polly Bernstein Schwartz passed away in Lenox, Massachusetts on October 4, 2011 from cancer. Born in the Bronx on October 29, 1924, she always liked to explain that she was conceived in China. Her parents, Jack Polly and Jean Morrison, returned from China to the U.S. to ensure Elayne's American citizenship. After spending her early years in China (where she learned lullabies she would later sing to her children), Elayne moved with her family to Brooklyn. After the death of her mother when Elayne was thirteen, her two aunts joined the household and jointly raised their children, including Elayne's older brother Sydney and her cousin Eileen, whom she regarded as a sister. From this experience, Elayne developed an unshakeable belief in the importance of family and extended family. Elayne was also a talented singer and actress. While at Erasmus Hall High School, she cut school one day in order to win the Betty Hutton Contest of Brooklyn. After graduation, she worked as a singer, performing on 52nd Street at the Zebra Club, and at the Onyx Club (she later called them "dens of iniquity") on the same bill with Lenny Bruce. After her marriage to high school sweetheart Harold Bernstein, Elayne moved to Great Neck, NY, in 1948, where she raised her five children. She served as a leader of the Free Nurses Institute of the Julia Bernstein League and was active in civic affairs, especially the effort to desegregate Great Neck Public Schools. Proud of her Jewish heritage, she was for many years an active member of both Temple Israel and Temple Beth El, starring in musical theater and singing in the High Holiday choirs. She proudly joined Beth El's first adult Bat Mitzvah class well after her five children had achieved this major milestone in their lives. And she was an ardent supporter of the Jewish Studies Program at Queens College. Her decision to enter Queens College as an adult mother of five was, she said, the most monumental one of her life, setting her on a path of education, inquiry and passionate engagement with the world of ideas, theater, art and music. She earned both a bachelor's and a master's degree (the latter magna cum laude), but her voracious appetite for education continued throughout her life and inspired her decades-long service as President of the Board of the Great Neck Public Library. She also privately supported the educational aspirations of disadvantaged children, enabling them to pursue successful careers in music and art. Her commitment to ORT led to the creation of the Elayne Bernstein Auditorium in Kiryat Yam, Israel to provide science and technology education to Ethiopian and Russian immigrant children. In conjunction with Peace Now, she sponsored two annual conferences in Lenox in which Palestinian and Israeli negotiators met to work on peace issues. Her sense of justice made her a truly righteous person. Elayne put her master's degree to work as an administrator at Queens College, where she was especially proud of organizing a 1985 conference on homosexuality and family life at the start of the AIDS epidemic, despite considerable disapproval. Most notably, she co-developed Backstage at the Berkshires, an adult education program at Queens designed to introduce the cultural treasures of the area to participants, with Shakespeare & Company as the crown jewel and the cultural/educational love of her life. Elayne supported Shakespeare productions everywhere she found them (becoming, for example, an ardent supporter of New York's Theater for a New Audience.) In Lenox Elayne served on the Board of Shakespeare and Company, working tirelessly to enable the organization to extend the reach of Shakespeare to everyone, especially young people. She was evangelical in her belief that Shakespeare speaks to us all. As a result of her devotion and support, Shakespeare and Company dedicated the Elayne P. Bernstein Theater (2009), the Bernstein Production Center, and, in 2011, Elayne's Corner, a garden that greets audience members on their way inside. Through her immersion in the cultural and artistic life of Lenox, Elayne met, fell in love with, and at age 80 married (in 2004) Sol Schwartz, and together they forged a joyous life of common interests in the arts, culture and education. Elayne is survived by her husband, Sol Schwartz; her cousin/sister Eileen Weinberg; her son and daughter-in-law Gene and Pamela Bernstein and their daughters, Jennifer Bernstein and Mindy Feinberg; her son and daughter-in-law Jay and Jill Bernstein and their children Julie Packin, Samantha Bernstein and Jamie Bernstein; her daughter Donna Bernstein and son Samuel Bernstein; her daughter and son-in-law Linda and Tony Rubin and their children Jacob and Gena Rubin; her son and daughter-in-law Matthew and Natalie Bernstein and their children Justin and Adam Bernstein; her grandsons-in-law Mark Feinberg and Ari Packin; her great-grandchildren Eliza and Jack Feinberg and Hallie Rose and Charlie Packin; and Sol Schwartz's children David and Risa Schwartz, and his grandson John. A memorial celebration will be held in the Elayne P. Bernstein Theater at Shakespeare & Company at 70 Kemble Street in Lenox, Massachusetts on Sunday, October 9, 2011 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, it was Elayne's wish that memorial contributions be made to Shakespeare & Company (70 Kemble Street, Lenox, MA, 01240) or to HospiceCare in the Berkshires, Inc. (877 South Street, Suite 1 West, Pittsfield, MA 01201. Everyone who met Elayne benefitted from her engaging smile, capacious heart, her superb ability to listen without judgment and provide wise advice, and her joyous sense of life. Many more benefited from her generosity without having the privilege of meeting her. To the very end of her life, she remained a woman of untrammeled honesty, integrity and hope. Her interests in the world and the people in it can only be described as all-encompassing, all-embracing and life affirming. It is for these many reasons that Elayne lives on.

Nearly every major Republican politician in Arizona issued a news release this week - all within an hour or so of one another on Wednesday afternoon - condemning a draft redistricting map approved by a state commission. Gov. Jan Brewer called the maps ''a travesty,'' ''gerrymandering at its worst,'' and ''every Democrat's dream.'' Joining her were Senators Jon Kyl and John McCain, who issued a joint statement calling the work of the Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission ''political'' and ''very disappointing.'' Releasing similar statements were the bulk of the Republican members of the House as well as State House speaker, Andy Tobin, who said the redistricting process had been ''hijacked.''

Two ousted Bank of America executives, Sallie Krawcheck and Joe Price, signed agreements smoothing their departures from the bank, according to regulatory documents. Ms. Krawcheck will receive $6 million and Mr. Price will get $5 million, under deals that came about a month after a management shake-up at the bank. Ms. Krawcheck was one of the most prominent women on Wall Street and president of the bank's global wealth and investment management, while Mr. Price was president of its consumer and small-business division. While still at the bank, Ms. Krawcheck received total compensation of $6.2 million last year and $1.9 million in 2009, according to the bank's regulatory filings. Mr. Price received $917,027 last year and $6.1 million the year before. In their final agreements, both executives agreed not to take jobs with competing companies or recruit Bank of America employees for a year. THEO FRANCIS

Crédit Lyonnais, a French bank, will pay $150 million to settle a suit filed by the American International Group's SunAmerica unit over its 1993 investment in a California insurance company. The A.I.G. unit sued a group of French companies including Crédit Lyonnais in 2005, saying that it was defrauded when it bought a 33 percent stake in the insurer, New California Holdings, because it did not know that the French owners, a group led by MAAF Assurances, were a front for Crédit Lyonnais. At the time, the French bank could not own an insurer under United States law. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

ETTELBRICK--Paula. The Board and Staff of the Stonewall Community Foundation mourn the passing of our immediate past Executive Director, Paula Ettelbrick. A lifelong advocate for LGBTQ people across the globe, Paula, age 56, died on Friday October 7, 2011. In addition to Stonewall, Paula held key posts at Lambda Legal, National Center for Lesbian Rights, Empire State Pride Agenda, the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force and the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission. Countless peoples' lives are better today because of Paula; she will be sorely missed. For more information, visit: www.stonewallfoundation.org.

8 P.M. (HBO) HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS: PART 1 (2010) In this penultimate installment of the film adaptations of the J. K. Rowling books, Harry (Daniel Radcliffe, above), Ron Weasley (Rupert Grint) and Hermione Granger (Emma Watson) are cast out from the cocoon of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry into a perilous grown-up world, devoid of Albus Dumbledore, now dead, and other adult supervision. It's up to Harry to destroy the power of Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) or risk losing his own life to his nemesis. The movie, directed by David Yates, ''belongs solidly to Mr. Radcliffe, Mr. Grint and Ms. Watson, who have grown into nimble actors, capable of nuances of feeling that would do their elders proud,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Even though it ends in the middle,'' he added, this film ''finds notes of anxious suspense and grave emotion to send its characters, and its fans, into the last round. The sorrow you experience may well be a premonition of the imminent end of a long and, for the most part, delightful relationship.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on arguments before the Supreme Court this week on a ''ministerial exception'' to employment discrimination laws, one that forbids the government from interfering in the relationship between religious groups and their employees whose duties include religious ones. Also, Judy Valente looks at the career of the Rev. Andrew Greeley, the author, sociologist and Roman Catholic priest who suffered a traumatic brain injury three years ago.

As a star of ''The Simpsons,''Harry Shearer provides the voices of dozens of characters on that Fox animated comedy, from the nefarious plutocrat Montgomery Burns to Homer's gentle next-door neighbor, Ned Flanders. And on Friday Mr. Shearer became the first performer on that long-running series to give voice to the current demands of its acting ensemble, which is locked in a tense negotiation with the 20th Century Fox Television studio while the fate of ''The Simpsons'' hangs in the balance. ''The Simpsons,'' now in its 23rd season, is the longest-running scripted series in prime-time television history. With the revenue from syndication of its nearly 500 episodes, as well as sales of DVD and numerous forms of merchandising, it is a billion-dollar worldwide business for the Fox studio, which produces the show, and the Fox network, which broadcasts it. But on Tuesday, the studio said it ''cannot produce future seasons under its current financial model.''

A Congressional Memo article on Friday about members of Congress who are reconsidering their pledges not to raise taxes misidentified the state represented by Senator John Thune, who suggested that anti-tax pledges are sometimes construed too broadly. He is a Republican from South Dakota, not North Dakota.

DES MOINES - Iowa Republicans are tentatively eyeing Jan. 3 as the date for the state's caucuses, the first stop in the party's battle to select a nominee to challenge President Obama. The date is the consensus of party officials, who are frantically working to keep the first votes of the 2012 campaign from creeping into December. But the date is not locked down and could change depending on when the New Hampshire primary is held.

Sugarland, the country music duo, will give a free concert in Indianapolis, where seven people were killed in August when stage rigging collapsed in high winds just before the band was to play at the Indiana State Fair. Sugarland announced on Friday that it would appear at the Conseco Fieldhouse on Oct. 28 and would collect money for survivors and relatives of victims of the accident. Scores of lawsuits have been filed in the wake of the collapse, and Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana has ordered an outside investigation into what went wrong and why state fair officials did not order an evacuation of the area around the stage for 10 minutes after receiving a warning that severe weather was approaching.

Richard C. Vaughan, an attorney in Lexington, Mo., was overjoyed with Abraham Lincoln's 1860 election. Not because the Republican Lincoln won; indeed, he had supported John Bell, the presidential candidate from the Constitutional Union Party. Rather, his joy came from the Democrats' resounding defeat. "The prospect of the final overthrow of the Democracy in Missouri as well as everywhere else," he wrote to a friend, "is to me a source of infinite and irrepressible pleasure in which I know you participate fully."

In "Being and Nothingness," Jean-Paul Sartre recommends skiing as a model of human behavior. But the trouble with skiing, says Sartre (with a slightly paranoid swerve) is that you leave tracks behind you. "The ideal form of sliding," he argues, "would therefore be one that leaves no trace: that is, sliding over water"' He might have been thinking of water-skiing, of course, but I have always liked to suppose it was surfing he had in mind.

After two rain delays interrupted Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Saturday night, Major League Baseball did not take any chances on Sunday. With more rain expected Sunday night, Game 2 of the series between the Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers was postponed Sunday afternoon, about seven hours before the scheduled first pitch. It was rescheduled for Monday afternoon at 4:19 Eastern. Tigers Manager Jim Leyland also announced that right fielder Magglio Ordonez injured his right ankle in Game 1 and is out for the rest of the postseason. More details are available here.

Since January experts at Sotheby's have been trying to privately sell a suite of four bronze sculptures of a woman's back that Matisse created over a period of 23 years beginning in 1908. The works belong to the Burnett Foundation in Forth Worth, and at the time the sale was announced, neither Sotheby's nor the foundation would say what the asking price was, although dealers approached by the auction house reported that they were hoping for around $200 million for all four.

Boxing robots were No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, as "Real Steel" (DreamWorks Studios/Disney) sold an estimated $27.3 million in tickets. That total was solid, but the picture, which stars Hugh Jackman as a reluctant father, will need to continue drawing large audiences to justify its hefty production budget of $110 million and tens of millions more in marketing support. Many critics disliked "Real Steel," but audiences, especially younger moviegoers, gave it strong marks in exit polls.

A J's Steak and Pizza might be intimidating, I was told - kind of a bikers' bar. But the burgers were cheap and good, the peanuts were free, the place was still open and it was right down the road from the room where I had just dropped my bags. Something about the warning didn't quite compute: an intimidating biker joint down the road from the Mary Stuart House, my cozy little bed and breakfast on rural Route 4 in Litchfield County, Conn.? The same Litchfield County known as a weekend escape for New Yorkers prosperous enough to afford a second home but put off by Hamptons haughtiness?
Art Roberta Smith

An article last Sunday about a Chicago woman's struggle with foreclosure referred imprecisely to the way JPMorgan Chase acquired Washington Mutual, which had held a mortgage on the woman's home. The Office of Thrift Supervision ordered Washington Mutual closed because of insufficient liquidity to meet its obligations, not for its predatory lending practices. Predatory lending was cited as a factor in the O.T.S. ruling that Washington Mutual be closed.

To the Editor: In ''The Problem With 'No New Taxes' '' (Economic View, Oct. 2) Tyler Cowen said that ''taxes will eventually go up, because they must.'' But one explanation for that ''must'' is not often heard: Our nation went to war in Afghanistan and Iran without raising taxes to pay for that war.

SCHAEBERLE--Robert M.,died on September 29, 2011 at the Ridge at Riverwoods in Exeter, NH. Mr. Schaeberle was formerly the Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Nabisco Brands, Inc. He was 88. Mr. Schaeberle began his career with Nabisco as a trainee in 1946 rising to become the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1973. He remained as Chairman of Nabisco Brands, Inc. after the merger of Nabisco and R.J. Reynolds. He retired at the end of 1986, with forty years of service to Nabisco. During his career he was active serving in advisory roles to many organizations including: President of Financial Executive Institute's New York Chapter, Chairman of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc, a Director of Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, a Director for The Prudential Insurance Company of America, a contributing Director to the American Arbitration Association, The United Nations Association of the United States of America and Committee for Economic Development, Chairman of the Uniform Product Code Council, member of the Advisory Committee of the New York Stock Exchange, the Advisory Board of Chemical Bank, New York Trust Company, and the Emergency Committee for American Trade and the Business Roundtable. He was a trustee and member of the Advisory Council of Pace University and received their "Leaders in Management Award". He was a man with a witty sense of humor who brought knowledge, understanding and warmth to many community and charitable involvements. He was the founding Chairman of Morris Tomorrow, an organization dedicated to improving the quality of life in Morris County, NJ. A native of New Jersey for eighty years, he was born on January 2, 1923 in Newark, NJ, the son of the late Frederick M. and Bertha Thielman Schaeberle. Formerly residing in the towns of Glen Ridge and Montclair, Mr. Schaeberle was a graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of '45. During World War II he served with the U.S. Navy for three years, seeing action in the South Pacific on the U.S.S. Kinzer. He held the rank of Lt. Commander USNR (Ret.) and remained active in the Naval Reserves until 1972. A devoted family man, Mr. Schaeberle was an inspiration to all who knew him. He could often be found in his workshop, perfecting a new invention or work of art. His spirits for exploration lead him on numerous travels throughout the world. Mr. Schaeberle was predeceased by his first wife, Barbara Slockbower Schaeberle who died in 1981, and by his second wife Barbara Schaeberle who died in 2003. He is survived by three sons, Robert Kim Schaeberle and his wife Beatrice of Longwood, FL, Mark Schaeberle and his wife Jeannie of Glenwood, MD, and Gregg Schaeberle of Newport Beach, CA; six grandchildren, Carolyn, Emily, Stephanie, Jennifer, Stephen, and Thomas; and two great grandchildren, Bruce and Mark. A memorial service will be held Sunday October 16th, 2011 at 2pm at The Glen Ridge Congregational Church, 195 Ridgewood Ave., Glen Ridge, NJ 07028. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the memory of Robert M. Schaeberle to the Glen Ridge Congregational Church Garden of Memory.

IF the shoes on the runways in Paris confirmed anything collectively, it's that next spring won't be about flats. Heels of all sorts -- square and spiked, platform and not -- were the finishing touch of choice for fashion's biggest names, shown mostly with bare legs or extra-long pants. Some heels were chic and subtle, made of barely there vaquetta leather. Others, like the hefty platforms at Céline with buckled ankle cuffs, or the pouf booties at Kenzo that resembled taffeta prom dresses from the 1980s, made much more of a racket. But the favorites were YSL's suede loafers with giant gold plates bent like armor across the top of the foot. In a season that saw many straps and funnier shapes, it felt so solid. Even in carnation pink. From top: Dries Van Noten, Isabel Marant, Yves Saint Laurent, Balenciaga and Kenzo. JANE HERMAN

Chris Szabo (a k a ''Ace of Skates''), 28 (left): This was at East Coast Derby Extravaganza. I'm on the New York Shock Exchange, and I'm reading that pack, trying to figure out how I'm going to get through. It's a pack of eight skaters: four from my team, four from the other. The other jammer -- the guy I'm leaning up against and trying to block -- he's trying to knock me down, I'm trying to knock him down, all while doing it cleanly and legally so I don't get sent to the penalty box. When you're in the moment, you don't think: you just react. It would probably feel like driving a race car 200 miles per hour.

SMALLEY--Patricia Tolles, passed away on October 4th at the age of 71. She is survived by her husband of 47 years, David, sons Brian and Gregory, daughter-in-law Susan, grandsons William and Nathan, a brother Tony Tolles, nieces Tracy Tolles Rueckert and Terrill Tolles, nephew Christopher Tolles, and many other beloved nieces, nephews and in-laws. Trix was pre-deceased by her brother Terry. While family and friends were the joyful center of Trix's life, she was also accomplished professionally. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Rd., Clinton, NY 13323, or Cancer Support Team, 875 Mamaroneck Ave., Mamaroneck, NY 10538.

IF ever there were a designer-to-brand matchup that was made of complementary parts, it would be the appointment of Manish Arora as creative director at Paco Rabanne this season. Mr. Arora's flair for fantastical and theatrical designs is not that far off from what Mr. Rabanne was doing in the 1960s, when he made dresses of metal plates and squares that occasionally gave literal meaning to the term ''fashion victim.''

Flash mobs - brief group assemblies usually for some whimsical purpose like dancing or pillow fighting - go commercial at the Marco Island Marriott Beach Resort near Naples, Fla. The hotel will assemble your very own flash mob to energize a sales convention or punctuate an engagement proposal. As a prelude to popping the question, for example, ''I could see a couple walking up to our beach hut to rent a WaveRunner, and the next thing you know the associates break out in dance,'' said Bob Pfeffer, director of sales and marketing. He orchestrated his first flash mob in the summer, pulling 25 participants in on a rehearsed dancing gag amid a meeting of 150 executives.

Clark Gillies, a former Islanders star, rang the Nasdaq closing bell recently, and the bell survived. In fact, the market jumped after Gillies, a rare player who could fight as well as shoot and skate skillfully, performed the honors. Gillies, 57, was a key player when the Islanders won four consecutive Stanley Cups from 1980 to 1983. A member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, he was recently honored at the 26th Annual Great Sports Legends Dinner to benefit The Buoniconti Fund to Cure Paralysis. Q.

Because of an editing error, a capsule summary in the Inside The Times column on Sept. 25 for the article about the Joint Mobile Group misidentified the country in which the city of Nizhny Novgorod is located. The city, site of the group's main office, is in Russia, but not in the region of Chechnya.

A map last Sunday with an article about recent residential development in flood-prone areas of New York City misidentified one such neighborhood on the East River in Queens. It is Hunters Point, not Hunts Point. (Hunts Point is in the Bronx.)

ORANGE CITY, Iowa - Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Saturday that he would offer a detailed plan for job creation next week in the first policy speech of his presidential candidacy. But during a weekend visit here, he spent much of the time focusing on another issue: immigration. -In three stops across northwestern Iowa, the state's most conservative region, Mr. Perry delivered a forceful recitation of the steps he had taken in Texas to enforce immigration laws. He reminded audiences that he vetoed legislation granting driver's licenses to illegal immigrants and he signed a law requiring voters to show identification.

JUDGE--Margot Perona, of Roxbury, CT. died unexpectedly on the 11th of September while vacationing in Maine with her husband Jerry of 58 years, from a sudden and unforeseen aortic arch dissection. Margot was born January 10, 1930. She married Jeremy Judge, June 27, 1953 after a year abroad following her graduation from Douglas College. Margot was the loving mother of Geoff, Jennifer and Peter, and encouraged them in their professional pursuits and marriages to three amazing women, Mary Ann, Ethelind and Kathy. She enjoyed loving and close relationships with her grandchildren, Jennifer, Alex, Eric and Louis, her cousin Betty, and her sister-in-law Jen Howes and her children Deborah, Wendy, Cindy and Chris, and grandchildren Ashley, Willie, Hank, Noli, Clara and Jack with whom they enjoy the property in Roxbury. Margot was a tremendous volunteer raising money for a myriad of worthy causes while also knitting together a fabulous quilt of dear friends. As one friend put it, "Margot Judge comes from an era of utterly classy ladies, family first, a matriarch with warmth, honesty and generosity for all that had the pleasure of relishing her company" Charitable donations may be made in memory of Margot Judge to either Christ Episcopal Church, 4 Weller's Bridge Rd, Roxbury, CT 06783 or to Minor Memorial Library, 23 South Street, Roxbury.

As chief medical and scientific officer of the American Cancer Society, Otis Webb Brawley -- who is also a professor of oncology and epidemiology at Emory University -- is the public face of the cancer establishment. He operates in a world of similarly high-achieving, multiple-credentialed, respectable professionals, where insults tend to be delivered, stiletto-style, in scientific language that lay people aren't meant to understand. So it can be more than a little jarring to hear, for example, James Mohler, chairman of the urology department and associate director of the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, say of his friend: ''I have known Otis for over 20 years. He doesn't come off as being ignorant or stupid, but when it comes to prostate-cancer screening, he must not be as intelligent as he seems.'' Or Skip Lockwood, the head of Zero, a prostate-cancer patient advocacy group, charge that Brawley is more concerned about saving men's sex lives than about saving the men themselves. Brawley has become the target of these attacks because of his blunt and very public skepticism about the routine use of the prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., test to screen men for early prostate cancer. ''I'm not against prostate-cancer screening,'' Brawley says. ''I'm against lying to men. I'm against exaggerating the evidence to get men to get screened. We should tell people what we know, what we don't know and what we simply believe.''

Great-grandfather of Dylan, Riley and Paige Garber and Katie and Camryn Berdon. Predeceased by his sister Eleanor (nee Berdon) Pearl; survived by his brother Dr. Walter Berdon of Mamaroneck, NY. Funeral services at Westchester Reform Temple, Sunday, October 9th at 11am. Remembrances may be made to Blythedale Children's Hospital, www.blythedale.org.

BERGL--Ralph. It is with profound sadness that we announce the passing of our father, and beloved husband, Ralph Bergl. He passed away September 27 after a long illness at the age of 82. Fortunately his family was at his side to say good-bye and help ease his pain and suffering. Ralph was a wonderful man who had many friends and was loved very much by his family; his wife of 60 years, Kay; his son, Derek; his daughter, Vivien; his son-in law, Dale; and two beautiful grandchildren, Colette and Ben. Everyone who knew him found what a dynamic personality he had and loved his incredible sense of humor. He made so many people happy. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make a contribution to the Pulmonary Hypertension Association (www.phassociation.org) so that they may continue their work to find a cure for the horrible disease that took his life. There will be a memorial service to commemorate the life of Ralph Bergl on November 6 at 3pm at the Garden City, Long Island, Unitarian Church. A reception to follow. All are welcome. Please visit www.uuccn.org for directions. The Bergl Family

A report in the In Transit column on Sept. 25 about an exhibition of four restored Flemish tapestries dating from the 1470s, at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, misstated the final date of the exhibition and misspelled part of its title. The exhibition runs through Jan. 8, not Jan. 12. And it is ''The Invention of Glory: Afonso V and the Pastrana Tapestries'' (not Alfonso).

WEINGER--Milton. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Milton, who will long be remembered and be in our hearts. May the many good memories of his life be a comfort to our dear Shirley and their family. Claire and Bob

SHELDON--Abe (nee Schmukler). February 10, 1912-October 4, 2011. We bid farewell to "The Scion" of our family. Abe was a true "Diamond in the Rough"; a man who "did it his way" and knew how to save for a rainy day! He was the most generous, wise, funny, brilliant person who always put the best interests of his family first. He is predeceased by his wife of 72 years, Eleanor, and is survived by his sons Robert (Gloria) and Paul (Harriet); his four grandchildren, and his three great-grandchildren. It was a privilege to have known him and he will be remembered by his progeny forever.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week. With the onset of fall came rain. More than two and a half inches fell in northern Manhattan last Friday. It fell slowly at first. As I stood in the woods, the canopy trees overhead provided cover. Then the rain came harder and faster, spoiling my leafy safe haven.

The $25 million sale of a penthouse in an East Side co-op to Paul G. Allen, a founder of the Microsoft Corporation, was the highest of the week, according to city property records. Mr. Allen bought the penthouse at 4 East 66th Street, also known as 845 Fifth Avenue, from Angela Thompson, the widow of Wade F .B. Thompson, who made Airstream, the travel trailer builder, a wildly successful company. He died in November 2009. The records show that the penthouse was transferred to her in March.

IN the Roncesvalles Village area of Toronto, shop windows still trumpet ''godziny otwarcia'' -- Polish for ''opening hours.'' But as young, creative types have snapped up homes, this west-end Polish enclave has morphed into a hub of local design and casual-hip dining. After a multiyear neighborhood reconstruction project that temporarily cut streetcar service and starved merchants, Roncesvalles Avenue -- the area's main artery -- is thrumming again. Despite their big-city location, the street's indie bookstores, quirky coffeehouses and smart boutiques feel more like small-town hangouts, with stroller-pushing locals popping in to chat up proprietors. Tree-lined and low-slung, with a blessed absence of the chain stores that have crept across Toronto, the rejuvenated ''Roncey'' now makes for one of the city's most engaging strolls. MICHAEL KAMINER

Making its debut in Paris last Sunday, the spring collection has all of the pieces that women have come to love from the mother line, including black motocross jeans, zebra-print pieces and shrunken leather jackets. The men's wear, too, is very rocker-looking, with leather bombers and slim shirts neatly tucked into skinny jeans. SARA MOONVES

IF your retail therapist is counseling you to find a happy place, a good place to start looking might be the corner of Broadway and 23rd Street, where a Marimekko flagship has just opened. The airy industrial space in the former Toy Building has been whitewashed and minimally outfitted, the better to show off the brightly colored, impossibly upbeat prints for which the 60-year-old Finnish company is famous. The founders, Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, always envisioned Marimekko not just as a lifestyle brand but as a way of life, and over the years, their graphic sensibility touched everything from textiles to teapots, all of which are sold there. There is even an on-site seamstress, to whip up, say, a set of napkins in the Unikko, the signature poppy print, or a pillow cover in the artist Astrid Sylwan's brushstroke-like Vattenblank. The folks at Marimekko hope New Yorkers will embrace the store as a meeting point; the next trick, it seems, may be getting them to leave. Marimekko, 200 Fifth Avenue; us.marimekko.com. ALIX BROWNE

ETTELBRICK--Paula. The Board and Staff of the Stonewall Community Foundation mourn the passing of our immediate past Executive Director, Paula Ettelbrick. A lifelong advocate for LGBTQ people across the globe, Paula, age 56, died on Friday October 7, 2011. In addition to Stonewall, Paula held key posts at Lambda Legal, National Center for Lesbian Rights, Empire State Pride Agenda, the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force and the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission. Countless peoples' lives are better today because of Paula; she will be sorely missed. For more information, visit: www.stonewallfoundation.org.

An article on Sept. 25 about the dangers faced by the Joint Mobile Group, an organization of human rights investigators in Russia's restive Chechen region, misidentified the sponsor of the Front Line Award for Human Rights Defenders at Risk, which was given to the organization in May at a ceremony in Dublin. It was Front Line, a Dublin-based group that is an advocate for human rights investigators. It was not the Mary Robinson Foundation -- Climate Justice, a Dublin-based group that advocates on behalf of poor and vulnerable victims of climate change. (The honorary presenter at the award ceremony was Mary Robinson, the former president of Ireland and the president and founder of the Mary Robinson Foundation -- Climate Justice.)

Metropolitan's cover article last week, by John Leland, told of a 58-year-old, uninsured illegal immigrant from Hong Kong who spent 19 months in New York Downtown Hospital after suffering a stroke, because his family would not take him. Outrage over his long stay -- and its $1.4 million cost, largely unpaid -- erupted in more than 230 reader comments on NYTimes.com; below is a sampling. Readers also wrote about Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, which criticized the New York Police Department's response to Occupy Wall Street and some earlier protests. I've worked in many hospitals in the region, and this is an astoundingly common problem. Each state has its own laws. Whereas in NYC, an undocumented, uninsured individual is able to get dialysis covered, this is not true in New Jersey, and one cannot get discharged without a dialysis center accepting them. I have seen young men sitting in hospital beds for months and even years, while social work figures out how to get them placed. It's heartbreaking to see these people trapped in the hospital.
OLD TAPPAN COLONIAL $969,000

SCHWARTZ--Elayne Polly Bernstein. Shakespeare & Company of Lenox, MA, mourns the passing of its dearest friend, Elayne Polly Bernstein Schwartz, on October 4, 2011. Elayne was one of the most remarkable and generous supporters of the arts and humanities throughout the Berkshires and beyond -- including Great Neck, Sarasota, New York City, and as far away as Israel. Her overriding passion revolved around Shakespeare & Company, where she served as a lifetime trustee. She discovered her love for Shakespeare in her middle years as a student at Queens College. She had always wanted to study theatre and the great playwrights in depth and threw her entire being into her courses with reverence and her ceaseless energy. Elayne always said, "I came to it late but it filled my life thereafter." When she married her beloved Sol Schwartz in 2004, Shakespeare & Company organized the event disguised as her 80th Birthday Party. In Sol, himself an artist, she had found a soul mate who loved the arts and Shakespeare & Company much like she did. In particular, Sol shared her passion for both the education programs and the beautification and development of the whole property. Together they forged a joyous life of common interests in the arts, not only in Lenox, but in Sarasota and New York as well. Elayne's special focus was Shakespeare & Company's nationally acclaimed and award-winning education programs, the largest in the Northeast, that annually reach more than 50,000 students and teachers with accessible and challenging performances, residencies and workshops. "If we can get the kids inspired early on, it will stay with them all their lives." In honor of Elayne's dedication and commitment, the Company named its new production center and theatre for her. Shakespeare & Company is now graced by The Bernstein Center for the Performing Arts, The Elayne P. Bernstein Theatre, and Elayne's Corner, a special garden with benches, a fountain and beautiful landscaping. Elayne was a passionate and inspired woman who possessed endless warmth and a sparkling sense of humor which charmed all who met her. She relished seeing Shakespeare's works performed on our stages, especially by our youngest artists. Elayne will be sorely missed by the entire cultural community of the Berkshires. Her impact will live on for generations to come. We will remember her always....."So long as men can breathe, or eyes can see, So long lives this, and this gives life to thee." -- William Shakespeare. A memorial service for family and friends will be held in the Elayne P. Bernstein Theatre at Shakespeare & Company on Sunday, October 9 at 2:00pm.
FARRELL--Thomas R.,July 16, 2011. Beloved husband of Diane (Efantes). Survived by six children and seven grandchildren.

The caravan arrived in Paris for the final shows of the spring 2012 collections, carrying luggage filled with autumn clothes to wear at Fashion Week. But it never happened: Paris suffered a heat wave, and the guests stripped down. Chloé even rolled back the roof of the tent so the audience would not feel like baked potatoes. Many guests wore wonderfully cut white shirts. Some balanced the white with black. Talk about drama! Other women wore their evening dresses to 10 a.m. shows, and why not? There were bare backs, daring cutouts filled with black net, peplums and silver parasols. Anna Dello Russo, right, strolled by in a Versace black fake leather dress to be sold at H&M for around $100 in November. Could the stained-glass palette of Haider Ackermann's stunning collection, top, get women out of solid black? Don't hold your breath. And keep a white shirt handy.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 25 about acronyms misstated the derivation of the word ''swag,'' in a reference to gifts given to celebrities at New York Fashion Week. The Oxford English Dictionary dates its first citation, as a term for a thief's plunder, from 1794; it only recently has been interpreted as an acronym for ''stuff we all get.''

MERRILL-OLDHAM--Jan. Jan Merrill-Oldham died peacefully at her home in Cambridge, Massachusetts on October 5th 2011. She is survived by her husband Peter Merrill-Oldham of Cambridge, her mother and father, Alice Cecarelli Merrill and James Hersey Merrill of Milford, CT, and her brother James Wallace Merrill of West Haven, CT. Janice Elaine Merrill was born on May 10, 1947 in Bridgeport Connecticut and raised in Milford Connecticut until she went to college, spending most of her summers with her grandparents Ed and Esther Trask in East Sumner, ME. She graduated from Jonathan Law High School in Milford in 1965 and from the University of Connecticut in Storrs in 1969. She married Peter Oldham in 1976 in Ashford, CT, and in 1978 they changed their last names to Merrill-Oldham. As the Malloy-Rabinowitz Preservation Librarian at Harvard University, Jan directed the Weissman Preservation Center in the Harvard University Library and the Preservation & Imaging Services Department in the Harvard College Library from November 1995 to February 2010. She created and administered a comprehensive program to preserve and enhance access to the 16.5 million volumes and extensive special collections and archives held in Harvard's more than 70 libraries. Jan became interested in the preservation of library collections while working in the bindery at the University of Connecticut Library. In 1979, a National Endowment for the Humanities fellowship at the Yale University Library allowed Jan to undertake formal training in library and archives preservation. She went on to earn a Masters in Library Science from the University of Rhode Island and to establish the University of Connecticut Libraries' Preservation Department. Over the course of 30 years, Jan became a recognized national and international leader in the field of library and archives preservation. Eager to learn and insatiably curious, she was an extraordinary teacher, mentor, author and administrator. Early on, her vision for libraries led her to move beyond the work of simply preserving collections to reformatting them for access via the Internet. Jan exercised her formidable powers of persuasion with university administrators, commercial suppliers, and by serving on key committees within the American Library Association (ALA), the Association of Research Libraries, the Council on Library and Information Resources, the National Information Standards Organization and many others. She authored and edited more than 40 publications. Jan's powerful influence within her profession was widely recognized. In 2011, the Association of Collections and Technical Services (ALCTS) and the Preservation and Reformatting Section (PARS) of ALA created a professional development grant in her honor. She also received the ALA/ALCTS Ross Atkinson Lifetime Achievement Award (2011), the ALA/PARS Banks Harris Award (1994), a University of Connecticut Distinguished Service Award (1994) and the ALA/PARS Esther Piercy Award (1990). Jan was one of those rare people who not only changed her profession but also the lives of the many family members, friends and colleagues who came to love and respect her. A memorial ceremony will be held at the Mount Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge, Massachusetts on Saturday, October 15th at 1pm in the Storey Chapel, followed by a reception celebrating her life at Pete and Jan's home in Cambridge. In lieu of flowers, donations in Jan's memory may be made to the Circle of Caring at Hospice of the Good Shepherd 617-969-6130 hospicegoodshepherd.org.

The first four weeks of the N.F.L. season have been filled with surprises, but there has been one constant: the extra point. COOPER--Frederick A.,born December 12, 1936, passed away while working on his book, September 25, 2011. Fred Cooper had an unquenchable thirst for knowledge that drove him to discover and unravel clues left by ancient civilizations. As a distinguished professor, he was a consummate Socratic pedagogue who mentored, challenged, encouraged, cajoled and taught innumerable students. He made lasting and valuable contributions to the study of ancient Greek architecture and the science of archaeology. He befriended everyone he met with his outgoing larger-than-life personality, loved to have diverse people around him, and threw great gourmet parties. Fred Cooper will be missed with much love by everyone whose lives he touched including his daughters, second wife, "son", son-in-law, step-children, grandchildren, two sisters and brother and many colleagues and friends.

NICK CAVE is an artist who makes costumes for sculpture. Actually, the costumes are the sculptures. He calls them Soundsuits because they're loud. Pitched at a decibel the eye can hear, they armor the body in dyed feathers, brilliant sequins, bugle beads, fake flowers, thatched twigs, strips of old sweaters and gaggles of pipe cleaners. They may have tall chairs or wicker baskets for heads. There's no way to know if they're male or female, or of what race or class, but they're too dazzling for anyone to care. Yet people do, and they've been showing it by crowding the Mary Boone Gallery in Chelsea, where the latest examples of Mr. Cave's art are on display. ''For Now'' is like a glittering cocktail party, with each guest trying to out-spectacle the others. This is a show for Cave fans eager to see him top himself. Happily, his assemblages meet all expectations. Through Oct. 22; Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street. LINDA YABLONSKY

WEIR--John. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague John Weir. We have known John since the early 1980s when he was a client of ours as the head of U.S. operations for Greycoat PLC and more recently as our partner at Taconic Investment Partners since 2000. John was a highly valued member of our executive team until his retirement at the end of 2010. We appreciate all he brought to our company: his hard work, his deep knowledge of real estate development, his integrity, his leadership in training many of our younger professionals, his commitment to getting the job done, and, last but not least, his valuable golf tips. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Barbara and his three terrific sons: Paul, Scott and Ryan. Charles Bendit, Paul Pariser & the Taconic Investment Partners team.

Packers (4-0) at Falcons (2-2) Sunday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Packers by 6. Tramon Williams's end-of-half interception return for the Packers against the Falcons in last year's playoffs may be remembered as a turning point in N.F.L. history. The Falcons were the better team entering the game, and while the Packers held a 21-14 lead before the play, the Falcons were driving and appeared likely to score. Williams's interception turned the game into a rout, and the Packers have been unbeatable ever since, while the Falcons have replaced them as the team with a young quarterback and lots of talent that cannot quite get its act together. Of course, for some that turning point arrived a little late. ''I'm really surprised that it kind of took him so long,'' Brett Favre said of the three interminable years it took Aaron Rodgers to lead the Packers to the Super Bowl. Who knew that through all of those quasi-retirements, through his stints with the Jets and the Vikings, Favre was just impatiently waiting for Rodgers to close the deal? Favre did not sound as if he was trying to insult Rodgers - he has simply lost the ability to compliment people who are not him - but teammates and analysts have rushed to Rodgers's defense, which he does not really need. It had been peaceful months since the last self-serving Favre rant. What took him so long? Pick: Packers Saints (3-1) at Panthers (1-3) Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Saints by 6.5 . The proper transitional form between terrible and great for an N.F.L. team is not ''average,'' but ''interesting.'' Average teams get stuck at average, or worse, get stuck in the N.F.C. West. Interesting teams, with great strengths but fascinating flaws, are usually on the fast track up or down. The Panthers are going up; the road down goes straight through Philadelphia. The Panthers are interesting because Cam Newton has settled into his role as the league's hottest prospect. His developing skills in the pocket make him more than just a scrambles-and-bombs playground passer, though the scrambles and bombs remain frequent and fun. Steve Smith has been rejuvenated by Newton's presence and is averaging 22.1 yards per catch. The supporting cast - running backs Jonathan Stewart and DeAngelo Williams, tight ends Greg Olsen and Jeremy Shockey - is deep and multi-talented. Defensively, the Panthers do not have much, but that keeps things entertaining. The Saints are always interesting, except when they play the Jaguars, who bring the bland with them. The Panthers are no match for the Saints just yet, but they are now game for a 34-29 or 40-33 final score, which is the next best thing to winning after a year of watching Jimmy Clausen throw two-yard passes to Tony Fiammetta. Pick: Saints
