KITCH--Laura W. Professor emerita of sociology at Brooklyn College, CUNY, was found dead in her Union Square apartment on Wednesday, September 21. She was born in New York City on August 2, 1938, graduated from Hunter College and took her Ph. D. from the New School. She started teaching at Brooklyn in January, 1966 and stayed for the rest of her career, establishing herself with pioneering work in the sociology of media and contemporary culture. She collaborated with Ronald Berkman on People, Power, & Politics (1984) and on Politics in the Media Age (1986). In 1971, she married her colleague, Jack Kitch, professor of English, who predeceased her in 1996. At the time of his death, she was chair of the Department of Sociology and, in December 1997, when Christoph Kimmich was recruited to serve as interim chancellor of CUNY, she was asked to assume the duties of Interim Provost, and held this post until September, 2000, retiring from Brooklyn College in February, 2002. She is survived by an older brother, Harold Weale, of Stamford, NY and a younger sister, Iris White, of Harrison, ME. Her ashes will be placed next to her late husband at the Calverton National Cemetery.

Three years later, the memory was still vivid for Mark Attanasio, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. BLOCH--Florence J, on October 4, 2011. Until the age of ninety she fiercely guarded her independence. Responsibility to her values and beliefs was of fundamental importance to her. Her life was one of service- to her family, her immediate community of friends and associates, and the society in which she fulfilled various posts and positions with firm dignity. Born in Washington Heights and educated in New York City Public Schools, Florence Bloch graduated, Phi Beta Kappa, from Hunter College in 1936 and received a Master's Degree in German from Hunter in 1938. Had she been born in a later era she would have continued her education no doubt with distinction. Instead, for nearly three decades (1936-1962) Florence Bloch devoted herself to her alma mater as secretary of Hunter's redoubtable Classics Department, where, as a lecturer, she also put her fluency in Latin to good use. In her private life Florence chose looking after her parents as long as they lived over pursuit of personal happiness. From 1962 to retirement in 1981, Florence Bloch served generations of CUNY graduate students as Director of Financial Aid where her reputation for strictness was matched by her determination to afford all those who had a right to assistance their fair chance. Among other academic distinctions Florence was a founding member and inductee into the Hunter College Hall of Fame (1972) and received the President's Medal from the CUNY Graduate Center (1981). In addition to Phi Beta Kappa, she was a member of Eta Sigma Phi (National Honorary Classics Society) and Sigma Epsilon Phi (National Honorary German Society). From early days, Florence Bloch was a consummate New Yorker attending and supporting its cultural events from ballet to the opera to its many museums. She was a diehard Dodger fan and once knew the batting averages of all her beloved Bums. Her volunteer work after retirement included her helping reorganize the local branch of New York's Finest. She was also a seasoned, indefatigable traveler who had little time for trees unless they were painted. She did not hesitate to refer to herelf as a television junkie, for she watched Congressional hearings on C-Span for days on end with all the fervor she once spent on baseball. Florence Bloch is survived by her nephew, Donald Bloch, of Amsterdam, Netherlands. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Graduate Center Foundation, 365 Fifth Avenue, 8th Fl., New York, NY 10016.

The recall covers the 2009-12 Jetta and Jetta SportWagen, the 2010-12 Golf and the 2010-12 Audi A3. Audis account for roughly 7,000 of the recalled vehicles. N.H.T.S.A. opened an investigation into the fuel leaks in August, but that inquiry was limited to the 2011 Jetta TDI.

Because of an editing error, an obituary last Sunday about Robert Whitaker, an official photographer for the Beatles, referred incorrectly to the 1966 Beatles album ''Yesterday and Today.'' It was a compilation released by Capitol Records in the United States without the Beatles' direct involvement; it was not ''a lesser effort by the Beatles.'' And although it did contain songs that had appeared on the British version of the ''Help!'' album, it did not contain the song ''Help!'' (Until 1967, the contents of the British and American versions of Beatles albums were not identical.) The obituary also referred imprecisely to the content of ''Yesterday and Today.'' While it did contain songs that had appeared on previous Beatles albums and that would appear on the group's album ''Revolver'' later that year, those songs were only on the British versions of those albums, not the American versions.

TOLEDANO--Mauricio Hatchwell. The America-Israel Friendship League is deeply saddened by news of the untimely death of our friend, Mauricio Hatchwell Toledano on September 28, 2011 after a long illness. Mauricio was born in Casablanca, Morocco in 1940 into a Sephardic Jewish family who left Spain in 1492 and returned in 1964. He achieved outstanding success in several businesses and was recognized as a leading figure in the Spanish Jewish community. He was devoted to the State of Israel and received many awards and honors in his activities on behalf of Israel and the Jewish people. He formed friendships around the world with many governments and communities and with leaders of Israel and the Jewish world in his advocacy for Israel who will also miss his magnetic charm and friendship. We send our deepest condolences to his dear wife Monique and his loving family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Dr. Alex Grobman Executive Director

PRESSMAN--David. Television and Broadway stage director, passed away on Monday, August 29th in his home in New York City. He was ninety seven years old. An acclaimed acting teacher, Mr. Pressman was head of The Neighborhood Playhouse School of Theater from 1957-1963, and started the Boston University acting program in the early 1950s. He was an original member of The Actors Studio. A successful director of early dramatic live television from 1947 until 1952, he fell victim to the McCarthy blacklist and was unable to work in television for almost twelve years. During that time he continued to teach and direct theater, including the acclaimed Broadway production of "The Disenchanted" starring Jason Robards in his first Broadway role. Mr. Pressman later directed the award winning play "Summertree" at Lincoln Center. He returned to directing television in the 1960s, with such shows as "The Defenders and NYPD". He went on to direct "One Life To Live", for which he won three Daytime Emmys. He continued directing until his retirement at the age of 85. A decorated World War II veteran with two Purple Hearts, Mr. Pressman saw combat for two years with the 45th Infantry Division in Italy, France and Germany. He was a beloved, kind and generous man, a loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed. He is survived by Sasha, his wife of 70 years; his three sons Gregory (husband of Emily), Michael and Eugene; grandchildren Joanna, Naomi, Joshua, Rachel and Brooks; and three great-grandchildren. A memorial to Mr. Pressman will take place at 11am on Saturday, October 22nd, 2011 at the Director's Guild of America, where he served on the Guild's Eastern Directors Council for many years. 110 West 57th Street, New York City. RSVP to 212-258-0807 or mleal@dga.org.

Cambridge, Mass. IN 1980, Steve Jobs went to a brown-bag lunch at Stanford business school, looking for summer help. Other Apple executives were busy explaining what a personal computer was when he sauntered in; they stopped mid-sentence as, dressed in a vest, jeans and Birkenstock sandals, he settled himself, cross-legged, on top of a desk. He looked as if he were about to hold a yoga class. Then he began to talk, instead, about revolutionizing the world.

The 450th anniversary of St. Basil's Cathedral in Red Square will be honored Oct. 14 to 17 with an international choir festival featuring a Russian choir from Boston and the premiere of a work for orchestra, organ and choir set to Anna Akhmatova's poem ''Requiem,'' about Stalin-era suffering. ''The cathedral's silhouette is famous around the world,'' said Lev Pankratov, the festival's musical director and the composer of ''Requiem.'' The festival opens with two concerts: one at St. Basil's (closed to the general public) and one at the State Historical Museum on the opposite end of Red Square. Folk music and Russian Orthodox music by composers like Dmitri Bortniansky and Rachmaninoff will be performed during the festival.

In the American fall collections of 1960, Norman Norell did something seemingly too radical for a man who ate most of his meals at Schrafft's and Hamburg Heaven. He had his models paint their faces in the bohemian-urchin style of Paris in the '20s, with darkened eyes and red lips, finished off with shingle haircuts. Then he put the girls in pants. Technically these were split skirts, but who cares? The effect was the same. Long before Yves Saint Laurent issued le smoking, square Norman was there. "They may seem a little avant-garde at first," he told The Times after his 1960 show, for which he received a standing ovation, "but I really do believe in the look." He had uncanny instincts for anticipating change: the elongated sweater look, the return of waistlines in the mid-'60s, the dolman-sleeve rage of the early '70s. He showed leopard patterns in the '40s. The flapper makeup told a lot about Norell as well: stage-struck at an early age, he designed costumes in the '20s at the Astoria studio of Paramount Pictures, dressing Gloria Swanson in "Zaza," and later worked on Broadway musicals and burlesque shows before moving to ladies' fashion.

This week the Appraisal visits TriBeCa Twelve, a soon-to-open home for young adults recovering from substance abuse. It will be run by Hazelden, the Minnesota-based operator of a network of rehab centers, and be housed in a planned luxury condo development on West Broadway that Hazelden bought after the development went belly up. The Columbia University psychiatry department is a partner in the effort. Although the popular image of live-in centers for people recovering from substance abuse runs more toward campus-like complexes in bucolic settings, where fresh air and natural beauty replace the lures of drugs and alcohol, this one - intended to serve as a transition from rehab to real life - is in the midst of a heavily traveled night life zone, near bars, clubs and restaurants that would seem to pose threats to a resident's hard-won sobriety. Have you or has someone you know been in rehab or a similar situation and found the temptations of city life hard to resist? Or do you think that treatment centers need not be remote to be effective? Please share your thoughts and experiences.

Paul Tough's article ''What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?'' received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazine's page views. But we were very excited to see the article have a kind of second life over at The Learning Network, a New York Times blog for students and teachers. Our colleagues at The Learning Network used the article to kick off a new ''Reading Club,'' and there were 534 student comments on Tough's article. The Reading Club forum encourages discussion, and it was pretty exciting to see students thoughtfully debate questions about social class and character; parental influence and character; and the difference between struggle and failure. There was a lot of respectful disagreement, though the comments I read seemed to be nearly unanimous on one point: No report cards for character, please.

The South African writer J. M. Coetzee wrote his Ph.D. dissertation on the early fiction of Samuel Beckett, receiving his degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969, the same year Beckett was awarded the Nobel Prize. Thirty-four years later, Mr. Coetzee himself received the Nobel Prize for literature. Now the Harry Ransom Center, the same library where Mr. Coetzee did his research on Beckett, has acquired Mr. Coetzee's papers. Among the more than 160 boxes and filing cabinets of material are family photographs, business correspondence, recordings of interviews, notebooks and early manuscripts for his novels and his autobiography.

There's no other comedy on television quite like HBO's "Bored to Death." It's simultaneously old-fashioned and amazingly up to the minute, a gumshoe fantasy set in a very real world: the Brooklyn brownstones and cafes and Manhattan co-op apartments and watering holes that shelter what passes for literary culture in 21st-century New York. The novelist Jonathan Ames, the show's creator, works out his love-hate relationship to the city's writing life (and those who live it) with a mix of whimsy and precise observation that can make even the most cleverly written network sitcoms -- "Modern Family," "Community" -- seem mass produced and one-size-fits-all in comparison.

I interviewed Tony Blair in his suite at New York's Carlyle Hotel on the steamy afternoon of Sept. 23. He was in New York for the meeting of the U.N. General Assembly in his capacity as Middle East envoy, a post announced just hours after he stepped down as British prime minister in 2007. Blair had a short window between official meetings to sit for an interview to promote the paperback publication of his 2010 memoir, "A Journey." Sadly he did not have enough time -- nor did the Carlyle have an extra room -- to allow photographer Christian Oth and his team to set their seamless backdrop anywhere or anytime else. So there we were, a trim, tanned, tieless former prime minister, his press secretary, an aide, a book publicist, a photographer and his two assistants and a reporter, all occupying one room in which the air conditioning seemed not to be functioning. At the conclusion of the interview, a flustered Cherie Blair rushed in to join the party, apparently after overhearing from the next room too many questions concerning reports that had run in the conservative tabloid that has dogged the Blairs for decades. "I couldn't resist coming in after hearing all that Daily Mail nonsense," she declared. Here's what was left on the cutting room floor.

9 P.M. (13, 49) THE WAR OF 1812 From 1812 to 1815, Americans battled the British, Canadian colonists and American Indians in a war that would shape the geography and identity of North America. Two centuries later this two-hour documentary by Lawrence Hott and Diane Garey, above, uses re-enactments, animation and commentary from historians and authors to examine important battles and figures including Tecumseh, the Shawnee who tried to form a confederation of American Indian nations; his adversary, William Henry Harrison, governor of the Indiana Territory; President James Madison; George Prévost, the governor general in British North America; and the British Maj. Gen. Isaac Brock, who captured a large American army at Detroit without a fight. 7 P.M. (OWN) THE ROSIE SHOW Rosie O'Donnell begins her new talk show with the actor Russell Brand as her first guest.

KEY PERFORMANCE Antonio Cromartie atoned for blown coverage on Aaron Hernandez by intercepting a deflected pass at the goal line to close the first half. What would probably have been a touchdown -- the ball went through Hernandez's hands, caroming to Cromartie -- became a brief momentum-stopper for the Jets, who thwarted a scoring threat that had begun at the Patriots' 7. It allowed the Jets to remain within a field goal at halftime, 10-7, instead of being down by two scores with New England preparing to receive the second-half kickoff.

PINCUS--Lionel. You have been gone for two years, but you are never far from me. You are with me always. I see you in all our many familiar places, feel you and even hear you every day. I honor the life we built together, our hopes, the work we cared so passionately about, and the adventures we shared over the years. Your memory shines brightly in my heart and in the legacy of your pioneering and accomplished successes, your discreet and constant giving, your elegant ways, your decency and tolerance, your strength and gentleness, and your serenity and nobility until the untimely painful end. You live in my heart and mind, and the deep love and total devotion we shared are my consolation. Peace for you my prince. Firyal

Since January experts at Sotheby's have been trying to privately sell a suite of four bronze sculptures of a woman's back that Matisse created over a period of 23 years beginning in 1908. The works belong to the Burnett Foundation in Forth Worth, and at the time the sale was announced, neither Sotheby's nor the foundation would say what the asking price was, although dealers approached by the auction house reported that they were hoping for around $200 million for all four. Now, as the fall auction season approaches and the sculptures remain unsold, Sotheby's is announcing that it will auction the four works separately -- in chronological order -- over the next year, starting with the earliest and most classical of them all, ''Back I,'' which will be included in its Impressionist and modern art auction in New York on Nov. 2. It is estimated to bring $20 million to $30 million.

Adrian Peterson, right, rushed for 122 yards and 3 touchdowns as the Vikings beat the Cardinals, 34-10, for their first victory. All three of Peterson's scoring runs came in the first quarter, and his yardage total and carries (29) were season highs. Chiefs quarterback Matt Cassel threw four touchdown passes and seemed to revel in tormenting the Colts by alternating scoring passes between Dwayne Bowe and Steve Breaston, who each caught two in a 28-24 win. ''If you're going to double one, you can't double the other,'' Cassel said.

Sinopec of China agreed on Sunday to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and gas producer, for about $2.1 billion in cash, as Chinese companies increasingly flock to Canada's oil-rich resources. Under the terms of the deal, Sinopec's international exploration and production arm will pay 10.08 Canadian dollars ($9.70) a share. That is more than double Daylight's closing price of 4.59 Canadian dollars on Friday, and 43.9 percent above the shares' 60-day weighted average trading price.

Everyone gets old. Even the clever young men who created Facebook, which is why Facebook is no longer going to be only about who you are now. It will soon allow you to curate, as they say in digi-speak, your past. What used to be your Facebook personal profile page will soon be known as Timeline. It is meant to contain information on your major milestones - marriage, the acquisition of a pet, purchase of house, the birth of children - and your minor ones as well, like the song you listened to on Tuesday or the dinner with friends on Friday. It will allow you to present a picture of yourself as you were once and are now. Facebook's algorithms will help create your Timeline. But you will be able to cut and paste the important milestones yourself.

Jason Shelowitz has made it his mission to educate New Yorkers on proper urban decorum. All he had to do was break the law. Seventy times. Beatles fans now have two reasons to toast to their favorite band each Oct. 9: On what would have been John Lennon's 71st birthday, Sir Paul McCartney married Nancy Shevell in a small civil ceremony on Sunday at Marylebone Town Hall in London, The Associated Press reported. After being showered with flower petals by their wedding guests, the newlyweds posed for pictures and waved at fans on the steps of the office wearing outfits designed by Mr. McCartney's daughter Stella.

Earlier this week, Oracle's chief executive Larry Ellison went to greater pains than usual to beat up on the competition. Considering the stakes, it was worth it to him. Speaking at a trade show with 45,000 registered visitors, Ellison announced his company's formal entry into the business of selling software via a ''public cloud.'' The cloud is a huge conglomeration of computer technologies. Clouds, and all that they imply for business and society, are the biggest thing going in tech today, promising billions of people access to nearly limitless amounts of computing, data storage, and communications. With that in mind, Oracle's entry into the market comes as no surprise.

An article on Thursday about a running-of-the-bulls event in Arizona misstated the connection between People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and an annual event in New Orleans in which a roller derby team chases runners. PETA endorses that New Orleans event, which does not use bulls, but Delcianna Winders, a PETA activist who criticized the Arizona event, is not an organizer of the New Orleans one. (Nola Bulls, LLC organizes it.)

-A stage version of ''The King's Speech,'' the film that won the Academy Award for best picture this year, is no longer on a fast track to Broadway, as its author and one of its producers had originally envisioned. The play by David Seidler, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay for the film, will have a world-premiere production in February in Guildford, England, and then tour theaters in five other British cities through mid-March, according to the producers. A London production of the play may follow, according to a spokesman for the show, and Broadway remains a possibility. Mr. Seidler and one of the producers, Michael Alden, previously said that they could envision the play going straight to Broadway as early as this year, to capitalize on the popularity and critical success of the film. Instead, Mr. Seidler and the creative team will have a chance to refine the script and staging during the tour, and the producers will be able to assess the appeal of the story without its two film stars, Colin Firth and Geoffrey Rush, whose performances were essential to the movie's success.
International ISRAELI CABINET BACKS

Boxing robots were No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, as ''Real Steel'' (DreamWorks Studios/Disney) sold an estimated $27.3 million in tickets. That total was solid, but the picture, which stars Hugh Jackman as a reluctant father, will need to continue drawing large audiences to justify its hefty production budget of $110 million and tens of millions more in marketing support. Many critics disliked ''Real Steel,'' but audiences, especially younger moviegoers, gave it strong marks in exit polls. ''The Ides of March'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment/Cross Creek Pictures) was second, taking in about $10.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. ''Ides,'' a well-reviewed political drama starring Ryan Gosling and George Clooney, cost just $12.5 million to make after tax rebates. ''Dolphin Tale'' (Warner Brothers/Alcon Entertainment) was third, taking in about $9.2 million for a three-week total of $49 million. ''Moneyball'' (Sony) was fourth with an estimated $7.5 million in ticket sales for a three-week total of $49.3 million. And the comedic drama ''50/50'' (Summit) was fifth in its second weekend, taking in $5.5 million for a new total of $17.3 million.

Paula L. Ettelbrick, a leading legal figure in the lesbian and gay civil rights movement who focused on defining ''family'' in the broadest possible way, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 56 and lived in Manhattan and Yonkers. The cause was primary peritoneal cancer, said Suzanne B. Goldberg, her former partner, with whom she had been raising two children.

JILIN CITY, China -- Wang Jianping and his wife, Shue, are a relatively affluent Chinese couple, with an annual household income of $16,000 -- more than double the national average for urban families. They own a modest, three-bedroom apartment here in this northeastern industrial city. They paid for their son to study electrical engineering at prestigious Tsinghua University, in Beijing. And even by frugal Asian standards, they are prodigious savers, with $50,000 in a state-run bank.

On Friday, I reported on an organization called Friends of the Children, which identifies children in kindergarten growing up in poverty and facing multiple risk factors at home and in their neighborhood - and then connects them with adult mentors for 12 years. The idea is to guarantee that these children have a consistent relationship with a caring and responsible adult whom they see at least four hours each week, from kindergarten until high school graduation.

One Saturday in late September 1861, Manhattan witnessed a scene that was becoming commonplace in countless New England towns and cities: well over 1,000 soldiers marched through the city, in the words of one observer, "Singing reverently and enthusiastically in praise of John Brown!" "No military hero of the present war," the New York Independent noted, "has thus been honored."

In 1979, George Segal, the famous Pop artist, was commissioned to create a sculpture to commemorate New York City's Stonewall uprising in 1969 - the seminal (although not the only) event to kick-start the gay liberation movement. The bronze sculpture, covered with a white patina, was finally unveiled in Christopher Park in Greenwich Village in 1992, after years of controversy. It depicts a life-size male couple standing a few feet away from another life-size female couple sitting on a park bench. Beth Suskin, my partner of 35 years, and I, Leslie Cohen, were the models for this sculpture. This is our love story.

Ouch. My face hurts. I know, it's killing you too - oldest joke in the book. But it's no joke: one occupational hazard of testing skin-care products is overdosing on irritants. Chemicals can get under your skin, and even natural substances - essential oils, for example - can wreak havoc: lavender's aroma can be therapeutic and calming, but don't ply your face with lavender oil. Ditto minty or citrusy oils and anything acidic, unless buried in a gentle formula. Hypoallergenics can also be problematic. Many contain potential endocrine disrupters and other nasty components. Besides, allergies are as varied as fingerprints; there's no one-size-fits-all solution to irritated skin.

Mariusz Kwiecien, the Polish baritone who was cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Don Giovanni," which opens on Thursday night, underwent surgery for a herniated disk on Tuesday, his manager said. "The doctors feel that Mariusz's prognosis is excellent," said the manager, William Guerri, of Columbia Artists Management. But it was unclear when he might return to the stage. "It's a wait-and-see proposition," Mr. Guerri said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the opening scene of Monday's dress rehearsal, the manager said. He was taken by paramedics to a hospital, said the Met spokesman, Peter Clark. The Met tapped Peter Mattei, who was on hand for a production of Rossini's "Barbiere di Siviglia," to replace Mr. Kwiecien for the opening of "Don Giovanni." The opera has 16 more performances into March, although Mr. Kwiecien was scheduled to be in the cast only through Nov. 11.

In his latest film "Footnote," the writer and director Joseph Cedar uses Hebrew philology and Talmudic scholarship to weave together a dramatic mystery. Concerning a father and son who are rival professors at a university, the movie looks at how a scholar can devote his life to a single topic of study. When he wrote about it at Telluride, A. O. Scott said the film "blends academic satire, classic Jewish humor and an almost Shakespearean sense of the tragic potential of the paternal bond." "Footnote" is screening at the New York Film Festival this week and in this video, Mr. Cedar discusses elements of the film and some of the research he did to put it together.

Babies raised in bilingual or non-English-speaking households in largely English-speaking territory think differently. Perri Klass has a fascinating article in today's New York Times on exactly how differently: they take longer to distinguish phonetic sounds in either language, but then hear them in both; they retain an interest in other languages longer; and as their languages develop, so do strong multitasking and problem-solving skills.

Patrick Cox's Wannabe loafer, a design-y take on the traditional schoolboy shoe, was a smash hit in the early '90s - almost a million pairs were sold every year. "I was just a kid in England doing this thing that became gigantic and global," says Cox, who was 31 at the time. Stores opened in London, then Paris and New York, and the chunky, heeled shoes all flew out the door. Then came what Cox now calls his Second Album Syndrome. "Wannabe was so huge," he remembers. "So big. So unexpected." What could he possibly do to top it? Though the company chugged along for a few years, Cox eventually sold it in 2007. Faced with a noncompete clause, he traveled for a bit and eventually opened a bakery called Cox Cookies and Cake on the naughty side of Soho in London, selling baked goods that cheekily made references to the peep shows and X-rated video stores that flanked his storefront.

In the last several months, the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby of BarberOsgerby have once gain proven their impressive versatility. And they've been on fire - pardon the pun - since they were named in June as the designers of the 2012 Olympic torch, a sleek, triangular form with 8,000 perforated circles that represent each of the people who will carry the torches. The comment stream in response to my Monday column - "Is the Tea Party Over?" - was divided for the most part into one camp of readers proclaiming the inevitable triumph of the Tea Party, and another, larger camp praying for its demise. There's no point quarreling with faith (in the first case) or hope (in the second). To my mind the question is whether the Tea Party will transform itself from a backlash - the Party of Against - into a force that can make things happen. The movement's best hope of making that leap any time soon, which you can view with approval or alarm, is Rick Perry.

"I like to think of our Web site as a bar," Bruce Weber says of the new BruceWeber.com, which was reintroduced on Monday. "It's like I'm showing my film and somebody from my studio is showing some pictures and somebody else is reading their poetry - it's the bar you always went to after school, in college." With no closing time - and no drinks (B.Y.O.B!) - the site hosts selected fashion photos, ad campaigns, music videos, commercials and documentaries spanning the past three decades of Weber's career alongside paintings from a show by the artist Jeremy Everett (a friend of Weber's), an appreciation of Simone de Beauvoir's book about Brigitte Bardot and high praise for Danny DiMauro, a barber in Montauk, N.Y. The bar you went to in college was never this cool.

It was a curious scene, walking up lower Broadway in broad daylight and hearing the heavy beats pumping from a window above. A freight elevator ride and hefty door charge later, you'd never guess it was midafternoon, as a few hundred people crowded an empty loft space and danced to music played by an all-star roster of D.J.'s. The nine-hour event was in celebration of the 12th anniversary of Tim Sweeney's weekly radio show "Beats in Space," which has been broadcast every Tuesday night on WNYU (89.1) since 1999. The lineup included Rub N Tug, Kimann Foxman (of Hercules and Love Affair fame, pictured here), Matthew Dear and Sweeney himself.

Melissa and Emily Elsen, two sisters from South Dakota, opened Four & Twenty Blackbirds, their pie and coffee shop in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, with the expectation that they would serve about 10 pies a day. A little over a year later, they are averaging more like 50 pies a day, with customers traveling from around New York City to sample their fresh, seasonal fillings, like blueberry rhubarb or strawberry balsamic. Though they are doing a brisk business, the sisters Elsen continue to make their crust from scratch, two pounds at a time. "We love the homespun, hands-on intensity of it," Emily says. There's something very sexy-cool about a glossy, nude lip. It says, "I'm hot, but I didn't try too hard," and it works for almost everyone. (And for almost every designer, judging by how many copped the bare-lip look for their resort and spring shows.) It's also super-low-maintenance. "You don't have to be concerned that your color will bleed," says Lisa Houghton, who did the makeup on the previous page. The only caveat: you need a well-prepped pucker. Houghton exfoliated our model's lips by dabbing on a bit of Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and rubbing it off with a tissue. Then she applied a mixture of Arden's Crystal Clear Lip Gloss and a touch of High Shine Lip Gloss in Tropicoral for the right pinkish tone.

BERNSTEIN--Barbara Soskin, died peacefully on October 9, 2011 in her home. A lifelong New Yorker, her life was characterized by fierce love for and loyalty to her family. In return, she enjoyed their adoration and love. The greatest source of pride and joy in her life was her nearly 40 year marriage and partnership with her late husband, Peter L. Bernstein, with whom she collaborated on his many books and essays. An avid reader, theatre-goer and lover of the arts, she remained vibrant, active and sharp until her final days. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Peter L. Bernstein, daughter Barbara Banks Brodsky, granddaughter Katherine Brodsky and sister Katherine Lee Meyers. She is survived by her grandson, three great-grandchildren, brother and nephews and nieces and their families. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday, October 16th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA, 01267.

McMAHON--Rev. Bernard. The College of New Rochelle Community marks with sorrow the passing of Rev. Bernard McMahon, Professor Emeritus of English, gifted and generous teacher and mentor who shared his enthusiasm for literature and theatre with thousands of students during his 29 years at the College. We mourn his loss and celebrate his extraordinary life and his gift of that life to the college and to our students. Judith Huntington, President Michael N. Ambler, Chair, Board of Trustees

SANTO DOMINGO--Julio Mario. The Board of Directors of Queen Sofia Spanish Institute joins Oscar de la Renta and Inmaculada de Habsburgo, as we mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Julio Mario Santo Domingo. Julio Mario and his family have contributed enormously through their advice and counsel to the programs and the spirit of the Institute. Their commitment to education and the arts has touched many people throughout the world. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Beatrice, to their sons, Alejandro and Andres.

FRIEDENBERG - Hon. Stanley (ret.) died on October 9, 2011 at the age of 92. Born in New York to Charles and Dorothy Friedenberg. Stanley was a graduate of New York University Law school and during WWII served as a counter intelligence officer. He was a partner in the CPA firm of Kurz and Kurz and the law firm of Kurz, Dick and Friedenberg. He practiced into his 90's. He served as Village Justice for the Village of Old Westbury for nine years. Stanley was a special man and those who knew him treasured his company and his wise counsel. Devoted husband of Hon. Marilyn (ret.) his partner of sixty years, beloved father of Ellen Cammer (Martin) and Robert Friedenberg (JoEllen). Grandfather of Jacob, Rosie, Julie, Sam and Harry. Survived by his sister Vivian Gluck and his brother Dr. Richard Friedenberg. A memorial service will be held at Guttermans in Woodbury on October 12, 2011 at 3pm. Remembrances may be made to Nassau County Bar Association's "We Care" Fund, www.nassaubar.org
RINGWALD--Christopher, D. September 26, 2011. Our brother, a kind and generous man. We will miss his larger then life presence. Marie, Carl, Anne, Tom

An obituary on Aug. 31 about Leonard Harris, a former arts and theater critic for WCBS-TV in New York, misstated a date in his journalism career. He began working for The Hartford Courant in 1958, not 1955. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail to The Times on Sunday.

Huntsman Jr. drew distinctions from his Republican rivals on Monday by calling for the United States to expand its global engagement and abandon a cold war military mindset. ''Simply advocating more ships, more troops and more weapons is not a viable path forward,'' Mr. Huntsman said. ''We need more agility, more intelligence and more economic engagement with the world.''

SANTO DOMINGO--Julio Mario. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Julio Mario Santo Domingo, husband of Beatrice Davila and father to Alejandro and Andres. The generosity of the Santo Domingo Family has made a significant impact on Mount Sinai Heart by funding programs to prevent heart disease both nationally and internationally. We are truly grateful for their support of our institution and extend our heartfelt condolences to Beatrice, Alejandro, Andres and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs Valentin Fuster, M.D., PhD, Director, Mount Sinai Heart The Mount Sinai Medical Center

WAHRMAN--Ralph, of Bowling Green, OH, died on September 30, 2011. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Judith (Stober); their three children, Francine, Eric (Emily), and Anna; a brother, Harvey (Stephanie); and five grandchildren. Born in NYC on October 22, 1939, he graduated from Stuyvesant High before earning his bachelor's at Queens College. He completed his master's and Ph.D. at Michigan State and was a professor of Sociology at BGSU for 34 years. His gentle soul will be remembered forever.

PAINFUL LOSS Tired of incessant leaks to the media about its poor performance, Paulson & Company, the hedge fund started by the billionaire John A. Paulson, below, decided a few weeks ago to amend its reporting policies to make it harder to obtain performance data. But the changes failed to obscure this painful fact: One of his largest funds is down 47 percent through September, a loss that would require returns of almost 100 percent to surmount, according to investors in the fund. AZAM AHMED

RISHIKOF--Trudith Noehren, known to all as Trudi, died on October 6, 2011, one day before her sixty-fifth birthday. Trudi was born in Rochester, NY to loving parents Dr. Theodore and Madeleine Noehren and raised in Buffalo. She attended high school at Buffalo Seminary and spent her childhood summers at Quaker Lake, PA, dominating on the tennis court and dazzling on the dance floor. Trudi went on to graduate from Mount Holyoke College with a B.A. in art history and earn an M.Ed. in English as a Second Language (ESL) from Boston University and an MBA from Arthur D. Little School of Management. Trudi's career was anchored by a love of languages, cultures, communication and public service. Early on she taught ESL, communications and international business practices to students across the globe, from Botswanan businessmen to Harvard MBA students to French senior executives. Trudi was also the senior editor for the French and German Journals on Politics and Society at Harvard's Center for European Studies. She moved on to a long career as a leader in non-profit communications and publications, including work at the National Alliance of Business, American University, the United Negro College Fund and Africare, from which she retired in 2009. Trudi also dedicated 18 years of service to the Alliance Francaise de Washington as an advocate and board member and twice served as its president. In June 2011, she was honored with a prestigious medal by the Alliance Francaise at the Belgian Embassy in recognition of her extraordinary dedication and efforts to advance French culture in Washington. In 1988, Trudi married her soul mate, Harvey Rishikof, with whom she enjoyed a life of love and laughter while traveling the globe, eating and cooking wonderful food, and appreciating theater, art, music and culture. They moved to Washington, DC in 1993 from Massachusetts, and Trudi loved living in the District. She delighted in her time with their daughters, Milena Nigam and Maja Orekar, sons-in-law, Kamal Nigam and Andy Orekar, three grandchildren, Oscar and Simon Nigam and Cecilia Orekar, her sister and brother-in-law, Nancy and George Melling, extended family and friends. Trudi was a devoted, beloved and beautiful wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, sister and friend. She will be missed for her intelligence, sense of humor, aesthetic sense and incredible toasts, but above all for the warmth she brought to all those around her. Her selflessness, kindness and positive energy for life touched all who knew her.

BOSTON -- With help from national fund-raising groups, Elizabeth Warren has already raised $3.15 million for her United States Senate campaign, catapulting ahead of her Democratic primary opponents. Ms. Warren, the Harvard Law professor who set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in Washington, entered the race last month but began raising money through an exploratory committee in August. According to her campaign, 96 percent of her donations came in amounts of $100 or less, and 11,000 Massachusetts residents contributed.

Wall Street banks often boast that they hire the best and the brightest. Now, scrambling to bolster profits, they have become full-time headhunters for some of their biggest hedge fund clients, a role that is rife with potential conflicts. Big banks have long provided extra benefits to hedge funds, including finding office space for firms and raising money for new portfolios. They have even acted like informal recruiters for their premier clients by passing along resumes or making introductions to industry professionals.

An article on Sunday about a judge's finding that supporters of Arizona State Senate President Russell Pearce recruited a candidate to siphon votes from his opponent in a recall election referred incorrectly to a 2009 New York race for Greene County Legislature, in which petitions were circulated on behalf of a candidate who had not given her consent. In that race, supporters, not opponents, of Linda H. Overbaugh mistakenly put the name of another woman, Linda L. Overbaugh, on the petitions, resulting in their disqualification.

Stephen Sondheim has been tapped to receive New York City's highest prize for achievement in the arts. The Handel Medallion will be awarded to Mr. Sondheim on Nov. 1 by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Alec Baldwin at a ceremony at Alice Tully Hall. Mikhail Baryshnikov; Alice Diamond, an arts advocate; the musician Jimmy Heath; the artist Maya Lin; and the Theater Development Fund, a nonprofit group that makes the theater more accessible to the public, will also be honored that evening for their contributions to the city's cultural life.

LOS ANGELES - Sony Pictures Entertainment, the studio that the produced high-speed and high-profile movies ''This Is It,'' with Michael Jackson, and ''The Social Network,'' about Mark Zuckerberg, could do it again with the Apple co-founder Steven P. Jobs. The studio late this week concluded a deal to buy film rights to the authorized biography ''Steve Jobs,'' from Walter Isaacson, according to a person who was briefed on the deal and spoke on the condition of anonymity because the studio had not authorized a public statement. A Sony spokesman declined to comment. Word that discussions were being completed was posted Friday on the Deadline.com Web site.

Andy Warhol has always had wide appeal, and now a new app for iPhones, iPod Touch, iPads and Androids will give art lovers in-depth archival materials, images, film and video clips spanning his entire career. -Put together by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh with Toura, a mobile app platform provider, the new Warhol app will allow users to view behind-the-scenes footage of the artist and his work including paintings like his ''Mao'' from 1972, ''The Last Supper,'' from 1986 and ''Self-Portrait,'' also from 1986. A visitor to the museum can stand in front of one of the artist's ''Mao,'' paintings and view a video of Warhol actually working on the canvas, get insights from a curator, view related works and read in-depth information. The app is designed to work both in the museum and on its own and will showcase the museum's extensive collection of Warhol's work.

Did you watch the markets on Monday? In the last 18 minutes of trading, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped more than 10 points with no news to account for the rally. If you were left scratching your head, you were not alone. Almost every day there is an article in the newspaper trying to explain the stock market's wild swings, or volatility, and often the explanation is inconclusive, involving everything from Europe's banking problems to new fears of recessions.

Charlton Street, a sleepy three-block lane in the southern end of the West Village, is not exactly the most famous roadway in New York. Its achievements, by this city's standards, are average stuff: a row of landmark 19th-century town houses; a former residence of George Washington. For the last three decades, however, Charlton has quietly enjoyed a more rarefied distinction: a spot on the city's official subway map, an honor granted to only a handful of streets. The map mostly includes big thoroughfares, but since 1979 Charlton has resided there, too, tucked between its more recognizable neighbors Houston and Spring.

The South African writer J. M. Coetzee wrote his Ph.D. dissertation on the early fiction of Samuel Beckett, receiving his degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969, the same year Beckett was awarded the Nobel Prize. Thirty-four years later, Mr. Coetzee himself received the Nobel Prize for literature. Now the Harry Ransom Center, the same library where Mr. Coetzee did his research on Beckett, has acquired Mr. Coetzee's papers. Among the more than 160 boxes and filing cabinets of material are family photographs, business correspondence, recordings of interviews, notebooks and early manuscripts for his novels and his autobiography. ''It is very satisfying to me to know that my papers will find a home at the Ransom Center, one of the world's great research collections,'' Mr. Coetzee, 71, said in a statement. Mr. Coetzee has published more than a dozen books, including ''Life & Times of Michael K'' and ''Disgrace;'' his novel ''Waiting for the Barbarians'' was adapted into an opera by composer Philip Glass.

Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, better known as Joe the Plumber from the 2008 presidential campaign, has filed papers to run for a House seat in northern Ohio. Mr. Wurzelbacher filed papers on Friday to run as a Republican in Ohio's Ninth Congressional District, a seat altered in redistricting that will pit two longtime Democratic lawmakers -- Dennis Kucinich and Marcia Kaptur -- against each other in the Democratic primary. For now, he is the lone Republican in the race.

Michael J. Drake, a planetary scientist, worked on many NASA space missions in his lifetime. But he remained devoted to one idea that he proposed several times in the last decade and that NASA officials rejected twice: to send a spacecraft to an asteroid, take rock samples from the surface and bring them home to study the origins of life. The expedition finally received NASA's approval on May 24 after a grueling two-year review process, during which Dr. Drake continued working despite receiving a diagnosis of liver cancer and undergoing liver transplant surgery.

McMAHON--Father Bernard, the former assistant Chaplin and associate professor of English at the College of New Rochelle died October 9, 2011. He was 88 years old. Father McMahon was born in Manhattan and graduated from Regis High School. Fr. McMahon earned his bachelor's degree from Fordham University and earned his master's degree in English from the University of Minnesota. Fr. McMahon earned his doctorate in English from St. John's University and was a Fulbright Fellow at Cambridge University. Fr. The prize-winning author Gary Giddins has written biographies of Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker and Bing Crosby. Now he will help other writers recreate the lives of their chosen subjects as the new acting executive director of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the CUNY Graduate Center. Among his many trophies Mr. Giddins can count a Guggenheim Fellowship, a National Book Critics Circle Award, a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Jazz Journalists Association, and a Grammy. The previous director and distinguished writer-in-residence, Brenda Wineapple, stepped down this month after a two-year stint. The center is also adding another prize-winning biographer, John Matteson, to the staff. Mr. Matteson, a professor of English, won a Pulitzer Prize for ''Eden's Outcasts: The Story of Louisa May Alcott and Her Father.'' His new book, ''The Lives of Margaret Fuller,'' is due out in January. He has been given the job of increasing the center's engagement with CUNY faculty and students.

I can't remember when I first became obsessed with the cafe's free bookcase, but sometime in the last year it was suddenly so, and I was regularly making pilgrimages there. I took books home to read, and brought others in to replace them. I noticed which ones were snapped up quickly and which sat for too long. I rooted for the galley of Emily St. John Mandel's smart novel "The Singer's Gun" to find a good home, but felt a little smug about another novel - which sucked up all the press in the universe when it came out, even though it was not its author's finest work, not by a long shot, and one might wonder if perhaps the author was even phoning it in - which no one touched for weeks.

For the Jewish festival of Sukkot, which starts Wednesday evening and which Jews celebrate by erecting (and eating in) a temporary booth called a sukkah, Congregation Beth Elohim, in Brooklyn, commissioned a community sukkah designed by B-an-G Studio, a new architecture firm. The firm's principals, Babak Bryan and Henry Grosman, won the people's choice award in last year's Sukkah City competition, held in Union Square. For Beth Elohim, Mr. Bryan and Mr. Grosman designed a sukkah made of 3,000 pieces of wood, which members of the congregation put together. To complete the design, temple members are painting 1,500 laser-cut cardboard leaves in colorful bursts of red, orange and yellow. The leaves will be affixed to the sukkah's frame of wood and bent-steel spines.

They met in 1929, in the photographer's shop where she worked, in Munich. He was 40, she was 17. He devoured her with his eyes, she said. Soon after, he had her family investigated, to check that her bloodlines were Aryan. He was Adolf Hitler, an amateur artist whose charisma as a reactionary orator had propelled him to the forefront of Germany's National Socialist party. She was Eva Braun, an attractive blonde from a middle-class family who, after one year at a school run by nuns, was back home living with her parents. We know how the story ends, though we can't help wondering why - was she completely lacking in intelligence, or morals, or both? In "Eva Braun: Life With Hitler," translated from the German by Damion Searls (Alfred A. Knopf), Heike B. Görtemaker takes on a task few biographers - I'm tempted to say no biographer in her right mind - would tackle, so scant and unreliable is the material.

So far, CBS has done pretty well for itself over the course of this still-young fall season. How well? According to Nielsen ratings data from Sept. 19 through Oct. 9, CBS has 20 of the top 30 shows among the broadcast networks in total viewership, making CBS the first network to accomplish such a feat. It was also the number one network in average viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Stalwarts "NCIS" and "NCIS: LA" certainly helped the network's cause on Tuesday, garnering 18.7 million viewers and 15.4 million respectively, although the two dramas hit season lows in the 18-to-49 demo. If it can hold steady, ABC will have a new entry in the top 30 with the new Tim Allen comedy "Last Man Standing." The two-episode series premiere was sampled by nearly 13 million total viewers.

I spent last night's Republican debate trying to imagine scenarios where Mitt Romney loses the G.O.P. nomination for president. Rick Perry gets bitten by a radioactive Lincoln-Douglas debate champion and develops a sudden facility for public argument? A long-lost codicil to the Constitution is discovered, in which the Founding Fathers endorse the 9-9-9 tax plan? Utah renames itself the Republic of Deseret and secedes from the Union, forcing Romney to make a tragic choice between his religion and his country? Or, perhaps most unlikely of all - Jon Huntsman is embraced by the Tea Party and pulls off a surprise upset in Iowa?

The saga of organized crime in America didn't end in 1921, and "Boardwalk Empire" won't conclude then, either. On Wednesday, HBO announced it had renewed "Boardwalk Empire," its period drama about mobsters, corrupt public officials and one particularly short-tempered federal agent in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, for a third season. The series, which is created by Terence Winter (a producer of "The Sopranos") and adapted from Nelson Johnson's book of the same title, was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards in its debut season, including nods for dramatic series and for the lead actor, Steve Buscemi, who plays the bootlegger and political powerbroker Nucky Thompson; among the eight Emmys it picked up was an award for the direction of its pilot episode, handled by Martin Scorsese, an up-and-comer we think you're going to be hearing a lot about. "Boardwalk Empire" is believed to be one of the costliest series that HBO has produced, with a reported budget of $18 million for its pilot episode alone.

When it comes to Acne, collaborations are few and far between - hence our excitement when we learned of its latest venture, a 28-piece collection designed with the London-based sculptor Daniel Silver. "It all stemmed from a shoot we did in Daniel's studio in London," says Acne's Jonny Johansson about the print-heavy kaleidoscopically colored tops, jackets and dresses. "I learned of his strong connection to Africa, so we embraced that," Johansson adds, referring to Silver's South African and Zimbabwean heritage. In the collection, vibrant tribal animal prints imposed on Acne's utterly cool wears create a whole new kind of contemporary, with leather biker jackets, crisp white oxford shirts patched with leopard pieces and loads of texture taking the lead. Until the fashion crowd follows.

Borough Market has long held sway as an essential stop on the London food tour. But in the wake of disagreement over increasing rents and trading loyalties, some of Borough's headlining purveyors left in search of new digs, setting up shop further east in and around the Victorian railway arches of Maltby, Stanworth and Druid Streets. A few years ago, Borough traders used these arches mainly for storage. But when the Monmouth Coffee Company started selling straight from its Maltby Street production site, word spread and a trickle of curious visitors began to arrive. Other vendors, encouraged, followed suit with their own stalls and the buzz got louder.

The 69-year-old British textile brand Ascher has been collaborating with artists since the 1950s, when the founder Zika Ascher had his friends - Henri Matisse, Andre Derian and Henry Moore among them - design scarves better suited for galleries than girls' closets. Now, Ascher's grandson Sam is reviving the tradition with two scarves by the Chinese artist Zao Wou-Ki, one of the company's original contributors. "When Zao Wou-Ki first worked with us he was 24 or 25, and just starting out," Sam says. "He was the last artist to do a collaboration with my grandfather and now he is the first to restart the project, so its come full circle." The scarves, painted with impulsive watercolors, come in limited editions of 150 and and are intended to be framed, though Ascher is used to witnessing women bend that rule. "At my grandfather's funeral they had one-of-a-kind Matisse scarves that auction for 20,000 pounds wrapped around their heads," he says. It'd be hard to resist doing the same with Zao's work. His reaction to the finished accessories? A simple, perfectly stated "C'est beau!"

When the Canadian police began connecting the dots in a series of child abductions and torture-murders in the summer of 1981, Clifford Olson, a career criminal with a history of sexual assaults, was placed on a list of potential suspects. It was a good hunch, as it turned out. But the police remain haunted by the fact that Mr. Olson, who died on Sept. 30 while serving a life sentence in Quebec, not only killed seven children before coming under suspicion; he also committed four more murders while supposedly under surveillance.

From 1983 to 1998, the San Francisco 49ers won at least 10 games each season. They made the playoffs 15 times in those 16 years, and again earned playoff berths in 2001 and 2002. But from 2003 to 2010, San Francisco missed the playoffs every season. Over that eight-year stretch, the team ranked 29th in winning percentage, topping only the Cleveland Browns, the Oakland Raiders and the Detroit Lions. Now at 4-1, the 49ers are fielding their best team since at least 2002 and seem destined to end their playoff drought by winning the otherwise anemic N.F.C. West. The seeds of this team were planted during a 366-day stretch in the middle of the last decade.

Mariusz Kwiecien, the Polish baritone who was cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Don Giovanni,'' which opens on Thursday night, underwent surgery for a herniated disk on Tuesday, his manager said. ''The doctors feel that Mariusz's prognosis is excellent,'' said the manager, William Guerri, of Columbia Artists Management. But it was unclear when he might return to the stage. ''It's a wait-and-see proposition,'' Mr. Guerri said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the opening scene of Monday's dress rehearsal, the manager said. He was taken by paramedics to a hospital, said the Met spokesman, Peter Clark. The Met tapped Peter Mattei, who was on hand for a production of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia,'' to replace Mr. Kwiecien for the opening of ''Don Giovanni.'' The opera has 16 more performances into March, although Mr. Kwiecien was scheduled to be in the cast only through Nov. 11.

Two new studies add to the growing body of evidence that taking extra doses of vitamins can do more harm than good. A study of vitamin E and selenium use among 35,000 men found that the vitamin users had a slightly higher risk of developing prostate cancer, according to a report published Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association. A separate study of 38,000 women in Iowa found a higher risk of dying during a 19-year period among older women who used multivitamins and other supplements compared with women who did not, according to a new report in The Archives of Internal Medicine.

MITCHELL--David. You were a willing and generous collabortor with George Balanchine during his lifetime. Filling a necessary role for his productions. Mr. Balanchine did not live to see your designs for "Liebeslieder Walzer" or the "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet" which you were both working on. Alas, your work for the proposed "Birds of America" and a two-act version of "Don Quixote" were never realized. One hopes that these collaborations will delight another world. Barbara Horgan The George Balanchine Trust

FICK-MELLECKER--Dorcas. Died October 9, after a brief illness. Educator, psychoanalyst, family counselor, born in 1919, Robertsville, PA. Former dean of women and Director, Counseling Center, Long Island University, Brooklyn; past president, National Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis. A woman of intelligence, composure, dry humor, and empathy. Predeceased by husband, John Mellecker, with whom she shared adventurous miles in their RV, and her sister, Doris. Survived by nephew, Mark Conrad, and wife, Robin, of Titusville, PA, stepdaughter, Judith Mellecker, and husband, Robert Parker, of West Cornwall, CT, stepson, John Mellecker, and wife, Janice, of Holden, MA, goddaughter, Susan Long, of South Pasadena, CA, and four stepgrandchildren. Special thanks to the staff of Geer Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Canaan, CT, for their care and appreciation of Dorcas. Service and Burial will be private.

You spend enough years in Las Vegas and eventually its kitschy charm leaves an indelible mark on you. Having made three movies about Danny Ocean and his Rat Pack-like team of casino-heist experts, as well as critically acclaimed films like ''Traffic,'' ''Erin Brockovich'' and ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' Steven Soderbergh has turned to the only subject that was left for him: a biographical movie about Liberace. On Tuesday HBO said that Mr. Soderbergh would direct a film called ''Behind the Candelabra'' for the cable channel, about the relationship between Liberace, the flamboyant pianist, and his live-in lover Scott Thorson, who later filed a palimony suit against him. Michael Douglas, the ''Wonder Boys'' and ''Wall Street'' star, will play Liberace in the film, and Matt Damon, who has worked with Mr. Soderbergh in the ''Ocean's Eleven'' series, ''The Informant!'' and ''Contagion,'' will play Mr. Thorson. The film is written by Richard LaGravenese (''Water for Elephants,'' ''The Fisher King''); its executive producer is Jerry Weintraub, and it will be produced by Gregory Jacobs.
FINCH--Edward Ridley, Jr. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave. and 50th St., Saturday, October 22, at 11am.

CHRISTAL--Janette Kunen, a 35 year resident of Riverdale, NY on October 10th at the age of 85. Beloved wife of 28 years to Jerome. Devoted mother of Dwight and Florence. Adoring sister of Anita and Sally. Cherished Baba of Jerome, Sara and Jack. The Dwight Auto Driving School in Manhattan, which was founded by Janette and her husband Jerome in 1965, was their passion and grandson Jack continues the legacy of the business, with dear family friend George Kwang. Janette was progressive and very politically aware, independent, never missed a day's work. She loved crossword puzzles, dancing and enjoyed a great sense of humor. Donations, may be made in Janette's memory to: Wiesenthal.com.

If Hungary ever finds itself the target of an undead invasion, its police force should now be well supplied to defend the nation. Law enforcement officers there have seized dozens of weapons, including pistols, rifles and machine guns, amid conflicting reports about whether they were to be used in the filming of ''World War Z,'' a zombie movie starring Brad Pitt, Matthew Fox and Mireille Enos, produced by Mr. Pitt's company, Plan B Entertainment. MSNBC.com reported that on Monday a Hungarian SWAT team raided a Budapest warehouse that was storing weapons to be used in the making of ''World War Z,'' seizing 85 functioning weapons that were mostly assault rifles.

SOLOMON--Beatrice of Detroit, New York, and Palm Beach died peacefully on October 10, 2011, at age 97. She was beloved wife to the late Sidney R. Solomon for 65 years; devoted mother of Susan and the late Bruce Waterfall and Steven and Lauri Solomon; grandmother of Spencer and Bonnie Solomon, Randy Solomon, Scott Straus and Sara Guyer, Jacquie and Brian Lederman, Kate and Michael Komorn, Jane Waterfall, and John Waterfall; great-grandmother of Hannah, Brandon, Ethan, Sadie, Zoe, Lyla, Solomon, and Zachary. One of ten children, she is survived by her brother Stanley Tannanbaum. As the founder and owner of Jane Baum Interiors, Beatrice continued to work into her 90s. She had grand style, impeccable taste, and a sharp mind. She was one of a kind and will be deeply missed by all who knew her. A private service will be held on Wednesday, October 12 .

ETTELBRICK--Paula. Quick-witted and vital, brave, enlightened and always ready to laugh, Paula will be missed by the community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation. Our hearts go out to her children Adam and Julia and all who loved Paula.

ETTELBRICK--Paula. We lost a loved family friend and travel companion, Ma to Adam and Julia. We will dearly miss her joyful, caring presence in our lives. Hal, Kitty, Mac, and Orian for the Baked Alaskans

An article on Oct. 4 about efforts to develop vaccines against drug addiction misstated the function of Suboxone and methadone, anti-opiates that are used to treat heroin addiction. While anti-opiates induce a mild high in many patients, they also block the effects of heroin; they are not used simply to replace the heroin high.

HOFFER--James J. Jr.,98, of West Columbia, SC and formerly of New York City, died Wednesday, October 5, 2011, of natural causes. He was born in Chicago, IL on November 23, 1912. Mr. Hoffer is survived by his sons, Meakin (Sam), Stuart (Sandy), and Jarvis (Carolyn); his daughters, Marilynn and Ellen (Dennis); and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Mr. Hoffer was a great lover of words, music, animals, food, martinis and family. Condolences may be sent c/o Stuart Hoffer, 318 1st, Mineola, NY 11501.

SEOUL, South Korea - On her first trip to South Korea, former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska sounded just like a politician on the campaign stump on Tuesday, lashing out at her pet enemy: ''crony capitalism.'' While Ms. Palin said last week that she was not running for president, she has been an active player in the campaign, touring early nominating states. And her words about crony capitalism echoed remarks of one Republican candidate she has had warm words for, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota.

Wall Street is bracing for major changes from a new rule that would overhaul how the banking industry conducts its trading. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation unanimously approved on Tuesday an initial version of the regulation, known as the Volcker Rule. Two other regulators followed suit, and the Securities and Exchange Commission is scheduled to vote on Wednesday.

Both Groupon and Zynga are slowly stumbling toward their initial public offerings. But don't feel sorry for either company - it's largely their own fault. The Groupon and Zynga offerings were to have been the event of the fall I.P.O. market. Both companies were expected to make their debuts to fat valuations and large stock price run-ups reminiscent of the Internet boom.

OFF THE MARKET The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group said on Tuesday that neither Hertz Global Holdings nor anyone else had submitted a buyout offer that met its conditions by a Monday deadline, and the company said it was no longer pursuing a sale. In August, Dollar Thrifty, the fourth-largest car rental company in the United States, asked bidders, including Hertz and the Avis Budget Group, to submit their ''best and final offers'' that would address the antitrust regulatory risk of a transaction.

BARTON--Nancy Barton, 60, attorney, died peacefully at Stamford Hospital surrounded by her loving family after a courageous battle with a long illness. A graduate of Tufts University ('72) and Boston University School of Law ('76), she was a partner at the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges before joining Stamford-based GE Capital where she became Senior Vice President and General Counsel. A highly regarded corporate attorney, she served as co-chair of the American Bar Association's Committee on Corporate Counsel. After retiring from GE Capital, she was active in the Greenwich CT community, serving as a member of the Greenwich Board of Estimate and Taxation (BET). A dedicated supporter of the Child Guidance Center of Southern Connecticut, she joined the board in 2001 and served as President from 2008-2011. In 2010 she ran for the 36th District Connecticut Senate seat which was held 80 years ago by her grandfather, H. Allen Barton. She was defeated by the Republican incumbent, L. Scott Franz. Born in Las Cruces, NM, she was the beloved daughter of David Knox Barton, Hanover, NH and Ruth (Breitenfeld) Barton, Burlington, MA. She is survived by seven siblings, 14 nieces and nephews and one great-niece. A Memorial Service will be held at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich on Saturday, October 15 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Child Guidance Center, 196 Greyrock Place, Stamford, CT 06901.

9 P.M. (Bravo) WORK OF ART: THE NEXT GREAT ARTIST Fourteen up-and-coming visual artists (including, above from left, Dusty, Tewz and Lola) assemble in New York City to compete for a solo show at the Brooklyn Museum and $100,000. Season 2 begins as the contestants are challenged to use ''bad'' works of art -- paintings of dogs playing checkers, a velvet cowboy and a sculptural golden peacock -- as their canvases. Simon de Pury, who acts as the participants' mentor, explains that to reach the top of the art world, they have to start at the bottom. China Chow is the show's host and a judge, along with Jerry Saltz, the senior art critic for New York magazine, and the gallery owner Bill Powers. They will determine the winner based on who can turn his or her abomination into something resembling a masterpiece. The photographer Mary Ellen Mark is the guest judge. 6:15 P.M. (TCM) MR. HULOT'S HOLIDAY (1954) Jacques Tati directed and stars in this amusing pantomime caper about a hapless vacationer at a middle-class beach resort in France who destroys everything in his wake. The comedy is part of a marathon of films with ''Mr.'' in their titles, starting at 6 a.m.

WILKINSON--Trudy. On October 10. Mother of George Klabin. Beloved aunt Edgar Gleich and Mirna Gleich. Visiting: Thursday 2pm-4pm at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

He is a familiar sight, the old man who solicits change from drivers stopped at a red light on East 35th Street in Midtown Manhattan every day near Third Avenue. -After all, he has been at it for 17 years now, seven days a week. MELVILLE--Bill. Bill Melville began his life on December 31, 1928 and left this world for a far better place on October 9, 2011. Born in New York City to the late William Randolph and Helen Cowan Melville. Bill spent 24 years with the Air Reduction Company before joining Kennecott Copper Corporation in 1972. Moving to Salt Lake City, Utah in 1978. Bill retired in 1992 as Vice President of Sales retiring in Park City, Utah. He chaired the planning committee to build St. Mary of the Assumption church in Park City, Utah. Bill was invested into the Equestrian Order of the Knights of the Holy Sepluchre of Jerusalem in 1998. Survived by his loving wife and best friend of 56 years Marilyn, his three children, William G. Melville Jr., David Melville (Yukie) and Allison Willingham (Preston) and nine grandchildren, Kathleen Petro (Steve), Will Melville III, Mary Melville, Alexandra Melville Hess, Brian Melville, Bennet Melville Hess, Noah Willingham, Andrew Melville, Erika Melville and great-grandson Samuel Melville, beloved brother-in-law Joseph Miller and the late Carol Miller and uncle to Richard Miller, Christine Warburton, Kathryn Jablkowski and Elizabeth Miller, their spouses, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Bill was graduated from Jamaica High School, New York University and Harvard PMD27. Bill was a founding member of Utahns for a Just Peace in the Holy Land. Bill's family, church and quest for peace in the Holy Land were the core of his existence. His leadership, optimism, and generosity will never be forgotten. Visitation and Rosary will be at Horton Mathie Funeral Home, 735 First Street, Greenport, NY 11944 on Friday, October 14, 2011 from 3 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. A funeral Mass will be said at St. Agnes Church, 523 Front Street, Greenport, NY 11944. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary of the Assumption in Park City, Utah at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Utahns for a Just Peace in the Holy Land, P. O. Box 680716, Park City, Utah 84068.

HUGGINS--John M.,of Houston, TX, died on October 5, 2011, after a long illness. He was 71. John spent his entire 40 year legal career with Baker Botts LLP, and was the partner-in-charge of the firm's New York office from 1994-2003. John is survived by his wife Kathleen, his daughters Joyce Marilyn Huggins Goettee of Houston, and Jennifer Huggins Modesett of Austin, TX, and five grandchildren. His many good friends and family will miss his unfailingly sound advice, his calm demeanor, and especially his sense of humor, which stayed with him to the end. GOLDENBERG--Doris Pearlman. We sadly mourn the passing of Doris Pearlman Goldenberg on Monday, October 10, 2011. Passion characterized her life and kept her alive through her remarkable three and a half year fight against pancreatic cancer. She was a great lover of the arts, both in life and profession. She worked as part of the team creating Bear Rocks Resort in western Pennsylvania, and as interior designer for Parke Interiors in Pittsburgh. Her beauty and dynamic presence brought her many admirers in Palm Beach, Boston and Pittsburgh. But it was her integrity, devotion and outspokenness that brought true respect and loyal friends. Above everything, she loved her family - her devoted husband Marvin Goldenberg, two daughters, Heidi Pearlman-Swartz and Jill Pearlman and her brother Lester Medvene. She was a loving wife to Robert C. Pearlman, who died in 1994. She is also survived by four grandchildren - Rachel, Lisa, Eve and Jason - and six of Marvin's grandchildren. Funeral Services and Interment will be held in Pittsburgh, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, PO Box 849168, Boston, MA 02284-9168. SULLIVAN--George W.,89, of Summit, NJ, died peacefully at home on Thursday, October 6, 2011. Mr. Sullivan was born in October 1921 in Baltimore, MD. He graduated in 1943 from Johns Hopkins University and earned his law degree in 1948 from the University of Maryland. He moved to New York in 1949 where he practiced law until his retirement in 2003. Mr. Sullivan specialized in the practice of Admiralty Law and was a founding partner of the firm Lilly, Sullivan, Purcell, Barkan & Junge. Mr. Sullivan was married in 1946 to Doris M. Carter. They lived in New York City until 1955 when they moved to Summit. They became members of the Fairmount Country Club in Chatham where Mr. Sullivan served as president from 1975-1976. Mr. Sullivan was predeceased by his wife in 1999. He is survived by his two sons, Michael and James Sullivan, his daughter, Mary Sue Fisher, and his five grandchildren, Mark and Emily Sullivan, Stephanie Reiches, and Duncan and Charlotte Fisher. Visiting hours are from 2-4pm and 7-9 pm, Friday, October 14 at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, N.J. Juvenile justice is a field where the cure aggravates the disease.  Take a kid of 15 or who shoplifts, gets into a fight, is caught with marijuana or is out at night spray-painting graffiti with a gang.  He's no hardened criminal - yet.  After a tour through the juvenile justice system, however, he may well be.  He'll be mixed in with real criminals, in an environment where violence is the only path to respect.  He'll understand what society expects of him:  more crime.   Perhaps most important, he'll have a criminal record - a major deterrent to getting a job.

Before music came in clouds it came in sleeves. For the iTunes generation this may come as a surprise, but to buy music in the pre-digital era required a trip to a store, where rows of labeled bins held vinyl discs in a variety of formats: long-playing albums, 45s, 12-inch singles. These records, as they were called, came in paper sleeves that were covered front and back with artwork.

No matter how many tickets and t-shirts a tour sells, the Arctic Monkeys still sleep on the bus.When you're a teenager, you drive in a van from Sheffield to small-town gigs across England, party every night, meet girls: everything moves fast and you like it. Your song about some girl who looks "good on the dance floor," which rhymes a reference to the Montagues and Capulets with "banging tunes and D.J. sets," leads to Internet fame, the fastest-selling debut in British history and, in 2006, instant, MySpace-amplified international stardom.

The director Pedro Almodóvar goes below the surface with his latest film, "The Skin I Live In." The movie, which played at the New York Film Festival and opens Friday, involves a plastic surgeon (Antonio Banderas) and a special woman in his life, Vera (Elena Anaya). Their relationship is complex, to say the least. In her review, Manohla Dargis describes the film as "an existential mystery, a melodramatic thriller, a medical horror film or just a polymorphous extravaganza." In this video, Mr. Almodóvar talks about how skin factors into the narrative. He also discusses reuniting, after 21 years, with the actor Antonio Banderas for the project.

The recent Good to Go show at the Bowery Poetry Club was a mishmash of performance types. The evening's host, the Canadian comedy star and television personality Sabrina Jalees, kept the audience entertained with hilarious in-character stand-up sketches, and Ben Lerman, an unassuming guy with a ukulele, sang an unexpectedly gripping story about being Ben Lerman - and playing the ukulele. The show was peppered with original choreography from the Good to Go Girls - Jessy Smith, Molly Merkler and Jillian Hollis (shown here) - a bubbly trio of classically trained dancers whose skits toyed with physical comedy and burlesque. All in all, it was a surprisingly professional and well-curated event from one of downtown's few remaining homes for the obscure.
