As a certain Shakespearean monarch has said, "An honest tale speeds best, being plainly told," and in the meantime a not-so-plain production of "Richard III" will make its way to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January as part of the 2012 winter-spring season. The Bridge Project's presentation of the play, starring Kevin Spacey as the "deformed, unfinsh'd" Duke of Gloucester and directed by Sam Mendes, will be presented at the Harvey Theater from Jan. 10 through March 4 with its official opening night scheduled for Jan. 18, the academy said Thursday. The production was first staged over the summer at the Old Vic Theater in London (where Ben Brantley wrote that Mr. Spacey "gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad man's corkscrew mind") and will be the final season of the Bridge Project, a three-year series of collaborations among the academy, the Old Vic and Neal Street, Mr. Mendes's company.

"California Design, 1930-1965: Living In A Modern Way," at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art through March 25, 2012, is a must-see. Even though the Golden State played a key role in shaping our material culture, the exhibition is, somewhat surprisingly, the first major museum survey of California design. Organized by Wendy Kaplan and Bobbye Tigerman of the museum's department of decorative arts and design, this sprawling show features more than 350 objects, including furniture, fashion, film, graphic and industrial design, ceramics, jewelry and architectural drawings and photography.

Songs simmer awhile inside her head before choosing their own moment to froth out fully formed. Or so has claimed Laura Marling, a 21-year-old British sensation who is perhaps the quintessential folk singer of her generation. It's a romantic idea, this ghostly pale lass with wispy blond hair transmuting somehow - perhaps via inspiration from the Muses - her own admittedly tangled emotions into divinely inspired songs to be sung by her divinely bestowed voice. And it's an idea bolstered by the fact that her first two albums earned her a Mercury Prize nomination each. Marling's newly released third effort, "A Creature I Don't Know," poetically titled like all her albums, trades some of her teenage urgency for a more muscular, acrobatic lyricism - the result being 10 tracks that feel evolved, or more grown-up even. In any case, it's clear that when Marling found this new sound, the Muses did not abandon her.

Brad DeLong and Atrios pile on to David Cameron for suggesting that his austerity program, which has rather notably failed to deliver growth, is responsible for Britain's low borrowing costs. The Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday gave an update on who will fill in for Mariusz Kwiecien in the title role of ''Don Giovanni.'' Mr. Kwiecien had to withdraw because of a back injury that led to surgery. Peter Mattei, who is replacing him on opening night on Thursday, will also step in for the performances of Oct. 17 and Oct. 22. Substitutes for Oct. 25 and Oct. 29 were not announced. Mr. Mattei had been engaged for ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia,'' which is now running at the Met. Rodion Pogossov will step in for Mr. Mattei as the barber, Figaro, on Friday and on Oct. 22, the Met said.

An article on Saturday about the release from a Florida prison of René González, one of five Cuban intelligence officers charged with spying against the United States in 1998, paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a South Florida Republican who is chairwoman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. She said Mr. González deserved a longer sentence because he ''has American blood on his hands.'' She did not say that he should be returned to Cuba.

An article in some editions on Saturday about a New York City official accused of taking bribes from developers in an affordable housing program described incorrectly the Department of Housing Preservation and Development's rules for awarding development projects and construction contracts. The rules say companies may be invited to bid through a process called ''requests for qualifications,'' in which developers submit their credentials, not through a process called ''requests for proposals,'' in which they submit proposals and cost estimates.

The State of the Art column on Wednesday, about the new Apple iPhone 4s, misstated the e-mail capabilities of the Siri virtual-assistant feature. While it can send e-mail by speech recognition and announce the number of pending e-mail messages, it cannot read the body of the e-mails.

MACDONALD--Peter. 84, passed away September 14, 2011 while vacationing in Scotland. Peter was born in Scotland in 1927, served in the Royal Navy during WWII, and attended Stowe College in Glasgow for career training as a printer. He married Mima Cambridge in 1950 and immigrated to the US. Peter was employed at the New York Times for 39 years and advanced in his field from a printer into management. He was a Freemason and Past Master at St Cecile Day Lodge #

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the Liberian presidential election misstated the credentials of the incumbent, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf. She has a master's degree in public administration from Harvard University; she is not a Harvard-trained lawyer.

Research in Motion said Wednesday that after three days it was still trying to restore service for BlackBerry customers spanning five continents. The service interruptions began on Monday and initially affected BlackBerry owners in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. By Tuesday, the problem migrated to Brazil, India, Chile and Argentina. On Wednesday, users in North America began complaining of the same disruptions. The failures have left subscribers in the affected regions without access to BlackBerry's instant messaging service, e-mail and the Web.

For the second year in a row books about war and foreign locales enchanted the judges of the National Book Awards, whose finalists were announced on Wednesday. The finalists for fiction are Andrew Krivak, for ''The Sojourn'' (Bellevue Literary Press), a novel set during World War I; Tea Obreht for ''The Tiger's Wife'' (Random House), a best-selling debut novel set in the war-torn Balkans; Julie Otsuka for ''The Buddha in the Attic'' (Knopf), about Japanese ''picture brides'' brought to the United States nearly a century ago; Edith Pearlman for ''Binocular Vision'' (Lookout Books), a story collection whose characters confront issues of identity and relocation; and Jesmyn Ward for ''Salvage the Bones'' (Bloomsbury USA), a story of a Mississippi Gulf family facing Hurricane Katrina.

The latest version of Mac OS X (10.7, also known as Lion) is the first version of the operating system sold as a download from Apple's Mac App Store. For those wondering how to revive an ailing Mac -- one that cannot start up on its own -- without a bootable disc and Apple's Disk Utility program, help is just a keyboard command away. Hold down the Command and R keys as the Mac boots up to see the Lion Recovery options on screen -- including the Disk Utility program. Other first-aid options include reinstalling the system, restoring it from a Time Machine backup or finding additional help online. Mac users who skipped the Mac App Store download and installed the system instead from the $69 USB drive need to reinstall Lion from the same USB drive.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a long-term lease for six floors in a long-vacant building at 470 Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn misidentified the new lease holder. It is the New York City Human Resources Administration, not the New York Housing Authority. (The housing authority earlier leased a smaller space in the building.)

7 P.M. (SNY) SNY SPOTLIGHT: HARRY CARSON Gary Apple sits down with Mr. Carson, a former New York Giants linebacker and the author of the recent memoir ''Captain for Life,'' to discuss his days on and off the field. Highlights include Mr. Carson's 13-year career with the Giants; meeting President Ronald Reagan at the White House, who doused him with a bucket of popcorn; his induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2006; and his relationships with his teammate Lawrence Taylor and Coach Bill Parcells. Mr. Carson, above in 1986, now the chief executive of a sports consulting firm and the executive director of the Fritz Pollard Alliance, which represents minority N.F.L. coaches and personnel, also talks about coping with depression and post-concussion syndrome. 8:15 A.M. (TCM) ÉTOILE SANS LUMIÈRE (1947) Translated as ''Star Without Light,'' Marcel Blistène's musical satire -- think ''Singin' in the Rain'' meets ''All About Eve'' -- stars Édith Piaf, in a rare screen appearance. She portrays Madeleine, a chambermaid plucked from obscurity and hired, with the understanding that she will receive no recognition, to sing and speak for a silent-movie star, Stella Dora (Mila Parély), worried about her foray into talking film. Yves Montand, Piaf's protégé, makes his debut as Madeleine's fiancé, an auto mechanic. The songs, composed by Marguerite Monnot, include ''It's Wonderful'' and ''Farewell My Heart.''

BERNSTEIN--Barbara Soskin, died peacefully on October 9, 2011 in her home. A lifelong New Yorker, her life was characterized by fierce love for and loyalty to her family. In return, she enjoyed their adoration and love. The greatest source of pride and joy in her life was her nearly 40 year marriage and partnership with her late husband, Peter L. Bernstein, with whom she collaborated on his many books and essays. An avid reader, theatre-goer and lover of the arts, she remained vibrant, active and sharp until her final days. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Peter L. Bernstein, daughter Barbara Banks Brodsky, granddaughter Katherine Brodsky and sister Katherine Lee Meyers. She is survived by her grandson, three great-grandchildren, brother and nephews and nieces and their families. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday, October 16th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA, 01267.

CAMEOS, as old-fashioned as thank-you notes, are attracting new attention this season. Shala Monroque, the oh-so-chic creative director of Garage magazine, wore her large oval cameo throughout the recent fashion shows: in New York, on a white V-neck top to punch up a denim skirt and navy blazer; in London, on a black trench (far left); in Paris, on a pale blue crew neck. The fashion writer Miroslava Duma was snapped in New York (left) wearing a statement cameo necklace (and ring) with a Victorian blouse and bright blue trousers. If you want to give your look a vintage vibe, and Mom doesn't have a cameo for the taking, Dolce & Gabbana has black-and-white resin and brass cameo cocktail earrings and rings ($355 at net-a-porter.com), which were shown on the runway with sharply tailored suits and sexy star-print dresses; and Bottega Veneta carries a selection of hand-carved lava stone cameos. Or visit a vintage store like the Family Jewels in Chelsea, where you'll find cameos from $50 to $200. Hand-carved lava stone and silver ring, $780 at Bottega Veneta and bottegaveneta.com.

CLEANING THE CLOSET Liz Claiborne, the women's apparel maker, announced on Wednesday the sale of its namesake brand and Monet to J. C. Penney and of Kensie to Bluestar Alliance. The transactions, along with the recent sale of its Dana Buchman brand to the Kohl's department store, will generate $328 million in cash proceeds, the company said. ''Over the past few years, we have worked diligently to turn this into a more efficient, dynamic, brand-centric, retail-based company, and today marks the culmination of these efforts,'' William L. McComb, above, the chief of Liz Claiborne, said in a statement. EVELYN M. RUSLI

GALVIN--Robert W.,longtime chief executive officer of Motorola, passed away on October 11 in Chicago at age 89. The son of Paul Galvin, the founder of Motorola, Bob was born in 1922 in Marshfield, Wisconsin. He attended Evanston Township High School in Evanston, Illinois, where he excelled in academics, student government, the debating society, and sports. He joined Motorola full-time in 1944, earning his way up through various positions. He was CEO from 1959 to 1986 and chairman until 1990. During that time, the company grew from $290 million to $10.8 billion in annual sales. Under his leadership and through the principles that his father imbued in the company, Motorola became a world leader in communications technology. Most notably, it led the creation of the global cellular telephone industry, installing the first prototype cell phone demonstration system in Washington, DC in 1971; unveiling the first portable cell phone prototype, the DynaTAC, in 1973; enabling the first commercial cell phone call, made on the DynaTAC by Ameritech, in 1983; and introducing MicroTAC, the first compact cell phone, in 1989. Throughout his career, Galvin made crucial investments in cellular and semiconductor R&D and advocated tirelessly for competitive telecom regulation and fair trade across the globe. He measured himself and his executive team by the company's treatment of its workforce, and he was proud that Motorola employees, who knew and referred to him simply as 'Bob', never felt the need to unionize in any of its global operations. Due largely to his commitment to continuous renewal and customer satisfaction, Motorola received the U.S. Commerce Department's Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award for Manufacturing in 1988. Galvin expanded Motorola's footprint into Europe, Southeast Asia, Israel, India, Japan, and Latin America, and made a major early push into China. He helped pioneer Technology Road-mapping and the Participative Management Program, founded Motorola University, and developed the Six Sigma Quality improvement system, which he disseminated across the globe. He was a trusted advisor to generations of US presidents and cabinet leaders, serving a term on the US Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board and acting as lead business liaison in numerous US Trade Representative, State Department, and Defense and Intelligence delegations. He also chaired the Commission to Reorganize US National Laboratories (known as 'the Galvin Commission'), the Commission on the Future for the National Science Foundation, and Sematech, the government initiative to revitalize US semiconductor competitiveness. In retirement, he joined his sons in founding investment management firm Harrison Street Capital, established two non-profit think tanks Perfect Power and the Galvin Transportation Initiativeand wrote several books, including The Genius of People: What the Scottish Enlightenment Taught Our Founding Fathers and The Idea of Ideas. Galvin was committed to the cause of education, notably through his support of the Illinois Institute of Technology. The recipient of several honorary doctoral degrees, he was elected to the American National Business Hall of Fame and awarded the National Medal of Technology, the Vannevar Bush Award, and the French Legion of Honor medal. He was a devoted husband of 67 years to Mary Barnes Galvin and an inspiring, loving father to his four childrenGail Galvin Ellis, Dawn Galvin Meiners, and Christopher and Michael Galvin. He is also survived by 13 grandchildren, 10 great-grandchildren (with one on the way), and eight valued in-laws. Bob delighted in passing time with family and friends, singing on the player piano and debating policy, books and ideas. He loved playing tennis, snow skiing, waterskiing, windsurfing and sculling. He discovered his highest passions pursuing the principles of leadership, innovation, creativity, integrity, and dignity and respect for all. His was an inspiring, principled, loving and accomplished American life. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him well. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts in memory of Bob be directed to the Robert W. Galvin Center for Electricity Innovation at Illinois Institute of Technology; send to Betsy Hughes at Illinois Institute of Technology, 10 W. 35th St., Ste. 1700, Chicago, IL 60616 (312-567-5045). A wake will be held at the Donnellan Family Funeral Home in Skokie, IL, on October 17 from 4-8pm; a funeral mass and tribute will be held at Faith, Hope and Charity Church in Winnetka, IL, on October 18 at 5pm, followed by a reception at the Indiana Hill Club at 6:15pm. For information, call (847)675-1990.

The shoes are Alexander Wang. I play around with metallic shoes when I wear prints. It breaks up the busy-ness, and pops.

KUSHNER--Jay, 81, beloved husband to Helaine, father to Jordan, Lance and Jonathan, father-in-law to Maya, and uncle and friend to many, passed peacefully on October 11, 2011. He served his country with honor and distinction, and was most proud of his service in the Honor Guard to President Eisenhower. He was a Columbia Law School graduate (J.D.), senior partner of Altieri, Kushner and Miuccio, and practiced law from 1955 to time of passing. He was the recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award from Subcontractors Association of NY. He proudly served as President of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck. Jay cared for so many and asked for so little. He was revered for his integrity selflessness, and diligence. His love will guide us for the rest of our days. Services at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, NY on Friday, October 14th at 11:30am.

Two-faced to the very end, Gustavo Fring, the seemingly mild-mannered proprietor of a fast-food chicken franchise but secretly an ice-cold drug kingpin (played by Giancarlo Esposito), got what was coming to him in a revenge scheme that was hatched, if not always smoothly executed, by his meth-cooking underlings Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), in the Season 4 finale of ''Breaking Bad.'' This very permanent checkmate -- or is it? -- was the culmination of a lengthy chess game plotted out by Vince Gilligan, the creator and show runner of ''Breaking Bad,'' and members of his writing team, who had been planning for a season-ending showdown between Walt and Gus on this AMC show. ''It was something my writers and I worked on pretty much the whole season, knowing that at the end of the year, one of them would have to go,'' Mr. Gilligan said in a phone interview. ''The town wasn't big enough for the both of them, as it were. In the best sense of the movie 'Highlander,' there could be only one.''

UNIQLO may be a great place for fashion on a dime, but have you ever stood in line at the dressing rooms? On Friday, the new 89,000-square-foot global flagship -- the largest Uniqlo in the world -- opens on Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street, and it has pulled out all the stops to keep traffic moving. There are 44 registers, 100 dressing rooms and up to 400 employees working at a given time, the sales clerks armed with hand-held devices to check available stock. There is a cellphone tower to improve the building's spotty service. Street-level shoppers will find 24 spinning mannequins and an endless staircase with changing LED lights -- oh, and a ceiling-high array of cashmere sweaters. Stop on the second floor for the final +J collection by Jil Sander. On the sprawling third floor, you'll find all the puffy jackets and familiar staples. Opening week will undoubtedly be mayhem, but promotional items, like Japanese-engineered straight-leg denim jeans for $9.90, are worth it. The takeover continues next Friday when the 34th Street store opens. Uniqlo, 666 Fifth Avenue, (877) 486-4756; uniqlo.com.

People confront you, and it's not once in a while, it's all the time. Each time is like a little paper cut, and you might think, 'Well, that's not a big deal.' But imagine a lifetime of that. It hurts. HEATHER GREENWOOD, the mother of three mixed-race children in Toms River, N.J. [A21]

The online music magazine that runs the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago -- the influential outdoor showcase for indie bands -- has plans to start a new festival in New York City next February, teaming up with one of the city's largest music promoters, the Bowery Presents. The festival will be called ''Pitchfork Presents: Forms'' and will include works by visual artists and game designers at galleries, museums and unconventional performance spaces around the city, along with four days of performances at clubs run by Bowery Presents, organizers said.

By almost any measure, Morgan Stanley is fine. Look at this impressive rundown of the bank's critical numbers and ratios from Paul Gulberg, an investment banking analyst with the independent research firm Portales Partners.

Wolf--Arlene, 91, died on October 10, 2011. She is survived by her four children: Peter, Wendy, Jack and Jill Wolf; her sister Rita Handman, four grandchildren and two great-grand-daughters. Arlene was devoted to friends and family, a highly respected social worker and hospital administrator at Queens Children's Psychiatric Center (the Arlene Wolf Day Treatment Center named in her honor), and an advocate for social justice.

Behind every top girls' school is ... a man? In a move sure to prompt discussion, Nightingale-Bamford, one of New York City's top private girls' schools, on Tuesday named Paul A. Burke, the current head of the upper school, to be its seventh leader.

The saga of organized crime in America didn't end in 1921, and ''Boardwalk Empire'' won't conclude then, either. On Wednesday, HBO announced it had renewed ''Boardwalk Empire,'' its period drama about mobsters, corrupt public officials and one particularly short-tempered federal agent in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, for a third season. The series, which is created by Terence Winter (a producer of ''The Sopranos'') and adapted from Nelson Johnson's book of the same title, was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards in its debut season, including nods for dramatic series and for the lead actor, Steve Buscemi, who plays the bootlegger and political powerbroker Nucky Thompson; among the eight Emmys it picked up was an award for the direction of its pilot episode, handled by Martin Scorsese, an up-and-comer we think you're going to be hearing a lot about. ''Boardwalk Empire'' is believed to be one of the costliest series that HBO has produced, with a reported budget of $18 million for its pilot episode alone. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PACKARD--Sandra. Douglas Elliman mourns the loss of their dear friend and loyal colleague Sandra Packard who fought a lengthy battle with courage and great fortitude. Sandy was a warm, caring person with a dry sense of humor who cared deeply about her family and friends. We shall remember with deep fondness our time together as our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Sandy's children and family.

An article on Saturday about the self-immolations by two Tibetan teenagers in China's remote southwest to protest the Chinese government's Tibet policies referred incorrectly to five monks who had immolated themselves since March. Only four of them -- not all five -- were from Kirti Monastery, a restive religious institution in the region that was at the heart of anti-China protests in 2008.

In his latest film, ''Footnote,'' the writer and director Joseph Cedar weaves a dramatic mystery around Hebrew philology and Talmudic scholarship in a story about a father and son who are rival professors at a university. The movie looks at how a scholar can devote his life to the study of a single topic. ''While I was writing this film I had a chance to speak to people about what is this act of philology,'' Mr. Cedar told Mekado Murphy for a video interview. ''When you're looking at a text, what are you doing?''

HUGGINS--John M.,of Houston, TX, died on October 5, 2011, after a long illness. He was 71. John spent his entire 40 year legal career with Baker Botts LLP, and was the partner-in-charge of the firm's New York office from 1994-2003. John is survived by his wife Kathleen, his daughters Joyce Marilyn Huggins Goettee of Houston, and Jennifer Huggins Modesett of Austin, TX, and five grandchildren. His many good friends and family will miss his unfailingly sound advice, his calm demeanor, and especially his sense of humor, which stayed with him to the end. The family requests that friends who wish to make memorial contributions direct them to the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, the Mayo Clinic, or to the charity of their choice.

It's been two and half years since Ryan Adams announced that he was taking a break from music because he had Ménière's disease, a debilitating inner-ear disorder that affects hearing and balance. He changed many things in his life. He left New York for Los Angeles, married the singer and actress Mandy Moore, stopped playing guitar and started writing fiction. He quit smoking. He gave up on modern medication and sought help from an acupuncturist, a nutritionist and a hypnotherapist for his balance problems and the incessant ringing in his ears.

BARTON--Nancy Barton, 60, attorney, died peacefully at Stamford Hospital surrounded by her loving family after a courageous battle with a long illness. A graduate of Tufts University ('72) and Boston University School of Law ('76), she was a partner at the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges before joining Stamford-based GE Capital where she became Senior Vice President and General Counsel. A highly regarded corporate attorney, she served as co-chair of the American Bar Association's Committee on Corporate Counsel. After retiring from GE Capital, she was active in the Greenwich CT community, serving as a member of the Greenwich Board of Estimate and Taxation (BET). A dedicated supporter of the Child Guidance Center of Southern Connecticut, she joined the board in 2001 and served as President from 2008-2011. In 2010 she ran for the 36th District Connecticut Senate seat which was held 80 years ago by her grandfather, H. Allen Barton. She was defeated by the Republican incumbent, L. Scott Franz. Born in Las Cruces, NM, she was the beloved daughter of David Knox Barton, Hanover, NH and Ruth (Breitenfeld) Barton, Burlington, MA. She is survived by seven siblings, 14 nieces and nephews and one great-niece. A Memorial Service will be held at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich on Saturday, October 15 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Child Guidance Center, 196 Greyrock Place, Stamford, CT 06901.

KIZILAY--Dogan, MD, on October 10, 2011. Beloved husband of Dr. Patricia Kizilay. Loving father of Lerzan and Lisa. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Schylar, David and Peyton. He was a well-respected and dedicated radiologist in the Metropolitan area. Friends may call on Friday, October 14, 3-5pm and 6-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

An article on Wednesday about some health insurers' opposition to New York State's decision to release justifications of their proposed increases misidentified, in some editions, the month in which insurers were notified of that decision. It was in late September, not on Oct. 3.

FICK-MELLECKER--Dorcas. Died October 9, after a brief illness. Educator, psychoanalyst, family counselor, born in 1919, Robertsville, PA. Former dean of women and Director, Counseling Center, Long Island University, Brooklyn; past president, National Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis. A woman of intelligence, composure, dry humor, and empathy. Predeceased by husband, John Mellecker, with whom she shared adventurous miles in their RV, and her sister, Doris. Survived by nephew, Mark Conrad, and wife, Robin, of Titusville, PA, stepdaughter, Judith Mellecker, and husband, Robert Parker, of West Cornwall, CT, stepson, John Mellecker, and wife, Janice, of Holden, MA, goddaughter, Susan Long, of South Pasadena, CA, and four stepgrandchildren. Special thanks to the staff of Geer Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Canaan, CT, for their care and appreciation of Dorcas. Service and Burial will be private.

GILMAN--Paul. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted, longtime member, Paul Gilman. We will miss his indomitable spirit, passionate devotion to family and friends and his courage under affliction. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wonderful wife, Maxine Borowitz, his children, Gail, David and Mark, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President
ROSENBERG--Beverley. Loving, warm grandma and great-grandma who will be missed. Love, Melly
An obituary on Tuesday about Robert Loughlin, an artist and dealer in 20th-century furnishings, misstated the given name of one of his three brothers, who survive him. He is Jerry, not Gary.

KUSHNER--Jay. The Subcontractors Trade Association mourns the loss of its long-time legal counsel, member and friend, Jay Kushner. Jay provided eight years of support as counsel and received the STA's Michael Mazzucca Lifetime Achievement Award in 2005. He will be missed greatly by those who knew and worked with him. The Officers, Board of Directors and Membership of the Subcontractors Trade Association
An article last Thursday about a former synagogue in which the painter Milton Resnick lived misspelled the middle name of an author whose works are in the home. He is Edgar Allan Poe, not Allen.

IGEL--Marguerite (Peggy). Born January 31, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY. Passed peacefully on October 11 in her 95th year. Devoted wife of the late Leon Igel, loving mother to George (Ronnie) and Tony (Lynn) Igel. Cherished grandmother to James, Brian (Stacy), Johanna, Leon (Cathy), and Bradley (Brittney). Her kindness and generosity knew no bounds when it came to her family and her friends. She will be missed. A funeral service will be held at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St, NYC, at 11:30am on Sunday, October 16.

Rebecca Skloot, the veterinary technician-turned-author whose nonfiction book ''The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks'' has not budged from the paperback best-seller list in 30 weeks, will write a new book focusing on the bonds between people and animals, her publisher said on Wednesday. The new book, currently untitled, will be released by Crown Publishers, part of Random House. ''It has been a long time since a first-time science writer dominated best-seller lists in the way that Rebecca Skloot has, and her success speaks to her rare ability to convey scientific and ethically nuanced subjects with real emotional power and clarity,'' her publisher, Molly Stern, said in a statement. ''The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,'' the story of a black woman whose cancer cells were used for research without her permission, has sold more than 1.25 million copies in the United States.

Last Friday, on a crystalline autumn afternoon, Michael A. Kimelman sat in the backyard of his home in Larchmont, N.Y. His toddler son was perched on his lap, sucking on a pacifier. His older boy played baseball with a friend, while his wife and daughter gawked at 10 egg-producing hens housed in their new chicken coop. It was a vision of suburban bliss, save for one grim fact: Mr. Kimelman is on his way to prison.

MITCHELL--David. You were a willing and generous collabortor with George Balanchine during his lifetime. Filling a necessary role for his productions. Mr. Balanchine did not live to see your designs for "Liebeslieder Walzer" or the "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet" which you were both working on. Alas, your work for the proposed "Birds of America" and a two-act version of "Don Quixote" were never realized. One hopes that these collaborations will delight another world. Barbara Horgan The George Balanchine Trust

ABRAMS--Lee S. The Fire Island Synagogue Board of Trustees mourns the passing of Lee S. Abrams, father of FIS Vice President Jill Abrams. Our deepest condolences to Jill, Joyce, Lori and the entire Abrams family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Fire Island Synagogue Shaul Magid, Rabbi Harry Trattner, Cantor

9:27 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES - For Comcast, it was a hard lesson in movie industry politics: on Wednesday its Universal Studios unit, under severe pressure from theater owners, suddenly tabled a plan to allow the early release on video-on-demand of its forthcoming film ''Tower Heist'' in two test markets.

5:51 p.m. | Updated Republicans are months away from their first presidential primaries and caucuses, but the Obama campaign already is giving Mitt Romney the nominee treatment -- trying to define him irrevocably as a shape-shifter, with an eye to the 2012 election. On the morning after Tuesday's debate in New Hampshire among eight Republican rivals, the Obama campaign's senior strategist, David Axelrod, held a conference call for reporters and singled out Mr. Romney. According to Mr. Axelrod, the latest evidence of the former Massachusetts governor's inconsistency was his repeated claims of being an advocate for the middle class, even as he opposed President Obama's proposed extension of a payroll tax cut for about 160 million households.

A Sunset Park man was arrested early Wednesday in a sexual attack on a young woman. The episode was the latest in a series of attacks that have alarmed Brooklyn communities from Park Slope to Bay Ridge since March. The police said the man, Adolfo Martinez, 26, groped an 18-year-old woman on Monday night on 36th Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues in Sunset Park, grabbing her buttocks before fleeing. He was charged with forcible touching and sexual abuse.

An article on Saturday about technology companies that produce software for use in classrooms misspelled the given name of a researcher whose study showed that the use of Cognitive Tutor, one such program, produced no benefits. He is Denis Newman, not Dennis.

STEPHENSON--Robert McCreary, 73, of Naples, FL and Williamsburg, VA passed away on October 10, 2011. Mr. Stephenson was born in Louisville, KY on May 15, 1938. He grew up in Ashland, KY and graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in Andover, MA in 1957. He received his B.S. in Physics from Yale University in 1961. After graduation, Mr. Stephenson went to work for the IBM Corporation, where he remained his entire career. Mr. Stephenson is survived by his wife of 46 years, Martha English LaFon Stephenson, his daughter, Elizabeth Hunt Stephenson Notman and her husband William Bennett Notman, Jr. of Richmond, VA, and his son, Robert McCreary Stephenson III of Chicago, IL. Also surviving are five grandchildren, Olivia English Notman, Hugh Preston Notman, Audrey Snow Notman, Madison McCreary Stephenson and Jack Rosser Stephenson, and two brothers, James G. Stephenson and wife Katy of Naples, FL and Dan T. Stephenson and wife Barbara of Hampton, VA. He was preceded in death by his parents, Rebecca Talbott Stephenson Jenks and Robert McCreary Stephenson, and his stepfather, Dan Hugh Jenks III. A funeral mass will be held at St. William Church, 750 Seagate Drive, Naples, FL, at 2pm on Friday, October 14, 2011. The family will receive guests at the Naples Yacht Club following the service. A private burial will take place in Williamsburg, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Moffitt Cancer Center Foundation Melanoma Research; 12902 Magnolia Drive, UTC-FOND, Tampa, FL, 33612. For condolences visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

Q. How can I change the program that opens when I click on a ''mailto'' link on my Windows XP computer? Although my default e-mail client is Thunderbird, whenever I click on such a link, Outlook automatically opens and I never use Outlook for any purpose.

POP-UPS Beetle Bailey and Popeye the Sailor have not been known to inspire fashion collections. Javits Convention Center. They will be sold at a pop-up booth during the event. Get to the pop-up before it closes next May to find the Joe's Wild collection, including velvet leopard-print pants, $189.

Like some people, I have misgivings about Twitter. Not a philosophical quarrel. It's more that I'm just not very good at tweeting. Mostly, I do it to promote the magazine's articles, but sometimes that feels too self-serving, and I impulsively tweet something that momentarily strikes me as witty and/or meaningful. That never goes well. A few weeks ago, I tweeted inanely about umbrellas. Why should anyone care? It haunts me still.

NO. 11 MICHIGAN AT NO. 23 MICHIGAN STATENoon Eastern, ESPNIf Michigan State wins today, it will have its first four-game winning streak against its in-state rival in almost 50 years. Michigan is trying to climb back to national prominence. The winner gets sole possession of first place in the Leaders Division of the Big 10. Michigan State comes in with the top defense in the nation, allowing 173.4 total yards a game and having held four of its five opponents to 7 points or fewer. Spartans linebacker Denicos Allen had two sacks against Ohio State last week. Michigan quarterback Denard Robinson, right, is electrifying but has nine interceptions. The Wolverines are outscoring opponents, 114-21, in the second half, and much of the credit goes to the defensive coordinator Greg Mattison.

If you have - or have ever had - a teenager in your home or, really, if you have ever known a teenager, then chances are there's been an occasion when you wondered, What was he thinking? (Or if he was thinking.) That's why you should check out National Geographic's October cover article by David Dobbs, "The New Science of the Teenage Brain." It's full of fascinating things. Even Shakespeare is enlisted to sum up the problem of teenagedom, through a character who says, of 10- to 23-year-olds, "There is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting." The bard neglects drinking, drug doing, driving while drinking or drug doing, cutting classes, indulging all sorts of cyber shenanigans, playing too much of that damn "Halo" video game - wait, I sound like the ancientry, don't I? - but you get the idea. Teenagers are crazy.*

This weekend is the kickoff for the first Cider Week in New York, which runs from Sunday through Oct. 23. There will be more than 85 restaurants throughout the city and Hudson Valley participating in the weeklong celebration of fermented apple juice. Consider the New Amsterdam Market, South Street (between Beekman Street and Peck Slip), which is holding a hard-cider revival on Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. with hard-cider tastings, Marlow and Sons is running a cider bar, and tapas-size snacks. Early admission is from noon to 1:30 p.m., with $45 tickets, which includes 10 tastings. General admission starts at 1:30 p.m., with five tastings for $20 and 10 for $35. Additional tastings are $5 each.

Pretty much every art fair seems to have its own drain - the place everyone eventually winds up at the end of the night. And the one that's emerged at Frieze this year is the lounge at the St. John Hotel, on Leicester Square in London's Chinatown, where the artist Sarah Lucas is in bed-sidency. Inside the Maritime bar, up one flight of blue, porthole-lined stairs from the hotel's entrance, several of Lucas's sculptures hang from the ceiling - plastic buckets and patio chairs from which stuffed pantyhose swing like Ernesto Neto-inspired breasts, conjuring the shapes of individuals who seem ready to party. Lucas herself evidently likes to stay up late; though she's spent most of the week in pajamas in Room 15, when I visited last night, around last call, she was holding court with a room packed with fair-weary revelers like Gavin Brown and MoMA P.S. 1's Peter Eleey.

CUMBERLAND, Md. -- One reason I began my cross-country bike trip in midsummer was so I could be on the road as the seasons changed. I had some chilly, autumnal weather before it was actually autumn, but the foliage has been slow to turn this year. It's only in the past week or so that the colors have taken on the burned yellows and burnished reds that we associate with fall, but I was lucky enough to be in the woods when it happened.

Just two weeks after undergoing surgery for a herniated desk, the baritone Mariusz Kwiecien will return to the stage in the title role of "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera on Oct. 25, the company said on Friday. Mr. Kwiecien, his surgeon and manager reported in a conference call that "his recovery is progressing at a remarkable pace," Peter Clark, the Met spokesman, wrote in an e-mail. He is expected to carry out all the stage action, with the possible exception of climbing down a ladder in the opening scene, Mr. Clark said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the dress rehearsal last week and had to withdraw from early performances in the run. Doctors operated on his back on Tuesday.

We asked the Paris-based artist and lighting director Thierry Dreyfus to make the T for our winter women's issue because he lights so many of the clothes that we see on the runways. (He did 25 shows last season alone.) But it wasn't just the halos at Comme des Garçons or the bulbed ceiling that lifted from the floor at Rag & Bone that made Dreyfus such an easy and desirable pick. All over the world - at hotels in Belgrade and Athens, in galleries in Singapore and Milan, and at design fairs in London and Miami - Dreyfus's installations alter and electrify their surroundings and our experiences of them. Here, he tells T how the projected image of our signature initial happened (by accident), and the kind of light he hopes women will wear this winter.

Poaching - cooking in simmering liquid - is a fairly forgiving way to cook fish, since it's not likely to dry out. (It also virtually eliminates the likelihood of anything sticking to the bottom of the pan, which is often in the back of your mind when you sauté.) I love using this method with striped bass, which has the added bonus of being a local fish, but you can use any firm white fillets or steaks. It's also a great way to cook mackerel or bluefish, other locals.

On the hardcover list, at No. 7, is The Definitive Irredeemable, a deluxe reprint of the first three volumes of the series. On the softcover list, at No. 2, is volume seven, which finds the ex-hero in exile at an alien asylum.

Before boarding a flight from Paris this week, Sophie Calle stuffed her suitcase with a selection of choice possessions that hold personal significance, including one red and one white wedding dress, a wig, a framed portrait of Freud, a sprawled stuffed cat and an issue of TeleStar with Peter Falk on the cover, circa 1986. Upon arrival in New York, the French artist, best known for her intensely autobiographical work, proceeded to unpack these items at the Lowell Hotel where she has taken over a suite for "Room," an installation commissioned by French Institute Alliance Française as part of Crossing the Line, an annual festival of contemporary art. Calle's inventory also includes a few specialty items she sourced locally, like a burnt mattress, a baby stroller and a Remington Noiseless Portable typewriter. The artist herself will also appear from time to time over the show's run.

With its 300 L.E.D. screens, 100 fitting rooms and three floors stocked top to bottom with basics beyond, the new 89,000-square-foot Uniqlo flagship on Fifth Avenue at 54th Street in Manhattan, which opens today, is just a tad overwhelming. And since vast shopping opportunities often end in devastating splurges, I arrived to test-shop the store with a plan: 10 items, $200 (which meant that the +J section on the second floor was off-limits). I started at the beginning, the bottom floor, where walls of cashmere V-neck sweaters bragged grand-opening price tags ($89.90 marked down to $49.90). So as not to throw the entirety of my allowance at four candy-colored sweaters, I jumped on the theme-park-style escalators and went straight up to the third floor. It was there that I did a double take: Japanese engineered denim for $9.90! With $190 left, I grabbed a men's flannel shirt ($29.90), a fluffy down vest ($49.90), a two-for-one Breton-striped lounge set ($24.90) and a pair of very holiday slippers ($12.90; if I don't wear them, someone in my family will come Christmastime); $72.50 to go and my winter shopping was almost done. Then I turned a corner and found myself staring into an aquarium-like tube filled with the company's famous (and effective!) Heattech pieces. I chose a knit cap ($12.90) and matching gloves ($12.90), a pack of socks ($9.90) and a camisole ($12.90). I had $23.90 left, enough for a pink umbrella ($12.90). Who knew Uniqlo sold umbrellas? Chic ones! Had I just $2 more - $11 was all that was left - I'd have bought two.

A few years ago, when I was anxiously trying to read every book ever written on markets and how they go awry, I came across a reviewer on Amazon with a particularly arresting take on the subject. His screen name was "the_carouser," and unlike most of the customers weighing in on these sorts of books, he did not seek to impress others with his catastrophic outlook. He presented himself as a U.K.-based trader who specialized in "fading market panics," and this seemed legitimate. I was so impressed by his point of view that I tried to contact him directly, thinking he might be useful as a source or possibly even a writer.

I met Patti Smith at the Electric Lady recording studios on West Eighth Street in Manhattan on a sunny August afternoon. Both the place and the date have a special significance in Smith's personal mythos and in the broader mythology of rock 'n' roll. The facility, which you enter through a nondescript storefront on a once famously scruffy block now given over to discount shoe stores and student-friendly eating places, was Jimi Hendrix's brainchild, and it stands as an enduring part of his legacy. A rack in the reception area is stocked with foldout LP sleeves of some of the legendary records that were cut here - Stevie Wonder's "Talking Book," AC/DC's "Back in Black," David Bowie's "Young Americans" - and the psychedelic murals that Hendrix commissioned line the subterranean hallways leading to Studio A. There, his portrait hangs in the lounge, a benevolent godhead gazing down at the latter-day strivings of his fellow musicians.

As a certain Shakespearean monarch has said, ''An honest tale speeds best, being plainly told,'' and in the meantime a not-so-plain production of ''Richard III'' will make its way to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January as part of the 2012 winter-spring season. The Bridge Project's presentation of the play, starring Kevin Spacey as the ''deformed, unfinsh'd'' Duke of Gloucester and directed by Sam Mendes, will be presented at the Harvey Theater from Jan. 10 through March 4 with its official opening night scheduled for Jan. 18, the academy said Thursday. The production was first staged over the summer at the Old Vic Theater in London (where Ben Brantley wrote that Mr. Spacey ''gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad man's corkscrew mind'') and will be the final season of the Bridge Project, a three-year series of collaborations among the academy, the Old Vic and Neal Street, Mr. Mendes's company. Other works planned for the academy's season include productions of ''Being Shakespeare,'' Jonathan Bate's one-man drama about the playwright, starring Simon Callow and directed by Tom Cairns; ''The Caretaker,'' by Harold Pinter, starring Jonathan Pryce and directed by Christopher Morahan, in a joint production of Liverpool Everyman and Playhouse and the Theater Royal Bath; John Ford's Jacobean drama '''Tis Pity She's a Whore,'' presented by the British theater company Cheek by Jowl and directed by Declan Donnellan; and Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' presented by the Russian company the Maly Drama Theater; as well as dance programs by Mark Morris Dance Company, Israel's Batsheva Dance Company and DanceAfrica 2012, and the United States premiere of ''Wear it like a crown'' by the Swedish contemporary circus troupe Cirkus Cirko r.

Five months after it introduced a cloud music service with limited capabilities, Google is in negotiations with the major record labels to expand that service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon. According to numerous music executives, Google is eager to open the store in the next several weeks. It would most likely be connected to Google's existing cloud service, Music Beta, which lets people back up their songs on remote servers and stream them to mobile phones and other devices, said these executives, who all spoke on condition of anonymity because the talks were private and continuing.

ICAHN'S STAKE The activist investor Carl C. Icahn, below, disclosed on Thursday that he had built up a 9.8 percent stake in Navistar International, a maker of trucks and buses. In a securities filing, Mr. Icahn said he had already held discussions with management, including about potentially adding members to the board. Mr. Icahn did not say anything more about his intentions. His playbook has ranged from pushing a company to explore a potential sale to making his own takeover bid, though with the hope that someone else will come in with a higher price. 12:20 p.m. | Updated In the midst of a deteriorating advertising climate, The New York Times plans to eliminate up to 20 newsroom positions and seek additional savings in the business units, the company said Thursday. The reductions, described by the New York Times Company as a rebalancing, were announced to employees on Thursday morning. The company will seek volunteers for buyouts in The Times newsroom, Jill Abramson, the paper's executive editor, said in a memo to the staff, adding that no newsroom employee would be laid off. She said there would be ''fewer than 20'' buyouts.

An obituary on Oct. 5 about Arthur C. Nielsen Jr., former chairman of the A. C. Nielsen Company, referred incorrectly to the company's current status. It is an independent company, now known as Nielsen Holdings N.V.; it is no longer owned by the Dutch publishing company VNU.

BERNSTEIN--Owen Ph.D. lived a life of commitment to social justice, equality, peace, fairness, animals and the environment. His beliefs were often expressed as being motivated by the Jewish principle of tikkun olum, the Jewish obligation to repair the world: leave it a better place than the world you were born into. In his almost 90 years, with Bebe Kirshenbaum Bernstein, his wife of 62 years, whom he cherished, they forged a life together based on tikkun olum. Owen Bernstein imparted his beliefs, through work, action and example, to his children and grandchildren, and touched the lives of so many with his sweetness and gentleness. For these qualities he was adored by his family: Wife Bebe Kirschenbaum Bernstein; Daughters Freya Bernstein and her husband Dr. Martin Broff, Karen Bernstein Belfer and her husband Andrew Belfer; and his four Grandchildren James, Gaby, Adam and Samantha. Owen was born in Brooklyn where he lived most of his life. He and his wife then moved to Bayside, Queens where he passed away on October 11, 2011. He was proud of his family vacation home in the Berkshires in Monterey, Massachusetts. Funeral will be on Sunday, October 16 at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

1:16 p.m. | Updated Though the idea of Alec Baldwin on public radio may immediately call to mind a vintage ''Saturday Night Live'' skit in which he, Ana Gasteyer and Molly Shannon bat around the name of a certain edible product, Mr. Baldwin, the ''30 Rock'' star and ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' de-motivational speaker, evidently sees the medium as being capable of so much more. On Thursday, WNYC announced that he would begin contributing a podcast, called ''Here's the Thing,'' for that station, which will allow Mr. Baldwin to ''pursue his passions and interests through conversations with a variety of newsmakers, artists, actors, writers and public figures who spark his fancy,'' according to a news release.

9:14 p.m. | Updated The fallen hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam received the longest prison sentence ever for insider trading on Thursday, capping an aggressive government campaign that has ensnared dozens and may help deter the illegal use of confidential information on Wall Street.

9:47 a.m. | Updated President Obama's campaign raised more than $42 million in the third quarter of the year, once again outpacing his Republican rivals despite the country's economic woes and his low poll numbers. In addition to the money raised directly for his campaign, Mr. Obama helped the Democratic National Committee raise $27.3 million for a combined total of nearly $70 million during July, August and September.

In a sign of the intensifying fight for control of the House of Representatives, allies of Congressional Republicans are forming a new Super PAC to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to defend the party's majority next year. The new group, the Congressional Leadership Fund, will be loosely affiliated with an existing group, the American Action Network, a nonprofit advocacy organization that spent about $26 million in 2010 to help Republicans win control of the House.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Of all those who might smile at Brazil's unfolding oil boom, Walter Link could rank near the top. A U.S. oilman here at a time of nationalist fervor, he was the former chief geologist for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey whom Brazil hired to find its oil reserves. The year was 1954. Petrobras, the newly created national oil company, put the blunt, Indiana-born Link to work creating Brazil's oil exploration sector. Six long years ensued before he issued his polemical ''Link Report,'' describing tepid results. For Brazil to meet its oil needs, he recommended going offshore or abroad.

David Hess, a songwriter for Elvis Presley, Pat Boone and others in the 1950s and 1960s who went on to play murderous movie villains, died last Friday in Tiburon, Calif. He was 75. The cause was a heart attack, his brother, Jeremy, said.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Pacific Standard Time art festival, at 130 museums and galleries in Southern California, misstated at one point the name of the Los Angeles museum where Jeffrey Deitch is the director. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it is the Museum of Contemporary Art, not the ''Los Angeles Modern.'' (There is no museum by that name.)

The Teatro Alla Scala in Milan has appointed Daniel Barenboim as its music director, the first person to hold the title since Riccardo Muti left amid acrimony six years ago. Mr. Barenboim, who is also music director of the Staatsoper in Berlin, will take up the post on Dec. 1, on a five-year contract. He has already spent two or three months a season in Milan over the last five years as a regular guest conductor. He will now spend about four months a season, also leading concerts with the theater's orchestra. His appointment comes at a time of increased touring, and relative stability on the theater's turbulent labor front.

LEVITAN--Max.,PhD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Max Levitan, PhD, a distinguished Professor of Anatomy, Genetics, and Genomic Science. Dr. Levitan joined Mount Sinai in 1968 and for more than four decades, carried out an extensive research agenda in population genetics. In 1999, he made the groundbreaking discovery that the chromosomes of Drosophila robusta had changed in response to global warming, a finding that was widely influential in the fields of evolution, genetics, anatomy, biology, meteorology, and environmental health. "My research was never intended to fuel the global warming debate," he said at the time, adding, "Now we have to see whether this is happening in other species and populations." Dr. Levitan published widely--his seminal Textbook of Human Genetics first appeared in 1971--but above all, he was a beloved teacher and a cherished mentor to generations of students. The Mount Sinai community extends its condolences to Dr. Levitan's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs at The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Jeffrey T. Laitman, PhD, President, Mount Sinai Alumni.

An article on Thursday about the lack of N.B.A. stars who have chosen to play overseas during the lockout misidentified the company that produced the new shoe line of the Knicks' Carmelo Anthony. Jordan Brand, a division of Nike, produced it -- not Nike itself.

10 P.M. (ABC) A HIDDEN AMERICA: CHILDREN OF THE PLAINS In this edition of ''20/20,'' Diane Sawyer, second from right above, travels to Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, where young members of the Oglala Lakota tribe -- among them a girl with dreams of participating in ''American Idol'' and a star middle-school quarterback -- are desperately trying to hold on amid alcoholism and poverty. Of the estimated 40,000 residents on Pine Ridge's 2.2 million acres, 47 percent live below the federal poverty level, and 65 to 80 percent of adults are thought to be unemployed. This episode is the latest installment in Ms. Sawyer's ongoing report about people living on the margins of society in the United States. 8:30 A.M. (HBO) SOMETHING THE LORD MADE (2004) In this adaptation of a true story, Alan Rickman plays Dr. Alfred Blalock, who pioneered open-heart surgery. Mos Def, at left below with Mr. Rickman, is Vivien Thomas, a janitor who became Dr. Blalock's technician. As a black man in the Depression-era South, he had his medical insights go largely uncredited. The movie ''is supposed to be an uplifting tear-jerker about two men who defy racism to accomplish miracles,'' Virginia Heffernan wrote in The New York Times. ''Fortunately, it's much, much better than that.''

Bertel Bruun, a co-author and designer of a hugely successful guidebook that helped make bird-watching more satisfying for millions of binocular-toting neophytes, died on Sept. 21 at his home in Remsenburg, on Long Island. He was 73. The cause was heart failure, his son Erik said.

An article on Tuesday about Susan Desmond-Hellmann, chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, misidentified the institution where she earned a medical degree. It is the University of Nevada, Reno -- not U.C.S.F., where she completed her clinical training.

The Philadelphia Orchestra management and musicians said on Thursday that they had approved a labor agreement that represents a major step toward bringing the orchestra out of bankruptcy court. The agreement would drastically cut salaries, reduce the size of the orchestra and pull the musicians out of the nationwide union pension plan, according to the musicians. Minimum salaries would drop from the current $124,800 to $106,000 and climb back to the original mark at the end of the agreement's four years, said John Koen, a cellist in the orchestra and a spokesman for the musicians. (Many players earn far more than the minimum.) A hiring freeze and retirements were expected to reduce the number of players from 105 to 95, a significant drop for an orchestra of Philadelphia's stature. ''Now I think we can say it's beginning to look toward the end of the process, getting out of bankruptcy,'' Mr. Koen said. The orchestra filed for protection under Chapter 11 in April.

BERNSTEIN--Barbara Soskin, died peacefully on October 9, 2011 in her home. A lifelong New Yorker, her life was characterized by fierce love for and loyalty to her family. In return, she enjoyed their adoration and love. The greatest source of pride and joy in her life was her nearly 40 year marriage and partnership with her late husband, Peter L. Bernstein, with whom she collaborated on his many books and essays. An avid reader, theatre-goer and lover of the arts, she remained vibrant, active and sharp until her final days. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Peter L. Bernstein, daughter Barbara Banks Brodsky, granddaughter Katherine Brodsky and sister Katherine Lee Meyers. She is survived by her grandson, three great-grandchildren, brother and nephews and nieces and their families. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday, October 16th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA, 01267.

MCLEOD--Laura Margaret. The Korein family mourns the death on October 12 of a former auditor after a long illness. Born November 20, 1920 in Hamilton Township, Ontario, Canada, Ms. McLeod attended the University of Toronto graduating with a degree in sociology. She later became a Chartered Accountant in Canada. She moved to New York where she was one of the first women CPAs in the country. She was associated with the hotel accounting firm then known as Harris, Kerr, Forster and first met the family when she became the resident auditor of the Croydon Hotel. She later worked for over 20 years at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. After retiring from the Museum, she again worked for the family as a resident auditor at the Hotel Delmonico. Ms. McLeod was a gifted musician and a founder of the Clan MacLeod Society. She is survived by two sisters and a nephew. With thanks to her caregiver Clevet Veronica Sam.

An article on Oct. 7 about a government panel's recommendation that healthy men should no longer receive a P.S.A. blood test to screen for prostate cancer described incorrectly the work of Richard J. Ablin, a researcher who has called widespread use of the test a ''public health disaster.'' Dr. Ablin discovered a prostate-specific antigen; he did not develop the P.S.A. test. The error was repeated on Wednesday in an article about the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday, in which Newt Gingrich condemned the recommendation, saying it would cause deaths.

KLEINMAN--Charles S.,MD. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New-York Presbyterian (NYP) Center for Prenatal Pediatrics mourn the passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague. Internationally known for his work in fetal and pediatric cardiology, Charlie was an integral part of our prenatal diagnostics program at the Center for Prenatal Pediatrics. He held appointments as Professor of Clinical Pediatrics in Obstetrics and Gynecology at Columbia and Chief of Perinatal Cardiology at NYP. His extraordinary clinical acumen and unique diagnostic skills were so important for our patients and for our program. Charlie met the challenges of his own illness with enormous courage and humor, never losing his devotion to his work, his patients, his colleagues and his family. We will miss him dearly; he was an inspiring teacher, mentor and friend--in the words of our colleague, Dr. Larry Platt, We lost a giant and a mensch. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his beloved wife, Jessie, their two sons, daughters-in-law and grandchildren that he adored. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, Director Obstetric and Gynelogical Services, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Sloane Hospital for Women; Chair Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

In one of the more recent sequels to ''Pride and Prejudice,'' Elizabeth Bennet does battle with zombies, so it's no great stretch to imagine her as a Regency-era crime sleuth. But the author who has done so is, of all people, P. D. James, the 91-year-old monarch of British crime fiction, better known for her novels about Adam Dalgleish, the brainy Scotland Yard detective who writes poetry on the side. Faber & Faber, the British publisher, announced that Ms. James's newest book, which comes out in Britain on Nov. 3 and will be issued in the United States by Knopf early in December, is called ''Death Comes to Pemberley'' and involves Elizabeth in a murder investigation. According to the publisher the book begins in 1803, when Elizabeth and Darcy have been married for six years and are raising two sons at Pemberley, Darcy's estate, but their tranquillity is disturbed when Elizabeth's sister Lydia rolls up in a carriage late one night, screaming that her husband has been killed. This will come as no surprise to fans of the original novel: Lydia's husband is the caddish Wickham, who elopes with her in that book, causing the family no end of shame and distress.

A brief note while waiting for a family member to finish with the doctor: From comments I see that some readers believe that Cain's second "9" is a profits tax, which I've argued in the past probably falls on capital owners. But it isn't: it's a tax on all business income, defined as sales minus purchased inputs and dividends -- but with no deduction for wages. So the new element here is, in effect, a 9 percent tax on wages paid.
