Hundreds of anti-Qaddafi militiamen fired heavy weapons on residential streets in a rare outburst of violence that may have been provoked by rumors of demonstrations by loyalists.
Radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant may have spread to places where Japan’s government hasn’t even thought to look.
Statistics on imports help show which countries in Europe are doing well, which are showing signs of stress but still growing and which have major problems.
The indictment of Robert Finn is the first of a Roman Catholic bishop in the 25 years since the scandal over sexual abuse by priests first became public in the United States.
The country’s largest employer of certified financial planners is accused of putting its own employees’ 401(k) money into underperforming funds.
Financial advisers point out that the rate of return on permanent life insurance is 3 to 5 percent and the money passes to beneficiaries free of income tax.
Michael Grandage, in his Metropolitan Opera debut, gave a tastefully safe staging of “Don Giovanni” after losing his lead, the Polish baritone Mariusz Kwiecien, to injury.
Michael Woodford lost his job after six months because his management style did not mesh with the Japanese camera maker’s executive team.
The abrupt reversal of plans to empty Zuccotti Park averted a clash at the southern tip of Manhattan.
The neighborhood in East Jerusalem is on the southern flank of the area projected as the capital of a future state of Palestine.
The most important document for determining financial aid for college is a form that recognizes only heterosexual marriage.
Pamela Paul reviews new children’s books about dreams and the night.
Pamela Paul reviews new children’s books about Halloween and spooky creatures.
Finance ministers meeting in Paris faced new hurdles after ratings agencies issued warnings about European banks.
Russell Banks based his new novel, “Lost Memory of Skin,” on a group of homeless sex offenders who sought refuge under a highway in Florida.
At a Colorado offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street movement, the police met little resistance, though two dozen arrests were made.
A coroner has agreed to open an inquest into the radiation poisoning of former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, potentially bringing the case before a British legal forum for the first time.
Liam Fox resigned on Friday after days of searing headlines about revelations that he had given a close friend extensive access to his official activities.
An Israeli soldier held captive by militants in Gaza for five years is likely to return home as early as Tuesday, news agencies and Israeli media reported on Friday.
Even with a primary vote on Sunday, only a few voters are passionate about their choices.
In a culture obsessed with dogs, dog whisperers and domestic pets of all kinds, religious groups are paying attention, too, with many megachurches sponsoring groups for pet lovers.
The “Moneyball” guru Billy Beane has found hard times, but the concept lives on. Shrewd management has helped the Brewers, Cardinals, Rangers and Tigers thrive.
Stocks rose after a report showed sales jumped in September, beating expectations.
Businesses are escaping a stagnant economy at home and raising concern in a country with big sovereign debt and a high jobless rate.
The Musée d'Orsay in Paris will open Thursday with a brand new look after spending €20 million to remodel its galleries of 19th-century masterpieces.
The Australia and New Zealand coaches have been eager to downplay their rivalry in the buildup to the match, but it is clear that defeat to the other would be an unpalatable experience.
The prime minister’s center-right coalition failed to secure a solid majority, making it increasingly difficult for him to pass legislation.
While Greece is grappling with its past and is increasingly uncertain about its future, the present is a wonderful moment of inspiration for the country’s artists.
Boaters are putting a twist on tailgating at University of Washington football games.
Boaters are putting a twist on tailgating at University of Washington football games.

A Connecticut mother and businesswoman has won the right to name her company after her daughter, Willa, despite the objections of the nation's largest consumer products company. Christy Prunier spent the last three years creating a line of skin care products aimed at preteenage girls like Willa, who is 11. But after obtaining trademark approval from the government early this year, she received a cease and desist letter from Procter & Gamble, which owns the hair care brand Wella.

8 P.M. (HBO) GULLIVER'S TRAVELS (2010) In Rob Letterman's modern-day adaptation of the novel by Jonathan Swift, Jack Black, above, portrays Lemuel Gulliver, a mail-room clerk on the adventure of a lifetime after being shipwrecked on Lilliput, an island populated by tiny people, next to whom the rotund Mr. Black looks like a giant. Billy Connolly is the king of the fantasy land, Emily Blunt his princess daughter, and Amanda Peet the gleaming woman Lemuel pines for. ''For myself, I was but seldom inspired to peals of true laughter, though I did relish that part when Mr. Black, confronting a fire raging in the Palace of Lilliput, douses the blaze through heroic use of such means as Nature has provided him,'' A. O. Scott, channeling Swift, wrote in The New York Times. ''This was, indeed, the only moment at which it seemed that the temperament of the Picture corresponded, in some degree, to my own.'' He added: ''I can further suppose that a Child of average Wit or even moderate Dullness -- a boy of Nine, let us say, who can be coaxed away from the Wii of a Christmas afternoon -- might pass a pleasant interval chuckling at the absurd incongruities that arise when something very large is placed beside something very small.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY In the first segment of a two-part series on containing Medicare costs, Betty Rollin interviews doctors and ethicists about the problem of aggressive and expensive end-of-life medical care and its effects on patients and their families. Kim Lawton interviews Emilio Estevez, who directed ''The Way,'' a film about the Christian pilgrimage route in Spain known as El Camino de Santiago, and his father, Martin Sheen, who stars in it.

PERELMAN--Bernard M. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved husband, father, and grandfather. He passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his family on October 14, 2011 at age 95. He had a long career as an accomplished accountant, and was a valued friend and trusted advisor. Bernie was an extraordinary man who loved and cherished his family. His presence lives on within his four children, twelve grandchildren, and wife, Marilyn, of 53 years.

Theirs is a comic book romance. Raina Telgemeier and Dave Roman, a dynamic duo in the colorful world of cartoon illustration, met at the School of Visual Arts a dozen years ago and fell in love faster than a speeding bullet.

Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro sustained a concussion in practice Wednesday and is out indefinitely, the team said. DiPietro was hurt at Nassau Coliseum when a hard slap shot by his teammate Brian Rolston struck his helmet, near his temple. DiPietro, 30, taken first over all by the Islanders in the 2000 N.H.L. draft out of Boston University, has had repeated injury setbacks. He has played a combined 39 games in the last three seasons. Jeff Skinner scored a power-play goal with 1 minute 24 seconds left, and Cam Ward made 39 saves in leading visiting Carolina to a 4-3 win over Buffalo. The Hurricanes have won two straight since getting off to a 0-2-1 start. At one point, Ward stopped 30 consecutive shots. (AP)

At Bistro Chat Noir, an upscale French restaurant on Manhattan's Upper East Side frequented by celebrities like Woody Allen, Madonna and Natalie Portman, the phone and Internet service is often out, so credit cards cannot be processed. When that happens, Suzanne Latapie, a manager and one of the owners, asks customers to fill out forms with their credit card information, so she can process payments later, sometimes using a neighbor's Internet line. ''Obviously, this is not the way we want to do business,'' said Ms. Latapie, who has started giving clients her personal cellphone number to avoid missing reservations when the restaurant's phone is not performing properly. ''When people can't get through, I tell them it's Verizon. And if they live in this area, they know - because they have the same problem.''

U.S. Soccer announced Friday that the national team would play a friendly against France on Nov. 11 at the Stade de France outside Paris. (Just another reason to follow @JackBell on Twitter; he teased this Thursday.)

An article on Page 10 this weekend about the new Wall Street movie ''Margin Call'' reverses the names of the two characters in the 1987 movie ''Wall Street'' who slugged each other in a scene in Central Park. It was Michael Douglas's character, Gordon Gekko, who punched Bud Fox, played by Charlie Sheen.

When moviegoers were first introduced to ''Star Wars'' in 1977 they were promised a story that took place a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away. At the New York Comic Con on Friday, Dark Horse is revealing a new comic book series, ''Dawn of the Jedi,'' that explores the Jedi myth long before Luke Skywalker took his first step. ''At the point that our story begins, what will become the Jedi order has been around for about 10,000 years,'' said Randy Stradley, the senior editor of the ''Stars Wars'' comics that Dark Horse publishes. ''All these guys have been studying the force, and trying to learn how to deal with it and maintain its balance.'' The Jedi, who have limited space travel abilities, are discovered by some villains with more technological muscle and ''mayhem ensues,'' Mr. Stradley said. The series, which will be published monthly, but with small breaks between story arcs, will be written by John Ostrander and Jan Duursema, who is also the illustrator.

GROSS--Shirley, 103, died peacefully on October 12, 2011. Her life was characterized by her love and compassion for her family. She was preceded in death by husband Paul I. Gross after marriage for 65 years. Survived by her loving daughters Gaye Moelis and Linda G. Singer; six grandchildren Ronald, Kenneth, Juliette, Cindy, Stuart and Lauren; and sixteen great-grandchildren. Private burial. Family receiving Sunday October 16, 2011 from 1:30 to 5:30pm at 9 Pilgrim Rd., Rye, New York.

Even before the fires were extinguished at ground zero, everyone agreed that St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 155 Cedar Street - crushed by the collapse of 2 World Trade Center - would rise again. For 10 years, however, no one has agreed exactly where it would rise, what sort of engineering would be needed to build it, how large it should be and who should pay for it. Discussions turned into negotiations. Negotiations turned into litigation. And the tiny congregation of St. Nicholas remained homeless. (The members now worship at SS. Constantine and Helen Cathedral in Brooklyn.)
International ANTI-QADDAFI MILITIA

An editorial on Oct. 8 about jobs incorrectly cited an analysis by the Economic Policy Institute. The report said 278,000 teachers and other public school employees had lost their jobs since September 2008 -- not December 2007.

A week before the News Corporation's annual shareholder meeting, the company is facing a growing chorus of investors rallying against company leadership after a phone-hacking scandal in Britain and a controversy this week over an unorthodox circulation arrangement in Europe. On Friday, California's two huge public sector pension funds said they would withhold support from some or all of the News Corporation's board nominees, including the chairman and chief executive,Rupert Murdoch, and push for the election of an independent chairman.

Just two weeks after undergoing surgery for a herniated desk, the baritone Mariusz Kwiecien will return to the stage in the title role of ''Don Giovanni'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Oct. 25, the company said on Friday. Mr. Kwiecien, his surgeon and manager reported in a conference call that ''his recovery is progressing at a remarkable pace,'' Peter Clark, the Met spokesman, wrote in an e-mail. He is expected to carry out all the stage action, with the possible exception of climbing down a ladder in the opening scene, Mr. Clark said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the dress rehearsal last week and had to withdraw from early performances in the run. Doctors operated on his back on Tuesday. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
We will keep the power until we have a president. MAJ. GEN.MAHMOUD HEGAZYof Egypt, speaking of the military. [A1]

A new biography of Vincent van Gogh and a ''60 Minutes'' report on it scheduled for Sunday night call into question the long-accepted notion -- central to the myth of the troubled artist -- that he committed suicide. In the book, ''Van Gogh: The Life,'' due out next week, the Pulitzer Prize-winning writers Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith present evidence that raises doubts about the source of the gunshot wound van Gogh sustained in or near the town of Auvers-sur-Oise, France, in July 1890.

Score one for the screenwriter. A United States District Court judge in Los Angeles has dismissed a lawsuit by an Iraq war veteran, Sgt. Jeffrey Sarver, that claimed the film ''The Hurt Locker'' was based on him without his permission and that he had suffered ridicule because of it and was denied employment. Sergeant Sarver sued Mark Boal, who wrote ''The Hurt Locker,'' a few days before the film won the Oscar for best picture at the 2010 Academy Awards and Mr. Boal took home a trophy for best original screenplay. Mr. Boal was embedded with Sergeant Sarver's unit in 2004 as part of an assignment for Playboy and wrote about him and other bomb disposal experts in the resulting article.

ESTERMAN--Helen, of Boynton Beach, FL and formerly of Englewood Cliffs, NJ on October 13. Devoted wife of the late Philip Esterman. Survived by her children Pamela (Joel Burris) and Bradley (Tracy) and five cherished grandchildren: Justin, Paige, Samuel, Philip and Lindsay.
COHEN--Reina. She was really special, an artist who made living an art until her last day. It's hard to imagine life without Reina. Carol and Jerry Halpern

Two men at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on Thursday could hardly have looked more different. One, Edward T. Hall III, 25, was barefoot and dressed in loud, multicolored tights. He wore a beaded American Indian necklace and New Age jewelry, with a baseball cap pulled sideways over his long hair.

SIRLIN--Alfred. Beloved husband of Sylvia 62 not enough years. Devoted father of Kenneth, Richard (Arlene) Jill Turner (Al), Cindy Saval (Jeff). Dear brother of the late Max Sirlin and Roslyn Davidson. Adored grandfather of Samantha (Mike), Brittany, Stacey, Carly, Lauren, Nicole, Brian, Kevin, Ryan, Max, Cara and Brandon. Services, Sunday 2pm at "Gutterman's" 8000 Jericho Tpk. Woodbury, L.I.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences on Thursday announced the 63 films that will be in the running in February for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, so the speculation season is now officially under way. New Zealand, which submitted ''The Orator,'' by the Maori director Tusi Tamasese, will be competing in the category for the first time, but the list of nominees, down by two countries compared with last year, includes many familiar names. China, for example, submitted ''The Flowers of War,'' starring Christian Bale and directed by Zhang Yimou, who has previously been nominated three times, without winning. Wim Wenders of Germany, Agnieszka Holland of Poland, Aki Kaurismaki of Finland and Nikita Mikhalkov of Russia are among the other prominent directors whose films were nominated by their home countries.
BRIN--Martin. 1911-2011. Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday, October 16 at 2pm.

Bank of America's new monthly debit card fee has been roundly criticized in recent weeks. But a new change in corporate policy change is likely to receive a much warmer reception. Starting next year, the nation's largest bank will begin reimbursing its employees with same-sex partners for the extra taxes they pay for health insurance - something that their married heterosexual co-workers don't have to worry about because the federal government recognizes them as an economic unit.

IGEL--Marguerite (Peggy). Born January 31, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY. Passed peacefully on October 11 in her 95th year. Devoted wife of the late Leon Igel, loving mother to George (Ronnie) and Tony (Lynn) Igel. Cherished grandmother to James, Brian (Stacy), Johanna, Leon (Cathy), and Bradley (Brittney). Her kindness and generosity knew no bounds when it came to her family and her friends. She will be missed. A funeral service will be held at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St, NYC, at 11:30am on Sunday, October 16.

BERNSTEIN--Barbara Soskin, died peacefully on October 9, 2011 in her home. A lifelong New Yorker, her life was characterized by fierce love for and loyalty to her family. In return, she enjoyed their adoration and love. The greatest source of pride and joy in her life was her nearly 40 year marriage and partnership with her late husband, Peter L. Bernstein, with whom she collaborated on his many books and essays. An avid reader, theatre-goer and lover of the arts, she remained vibrant, active and sharp until her final days. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Peter L. Bernstein, daughter Barbara Banks Brodsky, granddaughter Katherine Brodsky and sister Katherine Lee Meyers. She is survived by her grandson, three great-grandchildren, brother and nephews and nieces and their families. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday, October 16th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA, 01267.

An article on Wednesday about a backlash over the N.H.L.'s crackdown on hits to the head omitted attribution for comments by the deputy commissioner Bill Daly on Monday rebutting a report that some general managers had complained to the league that Brendan Shanahan, the league's new director of player safety, was being too strict. In a Los Angeles Times article by Helene Elliott -- not an interview with The New York Times -- Mr. Daly said: ''I will say unequivocally and for the record that no one at the league office has had any conversation with Brendan about changing the standard he is applying. Nor do we believe that he has or will 'back off,' as is being suggested in the media.'' The New York Times article also included another unattributed comment from Mr. Daly to Ms. Elliott, in which he noted that only one general manager had expressed concern about Mr. Shanahan's enforcement of the rules. An article on Friday about the Detroit Tigers' 7-5 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series misidentified, in some editions, the position of Detroit's Delmon Young, who hit two home runs in the game. He played left field, not right. An article on Tuesday about the Texas Rangers' 7-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series misstated, in some editions, Michael Young's batting history in the series before he led off the 11th inning for the Rangers with a single. He was 0 for 7, not 0 for 15.

WASSERMAN--Bernice S.,85, of Brooklyn Heights, died October 14. Dearly beloved wife of Dr. Bernard, cherished mother of Harvey and Kim and Andrew and Donna; loving grandmother of Jake and Sarah; beloved aunt, cousin and friend. Graduate of Erasmus High School and Hunter College, she worked for Science Magazine. She was an avid supporter of the arts and particularly loved opera. She enjoyed travel, crossword puzzles and reading. We will miss her deeply. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation appreciated. Services, Sunday, October 16, 11:30 am, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

La SELVA--Helen Lovell, wife of conductor Vincent La Selva, passed away October 13, 2011. A wake will be held at Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, NJ, Sunday, October 16, 2-6pm. A mass will take place Monday, October 17, 9:30am at St. Cassian Church, 187 Bellevue Avenue, Upper Montclair, burial to follow.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a circulation scandal involving The Wall Street Journal Europe misstated, in some copies, the price a Dutch consulting company paid for thousands of copies of The Journal. It was one euro cent, or about 1.3 American cents, per copy -- not one euro.

Could you live on $1,000 a month? An online game called Spent lets you see what it's like to make the tough choices necessary to get by on that amount of income. The interactive game was developed by a team at McKinney, a national advertising agency based in Durham, N.C., as a pro-bono effort to raise awareness of Urban Ministries, a local emergency services outfit seeing heavy demand in the tough economy.

BERNSTEIN--Owen Ph.D. lived a life of commitment to social justice, equality, peace, fairness, animals and the environment. His beliefs were often expressed as being motivated by the Jewish principle of tikkun olum, the Jewish obligation to repair the world: leave it a better place than the world you were born into. In his almost 90 years, with Bebe Kirshenbaum Bernstein, his wife of 62 years, whom he cherished, they forged a life together based on tikkun olum. Owen Bernstein imparted his beliefs, through work, action and example, to his children and grandchildren, and touched the lives of so many with his sweetness and gentleness. For these qualities he was adored by his family: Wife Bebe Kirschenbaum Bernstein; Daughters Freya Bernstein and her husband Dr. Martin Broff, Karen Bernstein Belfer and her husband Andrew Belfer; and his four Grandchildren James, Gaby, Adam and Samantha. Owen was born in Brooklyn where he lived most of his life. He and his wife then moved to Bayside, Queens where he passed away on October 11, 2011. He was proud of his family vacation home in the Berkshires in Monterey, Massachusetts. Funeral will be on Sunday, October 16 at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

An article on Page 44 this weekend about the struggle for control of the Republican Party refers incorrectly to a prescription-drug bill passed in 2003 under President George W. Bush and mentioned as an example of a ''nuanced view'' of the government's role. It was for Medicare recipients, not Medicaid. The article also misidentifies a state described as part of the Rust Belt. It is Michigan, not Missouri.

PERKINS--Jane Howard, (Mrs. Albert Carson Perkins). Born December 27, 1912. Died October 13, 2011. Daughter of Roy Wilson Howard and Margaret Rohe Howard. Sister of Jack R. Howard. Wife of Capt. Albert Carson Perkins, USN (Ret.). Mother of Anthony Carson Perkins, Timothy Howard Perkins, and Jennifer Perkins. Aunt of Pamela Howard and Michael B. Howard. Grandmother of Roy Howard Perkins, Mary Jane Perkins (Kissel), Elizabeth Perkins, Sierra R. Perkins, Chandra V. Perkins, and Tabitha S. Perkins. Great- grandmother of Roy Howard Perkins, Jr., John Perkins Muja, Sofia Rose Muja, James Timothy Kissel, Brian Earl Kissel, and Andrew Joseph Kissel. She was born and raised in New York City. Attended Spence School, Rosemary Hall, and graduated cum laude from Radcliffe College. Studied archaeology at Radcliffe (Harvard) and participated in early excavations at Chichen Itza. Working for the Honolulu Advertiser in the late 1930's, she traveled to the Far East on Pan Am's maiden trans-Pacific clipper flight, where she interviewed Mme. Chang Kai-Shek and gave an eyewitness account of the Japanese bombing of China. Lived for many years in Rome, Italy with her husband of 38 years, Cy, after he retired from the Navy, returning to live on Long Island and finally settling in Manhattan after his death. At the end she was surrounded by family and friends and died peacefully in her sleep.

Updated, 8:11 p.m. | Amid the chaos in Lower Manhattan on Friday morning as the Occupy Wall Street protesters marched through the streets, there were two encounters between protesters and the police that were captured, however imperfectly, on video and then ricocheted across the Internet. In one, a white-shirted police commander appears to grab a protester who is walking away from him, turn him around and punch him in the face.

COHEN--Reina (nee Lerman) 80, of Brookville and Long Beach, NY on October 13, 2011. Loving wife of the late Albert Cohen and sister of the late Gerald Lerman. Survived by loving daughter Alisa, son Jordan, daughter-in-law Randi, five cherished grandchildren. Funeral service Sunday 10am, Riverside Chapel 180 West 76th Street, NYC.

Piero Weiss, a former concert pianist and recording artist who turned to musicology, becoming an author and co-author of books in the field, including a widely used textbook, and founding the music history department at the Peabody Conservatory, died on Oct. 2 in Baltimore. He was 83. The cause was complications of pneumonia, said his son, Antonio.

An Israeli soldier held captive by militants in Gaza for five years is likely to return home as early as Tuesday, news agencies and Israeli media reported on Friday, a week after Israel and Hamas reached an agreement on a prisoner swap. The return of the soldier, Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, would mark the first phase of a deal brokered by Egypt that would see him exchanged for more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners. Israel and Hamas, which has held Mr. Shalit since June 2006, had been in close negotiations over the details since the deal was announced this week.

KLEINMAN--Dr. Charles S.,died peacefully on October 11, 2011. Adored husband of Jessica, father of Ari and Joshua, brother of Randy, father-in-law of Sarah and Allison, grandfather of Sydney and Matthew. He was considered the Father of Fetal Cardiology. His family and friends meant everything to him.

The Mets took another step in revamping their coaching staff on Friday by naming Bob Geren, the former manager of the Oakland Athletics, as their bench coach for the 2012 season. Geren was one of two candidates interviewed this week for the position, which became vacant after the Mets removed Ken Oberkfell last week. Jim Riggleman, who resigned as manager of the Washington Nationals midway through the 2011 season, was also interviewed.

Mildred Savage, the author of ''Parrish,'' a tale of a teenager struggling into manhood in the vast tobacco fields of the Connecticut River Valley in the late 1940s and early '50s -- a story later adapted for a popular movie of the same title -- died on Oct. 7 at her home in Norwich, Conn. She was 92. Her death was confirmed by her daughter, Susan Savage Simpson.

An editorial on Tuesday on ''housekeeping'' donations in New York State described imprecisely $1.1 million donated by Mayor Michael Bloomberg. He gave the money to the New York State Independence Party. The New York City Independence Party gave the mayor its 2009 ballot line.

MINKOFF--Ruth S. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Bruce (Barbara) and Edward (Paula). Loving grandmother of Jared, Karla, Clifford and Haley. Beloved great-grandmother of Leah, Eliana, James Theodore and William Thaddeus. Dear sister-in-law and aunt. Services Sunday at 11am at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave. Brooklyn, NY.

Nikolaj Hubbe, 43, the popular former principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, has extended his term as artistic director at the Royal Danish Ballet for another five years, the company said on Friday. Mr. Hubbe retired as a dancer and went to Copenhagen in 2008 to take on the job that year. The Danish Ballet has scored several successes under his leadership, including a major United States tour last year. Mr. Hubbe trained and spent the first half of his career at the Copenhagen company before joining City Ballet in 1992.

MCLEOD--Laura Margaret. The Korein family mourns the death on October 12 of a former auditor after a long illness. Born November 20, 1920 in Hamilton Township, Ontario, Canada, Ms. McLeod attended the University of Toronto graduating with a degree in sociology. She later became a Chartered Accountant in Canada. She moved to New York where she was one of the first women CPAs in the country. She was associated with the hotel accounting firm then known as Harris, Kerr, Forster and first met the family when she became the resident auditor of the Croydon Hotel. She later worked for over 20 years at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. After retiring from the Museum, she again worked for the family as a resident auditor at the Hotel Delmonico. Ms. McLeod was a gifted musician and a founder of the Clan MacLeod Society. She is survived by two sisters and a nephew. With thanks to her caregiver Clevet Veronica Sam.

An article on Tuesday about the Texas Rangers' 7-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series misstated, in some editions, Michael Young's batting history in the series before he led off the 11th inning for the Rangers with a single. He was 0 for 7, not 0 for 15.

An article on Thursday about congressional approval of free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama misstated the number of trade agreements that Congress had passed since 2007, when Democrats took control of the Senate and the House. It is one, a trade agreement with Peru, in 2007; it is not the case that no agreements were passed during that period.

We all have at least two types of capital that we should be managing: personal human capital and financial capital. In simple terms, human capital is the ability to earn money. Financial capital is our savings or investments. Based on my experience as a financial planner and talks with entrepreneurs, I believe everyone needs to manage these two types of capital differently than they do now. So I came up with some strategies -- a Unified Theory of Capital Management -- to help you manage these two distinct but connected resources.

RINDNER--Martin. Beloved husband and best friend to Anita; proud parent of Bob, Gary and Dorothy, Cathy and Leon; cherished grandfather of Austin; Grant and Drew; Julian, Marina, Audrey and Noah. The kindest and gentlest of souls: his greatest joy was in giving. Donations may be made to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

NO. 11 MICHIGAN AT NO. 23 MICHIGAN STATE Noon Eastern, ESPN If Michigan State wins today, it will have its first four-game winning streak against its in-state rival in almost 50 years. Michigan is trying to climb back to national prominence. The winner gets sole possession of first place in the Leaders Division of the Big 10. Michigan State comes in with the top defense in the nation, allowing 173.4 total yards a game and having held four of its five opponents to 7 points or fewer. Spartans linebacker Denicos Allen had two sacks against Ohio State last week. Michigan quarterback Denard Robinson, right, is electrifying but has nine interceptions. The Wolverines are outscoring opponents, 114-21, in the second half, and much of the credit goes to the defensive coordinator Greg Mattison. NO. 18 ARIZONA STATE AT NO. 9 OREGON 10:15 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Arizona State has two victories over top-25 teams and is a favorite in the Pac-12 South, but the Sun Devils will still be a 14-point underdog in Eugene. That may be because the two ranked teams that the Sun Devils defeated have since fallen out of the top 25 and because Oregon's offense is averaging more than 50 points a game. The Ducks, who dropped their season opener to Louisiana State but easily won their next four games against suspect opponents, could be without running back LaMichael James, who leads the nation with 170.4 rushing yards a game. Arizona State's defense has forced 18 turnovers this season, third most in the nation. Sun Devils cornerback Alden Darby has three interceptions in the last two games, and middle linebacker Vontaze Burfict is an intimidating presence.

An article on Friday about the Detroit Tigers' 7-5 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series misidentified, in some editions, the position of Detroit's Delmon Young, who hit two home runs in the game. He played left field, not right.

KLEINMAN--Charles S.,MD. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New-York Presbyterian (NYP) Center for Prenatal Pediatrics mourn the passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague. Internationally known for his work in fetal and pediatric cardiology, Charlie was an integral part of our prenatal diagnostics program at the Center for Prenatal Pediatrics. He held appointments as Professor of Clinical Pediatrics in Obstetrics and Gynecology at Columbia and Chief of Perinatal Cardiology at NYP. His extraordinary clinical acumen and unique diagnostic skills were so important for our patients and for our program. Charlie met the challenges of his own illness with enormous courage and humor, never losing his devotion to his work, his patients, his colleagues and his family. We will miss him dearly; he was an inspiring teacher, mentor and friend--in the words of our colleague, Dr. Larry Platt, We lost a giant and a mensch. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his beloved wife, Jessie, their two sons, daughters-in-law and grandchildren that he adored. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, Director Obstetric and Gynelogical Services, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Sloane Hospital for Women; Chair Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

Soon after he arrived in Paris, in early October 1861, John Bigelow, the newly appointed American consul general to France, paid a visit to a quiet house on Rue Taitbout, about a mile north of the Louvre. The home belonged to the grandly named Édouard-René Lefèbvre de Laboulaye, a small, soft-spoken professor of history at the Collège de France, one of the country's elite institutions of higher learning. Laboulaye was an expert on American history, and Bigelow was there to ask him for a small favor: to change the way the French thought about America's civil war.

Stan Lee, a co-creator of childhood mainstays like Spider-Man, the X-Men and the Fantastic Four, will join with 1821 Comics to start a multimedia imprint for children called "Stan Lee's Kids Universe." The imprint, announced at the New York Comic Con on Friday and reported on galleycat.com, is to feature five books, including "Monsters vs. Kittens," created by Dani Jones, and "Reggie the Veggie Crocodile." Also among their plans is a video game for iPhone and iPad. At a Comic Con panel presentation, Mr. Lee said, "Our main purpose is we feel that there aren't enough comic books or books for kids that really hit the target, that gives them excitement and humor together and are filled with surprises. We have a whole new group of new characters that the kids can call their own, just as the teenagers called Spider-Man their own so many years ago." Mr. Lee is also collaborating with the 1821 Comics co-founder Terry Douglas, the writer Max Work and the artist Skan Srisuwan on a graphic novel, "Romeo & Juliet: The War," a futuristic interpretation of the play - but with superpowers. The book is to be released in November.

The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced that Michael Boyd will step down as artistic director next year, after more than a decade in the job, the BBC News reported. The executive director, Vikki Heywood, will leave her post at the same time. Under their supervision, the company recently completed a $177 million renovation of its theaters in Stratford-Upon-Avon, England, and a successful six-week run of performances in New York at the Park Avenue Armory. Mr. Boyd is also a chief architect of the World Shakespeare Festival, a celebration set to run from April to September 2012. Mr. Boyd said in a statement that it was "time for me to pass the challenges on to a new artistic director." The company is expected to announce a successor early next year.

Hollywood's box-office blues continued over the weekend as remakes of "Footloose" and "The Thing" fizzled. "Real Steel" (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 by a sliver, taking in about $16.3 million for a two-week total of $51.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. "Footloose" stumbled in second place, selling an estimated $16.1 million in tickets, a frail result given the months-long marketing push that Paramount Pictures lavished on the film. The good news: "Footloose," built around a cast of unknowns, cost only about $24 million to make. "The Thing" (Universal Pictures) was third with $8.7 million in ticket sales - not exactly a bloodbath given its production cost of about $38 million but a disappointment nonetheless. George Clooney's "Ides of March" (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth, taking in about $7.5 million for a two-week total of $22.2 million. "Dolphin Tale" (Warner Brothers) rounded out the top five with $6.3 million in ticket sales, lifting its four-week tally to $58.7 million. For the weekend, North American theaters recorded $89 million in ticket sales, a 32 percent drop from the same weekend last year.

''THEIR batteries have probably all melted,'' said the photographer Mary Ellen Mark, looking with wry affection at the crowd of robots that have taken up residence in her downtown loft. ''I'm a bad robot mom.'' Pink fembots in frilly aprons! Mean metal guys with clock bellies! For this second installment of the Collect Call column in T: The New York Times Style Magazine, in which I track people's sometimes baffling, sometimes amusing, sometimes magnificent collections, I've come to examine Ms. Mark's need to -- if you can stand it -- save the robots. ''It started 10 or 15 years ago,'' she said. ''I don't collect for their value -- I don't think I've spent more than $150 for one -- but for their personalities. Some of them are very common. I have a robot camera, maybe my favorite robot, and I even have a robot pillow. And I have a witch robot! But that's at home.''

In 2007, a real estate agent, eBay peddler and amateur historian named John Maloof purchased 30,000 unattributed negatives on a hunch. This turned out to be the bulk of Vivian Maier's undiscovered oeuvre, virtuosic street photographs taken by a reclusive Chicago nanny who died quietly in 2009 at age 83, just before her work went viral. She is now considered to be a lost master of the form, the Windy City's own Helen Levitt. A giddy press has provided for her a whole slate of lofty comparisons: to Diane Arbus, Brassai, Walker Evans and Weegee. Her eye for midcentury street fashion - fox stoles, bonnets and bird-cage veils - made her something of a proto-Sartorialist. But she could also slum it with street urchins, drooling bums and sideshow performers. Or mine the Loop late at night shooting perp walks. Suffice it to say, her work was not published in her lifetime, and ''Vivian Maier: Street Photographer'' (powerHouse, $40), edited by Maloof, is the first book on this important woman about whom so little is known. As Geoff Dyer puts it in his brief introduction, Maier ''is someone who exists entirely in terms of what she saw.'' Her photos, remarkable in their range, show an uncommon affinity with children, perhaps unsurprising given her work. ''She was like Mary Poppins,'' one of her charges from the 1960s recalled recently in Chicago Magazine. ''She had an amazing ability to relate to children.'' In a weird twist, Maier was hired briefly in the '70s by the talk-show host Phil Donahue to care for his children. ''I once saw her taking a picture inside a refuse can,'' he said. ''I never remotely thought that what she was doing would have some special artistic value.''

Screen-swiping, pinching to contract, tapping an icon - these actions, popularized on smartphones, have become so ingrained in our mobile society's muscle memory that Cadillac has decided to build its new infotainment system around them. Called Cue, for Cadillac User Experience, the system will have its first application on the XTS full-size luxury sedan, going on sale next year. Cue incorporates screen swipes, haptic feedback, a multitouch interface and what the company describes as natural speech recognition.

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). Raise your hand if you thought Buffalo's Fred Jackson would be the top-ranked fantasy running back heading into Week 6? Right, didn't think so. Don't worry, neither did we. That's why fantasy football analysts don't get paid the big bucks: there are too many things we just can't see coming. But that doesn't mean we're going to stop trying. We feel confident enough to tell you that Jackson and Ahmad Bradshaw are in line for big fantasy days in Week 6 when the Buffalo Bills and Giants meet on Sunday. Keep reading to find out why.

THE 69-year-old British textile brand Ascher has been collaborating with artists since the 1950s when the founder Zika Ascher had his friends -- Henri Matisse, André Derain and Henry Moore, among them -- design silk scarves better suited for galleries than girls' closets. Now, Ascher's grandson, Sam, is reviving the tradition with two scarves by the Chinese artist Zao Wou-ki, one of the company's original contributors. ''When Zao Wou-ki first worked with us, he was 24 or 25, and just starting out,'' he said. ''He was the last artist to do a collaboration with my grandfather, and now he is the first to restart the project, so it's come full circle.'' The scarves, painted with impulsive watercolors, come in limited editions of 150, and though they're intended to stay framed, we would be sympathetic to those who feel the need to wear them out. Shown: Zao Wou-ki, Untitled, 2011, printed silk twill square, $5,000. Go to aschersquares.com. LILY MIESMER

My teenage memories of rainy weekends watching classic movies often had a star - Bette Davis, maybe - shrugging off a compliment with a sneer and the words ''This old thing?!'' So who would have thought that a vintage dress - from on- or off-screen - would later fetch a fortune at auction and become a fashion object of desire?

Known for electric facials that make A-list clients look as if they've had face-lifts, Melanie Simon uses her magic machines (and Circ-Cell, her product line) to coax youth from even the most stubborn complexions. Go to circcell.com. Tools of her trade Custom-built to administer Simon's electrical cocktail, this portable ST-8 machine stimulates lymphatic drainage using nano and pico currents. Microneedling, in which tiny needles are rolled over the face and neck, is her preferred technique for fighting acne and surgery scars. She developed Circ-Cell Creme ER3, which she says mimics the effect of hormone replacement on the skin, with her go-to beauty guru Dr. Michael Galitzer. ''He uses homeopathic and naturopathic medicines in conjunction with bioidentical hormone replacement,'' she says. ''There's no better specialist in this area in the world, and he's given many women a new lease on life.'' She uses surgical gauze to apply toners and serums. ''Saturate it with liquid and press and hold it to each area of your face for 15 seconds. This intensifies the effect of any product, so start slowly.''

''100 Shoes'' (The Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale, $25) is not a collection of fashion's most vertically daring heels, despite the Vivienne Westood platforms on the cover (and a preface by that stilt walker Sarah Jessica Parker). Instead it's a brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded: Moccasins were huge in Georgian England; American tango boots in the 1910s laced up like Grecian sandals; and that late-'60s prototype by Beth Levine - it kicks off the shoe slideshow above - seems to have come from a different planet. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

They met in 1929, in the photographer's shop where she worked, in Munich. He was 40, she was 17. He devoured her with his eyes, she said. Soon after, he had her family investigated, to check that her bloodlines were Aryan. He was Adolf Hitler, an amateur artist whose charisma as a reactionary orator had propelled him to the forefront of Germany's National Socialist party. She was Eva Braun, an attractive blonde from a middle-class family who, after one year at a school run by nuns, was back home living with her parents. We know how the story ends, though we can't help wondering why - was she completely lacking in intelligence, or morals, or both? In ''Eva Braun: Life With Hitler,'' translated from the German by Damion Searls (Alfred A. Knopf), Heike B. Gortemaker takes on a task few biographers - I'm tempted to say no biographer in her right mind - would tackle, so scant and unreliable is the material. Braun's letters to Hitler, which numbered in the hundreds, were burned at his behest. His letters to her have never surfaced; supposedly wrapped in plastic and buried, per her instructions, they are now presumed to have been destroyed as well. There are 20 pages of a diary, which at least one expert has deemed a forgery. The silent solidarity of Hitler's inner circle, which constituted an embargo on all personal information, broke down only after the war. But the testimony that emerged from the de-Nazification hearings at Nuremberg was blatantly revisionist, offered up by friends and associates eager to minimize their involvement, scrambling to save their own lives.

The article also misstated the status of United States players' funds at Absolute Poker, a site to which federal authorities blocked access earlier this year. While Absolute Poker says it plans to reimburse that money shortly, it has not yet done so.

In the American fall collections of 1960, Norman Norell did something seemingly too radical for a man who ate most of his meals at Schrafft's and Hamburg Heaven. He had his models paint their faces in the bohemian-urchin style of Paris in the '20s, with darkened eyes and red lips, finished off with shingle haircuts. Then he put the girls in pants. Technically these were split skirts, but who cares? The effect was the same. Long before Yves Saint Laurent issued le smoking, square Norman was there. ''They may seem a little avant-garde at first,'' he told The Times after his 1960 show, for which he received a standing ovation, ''but I really do believe in the look.'' He had uncanny instincts for anticipating change: the elongated sweater look, the return of waistlines in the mid-'60s, the dolman-sleeve rage of the early '70s. He showed leopard patterns in the '40s. The flapper makeup told a lot about Norell as well: stage-struck at an early age, he designed costumes in the '20s at the Astoria studio of Paramount Pictures, dressing Gloria Swanson in ''Zaza,'' and later worked on Broadway musicals and burlesque shows before moving to ladies' fashion. Norell has always been something of a quiet genius of American fashion - he was born Norman David Levinson on April 20, 1900, in Noblesville, Ind., and got his surname by chopping down ''Norman'' and taking one ''l'' from ''Levinson'' and the other from ''looks.'' And so it's intriguing to find a personal trove of Norells from the '60s and '70s, some of it in mint condition. On Oct. 19, the site 1st Dibs will sell more than 100 ensembles that belonged to Beverly Dowis Blettner, a Chicago socialite and philanthropist.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week. Recently, there were a string of days that felt stolen from summer. Tuesday, the day of my site visit, was the last of these. The warm sun flooded the woods of Inwood Hill Park with light, creating long shadows that foreshortened the scene. Harshly lit patches straddled pockets of deep shade.

Songs simmer awhile inside her head before choosing their own moment to froth out fully formed. Or so has claimed Laura Marling, a 21-year-old British sensation who is perhaps the quintessential folk singer of her generation. It's a romantic idea, this ghostly pale lass with wispy blond hair transmuting somehow - perhaps via inspiration from the Muses - her own admittedly tangled emotions into divinely inspired songs to be sung by her divinely bestowed voice. And it's an idea bolstered by the fact that her first two albums earned her a Mercury Prize nomination each. Marling's newly released third effort, ''A Creature I Don't Know,'' poetically titled like all her albums, trades some of her teenage urgency for a more muscular, acrobatic lyricism - the result being 10 tracks that feel evolved, or more grown-up even. In any case, it's clear that when Marling found this new sound, the Muses did not abandon her. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

If you travel over and over to the same place, you start to know people without really knowing them, exchanging a weak smile with a shopkeeper, a street sweeper, a waiter at the cafe. If the place is Provence, France, and you are interested in old things, especially textiles and folk costumes, you may have had a glancing acquaintance with the antiquarian Michel Biehn, an inescapable presence in the region from the late 1970s until last year. Biehn began small with a stand at the Aix-en-Provence flea markets, trading up to a cupboard-size shop on the Place des Trois Ormeaux, where he preached the gospel of Provencal boutis - wood-blocked quilts that, when he entered the business, were used as moving blankets to wrap Louis XVI commodes at chateau sales. Having attracted a following, Biehn moved on, living and dealing on the main drag in L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue in a town house whose hulk and hauteur seemed not accidental echoes of his own. Like Christian Lacroix, Cote Sud, Pierre Deux and braids of garlic, he's been an indivisible part of the global post-Picasso fashion for all things Provencal.

KESSLER--Theodore. The Kessler family sadly announces the passing of Theodore Kessler on October 14, 2011. Born on April 9, 1929 in Nyirbator, Hungary, Ted was a Holocaust survivor, a Korean War Veteran, and a CPA. He is survived and will be dearly missed by his wife, Frances, two sons, David and Andrew, and five grandchildren.

Approaching the Statue of Liberty by boat for the first time in 1999, Wang Qingsong had visions of Botticelli. ''It was just a little bit like 'The Birth of Venus,' '' he said. ''It was a goddess born from the water.'' Twelve years later, he took that image as inspiration for ''Goddess,'' featuring a 26-by-19-foot clay sculpture built in his studio in Songzhuang, an artists' village on the outskirts of Beijing. As with all of his work, Wang constructs elaborate tableaux, which he then photographs and dismantles. For ''Goddess,'' he imagined Lady Liberty in a Mao suit, a reflection of China's struggle between two ideals: the beliefs of the chairman and the tenets of democracy. The scaffolding around the sculpture alludes to the vast unfinished construction sites in China; the chickens that wander through the rubble enjoy a freedom that he believes the Chinese people do not. Though he has had only a few direct confrontations with the authorities (usually over nudity), Wang expects ''Goddess'' to be controversial. ''People have lost their dreams and their ideals,'' he said. ''As an artist, as a citizen, I am very puzzled about where we are going and why we are lost.'' height of plaster model: 24 inches amount of clay used for full-size statue: more than 20 tons

DISCONTENT over the economy has found a focus in Occupy Wall Street -- a movement that says it has no leaders but is united in seeking justice for the 99 percent of the population that isn't superrich. Now a month old, its protests have led to many others across the country, but nowhere are they more freighted with symbolism than in the area around the New York Stock Exchange. As the protesters camp out in the nearby Zuccotti Park, some onlookers -- among them members of the 1 percent who work in the area -- are asking: who are these people, and what exactly do they want? A visit to Lower Manhattan shows that their answers, although reflecting a general unhappiness with the status quo, are by no means similar.

Funeral services and interment are private. A memorial concert, open to the public, will be held at the Turner Auditorium of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, MD on Sunday, December 11 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts be made to the Piero Weiss Fund at the Peabody Institute, c/o The Peabody Development Office, One East Mount Vernon Place, Baltimore, MD 21202.

The University of Minnesota unveiled its $14 million expansion to the Frederick R. Weisman Art Museum on Oct. 2 in Minneapolis. Frank Gehry, who designed the original stainless-steel structure in 1993, also designed the expansion. Lyndel King, the museum's director and chief curator, said: ''I see this building almost as a giant sculpture, a work of art, and who can add on to a work of art except the original artist?'' The Weisman Art Museum, which has 150,000 visitors annually, has become as recognized for its distinctive architecture as well as the art it contains.

JOINING an acclaimed series already in progress can be a fraught proposition. But the British actor Charlie Cox faced an additional obstacle when he signed on to HBO's ''Boardwalk Empire'' for its second season: he'd never seen the show. ''I didn't start watching it until I'd already filmed four or five episodes,'' he said. ''The fact that I was playing someone from an entirely different world, who had no experience of this place at all, probably helped because it was similar to what I felt as Charlie on set in New York.''

Ruby Aldridge is a hard girl to pin down. Her schedule is such that it takes a few weeks to get a 10-minute phone call penciled in, and even then, when a time is agreed upon, her New York agent calls the day of to say she's a little tied up - scrambling around searching for her passport. (It's probably under a heap of clothes somewhere in her Lower East Side apartment.) But it's hard not to forgive her. She's only 20 after all, and isn't that what all 20-year-olds do? Lose their passports. Except most don't have to fly to Paris at dawn for a round of couture shows. Aldridge, who has catwalked for Prada, Gucci, Dior, Proenza Schouler and Miu Miu, starred in last year's Marc by Marc Jacobs campaign and is one of the new faces of Valentino, is having a moment. This shouldn't come as any surprise to the British, who have always had a fondness for the Aldridges: her mother is Laura Lyons, an American model and former Playboy Playmate, and her father is the famous English illustrator Alan Aldridge, whom Ruby describes as the love of her life. ''He's the best, and just the most amazing, creative, modest genius I ever met,'' she gushes. You might have seen his cartoony, psychedelic artwork in books for the Beatles and on album covers for the Rolling Stones, the Who and Elton John. Ruby is fortunate to have inherited good looks and a creative spirit (she's currently learning to play guitar) in equal measures, as have all the Aldridge offspring.

SHEPHERD--John, M.D. John Shepherd, M.D.,a renowned cardiovascular researcher, past president of the American Heart Association, Chair of the Space Medicine Committee of NASA, Head of Research and Dean of the Mayo Medical School died on October 4th in Rochester, Minnesota at the Mayo Clinic, where he spent most of his career. He was 92. He was born on May 21st, 1919 in Northern Ireland and received his M.B., B.Ch, M. Chir and M.D with honors from Queens University in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Subsequently he completed his internship and residency at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. Later he joined the academic staff at Queens in the Department of Physiology. In 1953 he was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship to come to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota for one year to engage in cardiovascular research. He returned to Northern Ireland but eventually emigrated to the US in 1957 to join the Mayo Clinic. Notably Dr. Shepherd and his three close colleagues in the small department of Physiology at Queen's University all later became Deans of Medical Schools around the world. Remarkably for the son of a Presbyterian minister from rural Ireland, he was one of 15 physicians in his family including his daughter, his son who is on staff at the Mayo Clinic and his grandson and namesake who is at Mayo Medical School. He made major contributions to understanding the regulation of the vascular system, particularly how the nervous system regulates blood pressure, producing over 300 scientific publications and four books. He was President of the American Heart Association in 1975-76. He was also a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in the UK and Ireland. Over the years he was the recipient of many awards including honorary degrees from the Universities of Bologna, Ghent and Queens. He was also actively involved with National Aeronautics and Space Agency (NASA) and the National Academy of Sciences where he was a member and subsequently Chair of the Committee on Space Medicine 1965-1974. During this time, he had many interactions with colleagues behind the Iron Curtain in the USSR working on space physiology. Many of their exercise and fluid protocols are still used in space travel. This led to his major hobby: collecting space-themed stamps. He developed one of the world's largest such collections. The Mayo Clinic was his professional home and he made many contributions to this institution. He was Director of Research from 1969 -1976. In this position, and as a member of the Board of Trustees, he was instrumental in enabling Mayo to become a separate degree granting institution in 1972 from the University of Minnesota. He became Director for Education of the Mayo Foundation and Dean of the new Mayo Medical School from 1977 1983. This included responsibility for the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine and Mayo School of Health-Related Sciences. Later from 1983-1988 he chaired the Mayo Board of Development and was actively involved in the development of the first Mayo satellite in Jacksonville FL. He retired from Mayo in 1989. In 2003, he published Inside the Mayo Clinic, a memoir. He was predeceased by his first wife, Helen Johnston Shepherd. He is survived by his wife, Marion Etzwiler Shepherd and his children, Gillian Shepherd Mestre, New York, NY; Roger Shepherd, Rochester, MN; stepchildren Nancy Etzwiler O'Neill, Lisa Etzwiler Clary, Diane Etzwiler Thallon, David Etzwiler, five grandchildren, eight step-grandchildren and one great-grandson. A Memorial Service will be held at The First Presbyterian Church, Rochester MN at 11am, Saturday October 22. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Mayo Foundation.

Miles Aldridge The British fashion photographer Miles Aldridge is surrounded by models: he's married to one (Kristen McMenamy); his eldest sister, Saffron, was once the face of Ralph Lauren; and his middle sister, Lily, is a Victoria's Secret Angel. When Ruby, his youngest sister/ -- wait for it -- became a mega-watt model herself, Aldridge had seen enough of the profession's downside to have his doubts. ''I said, 'Forget about it!' I was not going to be helpful.'' In ''Runaround Ruby'' (Page 82), Aldridge gives in to family tradition and photographs his little sister for the first time, who poses as a young, louche and beautiful city dweller.

SCHLIESSER--Peter, age 83, died at home on October 8, 2011. He was born in the Sudeten Region of the Czech Republic from where he fled in 1945 to Vienna, Austria. In 1950 he received a scholarship for Oberlin College, Ohio, where he majored in Government and went on to Yale Law School where he graduated in 1956. While working at Milbank Tweed he received a Fulbright scholarship to Chile where he worked and lectured on U.S. aid to Latin America. His legal career thereafter was devoted largely to Latin American business law. He is survived by his wife Helga. A memorial will be held December 5th at 6pm at the Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Ave., New York. Contributions to Peter's memory may be made to Amnesty International 5 Penn Plaza 16th floor, New York, NY 10001.

Officially, the designer Thakoon Panichgul (above left), of Thakoon, is an adviser to Thailand's ministry of commerce. But this summer he put business aside and spent two weeks looking for inspiration in the country's northern mountain villages near Chiang Mai. He found it in the bright, hand-woven and embroidered silk and cotton ikats of the Karen and Lua tribes - a vibrant palette similar to the saturated red, turquoise, mustard and pink yarns in his recent spring collection. ''There is something so special about these communities of grandmothers,'' Panichgul says. ''It's really a dying art. Each tribe's ikat pattern is based on memory.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Around the Nation college football notebook in some editions last Sunday misstated the location of the Miami University, where the former football coach Ara Parseghian was honored the previous day. It is in Oxford, Ohio -- not in Miami, Ohio. (There is no such city in Ohio.) The article also misstated the years Parseghian won national championships as a coach at Notre Dame. He won titles in 1966 and 1973 -- not in 1964 and 1974, which were the years he began and ended his coaching career there.

The Super PAC emerged out of two 2010 court cases and became a vehicle for unlimited political donations in that year's midterm elections. The committees are becoming even larger players this election cycle, aligning with individual candidates and providing millions of dollars in outside support. Some of them are connected to nonprofit groups, which do not have to disclose their donors.

THE photographer Elle Muliarchyk grew up speaking a half-dozen languages from Czech to Vietnamese (her father was a diplomat, and her mother was a journalist and linguist) and during a brief career as a model, she picked up some French and Italian. Her experience in the global village of fashion and her interest in languages come together in ''Lips of Babel,'' a series of mesmerizing close-up video portraits of models delivering tongue twisters in their native tongues. ''Tongue twisters are something we all have from childhood,'' Ms. Muliarchyk said, adding that they often say a lot about their culture of origin. One from Nigeria translates as: ''Lady Seamstress, why are you so sad? Did a hen lay an egg on the dress you just made?'' Another, from India, says, ''A husband slapped his wife for no apparent reason.'' News of the project spread quickly through the modeling world -- entirely by word of mouth -- and Ms. Muliarchyk has captured 50 and counting. The first 24 are on view starting next week at Motilo.com. ALIX BROWNE
'He'd say something that was contrary to what you believe in to see how strongly you believed in it.'

There's something very sexy-cool about a glossy, nude lip. It says, ''I'm hot, but I didn't try too hard,'' and it works for almost everyone. (And for almost every designer, judging by how many copped the bare-lip look for their resort and spring shows.) It's also super-low-maintenance. ''You don't have to be concerned that your color will bleed,'' says Lisa Houghton, who did the makeup on the previous page. The only caveat: you need a well-prepped pucker. Houghton exfoliated our model's lips by dabbing on a bit of Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and rubbing it off with a tissue. Then she applied a mixture of Arden's Crystal Clear Lip Gloss and a touch of High Shine Lip Gloss in Tropicoral for the right pinkish tone. Before getting your gloss on, use a targeted product like Bliss Fabulips Treatment Kit, which contains a cleanser, scrub, plumper and balm, or Fresh Sugar Lip Gloss, which smells practically edible. Kate Somerville's new Quench and Correct Plumping Gloss and Restorative Lip Treatment comes in a convenient, double-ended tube that's great for showing lips some love on the run.

ANISFIELD--Richard C.,age 89, died peacefully on October 8, 2011. His last months were characterized by the dignity and graciousness for which he has always been known. Son of Samuel and Lillian Anisfield, Richard was born in Paterson, NJ. He lived in Upper Montclair for 33 years before moving to Saddle River 27 years ago. A veteran of the United States Air Force, Richard served as a pilot with the 466th Bomb Group in World War II. From 1956 until 2005, he owned Kurt Versen Company, a lighting fixture manufacturer in Westwood, NJ, and held several patents for light fixture design. He retired in 2008. Richard took great pleasure in outdoor activities--particularly golf, skiing, and landscaping. He had a wonderful sense of humor which he shared with family and friends, while his generosity of spirit was demonstrated in various philanthropic endeavors. Richard is survived by his beloved wife Millicent to whom he was married for 63 wonderful years; two loving daughters: Susan Vallario and husband Nick of Upper Saddle River, and Nancy Anisfield and husband Terry Wilson of Hinesburg, Vermont; his devoted sister Rita Kirschner; and a number of nieces and nephews and their children. Cremation was private. A memorial service and reception will take place at Ramapo College, Mahwah, NJ, at a later date. Arrangements by the Vander Plaat Funeral Home of Wyckoff, NJ (vpfh.com). Memorial donations may be made to the Ramapo College Foundation (for the Anisfield School of Business), 505 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah, NJ 07430-1680; or to the Valley Hospital Foundation, 223 N. Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 07450.

Daimler announced Tuesday that it would show a prototype combination plug and port design intended for use on plug-in hybrids and purely electric vehicles. The system, a joint effort with Audi, BMW, Porsche and Volkswagen, will be on view at a technology conference in Baden-Baden, Germany, on Wednesday and Thursday. The announcement is the most explicit indication yet from German automakers that they favor the design standard coordinated by SAE International, an organization of scientists and vehicle engineers, over one developed by the Tokyo Electric Power Company and in wide use in Asia, known as Chademo.

In Ingo Schulze's cheery novel ''Adam and Evelyn'' (Knopf, $28), a lecherous East German dressmaker gets a bit too cozy with his comrade clientele, inciting his girlfriend to go on a sex-charged romp through newly democratic Hungary. ''White Truffles in Winter'' (W. W. Norton, $25), a novel by N. M. Kelby, imagines Escoffier's wife's attempt to get the great chef to name a dish for her, as he had for an Australian soprano (peach Melba) and a famous lover (potage Sarah Bernhardt). In Lindsay McCrum's photo book, ''Chicks With Guns'' (Vendome, $45), some young girls cradle hunting rifles, while Elena, a steely-eyed 911 dispatcher, grips a Glock. ''I've had people call in when someone's breaking into their home,'' she says. ''They have no weapons on them, and I'm thinking, That's not gonna be me.''

LAMBROSA--Mrs. Rose, 107, lifelong resident of Brooklyn Heights and Carroll Gardens, passed away on October 14th after a vibrant life and a sudden brief illness. Rose was the beloved wife of the late Joseph Lambrosa, loving mother to Elena Fasulo and the late Patricia Cartier, caring and loving grandmother to Patrice Cartier Roe, Vincent Cartier, Gregg Cartier, Louis V. Fasulo and Edward Fasulo, great-grandmother extraordinaire to Tricia Ann Roe, Nathaniel Roe, Arianna Fasulo and Alexa Fasulo, and friend to longtime assistant Ayisha Ouedraogo. Rose was a successful entrepreneurial real estate investor and the President and Manager of several historic Brooklyn Heights properties for over 75 years. She graduated from Browns Business School. She and her late husband owned Bromaco Macaroni Corporation which was the first macaroni producer in the United States. They subsequently opened the Salsina Tomato Cannery Company in Santa Clara, California and were also the first producers of canned tomatoes in the U.S. Contadina eventually purchased the company and the farms. Rose's life was dedicated to her family, and defined by her hard work, love of life and independence. She was a wise mentor, a savvy business woman and a philanthropic presence in Brooklyn for over a century. She was a role model for her family, all who worked with her and all who knew her. Most importantly, she exemplified the true meaning of living life to the fullest. Wake at F.G. Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton Street, Brooklyn New York 11231, Sunday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Mass on Monday 11am Sacred Hearts and St Stephen's R.C. Church. Entombment immediately following at Fairview Cemetery.

BERNSTEIN--Barbara Soskin, died peacefully on October 9, 2011 in her home. A lifelong New Yorker, her life was characterized by fierce love for and loyalty to her family. In return, she enjoyed their adoration and love. The greatest source of pride and joy in her life was her nearly 40 year marriage and partnership with her late husband, Peter L. Bernstein, with whom she collaborated on his many books and essays. An avid reader, theatre-goer and lover of the arts, she remained vibrant, active and sharp until her final days. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Peter L. Bernstein, daughter Barbara Banks Brodsky, granddaughter Katherine Brodsky and sister Katherine Lee Meyers. She is survived by her grandson, three great-grandchildren, brother and nephews and nieces and their families. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Sunday, October 16th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA, 01267.

SIDERIS--Niki. Founder and Chairman of the Ronald McDonald House New York Greek Division. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff wish to express our sincere sympathy over the passing of our friend, advisor, and Founder of the Greek Division at Ronald McDonald House New York, Mrs. Niki Sideris, who died on October 12, 2011. She was 70. Mrs. Sideris passed away while en route to New York City from her home in Greece. When the Ronald McDonald House opened its doors in New York City in 1978, Mrs. Sideris was there from the start. Among the many challenges faced by Greek families coming to New York City in search of better treatments and cures for their children's illness was the lack of affordable housing, an intimidating language barrier, and an inadequate family support system. Founding the Greek Division, Mrs. Sideris organized fundraising and educational events as a way to enlighten the local Greek community about Ronald McDonald House New York's mission to provide not just housing, but a comprehensive support system for families battling pediatric cancer. In addition to the Greek Holiday Party, Mrs. Sideris introduced the annual spring marathon event, which she referred to as her "Marathon of Love." She had arrived in New York City in 1970 where she met her late husband, Dr. Michael Sideris. They enjoyed a loving union that ended with his death in January 2005. Mrs. Sideris leaves behind her legacy of giving, kindness, and awareness of how a caring and compassionate community within New York City can give hope to thousands of families in crisis. A viewing will be held for Mrs. Sideris on Monday, October 17, 2011 from 3pm8pm, at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity at 319-337 East 74th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021. The liturgy will be held on Tuesday, October 18, 2011 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Ronald McDonald House New York at 405 E. 73rd Street, New York, NY 10021. For more information, contact Spiridoula Katechis at 212-639-0188. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting Mrs. Sideris as part of our family and love and care she offered so freely to those she touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

FAZIO--Vincent James, of New York City. Born September 1, 1928, died October 9th. Cum laude NYU grad, Vince was a CPA, held an MBA and studied at Fordham Law School. After serving as Korean War Marine Corps Sergeant, he worked at Peat, Marwick, Mitchell; Eastman Radio; and CAB, as Senior VP of Finance and Administration. Extensive career travel included posts in Italy and Wales. Retired, Vince took up Shakespearean acting and won "Best Grandpa, Ever!" He joins son, Stephen, and is survived by beloved wife of 51 years, Wilhelmina; daughter, Elisa; son, Christopher; grandchildren, Elena, Peter and GiGi; brother Joseph's family; sister-in-law Barbara Vandervloed, and Comparetto cousins. Remembrances may be made to the New York Public Library@ www.nypl.org/memorial/. November memorial; contact effazio@hotmail.com.

PACKARD--Sandra Barry Grove on October 7, 2011. She is survived by her children Elise, Timothy and Amanda Packard; three grandsons, Elliott, Colin and Lukas; and her cousin, Coralie McDonnell Otoshi. Sandra attended The Brearley School and graduated from The Garrison Forest School in 1959 and Briarcliff Junior College in 1961. She served as President of The Knickerbocker Greys from 1981-1993 and as a past President of The Lenox Hill Hospital's Women's Auxiliary. Through her Web site, bodyrock.tv, the abdominally flawless Zuzana Light, 29, has become something of a fitness fetish. Her calorie-clobbering workouts are watched on YouTube by about 25 million visitors each month. Yet just five years ago, she was emotionally adrift in her native Prague, earning her keep as a nude model. ''It was an incredibly humiliating situation,'' she said. On vacation, she met her future husband and partner, Frederick Light, who brought her back to Ontario, where the couple worked at a flower shop and filmed exercise videos in their free time. Light's workout relies on ''short, intense'' exercises that riff on the burpee, a suicide sequence of squats, push-ups and jumping that's catching on at gyms across the country. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ALTMAN--Meyer (Mike) (19212011), passed away peacefully on October 12. Born in Kishnev, Romania, Mike came to the US at age three. He was awarded the Bronze Star for heroic service in WWII as a medic in the 11th Army Armored Division. Mike was President of Altman Association and, in retirement, an active volunteer for Yonkers Public Library and the Jewish Council of Yonkers. A man of great integrity, admired by all, he will be remembered for his beautiful smile that could light up a room and warm outgoing nature. He is mourned by his beloved wife Shirley Leinwand, her family, his sisters Annie, Minnie and Dorothy, his brother Ike, and loving nieces and nephews.

Also survived by Sylvia's children, Alex (Miriam), Rebecca (Nicholas), David and Sylvia's five grandchildren. Also survived by his former wives, Katherine and Jeannie. Jack was a successful businessman, and avid golf and tennis player, pilot, horseman and dog lover. A charitable man who lived a very full life.

''A T-shirt?'' asked the Lanvin shopgirl on the other end of the receiver when I inquired about logo tees. ''We sell blouses. Have you tried calling the outlets?'' My recent sartorial scavenge was prompted by Celine's resort collection. I was already head over heels for the discreet French label, but then Phoebe Philo, its designer, showed an in-your-face Celine-tagged top, styled smartly beneath a bustier and a prim, tailored jacket. Only Philo could make blatant branding compulsively collectible so soon after we'd all stripped the initials (save our own) off our bags and sunglasses. ''I've heard they keep them in the back,'' said a saleswoman at Jeffrey when I went there looking for logos. ''That's the secret,'' he added. ''You have to ask.'' A recent trip to Yves Saint Laurent confirmed this to be true. ''We wouldn't be YSL if we didn't have an inscribed T-shirt, would we?'' the sales associate coyly whispered to me before returning from the stockroom with a yummy stash of initialed tees in navy and magenta. ''We'll always have them.'' Blouses, that is. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Late Patriots Drive Chips at the Jets' Foundation,'' Oct. 11: The Jets' defense is not solely to blame for the team's lack of production. The Jets have a ground-and-pound offense, and their production has decreased since 2009, when Rex Ryan took over as the coach. In 2009, the Jets were first with 172.2 rushing yards a game. In 2010, that number fell to 148.4, fourth in the N.F.L.

''I LIKE to think of our Web site as a bar,'' Bruce Weber said of the new BruceWeber.com, which was reintroduced this week. ''It's like I'm showing my film and somebody from my studio is showing some pictures and somebody else is reading their poetry. It's the bar you always went to after school, in college.'' With no closing time -- and no drinks (B.Y.O.B!) -- the site hosts selected fashion photos, ad campaigns, music videos, commercials and documentaries spanning the last three decades of Mr. Weber's career alongside paintings from a show by the artist Jeremy Everett (a friend of Mr. Weber's), an appreciation of Simone de Beauvoir's book about Brigitte Bardot and high praise for Danny DiMauro, a barber in Montauk, N.Y. The bar you went to in college was never this cool. Shown: Calvin Klein campaign, 1987. HOLLY BRUBACH
