May he rest in peace. Ron and Cecil

NICHOLAS RICIGLIANO, U.S. MARSHAL, SENIOR INSPECTOR: That morning we were going to arrest a suspect in Queens, who was wanted out of Pennsylvania for numerous counts of sexual assault on 12- and 13-year-old girls. We captured him shortly after this photo was taken. What's going through your head is, you're going down a mental checklist. Basically, are we at the right address? Do we have all the exits? And have we given out the assignments to make sure we have the whole perimeter covered? What could we possibly expect? And different scenarios, like if the guy opens fire, where's the nearest hospital? You know, if the guy's not there, what's the next course of action?

I met Patti Smith at the Electric Lady recording studios on West Eighth Street in Manhattan on a sunny August afternoon. Both the place and the date have a special significance in Smith's personal mythos and in the broader mythology of rock 'n' roll. The facility, which you enter through a nondescript storefront on a once famously scruffy block now given over to discount shoe stores and student-friendly eating places, was Jimi Hendrix's brainchild, and it stands as an enduring part of his legacy. A rack in the reception area is stocked with foldout LP sleeves of some of the legendary records that were cut here - Stevie Wonder's ''Talking Book,'' AC/DC's ''Back in Black,'' David Bowie's ''Young Americans'' - and the psychedelic murals that Hendrix commissioned line the subterranean hallways leading to Studio A. There, his portrait hangs in the lounge, a benevolent godhead gazing down at the latter-day strivings of his fellow musicians. ''Actually, this coming Friday is the 41st anniversary of when it opened,'' Smith told me as she settled into a couch under Hendrix's gaze. She is, by her own admission, a prodigious talker, seeming at once to choose her words carefully and to wander through mazes of memory and free association. ''And it's also the anniversary, which is so amazing to me, of when I met Jimi Hendrix on the steps.'' This was at a party to which Smith, then a young journalist, had been invited. ''But I was too shy to go in. I was sitting out on the steps in my straw hat, and my polka-dot dress, whatever I was wearing back then, and Jimi was on his way out, and he stopped to talk to me. He took 10 minutes to tell me about his hopes and dreams for the studio. It was an amazing thing that happened. I was, like, 22 at the time, and I had no aspiration to record - no thought that I would ever make a record in my life.''

JONES-CASON--Ruth Ellyn. Born and raised in Kansas, Ruth graduated from Nursing School and moved to New York City after a tour of duty in Vietnam, where her outstanding nursing skills evolved. She was a devoted mother and grandmother to her daughter, Glenda, son-in-law Fernando, and their son and daughter , and Ruth's son Christian and daughter-in-law, Neeta. Ruth brought her considerable talents to Mount Sinai Hospital and became an invaluable asset to the Department of OB/GYN for almost 30 years. Her unique clinical abilities served as an inspiration to me and many of my colleagues during our Residency training. She was a superb mentor on the labour floor, maintaining calm confidence during critical obstetric situations. Ruth displayed remarkable compassion towards per patients. Being an exemplary professional, she enhanced the years of my training and practice, for which I remain so grateful. Her memory will be cherished by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Rebecca, Nachamie, MD and Family

No matter how many tickets and t-shirts a tour sells, the Arctic Monkeys still sleep on the bus. When you're a teenager, you drive in a van from Sheffield to small-town gigs across England, party every night, meet girls: everything moves fast and you like it. Your song about some girl who looks ''good on the dance floor,'' which rhymes a reference to the Montagues and Capulets with ''banging tunes and D.J. sets,'' leads to Internet fame, the fastest-selling debut in British history and, in 2006, instant, MySpace-amplified international stardom. But then years and albums go by. More ...

The Cyprus-born, London-based beauty applies the same principles to home décor and personal style as she does to designing clothing, accessories and store interiors for her label, Caramel Baby & Child. ''I like things to be casual and comfortable, but also elegant and chic,'' she says. ''Informal formality, so to speak.'' Her closet, filled with pieces by Prada, Marni and Rochas, reflects a penchant for pops of color, lush fabrics, refined prints and clean tailoring -- the same attributes that separate Caramel from other kiddie companies

Last spring I met Patti Smith to discuss her art -- specifically her photographs, of which there is a selection at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford that opens on Oct. 21. Smith told me over lunch that taking pictures is one of the reasons that she has continued to tour these past decades (that and supporting her band, of course). But music has given her a means to see the world and to record it with her quiet, romantic and magnificently narrative eye. It is this synchronicity that A. O. Scott captures in his profile of Smith (''Requiem Lass,'' Page 94) as he goes into the studio -- Hendrix's Electric Lady, no less -- and behind the lens with this wonderfully original American artist. This issue is filled with artists who follow their own inclinations with tenacity and style. There are the Arctic Monkeys (Page 92), who tour the world with a Ping-Pong table to let off steam between sold-out shows. There is Kirsten Dunst (Page 98), who we have watched grow up on screen, from Mary Jane in ''Spider-Man'' to Marie Antoinette to Justine, the central figure in Lars von Trier's ''Melancholia,'' for which Dunst won best actress at Cannes. There is the British folk sensation Laura Marling (Page 106), whose precociousness as a songwriter keeps garnering accolades and astonishment from the music press. There is the singer Zola Jesus (Page 36; listen to her new album, ''Conatus'') and the actress Amber Heard (Page 29), arguably the coolest bombshell to emerge from Hollywood in some time. (See her in ''The Rum Diary'' and NBC's ''The Playboy Club.'')

KELLER--Frederick A. A major creative force in Western New York theater, education and film, and a pioneer in Buffalo television broadcasting, died Wednesday, October 5 in Los Angeles. He was 92. In 1947, Mr. Keller was one of four employees of WBEN Radio, then owned by The Buffalo Evening News, assigned to visit various experimental television stations around the country in preparation for the start-up of Buffalo's first TV station WBEN, now WIVB-TV. Shortly after the station began scheduled programming, Mr. Keller was appointed program director, a position he held until he left the company in 1962. In those daysmost of our programs were produced 'live' in our studios or on location, Mr. Keller wrote in a brief biography he penned in April 1997. As program director he created, produced, wrote, directed and supervised telecasts as they were going out on the air, including the first-ever dramatic weekly series to be televised, The Clue. That series, which lasted for five years, gave Academy Award-winning actor Broderick Crawford and Lorne Green of TV's Bonanza fame, their first acting opportunities in television. Mr. Keller also produced the first educational series of programs for children seen in Western New York. In those days, I had high hopes for television as an educational medium for the betterment of our world, Mr. Keller said. Mr. Keller also helped bring a number of important foreign and domestic art films to Buffalo, through the Circle Art and Glen Art theatres. He also appeared in a number of films, making his screen debut in the 1970 George Stevens film The Only Game in Town, starring Elizabeth Taylor and Warren Beatty. While living in Paris for seven years, Mr. Keller dubbed some 400 foreign films into English. He also portrayed the title character in a 1981 adaptation of Natalie Babbit's award-winning novel, Tuck Everlasting, directed by his son, Frederick K. Keller and co-wrote and starred in the 1987 independent film My Dark Lady, starring Buffalo actress Lorna Hill. On the stage, Mr. Keller Played Willy Loman in the 1960 Studio Arena production of Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman. The following year, he took the Grand Island Players' presentation of Miller's A View from the Bridge to the Festival International du Theatre in Monaco. He also directed other notable productions, including works such as Lorraine Hansberry's A Raisin in the Sun and Ossie Davis' Purlie Victorious. Mr. Keller taught acting, film and theater courses at the University at Buffalo, Erie Community College, Canisius College, Medaille and Niagara County Community College. Born in Buffalo, New York he was a graduate of South Park High School. He earned his bachelor's degree in general education from Buffalo State College and his master's degree in the foundations of education at the University at Buffalo. Mr. Keller was a captain in Army intelligence during World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star. He was part of a team of army intelligence officers who determined during the Battle of the Bulge that the Germans were recycling names of divisions instead of sending new troops to the front lines, which ultimately led to victory. Since 2000, Mr. Keller had lived in retirement in Southern California with his son and daughter-in-law. He taught a weekly course on Shakespeare and wrote a book on the Shakespeare authorship question, Spearing the Wild Blue Boar which was published when Mr. Keller was 90. Last year, at 91, he performed in David Mamet's The Duck Variations. He is survived by his wife Joyce D. Keller Ph.D. and son, film and television director Frederick King Keller. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, October 22 at 1:00pm at Gates, Kingsley & Gates Moeller Murphy Funeral Directors, The Little Chapel of the Dawn, 1925 Arizona Avenue, Santa Monica.

In 1979, George Segal, the famous Pop artist, was commissioned to create a sculpture to commemorate New York City's Stonewall uprising in 1969 - the seminal (although not the only) event to kick-start the gay liberation movement. The bronze sculpture, covered with a white patina, was finally unveiled in Christopher Park in Greenwich Village in 1992, after years of controversy. It depicts a life-size male couple standing a few feet away from another life-size female couple sitting on a park bench. Beth Suskin, my partner of 35 years, and I, Leslie Cohen, were the models for this sculpture. This is our love story. August 1965. My mother and my friend Lois have accompanied me on the 400-mile drive from Bayside, Queens, to Buffalo State, a teacher's college, where I am to begin my freshman year. After we unpack and settle in, we decide to explore the campus. As we walk past room after room, my mother suddenly stops at an open door. Uh, oh. Her Jewdar has picked up familiar accents. Before I can stop her, she sticks her head into the doorway. Beth's parents look up from the large trunk they are unpacking. Beth is preoccupied - giving instructions. My mother greets them as if they were long lost cousins, and we begin sharing our information. ''Where are you from?'' ''N.Y. - Queens - and you?'' ''Hewlett Harbor.'' ''Oh, really?! Did you just arrive?'' ''Yes.'' ''Is Beth a freshman too?'' ''Yes.'' ''Oh, maybe you two can be friends,'' my mother says. ''Wouldn't that be nice?'' I self-consciously look at Beth and see that she is beautiful - way beyond ordinary beautiful. She is elegant, like Catherine Deneuve. We smile. ''I'm sure I'll see you on campus,'' I say. And we move on. She was the first freshman I met at Buffalo State.

The 4-1 San Francisco 49ers will face the 5-0 Detroit Lions on Sunday, and if it feels as though it has been a while since they have had a relevant game against each other, that is because it has been. Although the former N.F.L. West foes have played 61 times over the past 62 seasons and have combined for five Super Bowl wins and three N.F.L. championships, this will be only the 12th time in the regular season that they have met when both had winning records.

I didn't think I was a good candidate for facial acupuncture. For one thing, the only time I'm perfectly still is when I'm asleep (or getting an expensive haircut). And quite frankly, if I'm going to be stuck with needles, I would like them to deliver the kind of instant gratification that only Botox can provide. That said, when I heard there was a kind man in Midtown who would listen to my problems (but not judge me), calm me down (without meds) and erase my fine lines (without toxins or fillers), all in under an hour, I snagged the first available appointment. The designer Norma Kamali (who is 66 but looks more like 46) turned me on to Dr. Jingduan Yang, the director of the acupuncture and Oriental medicine program at Thomas Jefferson University Hospitals and the medical director of the Tao Institute of Mind and Body Medicine, which has locations in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Manhattan.

A bona fide shopping destination, Larimer Square in downtown Denver has had a colorful history. The area thrived during the gold and silver rushes of the 19th century, filled with saloons, hotels and stores catering to miners headed for the surrounding mountains. After the rush ended, the neighborhood fell into disarray, but in the 1960s, a group of local businesspeople, led by the Denver preservationist Dana Crawford, started buying up century-old buildings with the goal of making Larimer a retail center. Chains like Williams-Sonoma soon invigorated the neighborhood; eventually, more homegrown boutiques started opening. Now, its collection of retail outlets, spread along a short block strung with lights, are mostly owned by locals. The stores stand out thanks to their personable feel -- chances are that the salesperson helping customers is also the owner. SHIVANI VORA

The first ice bar in Patagonia, Argentina, opened last week just outside the town of El Calafate. GlacioBar, billed as the only bar in the world made out of glacial ice, is the latest addition to Glaciarium, a new science museum dedicated to the region's hundreds of glaciers. Visitors to the bar receive futuristic-looking capes, gloves and boots for warmth. Still, the maximum allowed stay is 20 minutes, just enough time to try the house cocktail: Fernet con Coca, a bitter, aromatic digestive served with Coca-Cola.

BEFORE the multimillion-dollar purses, slowly panning cable documentaries and glitzy celebrity venues, there was this: a young boxer in a ring, surrounded by paint-chipped walls, hoarse-voiced trainers and smoke-shrouded promoters. If there was glamour to be found, it was in the dreams that struggled to survive against the odds. Jules Allen first stepped into the famed Gleason's Gym in 1983 -- when it was still in Manhattan, where he was a relatively new photographer. He had gone there to train -- which he did with Bobby McQuillan, who had also put Miles Davis through the paces. Mr. Allen was in his own way as hungry as any up-and-coming boxer: he had a vision of how he wanted to document African-American culture. He wanted to portray his subjects as people who were powerful and in control.

Until the mid-20th century, the world's greatest artworks were cataloged in shoeboxes. Then along came the computer, and for the first time, museums had a more efficient way to organize their holdings than the boxfuls of dog-eared index cards that had served them for generations. But they kept on using the shoeboxes.

MARION--John Addison, 77, died of cancer at his home in Manhattan on October 14. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Loretta, his daughter, Cyndy, and her fiancee, Vanessa, and his younger brother, Paul. John was born on October 25, 1933, the son of Julius J. and Helen Borden Marion of Maplewood, NJ. A '55 graduate of Amherst College, he served three years in the U.S. Air Force and was a SAC air-refueling pilot reaching the rank of Captain. He completed Officers' Training at Chase Bank; then, in the early '60's he set out to tour the world as a cruise director. He later became an executive and partner in the L.J. Charrot Co. in New York City. John served on the Board of Directors at The Players on Gramercy Park South and was an avid fundraiser for White Horse Theater Co. He is remembered as a loving, supportive husband and father, a loyal and generous friend to many, and a true lover of life. A public memorial visitation will be held on Tuesday, October 18th from 5 to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Amherst College Crew Fund, P.O. Box 5000, Amherst College, Amherst, MA 01002.

''I got an e-mail that said, 'Lars is obsessed with you for this part, you're Skyping with him tomorrow.' He was very shy and sweet, and then it was like - O.K., done,'' recalls Kirsten Dunst over sorbet and strawberries, describing how she came to play Justine, the central character in ''Melancholia,'' Lars von Trier's astonishing end-of-the-world flick. In person, Dunst is stunningly unpretentious. (When a taxi driver wonders why a paparazzo is bothering the fragile blond woman he has just picked up, she points to her face and jokes, ''Hello? 'Spider-Man'?'') At least on the surface, she has nothing in common with the magical, moody Justine, a character she describes as a ''romantic depressive, maybe even from another planet.'' Whoever Justine is, this haunting film (it gave one viewer, me, nightmares for weeks afterward) is hardly a joy ride. But Dunst insists the workplace atmosphere was anything but gloomy. ''The family on the set was so wonderful,'' she says, especially the two Charlottes - Gainsbourg, who plays her sister, and a riveting Rampling as her mother. ''For such an unfunny subject, it was so much fun. And hanging out with Lars - he is the funniest, but it takes a second to get used to his sense of humor.''

SEBAG-MONTEFIORE--Harold Henry, died peacefully on October 5th in Kensington, London. Beloved husband of Harriet, adored father of Jenny and much loved grandfather of Rafe. Funeral was held on October 9th.

BEHAR--Joyce, April 11, 1958 - October 10, 2011. Born in Far Rockaway, she lived in Manhattan until the time of her death. Joyce is survived by her mother Gloria Behar and father Albert Behar, formally of Woodmere, NY currently living in San Diego, CA. Her loving family and friends will miss her forever. Joyce devoted her life to helping others, touching the lives of everyone she met, with her compassion, love and wit. May she be in peace.

WARD--Milton Hawkins Milton Hawkins Ward, 79, of Kerrville, Texas passed away on October 13, 2011 in San Antonio. He was born in Lipscomb, Alabama to William Ward and Mae Ivy Smith on August 1, 1932. He married Sylvia Adele Randle on June 30, 1951 in Lipscomb, Alabama. Mr. Ward found great joy in his family, his profession and his personal development. During his career, Mr. Ward directed or was responsible for exploration, planning, development, processing, smelting, marketing and other activities in the mineral industry on six of seven continents. Mr. Ward's experience covered the world and spectrum of metals, minerals and ores ranging from A to Z, (Antimony to Zinc and Australia to Zambia). Mr. Ward's success and rise to meeting the upper ranks of management was fostered by the support of the wonderful cadre of individuals who helped him meet the challenges of the business in a creative and cost effective manner, by a desire to keep abreast of new techniques and an ability to gain the assistance of all levels of the operations that led to cost reductions and improved performance, morale and profitability. Mr. Ward relished creating and growing shareholder value of mining organizations. Mr. Ward was President, Chairman and CEO for Cypress Amax Minerals Inc. He was selected as CEO of the Year by Financial World and Wall Street Transcripts magazines. Mr. Ward was elected to the American Mining Hall of Fame, Copper Man of the Year by the New York Copper Club and the American Mining Hall of Fame. Mr. Ward received the AIME's William Saunders Gold Medal, the SME Daniel Cowen Jackling Award, National Mining Association's Distinguished Award, Distinguished Member of SME, and, numerous other industry accolades. Prior to Cyprus, Mr. Ward was President and COO with Freeport McMoRan Inc. Mr. Ward joined Freeport as Executive VP of Operations. Preceding Freeport, Mr. Ward was Vice President of Operations for Ranchers Exploration, Inc. Before Rancher's, Mr. Ward was General Manager of Homestake Mining Company's United Nuclear-Homestake Partners Mines. In addition, Mr. Ward was General Superintendent and Division Engineer for Kerr McGee Corporation. Mr. Ward's introduction to mining was as a Miner, Engineer, and Supervisor with San Manuel Copper Corporation. Mr. Ward enjoyed the structured learning and definitive goals provided by formal education. While working through the corporate ranks, Mr. Ward earned a PhD from University of London's Royal School of Mines. In addition, while working, he earned an MSc from the University of Alabama, where he was a member of the Hall of Fame and an MBA from University of New Mexico's Anderson School of Management where he was also a member of the Hall of Fame. Furthermore, Mr. Ward was awarded an Honorary PhD from the Colorado School of Mines. Prior to a life in mining, Mr. Ward earned a BSc from the University of Alabama. Mr. Ward was of humble beginnings, and he often cited the turning point in his life, as a young man, was when he joined the Boy Scouts of America. With the Scouts, Mr. Ward proved that he held the makings of success. Mr. Ward became an Eagle Scout and, later in life, was the National President of the Boy Scouts of America. In addition, Mr. Ward was with the National Academy of Sciences, Museum of Natural History, named Man of the Year for Achievement Rewards for College Scientists, was President of the New Orleans Art Museum and guided many other city, state and national; museums, universities and hospitals. Mr. Ward was a loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. Mr. Ward is survived by his wife Adele Ward; son Jeff Ward and daughter Lisa Ward; and grandchildren Jeff Ward Jr., Francesca Ward, Hunter Ward and Austin Ward. He was preceded in death by son, Milton Ward Jr. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to your local Boy Scouts of America. A private service will be held for the family in Kerrville, Texas. The family invites you to send condolences at: grimesfuneralchapels.com by selecting the "Send Condolences" link. Funeral services are entrusted to Grimes Funeral Chapels of Kerrville.

PATRICK COX'S Wannabe loafer, a design-y take on the trad schoolboy shoe, was a smash hit in the early '90s. Almost a million pairs were sold every year. ''I was just a kid in England doing this thing that became gigantic and global,'' said Mr. Cox, who was 31 at the time. Then came what he now calls his Second Album Syndrome. ''Wannabe was so huge,'' he reflects. ''So big. So unexpected.'' What could he possibly do to top it? Though the company chugged along for a few years, Mr. Cox eventually sold it in 2007. He traveled. He opened a bakery. Until a serendipitous meeting with executives from the shoe giant Geox ushered him back into the footwear world earlier this year. Cut to Las Vegas and the Colosseum at Caesars Palace, where Elton John wore a custom-made pair of Mr. Cox's Geox gold metallic wingtips for the recent premiere of his new show, ''The Million Dollar Piano.'' ''Elton being Elton, we couldn't just do a brown brogue,'' Mr. Cox said. Though the rainbow metallic wingtips are strictly for the Rocket Man himself, the Patrick Cox collection for Geox, debuting in the spring with around 40 styles for men and women, is set to finally prove he's no one-hit wonder. BRUCE PASK

PERKINS--Jane Howard, (Mrs. Albert Carson Perkins). Born December 27, 1912. Died October 13, 2011. Daughter of Roy Wilson Howard and Margaret Rohe Howard. Sister of Jack R. Howard. Wife of Capt. Albert Carson Perkins, USN (Ret.). Mother of Anthony Carson Perkins, Timothy Howard Perkins, and Jennifer Perkins. Aunt of Pamela Howard and Michael B. Howard. Grandmother of Roy Howard Perkins, Mary Jane Perkins (Kissel), Elizabeth Perkins, Sierra R. Perkins, Chandra V. Perkins, and Tabitha S. Perkins. Great- grandmother of Roy Howard Perkins, Jr., John Perkins Muja, Sofia Rose Muja, James Timothy Kissel, Brian Earl Kissel, and Andrew Joseph Kissel. She was born and raised in New York City. Attended Spence School, Rosemary Hall, and graduated cum laude from Radcliffe College. Studied archaeology at Radcliffe (Harvard) and participated in early excavations at Chichen Itza. Working for the Honolulu Advertiser in the late 1930's, she traveled to the Far East on Pan Am's maiden trans-Pacific clipper flight, where she interviewed Mme. Chang Kai-Shek and gave an eyewitness account of the Japanese bombing of China. Lived for many years in Rome, Italy with her husband of 38 years, Cy, after he retired from the Navy, returning to live on Long Island and finally settling in Manhattan after his death. At the end she was surrounded by family and friends and died peacefully in her sleep.

Melissa and Emily Elsen, two sisters from South Dakota, opened Four & Twenty Blackbirds, their pie and coffee shop in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, with the expectation that they would serve about 10 pies a day. A little over a year later, they are averaging more like 50 pies a day, with customers traveling from around New York City to sample their fresh, seasonal fillings, like blueberry rhubarb or strawberry balsamic. Though they are doing a brisk business, the sisters Elsen continue to make their crust from scratch, two pounds at a time. ''We love the homespun, hands-on intensity of it,'' Emily says. ''When you make a good pie crust, it's really gratifying.'' ABBY AGUIRRE

In Metropolitan's cover article last week, ''A Judge's Education, One Sentence at a Time,'' Benjamin Weiser chronicled the difficult decisions that Judge Denny Chin, now on the United States Court of Appeals, confronted during nearly 16 years as a federal trial judge in New York. Below is a sampling of NYTimes.com readers' comments. Readers also squared off over Ginia Bellafante's Big City column about Providence Hogan, who is charged with stealing about $100,000 from a Brooklyn PTA while she was its treasurer. I had the good fortune to observe a trial over which Judge Chin presided while he was still serving as a trial judge for the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. He was fair in all of his rulings and he demonstrated a complete command of the law. I was truly impressed. We will all be fortunate if he should be selected for elevation to the Supreme Court at the next opportunity.

Oliver Laric is an artist who rarely has anything new to say. His work frames the creative potential of repetition, championing the idea of "the copy" as denser in meaning and, in this day and age, somehow more genuine, than any notion of a true "original." A copy has simply lived more: it contains within it not just the image or idea at hand, but also the imprint of time, place or identity linked with that moment as well as the motive of duplication. "Versions," Laric's video treatise on this subject, features an animated slide show of contemporary copies (the infamously Photoshopped 2008 image of missile tests in Iran, in which the missiles were cloned for heightened visual impact; Internet memes like the Zidane head butt, remixed and disseminated by users around the world); and historical antecedents (recycled character animations from early Disney movies; figurative archetypes taken from classical sculpture) that trace its relevance back to far before copy and paste was a way of life. Laric updates the piece regularly, and now a handful of versions of "Versions" are circulating online with many of his other works, causing discrepancies and redundancies that surface as a digitally savvy form of authenticity.

My father has always said that raising children is a process of letting go. From the moment your children are born, your job is to prepare them to function in the world without you, and perhaps your biggest challenge is preparing yourself for that separation. I couldn't help hearing my father's voice this weekend, while reading Emily Rapp's moving piece in The Times's Sunday Review about having a son with Tay-Sachs, a rare and untreatable genetic disorder from which he will probably die before he turns 3. As Ms. Rapp writes, her story is closer to most of ours than we would like to imagine: on some level, we are all getting ready for the day when our children leave us or we leave them. Read her story, "Notes From a Dragon Mom," and then come back here to share your thoughts.

Regulators have faced a barrage of complaints from lawmakers and financial industry lobbyists in their 14-month-long quest to constrain risky trading on Wall Street, an effort known as the Volcker Rule. Now, as regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves. Though several federal agencies agreed last week to propose the initial version of the Volcker Rule, they are divided over some of its crucial details. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, for example, has pushed for tough language that would require bank executives to vouch for their compliance with the Volcker Rule - a measure that the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency has been fiercely resisting, say people close to the regulators.

TARR--William J. A sweet and courageous man, passed away due to a stroke on October 16, 2011. He was 82. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Judy (Fantel) Tarr, his son Paul, wife Wendy, and granddaughter Vivian, and some very special nieces and nephews. Bill was distinguished by his decency, kindness and spirited nature, and his ability to make people laugh and think with gentle, incisive humor. He was admired and respected in the building specifications industry where he made his career and by his colleagues at Modernfold/Styles, his employer for 43 years. In addition to his family, Bill loved art, athletics and New York City. He was a life-long art student and sculptor, dedicated museum-goer, a competitive sprinter in his youth and a devoted Yankees fan since the 1930's. He will be sorely missed - this dear man who charmed and disarmed all who were fortunate to know him. Funeral services to be held on Wednesday, October 19, at 9:45am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders or The DOE Fund.

Hollywood's box-office blues continued over the weekend as remakes of ''Footloose'' and ''The Thing'' fizzled. ''Real Steel'' (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 by a sliver, taking in about $16.3 million for a two-week total of $51.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. ''Footloose'' stumbled in second place, selling an estimated $16.1 million in tickets, a frail result given the months-long marketing push that Paramount Pictures lavished on the film. The good news: ''Footloose,'' built around a cast of unknowns, cost only about $24 million to make. ''The Thing'' (Universal Pictures) was third with $8.7 million in ticket sales - not exactly a bloodbath given its production cost of about $38 million but a disappointment nonetheless. George Clooney's ''Ides of March'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth, taking in about $7.5 million for a two-week total of $22.2 million. ''Dolphin Tale'' (Warner Brothers) rounded out the top five with $6.3 million in ticket sales, lifting its four-week tally to $58.7 million. For the weekend, North American theaters recorded $89 million in ticket sales, a 32 percent drop from the same weekend last year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The availability of apps, free and paid, has grown exponentially since 2008. According to Mobilewalla, which tracks the apps industry, there were 11,000 Apple apps in 2008, a figure that jumped to 115,000 the next year. Today, there are 533,544 Apple apps -- including 195,544 new ones in 2011. The top apps are as varied as games like Traffic Rush, above, or GPS-driven tools like Trapster Speed Trap Alert (a free product). There are almost twice as many apps for Apple as for Android, the second-largest operating system, with 290,389. SHELLY FREIERMAN

LOS ANGELES - If the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences really plunks its new movie museum in the old May Company building on the corner of Wilshire Boulevard and Fairfax Avenue, should Johnie's Coffee Shop Restaurant - just across the street - be the first exhibit? It seems a fair question, given the role Johnie's has played in film history. Any serious student of this city's movie myths knows that the end of the world was tipped at 4:06 a.m. to Anthony Edwards, a k a the fictional Harry Washello, by a misplaced call to a phone booth outside Johnie's.

10 P.M. (HBO) SING YOUR SONG (2011) In 1956 Harry Belafonte (above, center) became the first recording artist to sell more than a million LPs with his album ''Calypso'' -- thanks in part to its smash single, ''Banana Boat (Day-O)'' -- and in the process broke color barriers as he rose to success during segregation. ''Get them to sing your song, and they will want to know who you are,'' his mentor Paul Robeson had counseled him following an early performance at the Village Vanguard. Still, although he went on to be honored with Grammy, Tony and Emmy Awards, Mr. Belafonte was blacklisted during the McCarthy era, harassed by the House Un-American Activities Committee, spied on by the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., and threatened by the Ku Klux Klan, state troopers and Las Vegas Mafia bosses. This documentary from Susanne Rostock distills more than 700 hours of interviews, excerpts from F.B.I. files and archival film footage to chronicle the life and times of Mr. Belafonte, now 84, from his birth in Harlem and his childhood in Jamaica to his work with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his struggle against apartheid in South Africa and his actions to counter gang violence and the incarceration of youth. Tony Bennett, Diahann Carroll, Ruby Dee, Whoopi Goldberg, Quincy Jones, Coretta Scott King, Miriam Makeba, Nelson Mandela, Sidney Poitier, Archbishop Desmond Tutu and Andrew Young comment. Mr. Belafonte's daughter Gina was a producer of the film. 8 P.M. (Fox) TERRA NOVA A girl seeks asylum in the compound while some suspect there is a traitor in their midst. In ''House,'' at 9, a philanthropist (Wentworth Miller) collapses after making a large charitable donation, leading House (Hugh Laurie) to suspect that the patient's altruism might indicate a mental disorder. Meanwhile Thirteen (Olivia Wilde) finds her guilt getting in the way of her happiness.

Four new monthly magazines advising business owners on how to use social media tools will go on sale on Monday. Each publication focuses on one of the major platforms: Twitter, Facebook, Google and LinkedIn. The magazines, published by GSG World Media, will cost $7.95 each at Office Depot stores. They will also be free in various digital formats to five million people who will receive an e-mail from Office Depot this week. The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced that Michael Boyd will step down as artistic director next year, after more than a decade in the job, the BBC News reported. The executive director, Vikki Heywood, will leave her post at the same time. Under their supervision, the company recently completed a $177 million renovation of its theaters in Stratford-Upon-Avon, England, and a successful six-week run of performances in New York at the Park Avenue Armory. Mr. Boyd is also a chief architect of the World Shakespeare Festival, a celebration set to run from April to September 2012. Mr. Boyd said in a statement that it was ''time for me to pass the challenges on to a new artistic director.'' The company is expected to announce a successor early next year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Stan Lee, a co-creator of childhood mainstays like Spider-Man, the X-Men and the Fantastic Four, will join with 1821 Comics to start a multimedia imprint for children called ''Stan Lee's Kids Universe.'' The imprint, announced at the New York Comic Con on Friday and reported on galleycat.com, is to feature five books, including ''Monsters vs. Kittens,'' created by Dani Jones, and ''Reggie the Veggie Crocodile.'' Also among their plans is a video game for iPhone and iPad. At a Comic Con panel presentation, Mr. Lee said, ''Our main purpose is we feel that there aren't enough comic books or books for kids that really hit the target, that gives them excitement and humor together and are filled with surprises. We have a whole new group of new characters that the kids can call their own, just as the teenagers called Spider-Man their own so many years ago.'' Mr. Lee is also collaborating with the 1821 Comics co-founder Terry Douglas, the writer Max Work and the artist Skan Srisuwan on a graphic novel, ''Romeo & Juliet: The War,'' a futuristic interpretation of the play - but with superpowers. The book is to be released in November. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Every week or so comes another signal that CBS is reshaping ''The Early Show,'' its low-rated morning newscast. On Monday will come another: the announcement that John Miller is joining the network as a senior correspondent with a special emphasis on the morning show. Mr. Miller, a fixture in media and law enforcement circles for decades, was most recently a deputy to the government's director of national intelligence. Once Mr. Miller ''put the word out'' about his decision to leave government, ''there was a lot of interest in him'' from television networks, said David Rhodes, the president of CBS News. At CBS, Mr. Miller will report and comment on homeland security, law enforcement and other matters.

Arthur Dubin, a leading historian of the golden age of American passenger railroads, when trains bore names like ocean liners and Champagne glasses were filled by elegantly attired servers, died on Oct. 3 at a nursing home in Riverwoods, Ill. He was 88. His death was confirmed by his son, Peter.

SIEGEL--Norman H. Dr. Norman H. Siegel, 91, passed away Monday, October 10, 2011. He was born March 23, 1920 in Manhattan, New York. He was preceded in death by his wife Grace. Norman attended PS79 and PS80 primary schools and Dewitt Clinton High School in the Bronx. He attended New York City University graduating with a degree as an MD. Dr. Siegel then was in the service of our country from 1942-1945, as a bomber pilot with the 9th Air Force. After the service he attended Pace University majoring in Educational Communications. Dr. Norman Siegel worked his way thru the ranks serving as Director of Public Health, Director of Model Health Plans, Director of Outreach Services, and ultimately served as Assistant Commissioner of Health for the city of New York. He was made a Fellow of American Public Health. Was president of New York City alumni Assoc. He was invited by the American Health Assoc. to train people in India on Health and Hygiene and establish the American Public Health counterpart program. Dr. Siegel also went to Egypt to study the causes of Ameobiasis. Dr. Siegel also published the first baby book for New York City School Days, a publication, which went to all children and parents going to school for the first time. He helped develop articles and publications on child health services. Dr. Siegel was responsible for educational services and development of continuing medical education for staff and medical community. He was responsible for producing community materials for display at the meeting of Health Organization for New York City. Dr. Siegel also received a commendation from the city of New York for initiating the practice of giving all newborns a social security number. He retired in 1982 and settled in Pinellas Park Florida. Dr. Siegel and his wife will be inurned with military honors at Bay Pines National Cemetery in Bay Pines, Florida. Services handled by Garden Sanctuary Funeral Home: 727-391-0121. gardensactuaryfunerals.com

SAN DIEGO -- Watching all those people juggling phones and tablets and e-readers in stores, subways and coffee shops, not to mention the many small shops continually offering new models of phones, you could think that there are more wireless devices than people. You would be right. Data released this week from CTIA, the wireless industry association, shows that there were 327.6 million wireless customer connections, equal to 103.9 percent of the United States population. This is the first time there have been more customers than people. It is also a 9 percent increase from the 300.5 million connections of a year ago. Not bad, for a country teetering near recession, where about one-third of the population lives with little or no discretionary income.

The Web is porous. Remarkable information trickles in from everywhere. It also sometimes spills out without its users knowing exactly where or how. Take for instance these findings, released on Tuesday by computer scientists at Stanford University. If you type a wrong password into the Web site of The Wall Street Journal, it turns out that your e-mail address quietly slips out to seven unrelated Web sites. Sign on to NBC and, likewise, seven other companies can capture your e-mail address. Click on an ad on HomeDepot.com and your first name and user ID are instantly revealed to 13 other companies.

SIDERIS--Niki. Founder and Chairman of the Ronald McDonald House New York Greek Division. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff wish to express our sincere sympathy over the passing of our friend, advisor, and Founder of the Greek Division at Ronald McDonald House New York, Mrs. Niki Sideris, who died on October 12, 2011. She was 70. Mrs. Sideris passed away while en route to New York City from her home in Greece. When the Ronald McDonald House opened its doors in New York City in 1978, Mrs. Sideris was there from the start. Among the many challenges faced by Greek families coming to New York City in search of better treatments and cures for their children's illness was the lack of affordable housing, an intimidating language barrier, and an inadequate family support system. Founding the Greek Division, Mrs. Sideris organized fundraising and educational events as a way to enlighten the local Greek community about Ronald McDonald House New York's mission to provide not just housing, but a comprehensive support system for families battling pediatric cancer. In addition to the Greek Holiday Party, Mrs. Sideris introduced the annual spring marathon event, which she referred to as her "Marathon of Love." She had arrived in New York City in 1970 where she met her late husband, Dr. Michael Sideris. They enjoyed a loving union that ended with his death in January 2005. Mrs. Sideris leaves behind her legacy of giving, kindness, and awareness of how a caring and compassionate community within New York City can give hope to thousands of families in crisis. A viewing will be held for Mrs. Sideris on Monday, October 17, 2011 from 3pm8pm, at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity at 319-337 East 74th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021. The liturgy will be held on Tuesday, October 18, 2011 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Ronald McDonald House New York at 405 E. 73rd Street, New York, NY 10021. For more information, contact Spiridoula Katechis at 212-639-0188. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting Mrs. Sideris as part of our family and love and care she offered so freely to those she touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

The First Battle of Bull Run, like freshman year of college, was a time for earning reputations - and nicknames. On that same afternoon when Confederate Gen. Thomas Jonathan Jackson won his moniker, "Stonewall," he bestowed an equally flattering reputation on a Union regiment called the 14th Brooklyn, which wore red wool trousers as part of their local militia uniform modeled after the French chasseurs. The 14th Brooklyn - the only regiment in the Union Army called by a city's name rather than a state - was giving Jackson and his troops quite a time on Henry House Hill, and at some point Stonewall braced his soldiers for yet another charge by shouting "Hold on Boys! Here come those red-legged devils again!"

The Frame section of the Frieze Art Fair, curated by Cecilia Alemani and Rodrigo Moura, made space for experimentation on the fair's fringes in the form of 25 solo artist presentations presented by a younger batch of international galleries. Among them was Alex Zachary, one of New York's most idiosyncratic galleries both in terms of space and location. (It has been operating out of a multilevel, formerly residential condominium a couple of blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.) Fittingly, the artist Ken Okiishi's project at Zachary's Frame booth was a curious meditation on the psychogeography of Manhattan real estate and mythologies of uptown bohemia. Eulogizing the recently shuttered Lexington Avenue establishment Gino as a point of departure (which over time has hosted luminaries as diverse as Sophia Loren, I. M. Pei and Robin Byrd), Okiishi began by outfitting the booth in the iconic Scalamandré-designed zebra wallpaper that made its debut in the restaurant's dining room circa 1930. He applied the same print to parasols bolted to the walls, whose slow and steady motorized twirling evoked bygone pageantry and ritziness. Faux-antique photographs of an early-20th-century apartment were hung beside the umbrellas; in actuality these were digital images lifted from the present-day Streeteasy.com listing for a unit on West 67th Street that was once home to Marcel Duchamp, from 1916 to 1918. East Side, West Side, Depression era, recession era: Okiishi's project drew foggy connections between places and times that are factually disparate but psychically proximate. These artifacts repurposed as ready-mades contribute to a meandering mental map of the city that relies on legends like Duchamp (and Gino's) as its compass.

The subset of women in America who most frequently make use of abortion services, writes Lauren Sandler in Slate this week, are mothers. In 2008, according to the Guttmacher Institute, 61 percent of women who terminated their pregnancies already had at least one child. And in the period since the economic woes of the recession started hitting families, the National Abortion Federation reported to Ms. Sandler, fully 72 percent of clients who came seeking abortion services were mothers.

London may be brimming with private members' clubs, but its latest - the newly revamped Arts Club in Mayfair - is creating quite a stir. Founded in 1863 by a group of friends (including Charles Dickens), the formerly fusty establishment has reopened with Gwyneth Paltrow (an investor) as its creative director. The stylish Art Deco-inspired interior designed by David D'Almada features marble floors, cashmere walls and art by Tomas Saraceno, John Baldessari and George Condo. Boldface names like Cameron Diaz, Mario Testino and Charlotte Dellal have been spotted supping in the restaurant, and Paltrow is known to belt out a few tunes at Club Nouveau, the nightclub downstairs that's run by Mark Ronson. Also on the mike at times are Ronnie Wood, Mica Paris and Noel Gallagher. It costs £1,000 to join, the same fee applies each year, and the first list closes on Oct. 31. Being famous and fabulous is not a requirement, but it doesn't hurt to be either, or both.

ABC and CBS settled for a split ratings victory on Monday night as "Dancing With the Stars" averaged 17.5 million total viewers over a two-hour period and led ABC to the highest total audience. CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, though "Two and a Half Men" continued to fall from its lofty early-season perch to 14.9 million total viewers, down another million viewers from last week. In this week's Critics' Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Robert Bresson's 1966 drama "Au Hasard Balthazar," which tells the story of a donkey in rural France and the girl who loves him. Mr. Scott points out that the film isn't a fairy tale about an animal with human qualities, but rather "an unsettling and tragic examination of some of the deepest mysteries of existence." Balthazar is the name of the donkey who is adopted by a family and befriended by Marie (Anne Wiazemsky).

Gentleman of varying persuasions of style are already familiar with the name Mark McNairy. Shoes from the designer's footwear collection, Mark McNairy New Amsterdam, and tailored pieces from the Ivy League-inspired outfitter J. Press, where McNairy was formerly creative director, have made their way into an eclectic mix of closets, from traditional to trendy. When it was announced this summer that McNairy would introduce a complete line of subversive-preppy clothes and accessories for men in the spring, all those fans cheered, and now - it's official - he's doing women's wear, too. Inspired by his daughter, Daisy, the 50-piece collection is charmingly boyish, but (very McNairy) sexily so, with oxford shirts paired with boyfriend boxers and rugby tanks over miniskirts. Echoes of some of the men's line motifs - a daisy print, an exploded camouflage and a floral-on-plaid shirt - mix easily with more overtly feminine pieces, like the ditsy Laura Ashley-like button-down. "Basically, I make women's clothes from a guy's point of view," McNairy says. "It has nothing to do with fashion - they're items that transcend trend."

As I reported in Tuesday's paper, opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plant assert that its two reactors can be retired in the next few years because alternatives exist that pose less risk and would not cost substantially more. New York City's position, however, is that retiring the reactors would raise prices sharply and reduce reliability.

The respected character actor Michael Cristofer will play Adolf Eichmann, locked in a battle of wills and wits with Mossad agents in 1960 Buenos Aires, in the new drama "Captors" at the Huntington Theater Company this fall, the company said on Tuesday. An outside team of commercial producers has already secured the rights to transfer the work to Broadway, which they hope to do during the 2011-12 season after the end of the Huntington run, a spokeswoman for the theater added.

Here are three reactions to my post about Machiavelli's view of the impediments to making big changes in societies -- as in the asymmetrical nature of the battle to take the carbon out of energy systems in the face of both societal inertia and intensive efforts by entrenched interests to maintain the status quo. The first two remarks came in a group e-mail exchange and so relate to each other.

These are uncertain times for many established writers, as the case of the Hawaiian novelist Kiana Davenport shows. Until recently she had a deal with Riverhead Books, a literary line that is a division of Penguin, for a Civil War novel, "The Chinese Soldier's Daughter." Ms. Davenport received an initial $20,000 advance for the tale, which was scheduled for publication next summer. That wasn't enough money to survive on, so the writer cast about for another source of income, and self-published a book of old stories on Amazon. The result: Her novel has been canceled, the publisher wants its money back, and her publishing career is in jeopardy.

On Sept. 15, Matthew Grape, 21, got into the passenger seat of a car with one of his Duke University fraternity brothers. The driver hit a tree, escaping with minor injuries, but killing his dear friend. According to local press reports, the driver was charged with impaired driving.

Ryan Avent and I have been corresponding about the role of the economics blogosphere, for the Christmas issue of The Economist. I don't know what parts of our conversation will actually show up there, but having assembled my thoughts I might as well put some of them up here.

It was perhaps only a matter of time before the D.I.Y. ethos touched the spa world, and it has done so with style in Portland, Ore., with Löyly, a handsome, minimalist sauna in the southeast quadrant of the city. The owner, Jessica Kelso, was inspired by traditional Scandinavian bathhouses - "löyly" is Finnish for the steam produced when water is poured over sauna rocks - and wanted to bring their sense of accessibility to Stumptown. "I felt like your choices in Oregon were a hippie hot springs experience or really spendy, overly attentive spa experiences, neither of which had ever appealed to me," she says. The Löyly vibe is one of communal shvitzing rather than solitary pampering. A $15 fee gets you access to an elegantly designed cedar sauna, wet steam room and lounge; though massages and facials are available by appointment, scrubs, salts, masks and foot soaks are do-it-yourself. The place has become as popular with corporate types as it is with the city's artists, musicians and restaurant servers. "Everyone looks the same wrapped in a white towel," Kelso says, "although we do see a lot of tattoos in Portland."

Most iPhone users blithely believe that their phones are safe from hackers. Jamie Masada will never forget the phone call last year that alerted him to the erasing of a chunk of his business and of his life. The call came from a manager at the online backup-storage company to which Mr. Masada had entrusted what might well have been the world's most valuable collection of stand-up comedy video - 1,500 hours of acclaimed comics performing on the stage of Mr. Masada's groundbreaking Hollywood comedy club, The Laugh Factory. Some of the video was historic, including Rodney Dangerfield's earliest performances and stars like Dave Chapelle and Dane Cook honing their acts before hitting it big. And much of it existed only on the servers of the data storage company.

Amelia Holowaty Krales had been anxious the morning she photographed a boy in pink shorts floating in a shallow pool of coastal water, eyes closed, toes pointed up. [Slide 1.] It was the "king tide" in Tuvalu, a small archipelago in the South Pacific that is threatened by rising sea levels.

Tuvalu, a tiny archipelago of nine South Pacific islands threatened by rising seas, is on the front lines of the planet's climate change debate. Current projections indicate that it will  become unlivable within 50 years, resulting in an exodus and the erasure of a rich 3,000-year-old culture.

On Oct. 18, 1968, the United States Olympic Committee suspended the medal-winning sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos from the American national team and barred them from the Olympic Village for their conduct during the playing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" at a medal ceremony at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. Mr. Smith, who won the gold medal, and Mr. Carlos, who took bronze in the 200-meter event, wore black gloves on the podium. As the American national anthem played, the two raised their fists in a gesture of support for the black power movement.

A besieged Congress party suffered a "resounding defeat" in the by-elections whose results were announced on Monday (Indian Express). While the Congress denied a downslide, maintaining that none of the seats were their strongholds, the BJP hailed the victory of its candidates as the "people's verdict against a corrupt Congress government" (The Hindu).

Kinder Morgan's planned $21.1 billion takeover of the El Paso Corporation is seen as a potential catalyst for consolidation in an unheralded but increasingly important part of the energy industry: the companies whose pipes carry the oil and gas. Kinder Morgan's deal is based on the belief that natural gas will become an increasingly important fuel for the nation, and that its growth is hampered by a lack of adequate pipeline networks.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about low-profit limited liability corporations, a new company structure that combines elements of nonprofit and commercial entities, referred imprecisely to one such company, MOOMilk. While the company, whose full name is Maine's Own Organic Milk Company, is incorporated as a low-profit limited liability corporation, or L3C, in Vermont, it is based in Augusta, Me. It is not ''of Vermont.''

Change that pencil marking on the political calendar to ink pen: The Iowa caucuses will be held on Jan. 3. The Republican Party of Iowa announced Monday that the precinct caucuses, a collection of neighborhood meetings across the state, will be held in the first week of the New Year. The contest has traditionally opened the presidential nominating contest.

An article on Oct. 8 about the sentencing of Emanuel Goffer, a hedge fund co-founder, for insider trading misstated the prison term range suggested by federal sentencing guidelines. It was 41 to 51 months, not 51 to 63 months.

Richard Dutrow Jr. is still in the horse racing business after a New York State Supreme Court judge on Monday granted a 30-day stay of the 10-year suspension handed down by state racing authorities. The suspension, announced last week by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, was supposed to begin Tuesday. Judge Richard Giardino heard arguments in Schenectady and allowed Dutrow to continue training as his lawyers prepare his appeal.

House paint has been a part of the modernist fine-art supply cabinet for more than a century, from Picasso to Pollock to Bridget Riley. Now the Guggenheim Museum is hoping to make some money by turning the phenomenon back in the other direction. The museum has entered into a licensing agreement with Fine Paints of Europe, a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints, to create a set of 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the Guggenheim's collection and from wall colors that curators, artists and designers (including Frank Lloyd Wright himself) have used for exhibitions over several decades. The artists' colors are drawn from paintings in the museum's collection by figures like Cézanne, van Gogh, Kandinsky and Franz Marc, whose ''Stables'' from 1913 provides a yellow that seems cheerful enough to brighten even the most depressing windows-look-out-onto-an-air-shaft New York apartment. Neither the museum nor the company disclosed the value of the licensing agreement. The paints range from $35 to $130 per can.

When shares of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters began trading on Monday morning, they held the distinction of being the best-performing stock on a major exchange over the last five years. Better than Apple. Better than Google. Better than Starbucks.

Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board

People with Barrett's esophagus, a complication of acid reflux disease, have a higher risk of developing esophageal cancer. But the risk is far smaller than believed, a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine has found. Researchers at Aarhus University in Denmark reviewed data gathered over nearly 20 years on more than 11,000 people with Barrett's esophagus. The analysis found that every year, 0.12 percent of the patients with Barrett's esophagus go on to develop cancer of the esophagus, a disease that is particularly lethal.

MULLEN--Peter P.,passed away on October 15th after a long struggle with cardiac issues. He was an accomplished man: He graduated cum laude from Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his LL.B. from Columbia Law School in 1951, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. He was a visionary attorney: He joined the firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom in 1961. He served formally as Skadden's executive partner from 1981 to 1994 (and informally prior to 1981), becoming a key architect of Skadden's growth globally. He was instrumental in establishing the Skadden Fellowship Foundation. Peter Mullen was highly respected by all in the legal community. Guided always by his Catholic faith, he championed many charitable causes. Among others, he was Chairman of the Georgetown University Board of Directors; he also served as Chairman and Board Member of both ORBIS International and the Gregorian University Foundation. He was President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. Other organizations he served included The Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, The Advisory Committee of The Southwest Legal Foundation, The Legal Aid Society, Volunteers of Legal Services, The United Way, The Cardinal's Committee of the Laity and the Vatican Observatory. He felt his greatest accomplishment was his family and the life he built on the shores of Lake Waramaug in Litchfield County, CT. He was happiest when he was surrounded by his loving wife of 56 years, Billie; his children, Peter, Kirby, Elaine, Lucy and Jeff and their spouses; and his nine grandchildren. He was an avid sailor, skier, golfer, tennis player, gardener, birdwatcher, bush-hogger and neighbor. He was a friend and advisor to all. All in all, a life well lived!! In the end, he was optimistic about life, he was able to celebrate an early Thanksgiving with his family, attend mass and go out to dinner. He will be greatly missed. All donations in honor of Peter Mullen should be made to The Gregorian University Foundation, Project ORBIS or The Lake Waramaug Task Force. Funeral services are being coordinated by McGrath Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY: www.mcgrathandson.com The Mullen Family

MULLEN--Peter. Bill and Marilyn Frank express their sincerest condolences and prayers to Billie and the entire Mullen family. Peter was the personification of the words gentleman, grace and dignity. He was a true leader and visionary, a great law partner, a friend and a model of character, conscience and charity for all of us. He will be sorely missed.

MULLEN--Peter P. On October 15, 2011. With great sadness, the attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Peter P. Mullen, the firm's first executive partner, an invaluable colleague and a cherished friend. He was 83 years old. Mr. Mullen formally served as Skadden's executive partner from 1981 to 1994 and informally for several years prior. He joined the firm in 1961 as an associate and was named partner in 1962. He became of counsel at the firm in 1998, and he recently celebrated his 50th anniversary at Skadden. Mr. Mullen was a key architect of Skadden's growth globally and was highly respected by all for his wise day-to-day leadership of our institution. Together with Joe Flom in 1988, Mr. Mullen helped establish the Skadden Fellowship Foundation, which has provided two-year fellowships to more than 600 young lawyers seeking to pursue public interest law. Mr. Mullen was a champion of numerous charitable causes, having served as a trustee, director or member of ORBIS International, The Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, The Advisory Committee of The Southwest Legal Foundation, The Legal Aid Society, Volunteers of Legal Services, The United Way, and The Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, among other organizations. He also was a member of the board of directors of the Gregorian University Foundation of New York and Rome, having served as chairman until last year. From 1985 to 1992, he was chairman of the Georgetown University Board of Directors. Mr. Mullen was a member of the New York State Bar Association Committee on Securities Regulation from 1980 to 1983. Mr. Mullen graduated cum laude from Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his LL.B. from Columbia Law School in 1951, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. We join his wife Billie, sons Peter and Jeff, and daughters Kirby, Elaine and Lucy, as well as his nine grandchildren, in honoring his memory. All donations in honor of Peter Mullen should be made to The Gregorian University Foundation, Project ORBIS or The Lake Waramaug Task Force. Funeral services are being coordinated by McGrath Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY: www.mcgrathandson.com.

The health of Rick Ross, the Miami rapper, below, was unclear Monday after a tumultuous weekend during which he fell ill twice while trying to fly from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Memphis and was taken to hospitals in two cities. He also failed to show up at performances on Friday and Saturday nights. There was scant official information about Mr. Ross's condition; Gabriel Tesoriero, a publicist for him, did not respond to telephone messages. On Friday afternoon a plane carrying Mr. Ross from Fort Lauderdale to Memphis had to return to Florida and make an unscheduled landing after he became ill. He was traveling to Memphis to perform at an open University of Memphis basketball practice. After being treated at a Fort Lauderdale hospital, Mr. Ross was released that evening and issued a statement via Twitter saying ''Memphis here I come.'' He chartered a jet for the trip. But the second plane was also forced to land unexpectedly, in Birmingham, Ala., after Mr. Ross became sick a second time. News outlets in Birmingham reported that Mr. Ross had been admitted to the University of Alabama-Birmingham Hospital, but a spokeswoman at the hospital, Jennifer Lollar, said he was not on the public list of patients. She said that some high-profile patients may opt not to be listed, and that the hospital releases no information about their condition. On Saturday Mr. Ross was to appear at a restaurant in Memphis and to perform in Greensboro, N.C. He canceled both appearances without explanation.

An article on Monday about a proposed engineering graduate school in New York City contained a number of errors. Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the university that has dropped plans for a partnership with City University to develop the school. It is Columbia University, not Stanford. Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to a partnership between Stanford and City College, a branch of City University. Such a partnership is indeed planned; it is not the case that Stanford officials said last week that the university would not enter such a partnership. The article also described incorrectly an unrelated 7-million-square-foot expansion that Columbia University is planning. A portion of the expansion that will be devoted to studying the brain will occupy about 7 percent of the space, not ''much of it.'' And the article referred incorrectly to the teaching of engineering at New York University. The university had a school of engineering at its Bronx campus until 1973; it is not the case that N.Y.U. did not have an engineering school ''until 2008.''

When the Brooklyn artist Kabir Carter, below, goes to Istanbul next week he will be the first of 15 Americans chosen by the Bronx Museum of the Arts as part of a collaboration with the State Department's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to bring art projects to 15 foreign countries. The initiative, known as smART Power, is part a $1 million program announced last year to expand cultural diplomacy around the world. When the Bronx Museum put out an open call for proposals this year, it got 900 applicants, from which it chose a mix of 15 emerging and established artists. They will travel to all parts of the globe, including China, Ecuador, Egypt, Ghana, India, Kenya, Kosovo, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Turkey and Venezuela, where they will work with local arts groups and artists to develop community-based projects. When Mr. Carter, a performance and installation artist, arrives in Istanbul, he will lead a series of workshops with local people to gather and preserve their oral histories. He will also produce sound installations and encourage people to document their daily lives. In January a Panamanian-born artist, Arturo Lindsay, will head to Egypt, the first of two trips he plans to take there. His mission: to establish a contemporary-art workshop that will encourage installation and performance art around the theme of ''bearing witness.''

9:29 p.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS - Representative Ron Paul on Monday unveiled an aggressive budget plan that would greatly shrink the federal government that he is seeking to run, eliminating the agency that oversees airport security, the Departments of Energy and Education and three others, while cutting all war financing. Providing a stark vision of what a libertarian takeover of the White House would look like, the plan would slash the federal budget by $1 trillion in a single year and, Mr. Paul said, bring the budget into balance within three.

WALD--Edward (Eddie) G. Founder and President of Lew Wald Inc., passed away October 15, 2011 leaving his loving wife Peggy Wald; children Eric Wald and wife Susan, Jaime Seymour-Newton and husband Rupert, Candice Clark and husband Sam; stepsons Kirk Morgan and wife Tamera and Kasey Morgan; grandchildren McKenna, Rachel, James, Patrick and Christopher. "Simple Elegance" was his mantra in business and in life. He is loved and missed. For info. jewish-funeral-home.com

Tony La Russa does many infuriating things as a manager. He changes pitchers frequently, he sours on young players quickly and he seems to be constantly trying to outsmart the opposing manager. He also wins baseball games. Lots and lots of baseball games. With yet another 90-win season, his 12th, La Russa's career win total is at 2,728, just 35 wins short of John McGraw for second on the career list. While Connie Mack, who is first on the list, once said, ''There has been only one manager, and his name is John McGraw,'' La Russa, who made the playoffs just once in his first 11 seasons, would certainly pass McGraw next season should he choose to return.

TARR--William J. A sweet and courageous man, passed away due to a stroke on October 16, 2011. He was 82. He is survived by his beloved wife of 50 years, Judy (Fantel) Tarr, his son Paul, wife Wendy, and granddaughter Vivian, and some very special nieces and nephews. Bill was distinguished by his decency, kindness and spirited nature, and his ability to make people laugh and think with gentle, incisive humor. He was admired and respected in the building specifications industry where he made his career and by his colleagues at Modernfold/Styles, his employer for 43 years. In addition to his family, Bill loved art, athletics and New York City. He was a life-long art student and sculptor, dedicated museum-goer, a competitive sprinter in his youth and a devoted Yankees fan since the 1930's. He will be sorely missed - this dear man who charmed and disarmed all who were fortunate to know him. Funeral services to be held on Wednesday, October 19, at 9:45am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders or The DOE Fund.

Despite all the bleak economic news, a funny thing has been happening in the financial industry over the last few months: the banks have quietly turned on the lending spigot. Loan growth is still modest. And it remains heavily weighted toward the strongest corporate and consumer borrowers. But after several quarters of having their loan balances plunge or flatten out, several of the nation's biggest banks are reporting increases.

(13, 49) LOST IN DETENTION In this ''Frontline'' co-production with the Investigative Reporting Workshop, Maria Hinojosa investigates President Obama's immigration enforcement strategies and looks at some of the more than one million deportations that have taken place since he took office. (Above, a detainee awaiting processing in Phoenix.) Amid complaints of abuse and harsh treatment and charges that families have been unfairly separated, the administration has promised to make the detention system more humane. (Cinemax) SHERLOCK HOLMES (2009) Robert Downey Jr. and Jude Law adorn themselves with varying amounts of facial hair to play Arthur Conan Doyle's crack sleuth and his sidekick. Mr. Downey portrays Holmes, and Mr. Law, above right, with Mr. Downey, is Watson, in this Guy Ritchie adaptation set in ''a smoky, greasy, steam-punk rendering of Victorian London, full of soot and guts and bad teeth and period clothes,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Rachel McAdams plays a thief ''inserted into the picture in a pretty, flouncy red dress to add a splash of color and dispel a few hints of homoerotic subtext,'' he added. Mark Strong is an evil aristocrat, executed for a string of murders, who appears to have returned from the dead to mobilize an ancient secret society. ''Best of all is the banter between Mr. Downey and Mr. Law, who is looser and more mischievous than he's allowed himself to be in quite some time,'' Mr. Scott wrote.

This summer, Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, flew to Chicago to personally pitch his firm to underwrite what was supposed to be the hottest initial public offering of the year: Groupon, the fledgling online coupon company that was being valued at around $30 billion. Mr. Blankfein's pitch succeeded and Goldman was selected as one of three lead underwriters, including Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse. As the summer progressed, some insiders whispered that the offering could value the company at even more. For Wall Street, the I.P.O. was the ultimate bragging right.

NOTABLE NUMBER The last three weeks, the Jets have complained about the challenges of playing from behind. On Monday night, they trailed for all of 96 seconds. Their offense did not operate any differently with a lead, but that 7-3 advantage shifted the pressure to the defense, which, despite its own troubles, seems better equipped to handle it. The Jets went on to maintain their lead for the final 50 minutes 52 seconds, a relative eternity for them.

An article on Wednesday about a painting on loan to the Mary Brogan Museum of Art and Science in Tallahassee, Fla., that a federal prosecutor says might have been stolen from a Jewish family during World War II referred incompletely to a way museums may protect works on loan to them from being impounded by federal officials in ownership disputes. While American museums that receive such loans from abroad can indeed apply to the State Department for immunity from seizure before the objects enter the United States, the museums cannot be granted such immunity once an object has entered the country.

NEIDENBERG--Edith "Peggy" (Ruskay), passed away on Sunday, October 16 at the age of 93. A graduate of Woodmere Academy, she returned to college after the deaths of husbands Everett Ruskay and Lou Neidenberg and earned her BSW at the age of 63. She had a love for the arts, politics, gardening and most of all, her family. She is the beloved mother of Judy Ruskay Rabinor and John Ruskay, mother-in-law of Larry Wetzler and Robin Bernstein, grandmother of Ilana Ruskay-Kidd, Darone Ruskay, Rachel Rabinor, Zachary Rabinor, Hilary Cymrot, Joshua Bernstein and Max Bernstein and eight great-grand-children. Her memory will be cherished by all who knew her. Funeral October 18, 11:15am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

One of stalwarts of the restructuring world, the boutique investment bank Miller Buckfire, plans to name Harvey Golub its chairman on Tuesday, bringing in a financial services veteran to help oversee a revamping of its operations. The appointment of Mr. Golub, the former chief executive of American Express and a former chairman of the American International Group, comes amid major changes for the nine-year-old firm. Earlier this year, Miller Buckfire struck a partnership with Stifel Financial in a bid to gain access to the bigger firm's financing capabilities, which could help it win new business. (Stifel has also indicated that it is interested in eventually buying Miller Buckfire outright.)

An article on Monday about the dedication of a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King on the National Mall erroneously attributed a distinction to the monument in some copies. While the monument is the first on the Mall and its adjoining parks honoring an African-American, it is not the first to honor someone who was not a president. (A monument was dedicated in 2002 to George Mason, who wrote the Virginia Declaration of Rights and has sometimes been referred to as the ''forgotten founding father.'')

Hart Hanson, creator of the Fox crime drama ''Bones,'' may have said it best when the ratings for Sunday's second-season premiere of AMC's ''Walking Dead'' were released on Monday afternoon. ''Wow!'' he wrote on Twitter. ''Them zombies are coming for all of us on network TV.'' A total of 7.3 million people tuned in for ''The Walking Dead'' on Sunday night, up from 5.3 million for the first-season premiere last year. Of those, 4.8 million were aged 18 to 49, making the episode the highest-rated drama episode ever on cable in that age category, highly coveted by advertisers. The previous record, which AMC set during the first season of the show, underscored both the rise of this cable channel and of zombies (in pop culture). After being replayed at 10:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m., the episode had a cumulative 11 million viewers on Sunday, AMC said. The first season of ''The Walking Dead'' had an average of 5.2 million viewers for its initial broadcasts.

GROSSMAN--Saul, PhD.,Clinical Psychologist, died at 90 on October 11, 2011 of a stroke at home in Laguna Woods, CA. A beloved husband of Rosalind for 68 years. He leaves three children, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. His humor, wit and wisdom will be greatly missed.

HAYDEN--Lawrence R.S.,86 years old on October 13th. Larry, as he was known to his loving wife Laurie, and his friends and family, or Mr. Hayden, as he was known to the thousands of students he taught, first at Wooster College, and then at Poly Prep Country Day School, where he taught for 35 years, was born on May 5th, 1925. A decorated combat veteran of WWII, he graduated from Wooster College, did his graduate work at Columbia University, and then taught English at Wooster, before moving to Brooklyn, NY to teach 11th grade English at Poly. As his many students through the years can attest, he taught them more than just English, but lessons that have served them in life as well. He was an expert on a myriad of topics, ranging from English Literature, to the Duke of Wellington, to the professional sports teams of Cleveland, and The Ohio State University football team. He is survived by his adoring wife Laurie, his son Jim, his sister Barbara, his daughter-in-law Kathie, and his grandson Jamal. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in his name to: The Nature Conservancy/Long Island Chapter, 250 Lawrence Hill Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.
