A federal mediator met separately with officials from the N.B.A. and its players union in hopes of bringing an end to the league's four-month long lockout. In the meetings, which lasted a few hours each, the mediator, George H. Cohen, heard arguments from both sides and asked questions of the representatives from the league and the union. He will meet the two sides together on Tuesday. Cohen's suggestions are nonbinding, so he will have to use his powers of persuasion to get the league and the players to move closer to a deal.

In a rare appearance at an event that was not about food, New York's de facto first lady, Sandra Lee, on Monday offered a glimpse into the household she shares with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and gave young women some blunt career advice. Appearing on a panel about women's economic empowerment organized by Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand and held at New York University, Ms. Lee remarked that, just as women have more job opportunities today, men are expected to do more at home - including raising children, cooking dinner ''and doing dishes - if you're in my house.''

An article on Wednesday about a slowdown in container port traffic that may indicate a weaker holiday retail season described incorrectly a forecast from Frederick W. Smith, chief executive of FedEx. Mr. Smith cited forecasts for a 2.5 to 3 percent increase in retail sales this holiday season; he was not referring to expectations for an increase in that range for FedEx holiday shipping volumes.

A former signature of the ''Today'' show, ''Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?,'' is being revived after a three-year break. Mr. Lauer, below, will travel to five surprise destinations the week of Nov. 7, NBC announced Monday, adding something like 30,000 miles to the quarter of a million he has accumulated in nine previous trips for the show. The travel series started in 1998 and continued each year since, with one break in 2003. After the 2008 edition it was put on hiatus, in part owing to gloomy economic conditions in the United States. (In 2009 the ''Today'' co-hosts went on a United States tour instead.) This time, in a nod to social media, fans of the show on Facebook and Twitter will be able to gain access to a picture clue about his next stop, assisting those who are baffled by the clue Mr. Lauer gives on television. The feature is returning at a time when ''Today,'' the longtime No. 1 morning show., is being challenged by ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' the longtime No. 2. ''Today'' led by about 495,000 viewers for the week of Sept. 26, and by about 565,000 viewers for the week of Oct. 3; this time last year ''Today'' was leading by nearly a million viewers.

Remember judicial activism? Of course you do. Not so long ago, Republicans lined up to denounce President Obama's two Supreme Court nominees as judicial activists before the ink was dry on their nomination papers. Writing in The Wall Street Journal right after Sonia Sotomayor's nomination in May 2009, Karl Rove advised fellow Republicans that although Judge Sotomayor would almost certainly be confirmed, Republicans should nonetheless seek to score points by "making a clear case against the judicial activism she represents." The next year, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, undeterred by the fact that Elena Kagan, never having been a judge, was hard to describe plausibly as a judicial activist, explained his vote against her confirmation by saying that "Ms. Kagan's record shows that she supports an activist judicial philosophy."

Ida Ekblad is at once a sculptor, painter, video maker and poet. Her motley creations - crude and polished, blithe and bold - offer perspectives on modern art and culture, with and without a capital M. Her sculpture reaches back to beatific tropes of postwar art history, which she solders together with the harsh trash of today's world: industrial materials (scrap metal is a favorite) collected from streets and junkyards. Her paintings marry similar sentiments, committing the intangible debris of brutish shapes and colors to canvas.

The first day of the CMJ Music Marathon is for lowering expectations. I'm spoiled because most of the shows I hear during the year are by bands that have already gotten somewhere -- even if it's only to an opening-act slot with some indie-label pals -- and are playing clubs that expect people to listen. The beauty and aggravation of CMJ is that it's a plunge into the lower echelons, the ones triaged out of my usual schedule. This is the province of peculiar club layouts, blaringly murky sound systems and disheveled guys in yesterday's T-shirt poking at their keyboard and mixer, wishing they were Erasure circa 1989. I start to wonder if the next five days are going to be like that.

An article by Marc Lacey in Tuesday's New York Times looked at the many different issues motivating protesters in America and abroad to join the growing Occupy Wall Street movement. Reporting on protesters around the country, Mr. Lacey found that not every group or individual that has embraced Occupy marches for the same reasons. Though many protesters seem united in feeling that a system designed to benefit the rich and connected is not working in their favor, many are also more concerned with specific challenges affecting their local communities, such as education and the environment.

Keith Kloor has a fascinating interview with the British environmental writer and activist Mark Lynas on the Yale Environment 360 Web site. The exchange centers on Lynas's new book, "The God Species: Saving the Planet in the Age of Humans," and particularly on his conclusion that some technologies that have been anathema to environmentalists are vital to a smooth human journey in this century -- particularly nuclear power and crops developed using biotechnology. Also notable is Lynas's revised view of the "skeptical environmentalist" Bjorn Lomborg, whose face he once plastered with a pie. I encourage you to read it and weigh in here.

Our colleagues at the Bucks blog are reminding us that this is the peak time for deer-car collisions - October and November - because fall is mating season. State Farm says that deer vs. automobile crashes are on the decline, but they're still a problem. And the costs of repairing vehicles after a strike have risen. An annual analysis of the insurer's auto claims estimates there were 1.09 million collisions between deer and automobiles from July 2010 to June 30, 2011, down 7 percent from the prior year and 9 percent from three years ago. This season, design is busy doing its bit for charity. The Moment recently reported on the Pink Swan Project, in which designers riffed on Arne Jacobsen's classic Swan chair. Now comes Kartell Loves Milano, an auction on Oct. 25 by Sotheby's at the Rotondo della Besana in Milan. Proceeds from the sale will benefit the Umberto Veronesi Foundation, which supports scientific research. (Its founder, for whom the foundation is named, is a surgeon and oncologist known for his innovations in cancer treatment.) For the auction, 45 individuals and groups - from the worlds of design and architecture, art, fashion, music, photography, food and even sports - will reimagine one of the Italian manufacturer Kartell's plastic furniture designs, while also paying tribute to the city of Milan, Italy's design and fashion center. While it's now become commonplace to see a fashion house like Missoni or DSquared2 reworking a chair or a mirror, it's still a novelty when the soccer club A.C. Milan or the D.J. Linus does it. An interesting design-world statistic: of the 45 participants, 29 chose to put their stamp on pieces designed by Philippe Starck - including Starck himself, who has probably done more than any other designer to make Kartell, which pioneered plastic furniture designs in the 1950s, a global brand today.

The British author Simon Kuper was born in Uganda and grew up in England, the Netherlands, the United States, Sweden and Jamaica. His soccer writing has taken him to even more far-flung corners of the globe -- even on daring forays inside the minds of Diego Maradona and Wayne Rooney -- for the profiles of what he calls the "rogues, geniuses and neurotics" of world soccer that make up his new book, "Soccer Men." Kuper's previous books include the prize-winning "Football Against the Enemy" and the groundbreaking "Soccernomics," written with the economist Stefan Syzmanski.

Once upon a time, washing with soap and water was considered radical hygiene. There was even a church injunction against water on the grounds that bathing spurred sensuality and indolence - talk about the odor of sanctity. At the same time, pestilential stench was a sign of Satan; bad odors indicated physical and moral decay. Alain Corbin's "The Foul and the Fragrant" chronicles France in the 18th and 19th centuries when the masses stank to high heaven and perfumed gloves and sleeves inured the aesthete from those very rank rank and file. But the aristocracy was not entirely immune. Casanova, Corbin tells us, nearly fainted at the musky smell of an old nymphomaniac duchess. I sat next to her on the bus yesterday, and I nearly died too.

Good food and drink rank high among Hong Kongers' obsessions, so it's appropriate that there is a whole month devoted to it. Wine & Dine month kicks off with the Wine & Dine Festival, which runs Oct. 27 to 30 at a picturesque location on the West Kowloon promenade. Food and wine tastings may be purchased from over 200 exhibitors (general admission is free). New at the festival this year are Spanish and Japanese purveyors who promise themed food and entertainment.

Jason Garrett has received a lot of criticism for his decision to call three straight runs while up, 16-13, with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play in Sunday's game in New England, perhaps the harshest of which came from his boss. On Oct. 19, 1987, a day that became known as "Black Monday," the stock market crashed as the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 508 points, or 22.6 percent in value, its largest single-day percentage drop. The crash came after a two-week period in which the Dow dropped 15 percent.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about regulations being proposed under the Dodd-Frank Act, misstated the share of the risk that lenders must retain under the law when some mortgages are sold to investors. It is 5 percent, not 10 percent. And an accompanying picture caption misspelled the surname of the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in some editions. She is Mary Schapiro, not Shapiro.

-A collection of documents, articles and books about Bruce Springsteen's career that has been growing for years at the Asbury Park Public Library will be moved to nearby Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., the university said. -The Bruce Springsteen Special Collection includes nearly 15,000 documents from 44 countries and comprises books, concert programs, magazine and newspaper articles and other ephemera chronicling the career of Mr. Springsteen and members of his bands. Assembled by fan organizations, the archive has grown so large it can no longer be housed at the library in the town where Mr. Springsteen began his professional career in the 1970s.
An article on Tuesday about Michele Bachmann's plans to reconnect with voters in Iowa misstated the given name of Mrs. Bachmann's personal assistant in some editions. She is Tera Dahl, not Tara.

GOULD--Dr. Edwin Sheldon, 85, died October 11th at his home in Kent, OH. He had recently retired from 44 years of teaching chemistry at Kent State University, where he held the title of University Professor. He authored two textbooks, and was an esteemed violinist and poet. He is survived by his second wife Carol Williams Brown, sons Richard Gould-Saltman and Kirk Gould, and stepdaughter Laura Darby Singh. A memorial service will be held in Dr. Gould's honor in the Kiva at Kent State University, October 29th at 4pm. To view the full obituary please go to www.BisslerandSons.com.

11:18 p.m. | Updated A Queens man was charged on Tuesday in connection with at least one in a string of 20 sexual assaults in Brooklyn since March, the police said. Plainclothes police officers stopped the man, Joshua Flecha, 32, on Greenwood Avenue in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, between East Fourth and Fifth Streets, around 3:15 a.m. because they suspected he might be trying to break into parked vehicles, Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman, said.

MULLEN--Peter P. On October 15, 2011. With great sadness, the attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Peter P. Mullen, the firm's first executive partner, an invaluable colleague and a cherished friend. He was 83 years old. Mr. Mullen formally served as Skadden's executive partner from 1981 to 1994 and informally for several years prior. He joined the firm in 1961 as an associate and was named partner in 1962. He became of counsel at the firm in 1998, and he recently celebrated his 50th anniversary at Skadden. Mr. Mullen was a key architect of Skadden's growth globally and was highly respected by all for his wise day-to-day leadership of our institution. Together with Joe Flom in 1988, Mr. Mullen helped establish the Skadden Fellowship Foundation, which has provided two-year fellowships to more than 600 young lawyers seeking to pursue public interest law. Mr. Mullen was a champion of numerous charitable causes, having served as a trustee, director or member of ORBIS International, The Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, The Advisory Committee of The Southwest Legal Foundation, The Legal Aid Society, Volunteers of Legal Services, The United Way, and The Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, among other organizations. He also was a member of the board of directors of the Gregorian University Foundation of New York and Rome, having served as chairman until last year. From 1985 to 1992, he was chairman of the Georgetown University Board of Directors. Mr. Mullen was a member of the New York State Bar Association Committee on Securities Regulation from 1980 to 1983. Mr. Mullen graduated cum laude from Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his LL.B. from Columbia Law School in 1951, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. We join his wife Billie, sons Peter and Jeff, and daughters Kirby, Elaine and Lucy, as well as his nine grandchildren, in honoring his memory. All donations in honor of Peter Mullen should be made to The Gregorian University Foundation, Project ORBIS or The Lake Waramaug Task Force. Funeral services are being coordinated by McGrath Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY: www.mcgrathandson.com.

Goldman Sachs, once Wall Street's highest flier, has been grounded, and it does not bode well for the rest of the financial industry or the New York City economy that depends on it. The bank, both envied and loathed for its ability to churn out huge profits year after year, reported a quarterly loss on Tuesday - its first since the financial crisis and only its second since going public in 1999.

There are many unknowns about the Occupy Wall Street protest in downtown Manhattan: Where is the next march? Who are its leaders? What do they really want? When will it end? But an even bigger question, perhaps, has emerged: Who is the Hipster Cop? The questions keep popping up about the nattily dressed plainclothes officer who has become a fixture at the protest camp at Zuccotti Park.

When Mitt Romney takes the stage Tuesday evening in Las Vegas at yet another Republican debate, some people across the country in New Hampshire think he might be making a bad gamble. What started as early jockeying for relevance in the Republican nominating fight - with Florida moving its primary date into January, and Nevada scheduling its caucuses for Jan. 14 - has now reached fever pitch, with local officials in the Granite State calling on Republican candidates to boycott the Nevada caucuses. Though New Hampshire has yet to set a date for its ''first in the nation'' primary, officials there fear that the date Nevada has chosen for its caucuses could force them to move its contest into December.

MCGINTY--John Edward. September 24, 1946 - October 14, 2011. John E. McGinty, a senior advisor in the investment banking department of UBS, died at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, MA on Friday, October 14 of complications of multiple myeloma. He was 65 years old. Born in St. Louis and educated at Northwestern University and the University of Chicago, McGinty began his career in 1970 at the boutique New York City investment firm of H.C. Wainwright, training with John Suydam as a machinery analyst in a revered research department. Wainwright was acquired by Weeden & Co. and in 1977, when the company closed its doors, McGinty moved to First Boston in the same role. He continued as a managing director when First Boston was acquired by Credit Suisse, providing coverage based on, in some cases, relationships that extended over three decades. Ranked by Institutional Investor magazine among the top machinery analysts in 31 of his 33 years in the industry (occasionally in more than one category), McGinty became the centerpiece of the firm's global effort in machinery. He was a voice of enthusiasm in the research department and a willing mentor to younger analysts, an uncommon trait on Wall Street. He retired from Credit Suisse in November 2006 and moved to UBS as a senior advisor in investment banking. A strong believer in education, McGinty served as a trustee to Salve Regina University, was an active alumnus of Chicago Booth, and contributed to initiatives at Milton Academy, the Rivers School, the investment committee of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, Goddard House in Brookline, MA, and Trinity Church Boston. He also established the first girls town soccer league in Montclair, NJ. An avid golfer and devoted family member, he is survived by five sisters, his wife of 40 years, Sarah Myers, and three children, John, Sarah, and William, all of Boston, MA. Funeral service and reception will be held at Trinity Church Copley Square Boston at 10am on October 22. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John E. McGinty history chair at Salve Regina University c/o the Office of the President, 100 Ochre Point Ave., Newport, RI 02840.

Cornell University announced on Tuesday that it is joining forces with Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in its bid to build a science graduate school in New York City. Technion, a highly regarded university in Haifa that is heavily focused on computer science and electrical engineering, has been a crucial incubator for businesses in Israel's high-tech boom. Cornell was already seen as a leading candidate in the city's competition to start a new campus of applied sciences. Its chief competitor is Stanford University, which is vying for the same piece of city-owned land on Roosevelt Island; Columbia, New York University and Carnegie Mellon are also contenders.

For weeks, we have been told that the N.F.L. has turned into a passing league. That the pinball-machine passing and scoring numbers were the new norm. That all the rules changes over the past three decades had left us with a game that looks more like the Arena Football League. Then Week 6 came. You might have heard that the first four weeks of this year featured the four highest single-week passing yardage totals in league history. That was a little misleading, as each of those weeks had 32 teams playing, which was not the case for most of league history. But even on a per-game basis, the first four -- and then the fifth -- weeks of this season had huge passing numbers. In the first four weeks, the average team gained 246 passing yards and scored 22.8 points per game. In Week 5, the 26 teams playing averaged 239 passing yards and 25 points per game. But this past week, while the average team passed for 232 passing yards, scoring dropped to 20.1 points. And that drop in points can be attributed to the drop in passing touchdowns. There were 54 passing touchdowns in Week 1, and another 54 in Week 2. Last week -- the first with teams on byes -- 26 teams passed for 45 touchdowns, an even higher average per team game (1.73) than in the first two weeks. But the 26 teams this past weekend passed for only 27 touchdowns, and that includes the fake-field goal touchdown pass from Oakland punter Shane Lechler. In each of the first two weeks, 18 teams had at least two touchdown passes. This weekend, only 7 of the 24 teams threw for multiple touchdowns.
MAY--Irving. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Irving May, associated with The New York Times from April 17, 1956 until retiring on December 31, 1982.

9:30 P.M. (HGTV) KITCHEN COUSINS John Colaneri and Anthony Carrino (near left, with Mr. Colaneri) are designers and contractors who run a New Jersey-based construction company. They're also members of a large and tight-knit family, attended prep school together as teenagers and now live in condominiums in a converted Jersey City warehouse that was their first project as a team. This new series tags along as these cousins follow their passion for transforming dreary kitchens into works of art, starting with a brownstone galley lacking counter space and storage. They decide to take the room down to the studs and build it back up, blending original brick walls and yellow pine floors with modern Italian cabinets and a stainless-steel island. 6:10 P.M. (Encore) THE RUNAWAYS (2010) Kristen Stewart, below, portrays Joan Jett, and Dakota Fanning is Cherie Currie, the guitarist and lead singer for Ms. Jett's real-life band of the title in this biopic set in Southern California in the mid-1970s. ''Girls can't play the electric guitar,'' a teacher informs Joan. ''This is not about women's lib,'' counters Michael Shannon, as the promoter Kim Fowley, who takes the girls under his wing and preaches a brand of macho feminism. ''It's about women's libido.'' Reviewing this feature-film debut from Floria Sigismondi, based on Ms. Currie's memoir, and with Ms. Jett as an executive producer, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: '' 'The Runaways' balances nostalgia for wild bygone times with a cautionary sense of their less heroic side. Acknowledging the brazen, rebellious energy of rock 'n' roll at the dawn of punk, Ms. Sigismondi also tallies the costs that an ardent, ambitious love of the music can exact.'' He added, ''The movie may be a little too tame in the end, but at its best it is just wild enough.''

Mr. Lieb, 56, had held the position since 2006.

-Four original members of UB40, the British reggae band that sold more than 70 million records, have been declared bankrupt by a judge in Britain, the BBC and Billboard reported. A judge in the Birmingham County court said government tax officers could seize the band's assets and property to pay off outstanding debts in a ruling against the saxophonist Brian Travers, the drummer Jimmy Brown, the trumpeter Terence Oswald and the percussionist Norman Hassan. The judge's order follows the collapse of the band's record label, DEP International, which caused a fight over finances that led to a rift among the members in 2008. That year the lead singer, Ali Campbell, left the group, because of ''management difficulties'' and ''an ongoing investigation into the handling of my business affairs,'' according to a statement he released at the time.

An article on Monday about Amazon.com's foray into publishing misstated the actions of the publisher Penguin after Kiana Davenport, an author under contract to write a novel for its Riverhead Books imprint, published a collection of short stories as an e-book available on Amazon. Penguin canceled Ms. Davenport's novel and said it would sue if she did not return the advance for the book; it has not filed a lawsuit against her.

An article on Thursday about a collaboration between the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and W magazine referred imprecisely to his legal situation in China. While he was released from detention by the Chinese authorities after signing what they said was a confession to tax evasion, he has not been formally charged with evasion. The article also referred incorrectly to an English-language Twitter account that carries Mr. Ai's comments. It is maintained by supporters who translate his official account; it is not his account. And the article, using information from the Web site of Max Vadukul, who shot the photos of Mr. Ai's project, overstated Mr. Vadukul's role with Rolling Stone magazine. He says he is not in fact a ''leading photographer'' for it.

ST. LOUIS - In the 1932 World Series, when the Yankees swept the Chicago Cubs, the teams combined to average 14 runs per game. All these years later, withstanding strong challenges from the designated hitter and the steroids era, those 14 runs per game remain a World Series record. It may not stay that way for long. The St. Louis Cardinals and the Texas Rangers ride thunderous offenses into the 107th World Series, which starts Wednesday at Busch Stadium. St. Louis averaged nearly 7.2 runs per game while beating Milwaukee in the last playoff round, and Texas averaged 6.5 runs per game while taking down Detroit.

PARIS -- When the Musée d'Orsay unveils its makeover this week, visitors will get a fresh view of the world's richest trove of 19th-century artworks by Impressionist masters who essentially financed the Paris museum's $28 million face-lift. Two touring groups of masterworks by Degas, Monet and Renoir and Whistler's portrait of his mother roamed the world for almost two years on a lucrative journey to museums from San Francisco to Madrid, reaping almost $15 million for the remodeling.

A caption for a grouping of pictures on Tuesday with an article about the complicated sex lives of dragonflies misidentified the type of dragonfly shown in full view. It is a slaty skimmer, not a blue dasher.

The House Ethics Committee, after a two-year delay, has reopened its investigation into whether Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. conducted a ''public campaign'' in late 2008 to secure an appointment to President Obama's former Senate seat in Illinois, and perhaps broke House rules in the process. The investigation was put on hold at the request of the Justice Department, given its criminal case against former Gov. Rod Blagojevich of Illinois, who was convicted in June on 17 counts, including wire fraud, attempted extortion and soliciting bribes.

Quarterback Sam Bradford is having a rough season, but maybe it should not be a surprise. His rookie year with St. Louis in 2010 was overrated by many who viewed him as a surefire star. He finished near the top of the league in passes, inflating his yards and touchdown statistics. Yards and touchdowns are not necessarily good ways to grade quarterbacks, but that does not stop people from doing so. He played for a team that was 1-15 the year before his arrival, so he received credit for any regression to the mean in the form of a significant increase in wins in 2010 (the Rams improved to 7-9). And his team played a weak schedule (4.2 points below average, second easiest in the league).

MULLEN--Peter P.,passed away on October 15th after a long struggle with cardiac issues. He was an accomplished man: He graduated cum laude from Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his LL.B. from Columbia Law School in 1951, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. He was a visionary attorney: He joined the firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom in 1961. He served formally as Skadden's executive partner from 1981 to 1994 (and informally prior to 1981), becoming a key architect of Skadden's growth globally. He was instrumental in establishing the Skadden Fellowship Foundation. Peter Mullen was highly respected by all in the legal community. Guided always by his Catholic faith, he championed many charitable causes. Among others, he was Chairman of the Georgetown University Board of Directors; he also served as Chairman and Board Member of both ORBIS International and the Gregorian University Foundation. He was President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. Other organizations he served included The Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, The Advisory Committee of The Southwest Legal Foundation, The Legal Aid Society, Volunteers of Legal Services, The United Way, The Cardinal's Committee of the Laity and the Vatican Observatory. He felt his greatest accomplishment was his family and the life he built on the shores of Lake Waramaug in Litchfield County, CT. He was happiest when he was surrounded by his loving wife of 56 years, Billie; his children, Peter, Kirby, Elaine, Lucy and Jeff and their spouses; and his nine grandchildren. He was an avid sailor, skier, golfer, tennis player, gardener, birdwatcher, bush-hogger and neighbor. He was a friend and advisor to all. All in all, a life well lived!! In the end, he was optimistic about life, he was able to celebrate an early Thanksgiving with his family, attend mass and go out to dinner. He will be greatly missed. All donations in honor of Peter Mullen should be made to The Gregorian University Foundation, Project ORBIS or The Lake Waramaug Task Force. Funeral services are being coordinated by McGrath Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY: www.mcgrathandson.com The Mullen Family

ABC and CBS settled for a split ratings victory on Monday night as ''Dancing With the Stars'' averaged 17.5 million total viewers over a two-hour period and led ABC to the highest total audience. CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, though ''Two and a Half Men'' continued to fall from its lofty early-season perch to 14.9 million total viewers, down another million viewers from last week. One more drop of that size and the show will be in the same Charlie Sheen territory as last year. ''Terra Nova'' on Fox returned to its normal 8 p.m. time period with nearly 8 million viewers, down slightly compared to the last regularly scheduled episode two weeks ago.

The Broadway musical ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert,'' which opened to mixed reviews in March and had one of the rockiest summers at the box office for new productions, had its highest-earning set of performances last week since late May, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers. ''Priscilla'' earned $860,673, about 59 percent of the maximum possible gross last week; the show earned $920,741 during the playing week that included Memorial Day weekend, while it reached a low point of $547,180 in early September. The producers of ''Priscilla'' revamped their advertising and marketing strategies this fall, including highlighting the involvement of producer Bette Midler, and also began offering an unusual money back guarantee through group sales offers to help the musical through the fall. September and October are traditionally slow months at Broadway box offices - shows often close soon after Labor Day to avoid a fall slump - but ''Priscilla'' sales have been improving fairly steadily. According to the Broadway League database, ''Priscilla'' has earned more money since Labor Day than another new musical, ''Sister Act,'' and two recent winners of the Tony Award for best musical, ''Billy Elliot'' and ''Memphis.''

The merger market is like a pack of lemmings. If the economy is good , the takeover market will follow, but when times are bad, the market stalls. For the moment, there are still mega-deals, like Kinder Morgan's $21.1 billion acquisition of the El Paso Corporation, and takeover activity is up. The volume of global mergers and acquisitions was up 22 percent, to $2.748 trillion, for the last 12 months ending in August from the period a year ago, according to Thomson Reuters. The increase in deal volume was driven in part by a threefold increase in hostile offers and strong company balance sheets.

For Bank of America, it is the end of an era. With the bank shrinking its balance sheet and selling off assets, the company, based in Charlotte, N.C., surrendered its title as the country's biggest bank Tuesday, another sign of how a money-losing giant assembled over decades is being reshaped into a smaller and, investors hope, more profitable institution.

ABRAMS--Stuart Edward. Of New York City and Ancramdale, NY. Extraordinary spouse, father, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, cousin, friend, lawyer, historian, writer, pianist, cross-country skier, gardener, Red Sox fan. Born April 30, 1953 in Englewood, NJ, son of the late Dilys (Jones) and Selden Abrams, he died October 13, 2011 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Stuart was loved and admired by his spouse of 31 years, Caroline J. Downey, his children Alexandra and Stephen Abrams-Downey, his sister Nancy Abrams Gaess, his siblings-in-law Peter, Jim, Sally, Bob, Nancy, Steve, KT, Paul, Hallie, Eleanor and Jay, his 19 nieces and nephews, his cousins and his many friends. A 1974 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and Columbia Law School, 1977, he had been a partner at Frankel & Abrams since 1994 and was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. From 1982-1989, he was an Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York, where he served as Chief Appellate Counsel and Chief of the Major Crimes Unit. The respected character actor Michael Cristofer will play Adolf Eichmann, locked in a battle of wills and wits with Mossad agents in 1960 Buenos Aires, in the new drama ''Captors'' at the Huntington Theater Company this fall, the company said on Tuesday. An outside team of commercial producers has already secured the rights to transfer the work to Broadway, which they hope to do during the 2011-12 season after the end of the Huntington run, a spokeswoman for the theater added. The five-character play by Evan M. Wiener, based on the 1990 memoir ''Eichmann in My Hands'' by Peter Z. Malkin and Harry Stein, renders a 10-day standoff between Eichmann and the Israeli agents after they captured him living under a false identity in Argentina. At that time Eichmann, one of the Nazi architects of the Holocaust, was the most wanted war criminal in the world, and the play deals with the agents -- one of whom was Malkin -- trying to persuade Eichmann to face trial in Israel or else die at their hands.

The lawless manner of Muammar el-Qaddafi's death - he was apparently beaten, dragged and shot by a mob of armed men in the streets of Surt - is well-fitted to the lawless way he ruled his country. Like Mussolini and Ceausescu, he perished by the same sword that he lived by. We should regret the absence of the fair trial that even the worst criminal deserves, but it's hard not to feel a certain mordant satisfaction at the ignominious way that one of recent history's genuine monsters passed to his reward. Thus always to tyrants ...

Eva Zuckerman, the designer of Eva Fehren, a new fine jewelry line, first started tinkering with jewelry while working for Mor Mor Rita, a high-end children's brand. "Women actually bought my stuff!" exclaims Zuckerman, who put her Cooper Union fine arts background on hold for the opportunity to work for the jewelry designers Philip Crangi and, later, Monique Péan. "They're such wonderful teachers," she says, crediting both mentors with instilling in her the importance of sustainable gems (like petrified wood and lapis lazuli stones) and innovative craftsmanship (seen in her delicate gold stackable bands and geometric rings and bracelets). And from the looks of her debut effort, this promising pupil gets a gold star.

This year, after Western journalists poured into Libya as the civilian population took up arms and lunged into war, a line of coverage on makeshift arms production and distribution found its way into many newspapers, magazines and Web sites. The New York Times was part of this, with coverage on the anti-Qaddafi forces' hasty acquisition, production and fielding of all manner of repurposed arms and the vehicles to carry them. Often these weapons were poorly used. Sometimes they were fired just as indiscriminately as the weapons fired by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's troops that NATO, in its United Nations-approved bid to protect civilians, claimed to marshal international will to stop. Some of these weapons were also instrumental in the anti-Qaddafi militias' eventual success, as was visible in Misurata. (For a fuller view of many of these themes, read this report on the hidden plant in Misurata, or these explainers on the dangerous repurposing of 57-mm air-to-ground rockets or 122-millimeter Grad rockets or, in this case, the knuckleheaded firing of plainly labeled inert rockets toward Qaddafi forces in Libya's mountainous west.)

A team at the University of California Berkeley that set out to test the temperature data underlying the consensus on global warming has concluded that the mainstream estimate of the rise in the earth's surface temperature since 1950 is indeed accurate. I think Josh Ozersky is at least a little out of his mind in this piece about the demise of Friendly's and how sad it is that sit-down fast food chains are going out of business left and right. He's correct, of course, in saying that they're dying because people can't afford them, and indeed there is nothing good about that. But that's a disease, and the closing of bad restaurants is a symptom, and maybe an upside of that is that people cook the "casual food" that they've been going out to eat, and then recognize the advantages of doing so.

PARIS -- A strike by workers at the Musée d'Orsay postponed the long-awaited reopening of the museum's newly renovated galleries on Thursday. Some 34 employees, mostly security guards, staged the walkout to protest the fact that no additional workers had been recruited at the museum despite the addition of more than 21,000 square feet of display space, a museum spokeswoman said. That decision was made amid broad government cutbacks that see retiring civil servants - including museum workers - not replaced by new hires.

A great fan might make it to a dozen tailgate parties in a season. That would fall a bit short of Joe Cahn, the self-proclaimed commissioner of tailgating. Cahn sold his cooking school in New Orleans in 1996 to tailgate at every N.F.L. stadium. Since then, he says, he has been to 800 games and traveled about 800,000 miles. So, Cahn seemed like a good source to contribute to the collection of tailgate party recipes on The Quad, the Times's college sports blog, and he obliged with Joe's Jambalaya. "This is my favorite recipe because you can put just about anything in it," said Cahn, 63. "If it walks, crawls, swims or flies, it can be thrown into jambalaya. Everything goes into one pot, so cleanup's a breeze." It's not too late to contribute a dish. Use this form to send us your recipes, and please include a picture of your fare and perhaps an interesting back story. We're still looking for some great barbecue. And who's serving breakfast?

A PEPPY new boutique, C. Wonder, purveying bright, playful apparel, accessories and home décor, is set to open on Saturday in SoHo. The shop is the brainchild of J. Christopher Burch, the venture capitalist and a co-chairman of Tory Burch, his former wife's fashion empire. Mr. Burch used his retail expertise to reimagine a modern kind of gift shop, with an array of nicely priced goods and custom services. The items, all C. Wonder label, include ruffled flannel shirts, $78; cruiser bikes, $249; driving moccasins, $79; and ceramic ikat nesting bowls, $58. There is in-store monogramming for button-down shirts, glassware and nylon bags of every shape and color ($15 for engraving, $10 for embroidery). Build a charm bracelet or customize a belt ($48, with an initial buckle, $28). The dressing rooms have keypads for selecting music based on your mood. (Flirty? Confident? Cool?) You can sip lemonade while you wait. If you're feeling too hot or cold, find a store manager who can control the temperature from an iPad. And this is no mom-and-pop shop: three additional stores are planned for November -- at Westfield Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J.; Roosevelt Field in Garden City, N.Y.; and the Westchester in White Plains -- in time for the holidays. C. Wonder, 72 Spring Street, (212) 219-3500; cwonder.com.

Campfires, boomerangs and stone tools are not what most schoolchildren have in mind when they hear the word ''technology.'' But in a workshop last week at the Mott Haven campus of the Urban Assembly School for Careers in Sports, visiting instructors brought to life some of civilization's earliest innovations, using primitive tools and weapons. ''I thought rocks were just there to be there, to occupy space,'' said Josue Perez, 14, whose class on global history is studying the Paleolithic and Neolithic periods. ''I never thought that we would use rocks to cut things and make things and be useful.''

SARIS--Anthony, 88, of Bolton Landing passed away on October 17, 2011 at Glens Falls Hospital. He was born on September 8, 1923 in Joliet, Illinois. Anthony served in the U.S. Army Air Corps as a Flight Engineer during World War II. In 1948 he graduated from Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. After graduating he was a commercial freelanced illustrator in addition to being a Professor at Pratt Institute until his retirement. He was predeceased by his wife, Catherine Saris in 2008. Anthony is survived by his son, Jason Saris and his wife, Annette of Bolton Landing; his grandson, John Saris of Bolton Landing; also several nieces and nephews; and his sister-in-law, Athena Bentas. Per his request there will be no services. Those who wish may send donations in memory of Anthony Saris, to the National Endowment for the Arts, 1100 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Room 516, Washington, DC 20506. Arrangements are under the direction of Regan & Denny Funeral Home, 53 Quaker Rd, Queensbury. For those who wish, online condolences can be made to the family by visiting www.sbfuneralhome.com.

An obituary on Friday by The Associated Press about the actress Patricia Breslin misstated part of the name of a school from which she graduated. It is the Academy of Mount St. Ursula, not the Academy of Mount St. Ursuline.

4:59 p.m. | Updated The Andy Warhol Foundation announced on Wednesday that it will dissolve its authentication board early next year. In a statement, the foundation said the move reflects its intent to shift focus toward maximizing ''grant making and other charitable activities.'' In recent years, the foundation has been involved in legal disputes over its authentication process for works whose owners said they were by Warhol. One long-running lawsuit brought by Joe Simon-Whelan, a filmmaker who bought a work identified as a Warhol self-portrait in 1989 only to see it later declared inauthentic on two occasions by the board, contended that the foundation and the board had conducted a 20-year conspiracy to inflate the prices by denying the authenticity of a certain number as a way to create artificial scarcity. The board and foundation denied the accusations. After more than three years and rising legal bills, Mr. Simon-Whelan dropped the case. Others who had bad experiences with the board claimed it favored museums and powerful dealers over individual collectors, another charge foundation officials denied. Still, some dealers and collectors view the decision as irresponsible since it is the mission of the Warhol Foundation's to promote and protect the reputation and authenticity of the Pop master's art.

Critics from The New York Times have been squashed into many of the clubs hosting the CMJ Music Marathon alongside badge-wearing indie music fans and other chroniclers. But with nearly 1,400 acts in the 31st annual festival, they can't be everywhere. So this year we've invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter, and we published some reader reviews of Tuesday night's shows, including Wild Flag, Psychobuildings, Friends, Cerebral Ballzy, Radical Dads, Titus Andronicus and Gary Clark Jr. We'll suggest gigs each day online at nytimes.com/artsbeat; after the shows you can tweet your reviews -- 140 characters or less -- using the hashtag #mycmjreview and #CMJ. We'll choose from your tweets and publish some during CMJ.

Gov. Rick Perry's presidential campaign said Wednesday that it would reimburse owners of private jets an amount in the ''five figures'' one day after facing questions about whether it underpaid for using jets owned by wealthy donors, which could mean that the campaign may have received large, unreported in-kind contributions barred by federal election law. The campaign's outside general counsel, Bill Canfield, said he believed that fewer than 10 planes were involved and that the amount to be reimbursed was ''in five but not six figures.'' He said the campaign would amend its finance report filed last weekend and ask the Federal Election Commission for an opinion to resolve what he called differing interpretations of the relevant rules.

Often at the CMJ Music Marathon you don't have to walk more than 15 feet to have your mind changed about the sounds of the day. At Public Assembly in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Tuesday all you had to do was go to the next room. All night, and into the morning, two local labels were facing off in adjacent spaces. In the front room was Carpark Records, which began more than a decade ago as a specialist in experimental electronic music and now embraces all stripes of tuneful indie pop. The label's opener was Benjamin Boeldt's project, Adventure, which played one slick early-1980s electro-pop song after the next, with occasional bursts of shrillness.

9 P.M. (CMT) SWEET HOME ALABAMA Tribble Reese, above, the former college quarterback and self-defined ''bartender extraordinaire'' from Birmingham, Ala., who was the runner-up in the first season of this series, continues his quest for love as 22 women move in together and compete for his affections. ''Sweet Home Alabama: Outtakes & Updates,'' featuring extra footage from the inaugural season, leads in at 8. The sixth round of ''Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders: Making the Team,'' at 10, begins by following hundreds of candidates as they audition for a handful of positions on the squad. 2:30 P.M. (HBO2) CATFISH (2010) In this festival favorite from Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman, Nev Schulman (Ariel's brother), right, a 24-year-old New York City photographer, becomes entangled in an Internet relationship with a Michigan family that includes an 8-year-old art prodigy and her beautiful older sister -- with whom Nev supposedly falls in love. Reviewing the film in The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote: '' 'Catfish' flops down into this paradoxical reality and proceeds to generate some complications of its own. Judged by the usual standards it is a wretched documentary: visually and narratively sloppy; coy about its motives; slipshod in its adherence to basic ethical norms.'' He added: ''But at the same time -- precisely because of these lapses -- 'Catfish' is a fascinating document, at once glib, untrustworthy and strangely authentic. I say this with a heavy sigh: this is, by far, one of the most intriguing movies of the year.''

McGOWAN--James M.,MD 1937-2011. His family will welcome guests for calling hours Saturday, October 22 from 12-2pm at The Chapel of the Good Shepherd, Saint Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue.

The recent surge of new American plays on Broadway shows no sign of letting up. ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' which blends inventive staging with the world of make-believe in a tale of the orphan boy who became Peter Pan, will open this spring at a Broadway theater to be announced, the producers confirmed on Wednesday. Developed by Disney Theatrical Productions from Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson's popular children's novel of 2004, ''Peter and the Starcatcher'' had a critically acclaimed run at New York Theater Workshop last spring, starring Christian Borle (''Legally Blonde'') as the pirate Black Stache (who will go on to become Captain Hook) and Adam Chanler-Berat (now starring in the Off Broadway revival of ''Rent'') as Peter.

The Boîte column on Sept. 15 about NoBar, a bar in Bedford-Stuyvesant, misstated Ricardo Periera's connection to the bar. He is the manager, not the co-owner. (Anthony Mackie is the sole owner.) The reporter discovered the error and alerted The Times last week.

KAMENY--Seymour, age 92. Born in Poland on July 27, 1919. Emigrated to the United States when he was a toddler. He served in the U.S. Army, 20th Armored Division, for 4 1/2 years. After the war, with his late brother, Nat, they formed Kameny Associates Advertising which later became KSW&G. They specialized in promoting Japanese cameras including Olympus, Miranda and Konica. He was a lifelong painter who "retired" from agency life in his 50s to pursue his passion. His works have been exhibited in galleries throughout the U.S. He leaves behind his wife Frances (Weiss). Children Alice (and her husband Henry Feintuch) and Marian Smith. Grandfather to Alex and Joshua Feintuch and Justin Smith. Shiva Thursday - Saturday at Feintuch household, 50 Barnes Lane, Chappaqua, NY. Donations in memory of Seymour to Alzheimer's Association, 2900 Westchester Ave., Purchase, NY 10577 or http://www.alz.org/hudsonvalley/in--my--community--donate.asp.

A report in some editions of the National Briefing column on Wednesday about a lawsuit over Rhode Island's state pension system was published in error. The outdated report was inadvertently included in the column in place of the intended item -- about a proposal on Tuesday by Rhode Island's governor, Lincoln D. Chafee, to scale back pension benefits for state workers and retirees as part of an effort to help reduce the roughly $7 billion in unfunded obligations.

When you use a Wi-Fi connection to access the Internet, the data you transmit flies through the air. This allows us to remain blissfully connected while wandering through the house with a laptop, in a hotel with a tablet or in a departure lounge with a smartphone, but it also comes with privacy and security risks. While you surf, someone with the right software and equipment could snatch your private information from the airwaves, potentially reading e-mails to your boss or collecting the pictures you post to Facebook.
Q. I want to get an e-book reader, but do not have a Wi-Fi network. Can I still get books?

An article in some copies on Tuesday about new economic data from China misidentified the sales figures that rose 17.7 percent in the most recent quarter. That figure referred to retail sales, not real estate sales.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL The private equity firm Permira has agreed to buy Genesys, a call center provider, from the telecommunications giant Alcatel-Lucent in an all-cash deal worth $1.5 billion. Under the terms of the deal, Permira, based in London, will take over Genesys's global telecommunications business, which is expanding into new areas like cloud computing and managing and storing of data on remote network servers. Evanescence, a gothic-flavored alternative rock band, made a big splash in the early 2000s. Now the band has returned to the top of the music charts with its first new album in five years, although the sales are far from the blockbuster numbers of its -- and the music industry's -- heyday. The new album, ''Evanescence'' (Wind Up), sold 127,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan.That amount was significantly less than the 447,000 sales the band enjoyed when it released ''The Open Door'' in 2006, but it was enough to send the band to No. 1 on Billboard's album chart. ''Fallen,'' the band's debut, has sold 7.5 million copies since it was released in 2003.

Founded 230 years ago near the banks of the Thames, the Man Group has transformed itself from a British barrel maker to a rum merchant to a $70 billion money manager dominant in Europe and Asia. Now the company, the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund, is looking to conquer the United States, the world's largest hedge fund market.

8:01 p.m. | Updated Abbott Laboratories said on Wednesday that it would separate next year into two publicly traded companies, one focused on diagnostics and medical devices like heart stents and the other on what it called ''research-based pharmaceuticals,'' like Humira, its blockbuster rheumatoid arthritis drug.

The line outside Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night wrapped around the block for a CMJ Music Marathon showcase with the header ''Future Now.'' The question this seemed to invite was: Could ''jazz'' actually be making an impression this year? Let's be clear: ''Future Now'' wasn't really a jazz showcase, even if all three acts on the bill -- the Robert Glasper Experiment, and the vocalists José James and Taylor McFerrin -- have varying degrees of jazz experience. The show's compass pointed more toward sleek and stylishly woozy electro-soul, after the example of the influential producer J Dilla.

Dedicated smartphone apps for social media networks make it easy to post status updates on the go. Users with regular cellphones can also keep their friends in the loop by simply sending text messages directly to a phone number specified by the site. A few setup steps may be needed first to get the text-based posting activated, and every service may not work with every wireless carrier, but Facebook, Twitter and Google+ all have guides for getting started. Facebook has instructions for activating mobile texts on its site at on.fb.me /nECPu2 and a guide to text commands for things like updating your status or subscribing to friends' updates at on.fb.me/qOMiYf. Twitter also offers a guide for sending posts by text message at bit.ly/mvKaUq, and Google+ has instructions for its own service at bit.ly /qVrnlQ. While carrier rates for text messages may apply if the service is not included in the overall phone plan, it may still be a cheaper way to keep up with social media when a smartphone and data plan are out of financial reach. J. D. BIERSDORFER

An article last Thursday about fashion on college campuses referred incorrectly to the release of the movie ''Almost Famous,'' one of several films that have influenced the way college students dress. It was released in 2000, not in the 1980s.

Vogel wrote his best-selling book, ''Japan as Number One: Lessons for America.'' Now, at age 81 and retired from Harvard as a professor emeritus, Mr. Vogel has written an equally compelling study of the rise of another Asian super power.

If you'd like to see what happens when Trey Parker, Matt Stone and Robert Lopez combine their comic talents but can't get your hands on tickets for their bawdy, blaspheming Broadway hit, ''The Book of Mormon,'' cable television will soon provide a more easily accessible alternative. Mr. Lopez, who with Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone won Tony Awards for the book and score of ''Mormon'' (which earned nine Tonys in all, including best musical), will rejoin them in the writers' room at ''South Park,'' their Comedy Central series, where he'll be contributing to a new episode of that animated satire.

On Thursday, we asked readers to submit questions for Siri, Apple's new virtual personal assistant in the iPhone 4S. Below are some of Siri's most entertaining answers. We threw in some questions of our own because, well, once we got started, it was hard to stop. From Wally: What's the airspeed velocity of an unladen swallow? (Displays a Wolfram Alpha page indicating that the velocity is 25 m.p.h. ) From TheFaj: How much wood can a woodchuck chuck? 42 cords of wood, to be exact. Everyone knows that. We asked again and got an answer that will make more sense if you got the reference in the previous question: It depends on whether you are talking about African or European wood.

KHAZZAM--Salim. The Board of Governors and Members of Falls Golf & Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Salim Khazzam. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Albertine and their family. Gerald Fineberg, President

An article on Sept. 30 about the local elections held in Saudi Arabia, where women are still not permitted to vote, erroneously attributed a distinction to those elections and to the previous elections held in the kingdom in 2005. The most recent elections represented at least the third time in the history of the kingdom that local elections were allowed, not the second; the 2005 elections represented at least the second time, not the first. (Local council elections were held in Saudi cities and towns during the 1950s, according to Saudi historians, but there are no public records of them.)

9:15 p.m. | Updated Patrick J. Foye, a veteran of economic development circles and a well-known figure in Long Island's public life, was nominated on Wednesday by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to become the next executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The selection of Mr. Foye, a deputy secretary to the governor, coincided with a call by Mr. Cuomo for the Port Authority to take over the long-moribund Moynihan Station project, which would create an expanded train terminal on the West Side of Manhattan.

Stocks in the United States fell and the euro erased gains as a split emerged between France and Germany on ways to increase the European bailout fund. In addition, Apple's shares helped lead tech stocks lower after its iPhone sales in its fiscal fourth quarter disappointed. Technology shares fell 2.2 percent as a group and were the biggest drag on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple slumped 5.6 percent. The company's profit trailed analysts' estimates for the first time in at least six years as customers waited for the new iPhone model to go on sale.

A KNEE-GRAZING leather skirt, longer and fuller than a pencil skirt, is proving to be a fall statement piece, a look that leans more toward lady than rock 'n' roll. ''Now that fashion has moved in a softer, more feminine direction, the sometimes strict look of leather is less appealing,'' said Amanda Brooks, the women's fashion director of Barneys. ''Thus the longer, softer shapes we're seeing in leather now.'' Perhaps the first piece to grab the attention of the fashion pack was the black leather wrap skirt on the Altuzarra fall runway, shown with a smart argyle sweater. A tweak on chic grunge, it sold out at Net-a-Porter, despite a $4,890 price tag. At the recent spring shows, several young women, far left, looked demure, and tough, in pleated leather skirts with buttoned-up silk blouses and pullovers. Barneys is now stocked with curvaceous fishtail skirts in real ($1,795) and faux ($650) leather from Junya Watanabe's brilliant fall collection. Other statement styles, like these from Adam and Topshop, will look effortless matched with a silk blouse or graphic pullover.

G RENSON, the British footwear company that has been making Goodyear-welted brogues since 1886, and Barbour, founded in 1894 and known for those waxed canvas jackets so popular among the duck hunters of Manhattan, have collaborated on a men's footwear collection. ''I loved the idea of two companies, with almost identical heritages, getting together for the first time in their 100-plus-year histories,'' said Tim Little, the owner and creative director of Grenson. The shoes, six styles of country boots and brogues, will be available on the Grenson Web site later this month, but Barneys New York (212-826-8900; barneys.com) is already selling two of them: the derby boots, below, with a vamp of waxed British Millerain fabric (traditionally used in Barbour jackets) and a hand-stained green welt, $770; and, above, wing-cap brogues of calf leather and waxed Barbour fabric, $665.

An entry in the ''What's on Today'' television highlights in some editions last Thursday about shows on ABC, including ''Grey's Anatomy,'' misstated the relationship between the characters Catherine Avery and Jackson Avery on that show. She is his mother, not his mother-in-law.

A film review on Friday about the documentary ''Connected,'' directed by Tiffany Shlain, referred incompletely to her role in the annual Webby Awards for ''excellence on the Internet.'' Besides her role as the initial producer, she also founded the awards.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the election held by the Socialist Party of France to pick a presidential candidate, which was won by François Hollande, a lawyer and career politician, misstated a detail of his relationship to Ségolène Royal, the party's 2007 presidential candidate. While she was for many years his partner and they had four children together, Ms. Royal was not ''his rival for the Socialist candidacy in 2007.'' (Mr. Hollande did not seek to be the party's candidate that year.)

BOGEN--Elizabeth, died on October 18, 2011. Sister of Timothy and Nicholas, longtime employee of the City, devoted to her family, she sought to discern beauty and truth. Memorial service to be held on November 5 at location TBD.

Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about a discussion among Occupy Wall Street protesters in New York City and elsewhere about identifying specific demands quoted incorrectly from comments by Cullen Nawalkowsky, a demonstrator in Baltimore. Mr. Nawalkowsky said the point of the protest was a ''public sphere not mediated by commodities or mainstream political discourse.'' He did not say ''moderated'' by commodities or mainstream political discourse.

Resistance runs deep at Zuccotti Park. You might even say it is in the ground. The protesters clinging tenaciously to that little parcel in Lower Manhattan owe a big spiritual debt to Chock Full o' Nuts. In 1967, William Black, the Chock Full chairman and founder, refused to surrender the long-term lease for his luncheonette at Broadway and Cedar Street, what is now the southeast corner of the park. His obstinacy set back completion of the park by 13 years and was so celebrated in its day that it became a case study in ''Holdouts!'' (McGraw-Hill, 1984), by Andrew Alpern and Seymour Durst.

MULLEN--Peter P. The Honorary Ushers of the Cathedral of Saint Patrick express their condolences to the family of Peter P. Mullen on his recent passing. Peter was well known as a man of faith who served as Chief Honorary Usher from 1970-72. His presence and service inspired generations to follow in his footsteps, which are now, like so many, forever worn into the aisles and passage ways of our Cathedral. Peter F. Rizzo, Chief Usher John Leopoldo Fiorilla, Secretary

It seems to happen to most Windows users: You buy a new desktop or laptop PC. It runs fast. But a few months later, you're sure it's slower than it used to be. Ask for help on the Internet or in real life, and you usually get one of two answers: you must have downloaded a virus, or you need to defragment your hard drive. Bad advice. You probably don't have a virus, and Windows doesn't need you to run the defragmenting tool yourself these days. Your problems lie elsewhere.

Since taking over in March, writing the Talk Q. and A. hasn't been exactly what you could call a white-knuckle experience. Since the pages of The New York Times Magazine close more than a week before they hit newsstands, we can't outrun the news. So this week's interview with the C.E.O. of Netflix, Reed Hastings, provided some rare deadline drama. On Oct. 6, just as we were putting the finishing touches on the interview for the Oct. 16 issue, I got an e-mail from Netflix with the subject line "URGENT." If the magazine ran the interview with Hastings as planned, The New York Times would look "foolish." My contact refused to offer me any specifics about what was afoot, but he said I would understand early the following week. He was good on his word. The initial interview - in which Hastings provided his justification for spinning off the disc-only service of his company into Qwikster - would have made us look pretty dopey had we published almost a week after Netflix announced that it was ditching Qwikster altogether. So we quickly put moved up our Melissa McCarthy interview to run in Hastings's place. Hastings talked to me three days after the Qwikster mercy killing and I drew the entirety of this week's column from that one interview. But here's one exchange from that earlier interview that's worth rescuing.

It is a truism that children represent the future, but here in Afghanistan, that future is a very uncertain one. I have interacted with Afghan children as much as possible during the first half of my yearlong tour in eastern Afghanistan and am just as uncertain about the future of this country as when I arrived. While they have provided some of my best memories and most optimistic moments, they also have given rise to some of my deepest despair. While my experiences are by no means authoritative, I offer them as an imperfect window into Afghanistan's future.

Revolutions with the sidearm of the Internet expose much, not least perfidy. The Telegraph in London has a fascinating obituary of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi - serious, dryly funny - that contains the observation that the Libyan leader looked like "a parody of Sixties radical chic." It was those craggy features and retro blue-tinted shades. Colonel Qaddafi was no joke, but we once laughed (as the obituary noted) at his outlandishness. For a trip in 2002, to South Africa, his entourage consisted of a personal jet, two transport planes, a container ship filled with buses and goat meat, $6 million in petty cash and 400 security guards. Well, no more.

Colts (0-6) at Saints (4-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Saints by 14.The famous quote by the former N.F.L. commissioner Bert Bell - "On any given Sunday, any team in the N.F.L. can beat any other" - has been a source of reassurance for both fans and television programmers for decades. The league's carefully maintained competitive balance almost guarantees that every week will feature several compelling games between high-quality, evenly matched opponents. Almost.Bell would never imagine a week like this, in which the best (the Patriots) and most fascinating (the Eagles, the 49ers) teams have byes, while the top contenders face pushovers and the mediocre slug it out with the middling. Matchups that looked good when the schedule was announced now merit double-digit point spreads. Case in point: the Colts vs. the Saints, a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV that promised to be a seesaw offensive battle, is now little more than a three-hour wake for Indianapolis and a chance to watch Sean Payton coach New Orleans from the booth instead of the sideline.Granted, Curtis Painter, like a frozen burrito under a filling station heat lamp, is slowly warming to the Colts' starting quarterback job. His completion percentage has gone up every week, and the Colts offense no longer looks like an intramural team playing in a downpour. Also, Drew Brees offered hope that Payton might find a way to stand on, or slightly above, the field on the surgically repaired leg he broke in last week's game. "I'm envisioning some kind of hovercraft on the sideline," Brees said. Levitating coaches: another thing that Bert Bell could never imagine. Pick: Saints.

KRANTZ--Harriet. An elegant soul has left this earth. Dr. Harriet Lynne Krantz passed away on October 18th. She was the loved and cherished daughter of Solomon and Dorothy and the dear sister of Andrea. She will be remembered for her honesty, integrity and charitable heart. Everyone was blessed by her loveliness.

HEDGE FUND CUTS The hedge fund Perry Capital is retrenching, according to two people with knowledge of the situation, and has cut about 30 portfolio managers and analysts and three partners. Perry is also closing its Hong Kong office, these people said.

WHITE--Silvia N.,1928-2011. Beautiful and resilient, charming and strong willed to the end, Silvia Nunez White died on October 19, 2011 at the age of 82. A native New Yorker, she lived in Forest Hills Gardens since 1938 when her parents Luis Gaspar Nunez and Maria Luisa Reichard moved there from the upper west side. Her high school years were spent at Marywood Academy in Scranton, PA where she made lifelong friends. Her love of music and education remained constant throughout her life- first as a gifted pianist then as a member of the OLQM choir and in her career as a Bi-lingual Special Education Evaluator. A wonderful mix of Cuban, French and German heritage produced a woman who embraced life, craved order and was consistently authentic. An only child and a mother of six children-Lisa White (Michael LaVigne), Mimi Gabriel (Mark), Judy White, T.J. White (Heidi), Madeleine White and Elizabeth White and her grandsons Peter (Sarah), Christopher, T.J., Matthew, Martin and her great grandson Lucas, she will be missed by her family and many friends for her straightforwardness and clarity. Her husbands Edward Mangan and Thomas J. White predecease her. We always knew where to find our mother and now that pin on the map is gone. Services: Fox Funeral Home, 9807 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. Saturday, October 22, 2-7pm, Sunday, October 23, 2-7pm. Monday, October 24, 10:30am Funeral at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 7001 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, NY. Tuesday, October 25, 1:00pm Burial at Westhampton Cemetery, Westhampton, NY.

MCGINTY--John Edward. September 24, 1946 - October 14, 2011. John E. McGinty, a senior advisor in the investment banking department of UBS, died at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, MA on Friday, October 14 of complications of multiple myeloma. He was 65 years old. Born in St. Louis and educated at Northwestern University and the University of Chicago, McGinty began his career in 1970 at the boutique New York City investment firm of H.C. Wainwright, training with John Suydam as a machinery analyst in a revered research department. Wainwright was acquired by Weeden & Co. and in 1977, when the company closed its doors, McGinty moved to First Boston in the same role. He continued as a managing director when First Boston was acquired by Credit Suisse, providing coverage based on, in some cases, relationships that extended over three decades. Ranked by Institutional Investor magazine among the top machinery analysts in 31 of his 33 years in the industry (occasionally in more than one category), McGinty became the centerpiece of the firm's global effort in machinery. He was a voice of enthusiasm in the research department and a willing mentor to younger analysts, an uncommon trait on Wall Street. He retired from Credit Suisse in November 2006 and moved to UBS as a senior advisor in investment banking. A strong believer in education, McGinty served as a trustee to Salve Regina University, was an active alumnus of Chicago Booth, and contributed to initiatives at Milton Academy, the Rivers School, the investment committee of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, Goddard House in Brookline, MA, and Trinity Church Boston. He also established the first girls town soccer league in Montclair, NJ. An avid golfer and devoted family member, he is survived by five sisters, his wife of 40 years, Sarah Myers, and three children, John, Sarah, and William, all of Boston, MA. Funeral service and reception will be held at Trinity Church Copley Square Boston at 10am on October 22. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John E. McGinty history chair at Salve Regina University c/o the Office of the President, 100 Ochre Point Ave., Newport, RI 02840.

ARONSON--Helen S.,at the age of 94. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Ellen and David. Cherished sister of the late Dorothy and Alex. Adoring "Mana" of five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

The illness that has forced has forced the tenor Gary Lehman to withdraw from the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Siegfried,'' the third installment in the company's new ''Ring'' cycle, is an energy-sapping virus, his manager said on Thursday. Just hours after Wednesday's rehearsal, the Met said it would replace Mr. Lehman, 47, for the three performances this fall; opening night is Oct. 27. Filling in will be his cover, Jay Hunter Morris, who sang Siegfried at the San Francisco Opera. Reviews of Mr. Morris were not spectacular but the role is the most punishing in the heroic tenor repertory and the world has always been short of Siegfrieds. Ben Heppner, considered a leading Wagner tenor, was originally cast by the Met but withdrew in February because he was said to have found the role difficult and ungratifying.

Michigan State might have beaten rival Michigan rather easily last Saturday in East Lansing, but the reverberations from the game are far from over. Spartans defensive end William Gholston was suspended by the Big Ten Thursday for Saturday's game against Wisconsin. The conference also issued a public reprimand to Gholston for his punch to the face of Michigan lineman Tyler Lewan, who had helped Gholston up off the ground after a play.

To judge by the television ratings, some people just cannot seem to get enough of the Republican presidential debates. Perhaps to satisfy that appetite, Fox News said Thursday that it would sponsor two additional debates, adding to an already packed schedule of face-offs.

The Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain is facing questions from social conservatives over whether he opposes abortion rights under all circumstances after he was interviewed Wednesday evening by CNN's Piers Morgan. ''I believe that life begins at conception,'' Mr. Cain told Mr. Morgan, adding, ''and abortion under no circumstances.''

HASTORF--Albert H.,Professor of Psychology, 90, died September 26. He received a BA and an Honorary MA from Amherst College and an MA and PhD from Princeton University. He was a pioneer in the study of social interaction and social perception. He spent 30 years teaching, doing research and serving as a top administrator at Stanford as Dean of Humanities and Sciences followed by four years as Vice President and Provost. He was a Professor and Chairman of the Psychology Department at Dartmouth College and A Memorial Service will be held at 3:30pm, on Wednesday, October 26 at Stanford University Memorial Church.

PARIS -- A strike by workers at the Musee d'Orsay postponed the long-awaited reopening of the museum's newly renovated galleries on Thursday. Some 34 employees, mostly security guards, staged the walkout to protest the fact that no additional workers had been recruited at the museum despite the addition of more than 21,000 square feet of display space, a museum spokeswoman said. That decision was made amid broad government cutbacks that see retiring civil servants - including museum workers - not replaced by new hires. The museum, in a former railroad station, opened 25 years ago and holds what is regarded as the world's greatest collection of Impressionist works.

ROSENBLUM--Joan, age 87, in New York City on October 20, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Marvin and loving partner of the late Herb Gersten. Devoted mother of Wendy Schuman and husband Ken. Adoring grandmother of Cory Schuman Buckland, Andy Schuman and Cory's husband Mike. Proud great-grandma of Emma. Dear sister of Lila Baldridge, loving aunt. A woman of style, substance, and spirituality. Longtime owner of Joans Sportswear. Friend and fashion guru to many. A true New Yorker. Thank you to her amazing caregivers, Doreen and Sandra. Service Sunday, October 23, 2011, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

MOORE--George C.,81, of New York and Watch Hill, RI, died peacefully on October 19 after a bicycle accident on Madison Ave. Son of the late Thomas Moore and Marion Hiscox, brother of Thomas, Jr. and the late Susan Markham. A pianist, musicologist (particularly of Jerome Kern) and daily swimmer. Graduate of Portsmouth Priory, and class of '53 at Bowdoin College. Beloved husband of Audrey Connell for 50 years on November 4th. For decades George donated and collected blood for Lenox Hill Hospital, did "sing alongs" for patients at Mary Manning Walsh and McKeen in West Palm Beach. Adored father of George C. Moore, Jr. (Catherine) and Nicholas C. Moore (Allison). Grandfather of Chip, Faith, Julia, Nick and Christina. Frineds may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. this Sunday 4:30pm-7:00pm. Funeral Mass at St. Jean The Baptist, Monday 11am. Donations to a charity of choice would be most appreciated.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a malicious new program thought to be created by the designers of the Stuxnet computer worm referred incorrectly to the method by which the new program, called Duqu, gains access to digital data. Duqu is a Trojan horse program, not a worm. The error was repeated in the headline.

An article on Thursday about the salmon industry's reaction to a deadly marine virus having been detected in British Colum- bia misspelled the surname of an official at the United States De- partment of Agriculture, who contends that Pacific salmon are more resistant to viruses than those in the Atlantic. She is Jill Rolland, not Rowland.

Leonard Cohen, the celebrated songwriter, dropped the news that he will release his first album since 2004 sometime next year, Reuters reported. Mr. Cohen, in Spain to receive a literary award, said the album has already been recorded and contains 10 unreleased songs. It will be called ''Old Ideas.'' ''I've played it for a few people, and they seem to like it,'' Mr. Cohen, who is 77, said. He spoke to reporters in the Spanish town of Oviedo, where he had traveled to pick up the Principe de Asturias Prize for literature, which he was awarded in June for his poetry. The award is given each year by the Asturias Foundation to an outstanding author who does not write in Spanish.

GARVEY--Rev. John F.,S.J., died on October 19, 2011. Son of Thomas (deceased) and Patricia Grivach (deceased); brother of Bro. Thomas J. Garvey S.J. (deceased). Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1944; entered the Society of Jesus on August 14, 1962 at Lenox, MA. Fr. John worked in the Jesuit Missions in the Caroline Islands, and also at St. Ignatius Retreat House in Manhasset, L.I. He was Campus Ministry Director at Xavier High School from 1989-95, and also was Associate Pastor at St. Ignatius Church, Manhattan for a number of years. Most recently, Fr. John was Publications Assistant for the New York Province of Jesuits. Visiting is on Friday, October 21 at the Jesuit Community, 53 East 83 Street, New York, NY from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, October 22 at 11am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations may be made in Father John's name to the New York Province of the Society of Jesus, 39 East 83 Street, New York, NY 10028.

An article on Wednesday about an exhibition of works by Alexander Calder at the Pace Gallery on East 57th Street in Manhattan that focuses on his work in 1941 misidentified the studio in which some well-known photographs of Calder were taken that year. While it was indeed a studio on his property in Roxbury, Conn., it was not the studio there that Calder fashioned from an old icehouse.
