The Senate voted 74-26 on Thursday to confirm the nomination of John Bryson to be the next commerce secretary, ending a months-long struggle over President Obama's choice. Mr. Obama nominated Mr.. Bryson to replace the outgoing secretary, Gary Locke, in May. Mr. Locke succeeded Jon M. Huntsman Jr. as U.S. ambassador to China. Senate Republicans threatened to block Mr. Bryson's confirmation unless Mr. Obama submitted long-delayed trade agreements with Colombia, Panama and South Korea for congressional approval. He did so, and Congress passed those trade deals last week.

An article on Wednesday about a legal dispute over the sale of a home once owned by Norman Mailer misidentified the location where Mailer stabbed one of his wives, Adele. It occurred in their home on the Upper West Side, not in Brooklyn Heights.

Two philanthropic organizations are uniting to save celebrities like Hilary Swank and Beyonce from the embarrassment of getting caught taking money from people or groups that abuse human rights. Global Philanthropy Group, a celebrity-focused advisory firm, and Human Rights Watch on Thursday announced a free, confidential service to help stars and their handlers verify the records of people who want to hire them to appear at birthday parties and other private events.

An article on Wednesday about the new autobiography of the former Los Angeles Lakers great Jerry West misstated the year and circumstances of a surprise visit by the Boston Celtics star Bill Russell at a ceremony honoring West, where he told West: ''If I could have one wish granted, it would be that you would always be happy.'' It was at Jerry West Night at the Forum in 1971, not at West's farewell ceremony as a player in 1974.

9 P.M. (13) PEARL JAM TWENTY In this ''American Masters'' documentary, part of the PBS Arts Fall Festival, the director and music journalist Cameron Crowe culls material -- from more than 1,200 hours of rarely seen film footage and an additional 24 hours of recently shot concert and interview video -- to profile the Seattle-based rock band. Mr. Crowe begins with the period leading up to the group's formation (it is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year), the chaos the resulted not long after its rise to stardom and its step back from center stage. Among those interviewed are the band members (above, from left) Mike McCready, Matt Cameron, Eddie Vedder, Jeff Ament and Stone Gossard, as well as the Soundgarden singer and guitarist Chris Cornell. Mother Love Bone, Temple of the Dog, Kurt Cobain and Neil Young are seen in archival clips. Taylor Hackford narrates. 7:35 A.M. (Sundance) FLIGHT OF THE RED BALLOON (2008) The Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien creates a love letter to Paris -- and to Albert Lamorisse's 1956 classic, ''The Red Balloon'' -- in this tale about Suzanne (Juliette Binoche), above, a puppeteer; her lonely, 7-year-old son, Simon (Simon Iteanu); and Song (Song Fang), a Chinese film student hired to be his nanny. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said: ''In the end what elevates Mr. Hou's films to the sublime -- and this one comes close at times -- are not the stories but their telling. In 'Flight of the Red Balloon' Mr. Hou plays with light and space on the small canvas that is Simon and Suzanne's apartment, moving the camera around as gracefully as if it were a brush (or a balloon).''
MYAN--Thomas John. August 30, 1932 - October 21, 2009 In loving memory. Mary

10:35 p.m. | Updated Two New York taxi medallions - aluminum plates that grant the right to operate a yellow cab - changed hands this week for $1 million apiece, the highest recorded sale since the city's modern livery system began. The sale was the culmination of decades of astonishing growth for the humble medallion, which is nailed to the hood of every yellow cab in the city. When New York issued its first batch of medallions in 1937, the going price was $10 even, or $157.50 in today's dollars.

NORWOOD--John. 90, Sportsman and Publisher. John Norwood, 90, of Cobb Isle Road, Water Mill, died peacefully on October 14th at his home in Water Mill, New York. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, nee Havemeyer, and five children, his daughters Christopher Norwood of Sag Harbor and New York, Karen Hoover of Chicago, and Nanette Norwood of New York; and his sons John H. Norwood, Jr., and Marquis James Norwood, both of New York. He is also survived by three grandsons, Forrest and Hamilton Hoover and James Norwood as well five great-grandchildren and two nephews, William and Guy Mills. His first two marriages ended in divorce. He was the son of the late Dorothy Swarbrick and O.Guy Norwood, a descendent of a family that become prominent in Gloucestershire in the 1450's; the Norwood family was established in America in the late 1640's, in Virginia, after a cousin, Sir William Berkeley, became governor. A graduate of Lehigh University, he was a lieutenant in Naval Intelligence during Word War Two. He had a long career in magazine advertising and publishing, starting at Life Magazine and then becoming part of the original Time-Life team that launched Sports Illustrated. He later became publisher of Sport Magazine and, at his death, was still publishing and writing Motorsports America, an annual book covering American Motorsport racing. Mr. Norwood, himself, raced extensively at major sports car tracks, including Lime Rock, Daytona and Bridgehampton. In 1959, as Team Captain, he led Franklin Roosevelt Jr's 5-car Fiat-Aborth team to a 1-2-3 finish in every national race in its class. A member of the Meadow Club, River Club and Queens Club in London, he was also a skilled and dedicated tennis player who routinely won club championship. Viewing and services will be held from 6 to 8 on Friday the 21st at the Brockett Funeral Home at 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, New York. Donations would be welcome to Health People, a Bronx program for families affected by AIDS, founded by his daughter, Chris, or to the Southampton Fresh Air Fund.

A hedge fund manager from a prominent Denver family is expected to plead guilty on Friday to insider trading charges. Bo K. Brownstein, the head of Big 5 Asset Management and a former banker at Credit Suisse in New York, is expected to appear in Federal District Court in Manhattan and admit to making illegal profits by trading on a confidential stock tip about a corporate merger, according to two people briefed on the case who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it.

A major study of nearly 360,000 cellphone users in Denmark found no increased risk of brain tumors with long-term use. Although the data, collected from one of the largest-ever studies of cellphone use, are reassuring, the investigators noted that the design of the study focused on cellphone subscriptions rather than actual use, so it is unlikely to settle the debate about cellphone safety. A small to moderate increase in risk of cancer among heavy users of cellphones for 10 to 15 years or longer still ''cannot be ruled out,'' the investigators wrote.

SZCZARBA--Robert H. Robert H. Szczarba, 78, of New Haven, CT, died peacefully at home surrounded by family and friends on October 18, 2011. He was the beloved husband of Arlene (Roschild) Szczarba for 56 years. Born in Dearborn, MI November 27, 1932, he was the son of the late Julia and Michael Szczarba. Bob received a BS in physics from the University of Michigan and a Masters and PhD in mathematics from the University of Chicago. He joined the Yale faculty of Mathematics in 1960. He was a leading figure in algebraic and differential topology. In addition to teaching and research, he served the mathematics department in numerous administrative roles and was appointed by Yale as Deputy Provost for The Physical Sciences and Engineering. An accomplished sculptor, he welded his love of mathematics and art, creating sculpture with a mathematical flavor. His commissions included: "Three Pentagons" which was presented to Mathematical Association of America in Washington, D.C. and "Continents." for Yale University. In addition he had numerous exhibitions in New Haven. Bob enjoyed music, film, sports, and the arts. He is also survived by his son Gary (Susan) of Delaware, his daughter Cheryl (Bart Connors) of Connecticut, and his sister Rosemarie Riley of Michigan.

LIPTON--Edgar. The members of the NY Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Dr. Edgar Lipton. A devoted colleague and friend for 50 years, he will be dearly missed. We extend our condolences to his family. Roger Rahtz, MD, President

Betsy Pinover Schiff took some photographs that did not make it into her new book. Consider the ones from the apartment where the owner led her into the bedroom and told her, ''I don't want my wife to know about this.'' Ms. Pinover Schiff had been setting up equipment to photograph Central Park through the big picture window. She said she ''felt very uncomfortable'' when she realized the man had settled in on the bed. She took a few perfunctory shots ''so as not to appear rude,'' told the man she had another shoot somewhere else and left.

It is boilerplate language found in nearly every settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission: A company settles its case ''without admitting or denying'' wrongdoing. There it was again in the S.E.C.'s announcement on Wednesday that Citigroup had agreed to pay $285 million to settle a civil complaint that it had defrauded investors in a mortgage securities deal. The bank did so ''without admitting or denying'' the government's accusations.

LIPTON--Dr. Edgar Louis, 88; loved and loving husband of Judith, father of Maggie, Rosemarie, James, and Anne and grandfather of nine, passed away peacefully October 14th. He was the rock of our family, had a gentle spirit and a great sense of humor up until the very end. He was a U.S. Army Veteran, a prominent psychiatrist and long time member of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute. Services will be held Sunday, October 23rd at 2pm at Little Neck Jewish Center 49-10 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, NY.

An article on Tuesday about the discovery of a virulent virus in two wild Pacific salmon in British Columbia referred incorrectly to the remedies that are available to try to protect fish from the virus. Several vaccines have been developed to inoculate Atlantic salmon from the virus, infectious salmon anemia, although researchers say they are not fully effective and are impractical to administer; it is not the case that such vaccines are nonexistent.

The torments of the euro would be funny if they weren't so tragic. At this point the urgent need is for a big Panzerfaust -- a bailout fund big enough to head off a self-fulfilling liquidity crisis for Italy. But such a fund would be backed by the credit of the euro area's remaining AAA governments, basically Germany and France -- yet at this point the euro situation has deteriorated sufficiently that taking on another commitment would undermine French credit. There's a hole in the bucket, and every attempt to fix that hole ends up being stymied because, well, there's a hole in the bucket.

A followup on my last Iceland post. A key point there was that nominal wages are downwardly rigid -- it's very hard to cut them even if your country clearly has costs that make it uncompetitive. That's why "internal devaluation" is so difficult a strategy as compared with, well, devaluation devaluation.

Kashmir: An inquiry by an RTI activist found that the University of Kashmir has spent more than 2.16 crore Indian rupees, or 21.6 million (about $400,000), on vehicles for the university staff but has disbursed only 59 lakh rupees, or 5.9 million, towards student scholarships and fellowships in the last five years. It seems you can't have a Chloe Sevigny project without a character or characters trying to hide a shocking secret, whether it's a lover who disguises her gender (in ''Boys Don't Cry'') or a polygamist family concealing its multiple marriages (on the HBO series ''Big Love''). So try to sound surprised when you learn that there are a couple of unexpected twists to the character that Ms. Sevigny plays in her latest project, at least one of which is strongly hinted at in its title. In ''Hit and Miss,'' a new series that will be shown on the satellite service DirecTV, she portrays a character named Mia who is a hired assassin as well as a pre-op transsexual. When Mia learns she's had a son by an ex-girlfriend who is dying of cancer, she is forced ''to mix her killer instincts with her newly acquired maternal ones'' (hey, that's what it says in the press release). ''Hit and Miss'' is created by Paul Abbott, whose previous series include the British programs ''Cracker,'' ''State of Play'' and ''Shameless'' (which was adapted for American viewers on the cable channel Showtime). DirecTV said on Friday that it would show ''Hit or Miss'' next year on its Audience Network, though an exact debut date remains - what else? - a secret.

FREUDENBERGER--Joachim. We mourn the death of Joachim Freudenberger, son of Dr. Rudolf and Amalia. Survived by wife Shirley, children Michelle (Andy Dimond) and Ron (Emily), siblings Marion Freilich and Joseph, and grandchildren Eve and Max. He died from complications of Parkinson's disease in his home surrounded by his family on October 19, 2011. He was born November 1, 1924 and fled Nazi Germany in 1938 to NY where he studied at Brooklyn Technical High School and CCNY. He was a decorated Army veteran. He was a great person, teacher, husband, grandfather and father. He will be missed by all. Funeral services Sunday at 9:45am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

CHICAGO (AP) -- Theo Epstein is joining the Chicago Cubs as president of baseball operations. The 37-year-old Epstein resigned from the Boston Red Sox on Friday night with a year remaining on his contract as general manager to run a team that has gone 103 years without a World Series championship.

There seems to be a constant battle between what we have, what we need and what we think we want. About a year after my wife and I had our first child, we moved into a neighborhood with homes built decades earlier. Each had two or three bedrooms. We soon noticed that when people had a third or fourth child, they moved from the neighborhood in search of more space. I mentioned this to my next-door neighbor, who was 70 at the time, and he expressed surprise.

Ingvar Wixell, a Swedish baritone whose intelligent, vivid performances in the Italian repertory made him a respected fixture on the world's opera stages, died on Oct. 8 in Malmo, Sweden. He was 80. His death was announced on the Web site of the Deutsche Oper in Berlin.

LORBER--Jerome Zachary; 93 years old, joined his beloved Bette on October 21, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Perlish Lorber and Bette Weintraub Lorber. Devoted father of Dan and Deborah Lorber, Henry and Elizabeth Lorber, Julia Benson, Carol and Lawrence Rizzolo. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Eric, Kathryn, Michael, Sarah, David, Gregory, Douglas, Trevor, and Cathy. Loving stepfather of Barbara and Stewart Sims, Richard and Patti Weintraub, Mark and Alice Weintraub. Proud grandfather and great-grandfather to Bette's grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Jerry was a proud graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. He was admitted to the Bar of the United States Supreme Court, but never practiced law. From 1941 to 1945, he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army General Staff In the Pacific theater, receiving a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. Coming home after the war, he married Ruth Frank. He became President of Woodside Savings and Loan and began an illustrious real estate career, housing many returning veterans of the Korean War in Queens. He became President of Temple Sinai in Roslyn and was active in numerous Jewish organizations. Jerry was an active philanthropist, generously donating to many, many charitable organizations. He was a believer in education and funded an important medical education initiative at Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he was a life trustee. He was an avid reader of history, political science, and philosophy, always ready to discuss these topics with great wisdom. He leaves a legacy of love and knowledge for generations to come. Donations in Jerry's memory can be made to the Bette and Jerome Lorber Center for the Advancement of Medical Education at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Services, Sunday October 23, 2011 at 1:30pm; Temple Beth-El of Great Neck.

Former Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina may have not have been able to run for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination after his 2009 cheating scandal, but he will at least get to talk about the campaign on national television - as a paid contributor on Fox News, the Caucus has learned. A network spokeswoman confirmed that Mr. Sanford, once considered a potential Republican presidential contender, has signed on with the network. While he is certain to appear prominently at the debate Fox News is holding in South Carolina in January, he will appear well before that and will stay on with Fox even beyond the general election.

DUVAL--Betty Ann, passed away Saturday, October 15, 2011 at home in Bronxville, NY after a long and courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. Betty Ann was born on May 13, 1921 in Bolivar and raised in Richmond, MO, the daughter of William and Marie Townsend Duval. She is survived by her sister-in-law Barbara Duval of Muscatine, IA, several cousins and many friends. She was preceded in death by her parents William and Marie Townsend Duval and her brother William. She graduated from DePauw University, Greencastle, IN. Betty Ann loved life, her family and her friends. She had a generous heart and her natural kindness and generosity earned her friendships where ever she went. Betty Ann found her true calling in working with people. She enjoyed a long and successful career in Human Resources. In her early career with R.C.A. then General Foods and later Dow Jones and Co. After retirement she became a consultant to various companies. She was active in the Reformed Church of Bronxville, a former member of great consistory, a former advisory board member for the Bronxville Senior Citizens Council. A former board member of Hope College in Holland, Michigan. A former board member of 900 Palmer Road, Inc. Cooperative and a member of General Foods Northeast Alumni. A memorial service will be held Thursday, October 27, 2011 at 2pm at the Reformed Church Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in her name to The Reformed Church Music Fund, P.O. Box 397, Bronxville, NY 10708-0397.

The Rubin Museum of Art, the only museum in the United States dedicated to arts of the Himalayas and India, announced that its founders, Shelley and Donald Rubin, had donated $25 million to help support operations, exhibitions and programs over the next five years. It also said that Mr. Rubin has decided to step down as chief executive in a plan to broaden the museum's leadership and fund-raising operations. Patrick Sears, formerly the chief operating officer of the museum, has been named deputy director and will assume many of Mr. Rubin's responsibilities. Ms. and Mr. Rubin will continue to lead the museum's board.

A Long Island credit union, seeking to capitalize on growing antibank sentiment, is offering new customers guaranteed ''fee free'' checking accounts -- for life. Bethpage Federal Credit Union says that, effective immediately, new customers opening a Bethpage Bonus checking account can be assured of a lifetime of no debit card fees, no monthly maintenance fees, no transaction fees, no minimum balance fees and no fees charged by Bethpage for use of other banks' A.T.M.'s. In addition, there are no fees for online, mobile or telephone banking.

9 P.M. (Starz) LET ME IN (2010) Owen (Kodi Smit-McPhee), a trembling, big-eyed 12-year-old who is easy bait for the bullies at his new school, befriends a neighbor, Abby (Chloë Grace Moretz, above left with Mr. Smit-McPhee), an undead pixie. What follows is some horrifying violence at the same time that the area is terrorized by a serial killer. Owen assumes that the culprit behind the gruesome deeds is Abby's father, trying to fulfill his daughter's craving for blood. But the poor man botches his mission a lot of the time. And that gives Abby (and the film's director, Matt Reeves) ''a chance to show off some creepy computer-aided monster skills,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this ''worthy and honorable remake of 'Let the Right One In,' Tomas Alfredson's Swedish adaptation of the novel by John Ajvide Lindqvist.'' Mr. Scott added: ''The story holds a few surprises, but what makes 'Let Me In' so eerily fascinating is the mood it creates. It is at once artful and unpretentious, more interested in intimacy and implication than in easy scares or slick effects.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY In Part 2 of a series on end-of-life costs, Lucky Severson reports on the efforts of the Gundersen Lutheran Health Network in La Crosse, Wis., which since the 1980s has significantly reduced expenses by working with patients and their families to create written statements about the kind of care elderly patients choose. Mr. Severson also interviews Leith Anderson, a minister and president of the National Association of Evangelicals, who strongly supports advance directives. In another segment Saul Gonzales looks at the Claremont School of Theology in California, which has created Claremont Lincoln University, a controversial graduate program that will grant degrees to students who want to become ministers, rabbis or imams, with plans eventually to include Hindus, Sikhs and adherents of other religions.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a recommendation by the American Academy of Pediatrics that parents limit television time for infants and toddlers described incorrectly the professional credentials of Kristin Gagnier, who said she and her husband only occasionally let their 2-year-old daughter watch ''Sesame Street.'' She is a postdoctoral researcher at Temple University, not a postgraduate student.

The Drug Enforcement Administration took emergency action on Friday to ban three synthetic stimulants used to make products that are marketed at head shops and on the Web as ''bath salts,'' but are actually used as recreational drugs that mimic the effects of cocaine, LSD and methamphetamine. The emergency measure places these substances -- mephedrone, methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and methylone -- under the D.E.A.'s most restrictive category for at least a year, while they study whether they should be permanently banned. This classification is reserved for substances with high potential for abuse and no accepted use under medical supervision. These products, sometimes called plant food, are sold under names like Bliss, Purple Wave, Vanilla Sky and Ivory Wave. Though not approved by the Food and Drug Administration for consumption, they have become increasingly popular, especially among teenagers and young adults, the D.E.A. said. ''These chemicals pose a direct and significant threat, regardless of how they are marketed, and we will aggressively pursue those who attempt their manufacture and sale,'' Michele M. Leonhart, the agency's administrator, said in a statement. The longterm effects are unknown but the D.E.A. considers them ''potentially severe.''

An article on Tuesday about the decline in street homelessness in the Bronx misstated the position of Patrick Markee, a policy analyst with the Coalition for the Homeless, on the decline in the number of homeless people. While Mr. Markee, a critic of the city's methods of determining the number of homeless people, acknowledged that street homelessness had declined, he was referring only to the Bronx, not to the city at large.

An article in some editions last Saturday about the success of the Jets' kickoff return unit misstated the rule for out-of-bounds kickoffs. When a kickoff travels out of bounds between the goal lines, the receiving team can elect to take the ball 25 yards, not 30 yards, from the spot of the kick. On a standard kickoff from the 35-yard line, the receiving team would take possession at its 40-yard line, not its 35-yard line. (The receiving team may also choose to take possession at the spot the ball went out of bounds.)

Foye to become the next executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey misstated, in some editions, the length of time that Mr. Foye was a co-chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. Workers will be able to contribute more money to their 401(k) retirement plans next year, under new limits set by the Internal Revenue Service. The I.R.S. is increasing the maximum annual contribution that employees can make, without paying upfront taxes, to $17,000. The increase, required by law to adjust for inflation, is $500 higher than this year's level. The ceiling hadn't been raised since 2009 because inflation had been too low to trigger an increase.

Pat Schoenfeld, the widow of the powerful Broadway theater owner and producer Gerald Schoenfeld, has completed work on his forthcoming memoir, ''Mr. Broadway: The Inside Story of the Shuberts, the Shows and the Stars,'' which is set to be published in April by Applause Books. As the longtime chairman of the Shubert Organization, Mr. Schoenfeld, along with his business partner Bernard B. Jacobs, provided homes to some of the greatest Broadway hits, including ''A Chorus Line,'' ''Cats,'' ''Les Miserables,'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' Ms. Schoenfeld, a beloved Broadway figure in her own right, said in an interview that Mr. Schoenfeld finished the book shortly before his death in 2008 at 84. Six months later she read the manuscript for the first time and began editing parts of it, which was largely drawn from dictated recordings that Mr. Schoenfeld made to an assistant. She wrote a prologue and epilogue, while also ''adding quite a bit'' of details to anecdotes about his business dealings and personal life.

WHITE--Silvia N.,1928-2011. Beautiful and resilient, charming and strong willed to the end, Silvia Nunez White died on October 19, 2011 at the age of 82. A native New Yorker, she lived in Forest Hills Gardens since 1938 when her parents Luis Gaspar Nunez and Maria Luisa Reichard moved there from the upper west side. Her high school years were spent at Marywood Academy in Scranton, PA where she made lifelong friends. Her love of music and education remained constant throughout her life- first as a gifted pianist then as a member of the OLQM choir and in her career as a Bi-lingual Special Education Evaluator. A wonderful mix of Cuban, French and German heritage produced a woman who embraced life, craved order and was consistently authentic. An only child and a mother of six children-Lisa White (Michael LaVigne), Mimi Gabriel (Mark), Judy White, T.J. White (Heidi), Madeleine White and Elizabeth White and her grandsons Peter (Sarah), Christopher, T.J., Matthew, Martin and her great grandson Lucas, she will be missed by her family and many friends for her straightforwardness and clarity. Her husbands Edward Mangan and Thomas J. White predecease her. We always knew where to find our mother and now that pin on the map is gone. Services: Fox Funeral Home, 9807 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. Saturday, October 22, 2-7pm, Sunday, October 23, 2-7pm. Monday, October 24, 10:30am Funeral at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 7001 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, NY. Tuesday, October 25, 1:00pm Burial at Westhampton Cemetery, Westhampton, NY.

''Shakespeare in Love,'' the 1998 romantic comedy that won seven Academy Awards, including best picture and acting honors for Gwyneth Paltrow and Judi Dench, is the latest film being eyed for adaptation to the stage. Two leading producers, Disney Theatrical Productions and the British impresario Sonia Friedman, have been holding meetings with the playwright Tom Stoppard - who shared an original screenplay Oscar for ''Shakespeare in Love'' with Marc Norman - and the director Jack O'Brien about the project, according to theater executives familiar with the creative discussions. The new version would be a straight play, an exception to the movie-to-stage trend; most films these days are turned into musicals, most recently ''Catch Me If You Can,'' ''Ghost,'' ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert,'' and ''Sister Act.'' Mr. Stoppard and Mr. O'Brien are long-time collaborators on plays: They won Tony Awards -- for best play and best director -- in 2007 for Mr. Stoppard's Russian-history drama ''The Coast of Utopia,'' and they were both Tony nominees in 2001 for ''The Invention of Love.''
LORBER--Jerome Z. Bless you and thank you for all your kindnesses over all the years. You will always be "Pop" to me. Sending love and comfort to your children and grandchildren.

Survived by his three children: David C. Beebe, III, Evelyn L. Beebe, and Scott M. Beebe as well as eight grandchildren. Predeceased by his loving wife of 49 years, Jean Lewis Beebe in 2002. An article on Sept. 16 about a national election in Denmark that the ruling center-right party lost to a center-left coalition misstated the outcome of a push by the Danish People's Party, an anti-immigration party, for Denmark's withdrawal from the so-called Schengen agreement, which creates what has been called a ''borderless'' Europe. The Danish People's Party, which had often voted with the ruling party, failed in its efforts to persuade the country's leaders to pull out of the agreement. The party did not successfully push for Denmark's withdrawal. Readers pointed out the error in e-mails to The Times on Sept. 16. This correction was delayed for research on other points in the article.

The soprano Anna Netrebko has once again canceled her New York recital debut, which was scheduled for Carnegie Hall next Wednesday. This time she cited a doctor's order to rest her voice for 10 days after a long and taxing run singing at the Metropolitan Opera. Ms. Netrebko gave seven performances in the title role of Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena,'' the last on Tuesday - eight days ahead of her recital. She was to have sung a program of songs by Tchaikovsky and Rimsky-Korsakov, accompanied by the pianist Elena Bashkirova.

On April 24, 1993, I legally adopted my daughter in Asuncion, Paraguay. I will never forget that day. I was a complete nervous wreck. Our adoption was being expedited because the first free elections in decades were to be held that spring, following the 35-year rule of the dictator Alfredo Stroessner, who was ousted in a military coup in 1989.  There was much uncertainty as to whether the election would even take place, and concern that another military coup might prevent it. Tanks were in the street, and there was a sense that the country might well fall in to a civil war.
David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Soussa, Tunisia, where the first democratic elections since the beginning of the Arab Spring are underway.

North American moviegoers were in the mood to be scared over the weekend, powering the micro-budgeted "Paranormal Activity 3" to a stronger-than-anticipated $54 million in ticket sales. That total, easily enough for No. 1, prompted Paramount Pictures, the studio behind this wildly successful horror franchise, to shriek with delight, or at least superlatives. (According to Paramount, the opening weekend total for "Paranormal Activity 3," which cost just $5 million to make, is the biggest in history for a horror film -- not accounting for inflation.) The studio partly attributed strong sales to strikingly positive reviews, which helped draw more moviegoers in their 30s and 40s.

If anything is certain about the recent discovery of infectious salmon anemia in two wild juvenile salmon in British Columbia, it is the extent of the uncertainties. Questions range from whether its discovery will be confirmed in additional laboratory tests to whether it has spread widely to how to contain it. Filling in the unknowns is the first order of business.

An up-and-coming festival dedicated to Latin and African dance moves kicks off in Prague's Old Town on Nov. 2. Heading into its second year, the Afro-Bailar Festival is taking over the Latin dance club Palanca on the fifth floor of the newly renovated Kotva department store (Namesti Republiky 8; www.palanca.cz), with a solid offering of international dance performances and workshops. There will be a little of everything, from salsa, reggae and tango to the sweet rhythmic beats of Africa's popular kizomba, mbalax and semba music.

Outlook magazine's issue this week is an anniversary special about India's much discussed youth. In the lead essay, Akash Kapur, who previously wrote the International Herald Tribune's Letter from India, says the youth's "optimism and self-assuredness, their faith in the future, have come to sand, metonymically, for a nation that is itself regularly rates, in surveys and opinion polls, as among the most optimistic and self-assured in the world." The special also includes interesting features about young Indian politicians, journalists, entrepreneurs and the cosmetics business.Tehelka has a story on the plight of residents of Delhi slums who have been evicted to make way for shopping malls, apartments and other new developments. Many of the evicted residents have ended up in worse conditions further away from the city, the piece argues, because local authorities have not made any provision for low-cost housing. One evicted resident tells the magazine: "For the government, we are like cattle who have strayed into their fields uninvited."

An article last Sunday about a proposal to create a memorial park in Greenwich Village for AIDS victims and the New Yorkers who cared for them misstated part of the name of an organization for which Paul Kelterborn, an advocate for the memorial, works. It is the Municipal Art Society, not the Municipal Arts Society. And because of an editing error, the article misidentified the agency that will receive advisory recommendations on the plan. It is the City Planning Commission, not the Department of City Planning.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Seemingly Ordinary Game, Then the Player Dies,'' Oct. 20: As a physician and the father of a high school lineman, I think the story of Ridge Barden, who died from a subdural hematoma sustained during a football game, makes it all the more compelling to say that despite the admirable interventions to protect brains, what is needed now are drastic changes in the rules of the game that diminish the trauma to which we expose its players.

SIEGEL--Norman H. Dr. Norman H. Siegel, 91, passed away Monday, October 10, 2011. He was born March 23, 1920 in Manhattan, New York. He was preceded in death by his wife Grace. Norman attended PS79 and PS80 primary schools and Dewitt Clinton High School in the Bronx. He attended New York City University graduating with a degree as an MD. Dr. Siegel then was in the service of our country from 1942-1945, as a bomber pilot with the 9th Air Force. After the service he attended Pace University majoring in Educational Communications. Dr. Norman Siegel worked his way thru the ranks serving as Director of Public Health, Director of Model Health Plans, Director of Outreach Services, and ultimately served as Assistant Commissioner of Health for the city of New York. He was made a Fellow of American Public Health. Was president of New York City alumni Assoc. He was invited by the American Health Assoc. to train people in India on Health and Hygiene and establish the American Public Health counterpart program. Dr. Siegel also went to Egypt to study the causes of Ameobiasis. Dr. Siegel also published the first baby book for New York City School Days, a publication, which went to all children and parents going to school for the first time. He helped develop articles and publications on child health services. Dr. Siegel was responsible for educational services and development of continuing medical education for staff and medical community. He was responsible for producing community materials for display at the meeting of Health Organization for New York City. Dr. Siegel also received a commendation from the city of New York for initiating the practice of giving all newborns a social security number. He retired in 1982 and settled in Pinellas Park Florida. Dr. Siegel and his wife will be inurned with military honors at Bay Pines National Cemetery in Bay Pines, Florida. Services handled by Garden Sanctuary Funeral Home: 727-391-0121. gardensactuaryfunerals.com
TICHNER--Alan. 3/2/27 - 10/22/03. Forever your Gloria.

''CALIFORNIA DESIGN, 1930-1965: Living in a Modern Way,'' at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, is (surprisingly, given the state's role in shaping our material culture) the first major museum survey of 20th-century California design. It features more than 350 items from the fields of design, fashion, film, ceramics, jewelry and photography. Traditional craft, like Edith Heath's pottery or Sam Maloof's furniture, is displayed alongside Modernist industrial designs using innovative postwar materials. The exhibition's showstopper is a re-creation of the living room of Charles and Ray Eames's house, Case Study House No. 8, for which the Eames Foundation lent hundreds of objects, providing a glimpse into the designing couple's private world. Through March 25, 2012. BROOKE HODGE
LEONARD--Carl. Dear Carl, we will always remember the wonderful times we shared with you and Leon. We'll miss you. Love, Barbara and Gary

Anita Caspary, the onetime mother superior who led the largest single exodus of nuns from the Roman Catholic Church in American history, died on Oct 5 in Los Angeles. She was 95. Her death was confirmed by a spokesman for the Immaculate Heart Community, a lay Christian group that she and the 300 nuns who followed her established in 1970 after their break with the church.

REVOLUTIONS with the sidearm of the Internet expose much, not least perfidy. The Telegraph in London has a fascinating obituary of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi -- serious, dryly funny -- that contains the observation that the Libyan leader looked like ''a parody of Sixties radical chic.'' It was those craggy features and retro blue-tinted shades. Colonel Qaddafi was no joke, but we once laughed (as the obituary noted) at his outlandishness. For a trip in 2002, to South Africa, his entourage consisted of a personal jet, two transport planes, a container ship filled with buses and goat meat, $6 million in petty cash and 400 security guards. Well, no more. Although some quarters of the fashion world continue to plead for a frivolousness that seems as naff as those blue shades (let's face it, we have a lot of old-school designers who haven't seen the light), there are small signs of sanity. Or so I like to think.

A picture caption today with an article about the new AMC television series ''Hell on Wheels,'' about the building of the Transcontinental Railroad, misstated the surname, based on information from AMC, of the character on the show played by the rapper and actor Common. It is Ferguson, not Jefferson.

An article last Sunday about the rising cost of renting in New York City misstated a rent increase offered to Tom Graney, a tenant at the Helena, at 11th Avenue and West 57th Street. He was offered a new rent of $3,590 for a one-year lease; it was not ''more than $5,000 a month.'' (The information about the increase was supplied to The Times by Mr. Graney. Efforts to reach his landlord, Durst Fetner Residential, to confirm his account in advance of publication were unsuccessful.)

An article last Sunday about airstrikes believed to have been carried out by American drones in Yemen on Oct. 14 attributed an erroneous distinction to an American killed in the attack. The American, Abdelrahman al-Awlaki, was at least the fourth American killed in such a strike, not the third. The others include his father, Anwar al-Awlaki, a Qaeda propagandist killed last month; Samir Khan, the editor of Al Qaeda's online magazine, who was killed in the same strike as the elder Mr. Awlaki, and Kamal Derwish, believed to be the leader of a group of Qaeda recruits from Lackawanna, N.Y., who was killed in November 2002.

THERE they go again, stealing the spotlight from their cowed and embittered progeny, the unforgivable but unforgettable monsters Mom and Dad. These Freudian demons have been showing up all over the place for ages, in recurring nightmares, best-selling memoirs and novels and, perhaps most deliciously, onstage. ''Ready or not, here comes Momma!'' Rose yells in ''Gypsy,'' that sharp-needled evergreen from 1959 and probably the greatest musical of all time. It makes sense that Rose, one of the fiercest and most flamboyant examples of the theater's cannibal parents, is a tiger stage mother and a thwarted actress. In the final scene she says to her daughter Louise (who works under the stage name of Gypsy Rose Lee), ''I guess I did do it for me.'' When Louise asks why, Rose answers, ''Just wanted to be noticed.''

A subheading on Oct. 2 with a review about ''The Swerve,'' Stephen Greenblatt's account of the legacy of the Roman poet Lucretius, referred incorrectly to the Renaissance humanist Poggio Bracciolini, who was instrumental in preserving Lucretius' writings. He sought out manuscripts of ancient authors for scholarly reasons; he was not a ''book dealer.'' The error was repeated in the Editors' Choice column on Oct. 9.

AFGHAN PORTFOLIO More photos taken around Afghanistan are online at nytimes.com/magazine. It happens every day, though it rarely makes the news. Families picnicking on the rocky banks of Lake Qargha; couples pedaling fiberglass swan-boats over the reflected Paghman Mountains; old men in shalwar kameez bumping volleyballs in Shar-e Naw Park; teenagers smoking hookahs in Karte Seh; children skipping school to play video games in the Old City's illicit arcades or constructing intricate dioramas from scavenged detritus or paying out paper kites -- almost as high as the tethered blimp that surveils Kabul -- from the barren terraces of Nadir Khan Hill; early-Friday-morning dogfights and bird fights; fathers and sons feeding pigeons outside the Mosque of the King of Two Swords; raucous dance parties at neon-lighted wedding halls; soccer and cricket in trash-strewn lots. After more than 30 years of war, Afghanistan's special tragedy -- its wonder -- is that the obstinate violence no longer represents an assault on daily life. Rather, life, in its obstinacy, represents a daily assault on the violence.

L IVERPOOL, England, was once the epicenter of the world's trade routes, so perhaps it is fitting that its waterfront is seeing a notable revival. In 2008 the city received the European Union's Capital of Culture Award in recognition of its contribution to the world of art, performance and music (Beatles, anyone?). The subsequent attention has led to major revitalization efforts to the city center, with particular attention to the area around the waterfront. Blocks that were previously home to boarded-up buildings now make up a lively downtown, with more cultural offerings than ever before.AMY ROSE DOBSON

WHITE--Silvia N.,1928-2011. Beautiful and resilient, charming and strong willed to the end, Silvia Nunez White died on October 19, 2011 at the age of 82. A native New Yorker, she lived in Forest Hills Gardens since 1938 when her parents Luis Gaspar Nunez and Maria Luisa Reichard moved there from the upper west side. Her high school years were spent at Marywood Academy in Scranton, PA where she made lifelong friends. Her love of music and education remained constant throughout her life- first as a gifted pianist then as a member of the OLQM choir and in her career as a Bi-lingual Special Education Evaluator. A wonderful mix of Cuban, French and German heritage produced a woman who embraced life, craved order and was consistently authentic. An only child and a mother of six children-Lisa White (Michael LaVigne), Mimi Gabriel (Mark), Judy White, T.J. White (Heidi), Madeleine White and Elizabeth White and her grandsons Peter (Sarah), Christopher, T.J., Matthew, Martin and her great grandson Lucas, she will be missed by her family and many friends for her straightforwardness and clarity. Her husbands Edward Mangan and Thomas J. White predecease her. We always knew where to find our mother and now that pin on the map is gone. Services: Fox Funeral Home, 9807 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. Saturday, October 22, 2-7pm, Sunday, October 23, 2-7pm. Monday, October 24, 10:30am Funeral at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 7001 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, NY. Tuesday, October 25, 1:00pm Burial at Westhampton Cemetery, Westhampton, NY.

LIKE--Barbara. Barbara Like, 65, of Weaverville, North Carolina. Barbara Like passed away on September 1, 2011 from cancer. Daughter of Benjamin and Esther Like, Barbara grew up in Teaneck, NJ. She attended Wellesley College for two years followed by studies in Israel, and then earned from Columbia School of General Studies, in New York City, her Bachelor's in Art degree in 1969, with Phi Beta Kappa honors, a Master's degree in Arts & Sciences in 1971 and her Masters degree in Music and Piano, in 1975, from the University of Missouri at Columbia. She subsequently lived in Santa Monica, CA; Pensacola, FL; Weaverville, NC; and Israel where she had made many friends. Barbara was a multi-talented and worldly "Renaissance woman." She was an accomplished piano soloist, chamber musician, classical music radio commentator and writer, with additional interests in the arts, including photography, and literature. Barbara also had an entrepreneurial side to her life. She successfully exhibited and sold her photography work, and also developed an interest in the management and renovation of real estate. In keeping with her independent and upbeat spirit, Barbara continued to retain a remarkable cheerfulness, lucidity and competence in bidding farewell to her cherished ones while in hospice care. She remained concerned to the very end about arranging for the needs of others. She was a class act. Barbara is survived by her husband Ed Hanlon, her siblings (Irving Like, Esq., Lillian Barbash, Arthur Like, M.D. their children (Robert Like, M.D. Sharon Like, Esq., Steven Like; Cathy Barbash, Susan Barbash, Shepard Barbash; Benjamin Like, Betsy Like, Gail Like, David Like, Sarah Rhatigan, Esq.); Barbara's former husband Haim Misholy, M.D. and by close friends, Celeste Pfau and Tom Pfau. Expressions of prayers and remembrances of our beloved Barbara may be posted at legacy.com. Donations in Barbara's name may be made to The American Cancer Society.

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies on Oct. 9, about efforts to create a town center in West Windsor, misstated the township's position on applying to the state for Transit Village designation. West Windsor has indeed filed an application, which is pending; it is not the case that officials decided not to seek the designation.

EVA ZUCKERMAN, the designer of Eva Fehren, a new fine-jewelry line, first started tinkering with jewelry while working for Mor Mor Rita, a high-end children's brand. ''Women actually bought my stuff,'' said Ms. Zuckerman, who put her Cooper Union fine arts background on hold for the opportunity to work for the jewelry designers Philip Crangi and later Monique Pean. ''They're such wonderful teachers,'' she said, crediting both mentors with instilling in her the importance of sustainable gems (like petrified wood and lapis lazuli stones) and innovative craftsmanship (like her delicate gold stackable bands and geometric rings and bracelets). And from the looks of her debut effort, this promising pupil gets a gold star. Eva Fehren jewelry, starting at $800. Go to roseark.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

BERNSTEIN--Amelia, of The Wyndham in Garden City, NY, died of a massive stroke on October 20, 2011. Born in Vienna, she was the youngest of three sisters. When Hitler annexed Austria in 1938, the family was forced to flee their beautiful home. Amelia and one sister, each carrying only a small suitcase and no legal documentations, were escorted from Vienna into Switzerland by a complete stranger; one of their father's Christian friends. The parents also escaped but the older sister, along with her husband and baby, died in the gas chambers. Throughout Amelia's life she made many friends. A published essayist and an accomplished sculptor, she also loved music and dance from the time she was a toddler, and never forgot a tune. Surviving are Harold, her husband of 65 years, son Donald of New York City, daughter Pamela and her husband, Larry Lahiff of Florida, granddaughter Molly Lahiff, brother-in-law Walter Roberts of Washington, DC, and sister-in-law Frances Ross of Long Island. There will be a private graveside service for family members.

Shaquille O'Neal was in Manhattan the other day, dunking, grabbing rebounds and even making his free throws. After announcing his retirement in June, was he preparing for a comeback after the lockout? No, that was the virtual Shaq; the real O'Neal was controlling his moves on the new digital download of EA Sports NBA JAM: On Fire Edition. O'Neal, an analyst on TNT, was hopeful there would soon be real N.B.A. games. Q.

The lights at the Kiel Opera House in St. Louis went dark after a philharmonic performance in 1991. Unused for years, the theater reopened on Oct. 1 as the Peabody Opera House, after undergoing a $78 million restoration that began in July 2010. Brian Hall of the St. Louis Convention and Visitors Commission called the renovation ''a revitalization linchpin,'' adding that it ''creates a very attractive tourism core to downtown St. Louis,'' connecting ''the historic late 1890s Union Station building two blocks away to our Gateway mall leading to our Gateway Arch.''

Colts (0-6) at Saints (4-2) Sunday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Saints by 14. The famous quote by the former N.F.L. commissioner Bert Bell - ''On any given Sunday, any team in the N.F.L. can beat any other'' - has been a source of reassurance for both fans and television programmers for decades. The league's carefully maintained competitive balance almost guarantees that every week will feature several compelling games between high-quality, evenly matched opponents. Almost. Bell would never imagine a week like this, in which the best (the Patriots) and most fascinating (the Eagles, the 49ers) teams have byes, while the top contenders face pushovers and the mediocre slug it out with the middling. Matchups that looked good when the schedule was announced now merit double-digit point spreads. Case in point: the Colts vs. the Saints, a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV that promised to be a seesaw offensive battle, is now little more than a three-hour wake for Indianapolis and a chance to watch Sean Payton coach New Orleans from the booth instead of the sideline. Granted, Curtis Painter, like a frozen burrito under a filling station heat lamp, is slowly warming to the Colts' starting quarterback job. His completion percentage has gone up every week, and the Colts offense no longer looks like an intramural team playing in a downpour. Also, Drew Brees offered hope that Payton might find a way to stand on, or slightly above, the field on the surgically repaired leg he broke in last week's game. ''I'm envisioning some kind of hovercraft on the sideline,'' Brees said. Levitating coaches: another thing that Bert Bell could never imagine. Pick: Saints. Bears (3-3) at Buccaneers (4-2) in London Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Bears by 1. The Buccaneers rookie defender Adrian Clayborn tried fish and chips for the first time as soon as Tampa Bay arrived in London on Monday. ''It didn't sit well with me at all,'' Clayborn told The Tampa Tribune. ''It messed up my stomach bad.'' Do not let Clayborn anywhere near steak and kidney pie. You would think that most Americans have encountered fish and chips by now, and conversely, that most Britons would be able to differentiate a football team worthy of international acclaim from, say, the Bears. However, Lovie Smith (whose Bears stayed in the United States until Thursday) expects something close to a home-field advantage. ''I'm told we have a big following overseas,'' Smith said, not realizing that many Londoners are still expecting to see William (The Refrigerator) Perry. Smith does not expect his Bears to be jet-lagged, any more than Raheem Morris expects his players to be cramped up from too much bangers and mash. Smith also hopes to win some new fans. ''I know the guys are excited about showing our brand of football over there,'' he said. The Bears brand includes Jay Cutler's occasionally uttering profanities, heard by a microphone, about the coordinator Mike Martz. Though if you really want to hear Cutler swear, get him to try bubble and squeak. Pick: Buccaneers.

Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

Core Jones, 20: I agree with the Occupy Wall Street demands. I'm a college student working for my education. Both my parents are cops, and I split the tuition payments with my father. I get paid about $300 if I work 20 hours at AutoZone in Brooklyn. They give me good hours, so it's $717 a month. But when I get out of broadcasting college, what job am I really going to get? I may have to go to Kansas just to get a normal job with low pay, and that frustrates me. I want to stay in New York. I was born and raised here. My dad was there in the civil rights movement; he was there on the Freedom Riders bus. He's actually happy that I'm protesting, coming here after school, after work, every single day. I haven't slept in three days. I clean garbage, stuff like that. I'm so tired, but I feel like doing anything I can because just being here is not enough. I feel like doing something to actually say I helped the cause.
MYAN--Thomas John. August 30, 1932 - October 21, 2009 In loving memory. Mary

BRACKLEY--Dean. Father Dean Brackley, S.J.,who joined the faculty at the University of Central America after six of his fellow Jesuits were killed at the height of El Salvador civil war, died of pancreatic and liver cancer October 16. He was 82. Originally a member of the Jesuits' New York province, Father Brackley joined the university's theology faculty after the 1989 murder of the Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter by Salvadoran military troops. An upstate New York native, Father Brackley was working as an educator at Fordham University and as a community organizer in Manhattan's Lower East Side when he offered to move to San Salvador. There, he administered the University of Central America's School for Religious Education from 1990 to 1996 and assisted in the work of schools for pastoral formation sponsored by the university. He also hosted numerous delegations of students from Jesuit universities, church leaders and journalists from the United States and elsewhere. He worked tirelessly for human rights and social justice in El Salvador. Father Brackley entered the Society of Jesus in 1964 and was ordained to the priesthood in 1976. He earned his doctorate in religious social ethics from the University of Chicago Divinity School in 1980. Early in his ministry he worked as a community organizer in the South Bronx, where he experienced the difficulties faced by people living in poor communities. Father Brackley was presented with an honorary doctorate of religious studies by Marquette University. He also served as a trustee of The University of San Francisco, where a scholarship for Latino students was established in his name, from 2003 until his death. The wake, funeral and burial for Fr. Brackley were all held in San Salvador. The funeral was at the chapel at the University of Central America.

The ''Block by Block'' column last Sunday, about Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, described incorrectly a former public school that was in the building now occupied by MoMA PS1, the contemporary arts center in the neighborhood. The building housed kindergarten through eighth grade. It was not a high school.

The most expensive apartment sale of the week in Manhattan, according to property records, was a 15-room, 6-bedroom co-op at 625 Park Avenue that had an asking price of $29.75 million - although the final sale price could not be confirmed before publication. But it came with a catch: It's a fixer-upper. A gilded fixer-upper, to be sure, but still a work in progress.

LIPTON--Dr. Edgar Louis, 88; loved and loving husband of Judith, father of Maggie, Rosemarie, James, and Anne and grandfather of nine, passed away peacefully October 14th. He was the rock of our family, had a gentle spirit and a great sense of humor up until the very end. He was a U.S. Army Veteran, a prominent psychiatrist and long time member of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute. Services will be held Sunday, October 23rd at 2pm at Little Neck Jewish Center 49-10 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, NY.

HASTORF--Albert H.,Professor of Psychology, 90, died September 26. He received a BA and an Honorary MA from Amherst College and an MA and PhD from Princeton University. He was a pioneer in the study of social interaction and social perception. He spent 30 years teaching, doing research and serving as a top administrator at Stanford as Dean of Humanities and Sciences followed by four years as Vice President and Provost. He was a Professor and Chairman of the Psychology Department at Dartmouth College and A Memorial Service will be held at 3:30pm, on Wednesday, October 26 at Stanford University Memorial Church.

ZACH COLLAROS The senior Cincinnati quarterback threw for three touchdowns and ran for two more in the fourth quarter, helping Cincinnati come from behind in the closing minutes to stay atop the Big East standings with a 37-34 victory against host South Florida. Collaros finished 26 of 41 passing for 389 yards. MARVIN MCNUTT The senior Iowa receiver, a former quarterback, caught three touchdown passes to become the Hawkeyes' career leader in a 45-24 victory against visiting Indiana. McNutt finished with six catches for a career-high 184 yards and now has 24 touchdown catches in his career. He had been tied for the lead with Tim Dwight and Danan Hughes. McNutt has 2,303 receiving yards, 313 behind the team record.

BEEBE--David C.,Jr, Age 80. Of Ridgefield, CT. Englewood, NJ native and son of the late David C. Beebe, Sr. and Lucretia Cott Beebe. Graduate of Englewood School for Boys and Yale University. After serving the U.S. as a Naval Officer, he began a long distinguished career in the marine insurance industry, serving as Chairman of the National Cargo Bureau, Chairman of the Cargo Reinsurance Association, Chairman of the War Risk Reinsurance Exchange, Director of the Associated Aviation Underwriters, Chairman of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters, culminating as the Managing Director of Marine at Chubb & Sons. Survived by his three children: David C. Beebe, III, Evelyn L. Beebe, and Scott M. Beebe as well as eight grandchildren. Predeceased by his loving wife of 49 years, Jean Lewis Beebe in 2002. Memorial service Saturday, October 29, 2011, 11:30am at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Ridgefield, CT. Memorial contributions to Housatonic Habitat for Humanity, 51 Sugar Hollow Road, Danbury, CT 06810, www.housatonichabitat.org, would be appreciated.
Film Neil Genzlinger

''AN infamous rear end'' was Alfred P. Sloan Jr.'s complaint about Chevrolets of the early 1920's, and when he gained power at General Motors he had the problem fixed. Sloan, who oversaw G.M.'s growth into one of the world's largest corporations, saw Chevrolet as a way to challenge Henry Ford's dominant Model T: for just a little more money, Chevy would give you much more car, along with a bit of style.

An article last Sunday about Susan G. Komen for the Cure, a nonprofit that raises money for breast cancer awareness and research, misstated the reason for a factual error in a public service announcement read by Dallas Cowboys players including Bradie James. The Komen group says the error was in the script it provided to the team; Mr. James did not misread it, as the group said earlier. And a picture caption with the article misidentified a breast cancer survivor whose shirt was being signed at a Cowboys game. She is Kendra Russell, not Jill Tarpenning.

SIMON--Sidney. We mourn the loss of Sidney Simon, for two decades one of the most loyal supporters of the research and clinical care endeavors of the Nathaniel Wharton Fund at Columbia University. Sid was one of the greatest generation of soldiers, winning a Bronze Medal and a Purple Heart in Korea. He was a decent loveable gentleman, successful president of his textile company, as well as a saxophonist, lover of music and literature, Lotosian and wonderful friend. We shall miss his genial presence. Our condolences to his wonderful wife Elaine, his children and grandchildren. Ralph N. Wharton, MD, Executive Director The Nathaniel Wharton Fund for Research in Brain, Body and Behavior

MASLANSKY--Dr. Lawrence of Rye, New York, on October 21, 2011 at age 99. Papa Larry was loved and will always be remembered by his wife of almost 70 years, Jean Maslansky, his sons and daughters-in-law, Harris, Jayne, Steve and Carol, his grandsons and granddaughters-in-law, Michael, Susie, Scott and Liz, and his great-grandchildren, Morgan, Max and Atticus. Dr. Larry was an extraordinary man, distinguished doctor, championship boxer, and lifelong big thinker. He was commanding officer of a hospital ship in World War II, and retired as a full Colonel after more than 40 years of active and reserve duty. Larry graduated the University of Louisville and the School of Medicine at University of Louisville. After settling in White Plains, NY, Dr. Larry was an allergist for thousands of patients over his more than 60 of medical practice. Those wishing to honor Larry's memory may consider donations to the charity of your choice.

EISMANN--Marianne P. Our beloved Marianne Phillippa Eismann of Newbury Park, CA, died after a long illness on October 19, 2011. Born January 8, 1958 in New York, NY, Marianne graduated from St. Ann's School in 1975, from Princeton University in 1979, and received an M.A. from the University of Chicago in 1984. Marianne taught literature and writing at the University of Chicago and Wake Forest University, among other institutions. A Dickens, Dante and Shakespeare scholar, Marianne was also a jewelry maker, hiker and Yankees fan, but she was never happier than when rescuing dogs. She is survived by parents, Bernard and Suzanne Eismann, brother, sister-in-law and nieces, Jonathan, Nia, Morgan and Landon Eismann, all of Miami, FL, aunt, Goldine Eismann, and husband, Alejandro Benes. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.
Dance Jack Anderson

REISS--Stephen. A wonderful human being deeply loved by all who knew him, Stephen Reiss died at the age of 89. Born in Brooklyn to Rena and Joseph Reiss he went to Lawrence High School and University of North Carolina. He then served in the US Navy rising to the rank of Lieutenant. He fought in Italy. Steve moved to San Francisco and worked in the advertising industry for many years. Steve most of all was a people person. He was a dedicated tennis player and avid skier. He was always the life of the party and loved music and the theater. He will be terribly missed by his brother Marc, sister-in-law Barbara and his longtime companion Iris Berman. His nephews, John and Adam, and niece Helenbeth Reynolds and their spouses Meryl, Sheri and John and children, Jill, David, Spencer, Michael, Jennifer, Michael Raye and Ryan will also terribly miss him but will always remember him.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Unflinching Underdog Working on an Upset,'' Oct. 15: How utterly refreshing to read of Heidelberg University's Davidic, nay quixotic, rendezvous with destiny in the form of invincible Mount Union. Its 150 nonscholarship players are my new paladins. How could one not be charmed beyond joy at the knowledge that the team nickname is Student Princes?

The Transpantaneira Highway, despite its grand name, is an unfinished dirt road running 90 or so miles from the Brazilian town of Pocone into the Pantanal, a vast wetlands many consider South America's finest destination for animal viewing. But it's not just a road: it's a crocodilian slalom course. As I jolted along in a rented Fiat Uno on a late August night, my headlights caught the glare of dozens of red eyes staring in the near pitch-black far ahead. They belonged to Yacare caimans, alligator cousins that had decided the road was a comfortable resting spot.

WHEN it comes to selling cars, few advertising boasts are more cherished than the claim to being first. For an automaker to declare that its car is first with a new feature is to proclaim inventiveness, boldness and exclusivity, all in a single word. Chevrolet has only rarely been the leader in this pursuit. It was not first with electric starters (that was Cadillac, in 1912) nor did it pioneer the use of turbochargers (Oldsmobile was an early adopter, in the 1960s). This was no accident: General Motors let its higher-priced brands introduce the breakthroughs. Chevy was the value brand.

He is survived by his mother, Carol Ebenstein Holtzmann, daughter, Jill van Berg, grandson, Theo Julian Manela, who gave him particular joy, sister, Louise Muller, and brother, William van Berg. He will be deeply missed always. A memorial service will be held in New York City on a future date.
Classical Allan Kozinn

CHEVROLET may be celebrating its centennial, but along with the century's highlights are missteps too glaring to be ignored. The 1917 Model D, for instance, was powered -- barely -- by a 288-cubic-inch overhead-valve V-8 that wheezed out 36 horsepower. It was short-lived, but at least it ran, unlike the 1923 ''copper-cooled'' 4-cylinder models, which used copper fins instead of water passages to inadequately cool its 135 cubic inches. Production was halted after five months, and all were recalled.

An article last Sunday about Mayor Rahm Emanuel's $150 million plan to make Chicago ''the bike-friendliest city'' in the United States incorrectly stated that a protected bike lane to be built on 18th Street is the only biking-related project slated for lower-income areas. Several blocks of another protected bike lane, to be built on Jackson Avenue west of the city's Loop, and sections of the Bloomingdale Trail, a two-and-a-half-long park to be built on an abandoned rail line from Wicker Park to Humboldt Park, will also be in low-income areas.

WRAPPING an American flag around a brand has long been a popular way to peddle products -- to Americans, certainly, and sometimes to citizens of other countries (say, Coca-Cola and Levi's). In this country, no other automobile line -- and few brands of any kind -- have been as successful as Chevrolet with flag-waving pitches. After years of unmemorable advertising slogans like ''Eye it, try it, buy it,'' the brand struck pay dirt with the theme ''See the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet,'' as promulgated through a catchy jingle that became identified with the singer Dinah Shore after she sang it in two Chevy-sponsored television series that ran from 1951 to 1963.

ABRAMS--Stuart Edward. Of New York City and Ancramdale, NY. Extraordinary spouse, father, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, cousin, friend, lawyer, historian, writer, pianist, cross-country skier, gardener, Red Sox fan. Born April 30, 1953 in Englewood, NJ, son of the late Dilys (Jones) and Selden Abrams, he died October 13, 2011 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Stuart was loved and admired by his spouse of 31 years, Caroline J. Downey, his children Alexandra and Stephen Abrams-Downey, his sister Nancy Abrams Gaess, his siblings-in-law Peter, Jim, Sally, Bob, Nancy, Steve, KT, Paul, Hallie, Eleanor and Jay, his 19 nieces and nephews, his cousins and his many friends. A 1974 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and Columbia Law School, 1977, he had been a partner at Frankel & Abrams since 1994 and was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. From 1982-1989, he was an Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York, where he served as Chief Appellate Counsel and Chief of the Major Crimes Unit. He also served as an Associate Independent Counsel for Iran-Contra Matters from 1989-1990. Those wishing to honor Stuart's memory may consider donations to Obama for America 2012 and Partners in Health. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 29, at 1:00pm at the Ethical Culture Society, 64th St and Central Park West.

SIMON--Sidney is mourned by Elaine, his soul mate of 62 years. He was the father of Karen and Bradley; adored and adoring grandfather of Ellen, Amanda, Glenn, Graham, Courtney, Michael, Jonathan and Madeleine and step-grandfather of Simon. Sidney was successful in nearly everything he did. He earned a purple heart and a bronze star fighting alongside the men of the 10th Mountain Division in World War II; he oversaw decades of growth as president of Dexter Knitting Mills; and he was a grandfather who led by example and taught his grandchildren to expect the best of themselves at all times. But it was as a husband where Sidney truly excelled. His absolute love for Elaine carried him through war, motivated him in business and informed each second he spent with his children and grandchildren. He passed away on October 20. He was 85.
Theater Ben Brantley

An article last Sunday about a new public fund that is meant to help mayoral candidates, even those with a slim chance of winning, pay for the cost of a campaign misspelled the name of one of the candidates. He is Bevan Dufty, not Beaven.

NATHAN--Murray L.,96, of New York City, died peacefully on October 10th. Loving husband of the late Belle Calderon Nathan. Adored uncle, great and great-grand uncle, cherished and trusted friend to many. In the 1930's Murray worked for the ILGWU, where he met Belle. Eager college students impassioned by education, the arts, and social/economic justice issues, they put their dreams on hold while Murray served in WWII. During his non-combat service, Murray took up leather crafts, with Belle sending him swatches from New York. After the war, they reinvented their wartime "hobby" skills, working side by side for the next four decades to build Calderon Belts & Bags, a thriving manufacturing business. In their long retirement, they continued traveling and devoted themselves to Philanthropy. Well into advanced age, Murray enjoyed reading, finishing The Times crossword puzzles, and family visits. Up to the end, he maintained his compassion for others and his kind, gentle manner, spiked with quick wit. We will miss him deeply. A private memorial service will be held.

LORBER--Jerome. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourn the loss of Jerome Lorber, husband of the late Bette. A Life Trustee, Jerry was a long-time benefactor of LIJ Medical Center. He was dedicated to medical education and the use of technology in its service. Thanks to his and Bette's generosity, the Bette and Jerome Lorber Center for the Advancement of Medical Education was established, ensuring that a variety of resources, special programs and activities are available to all LIJ medical residents. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Funeral services will be held at 1:30pm on Sunday, October 23, at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY, (516) 487-0900. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

MULLEN--Peter. The New Milford Hospital and Foundation families mourn the passing of Peter Mullen, a dear friend, board member and benefactor. We extend our sincere condolences to Mrs. Billie Mullen and members of the family.

The Occupy Wall Street protesters have endured the scoffs. They have endured the arrests. They have endured the sardine-can conditions in Zuccotti Park. (O.K., they bear some responsibility for that one.) But last week, even after the demonstrators had successfully occupied Times Square and Washington Square Park, they had yet another challenge: celebrities, in person and on Twitter, elbowing their way into the glow of the protest spotlight.

LAND--Thomas Howard, 87, of Mount Kisco, NY died on October 12. Graduate of Harvard University and University of Chicago School of Business. A successful career in market research was balanced by his love of public service, piano and opera. Tom is survived by his wife Phid; his children Thomas, Martha and Sarah; and four adoring grandchildren. Memorial donations in his name to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, AL 36104, www.splcenter.org.

AMERICANS who grew up alongside the Honda Accord or the Hyundai Elantra may not fully appreciate the chromed grip Chevrolet had on popular culture in an age when American wheels ruled the road. In the 1950s, if you tuned in ''The Dinah Shore Chevy Show'' on your Magnavox console TV, you heard the host belting out ''See the U.S.A. in Your Chevrolet.'' Starting in 1960, on CBS, George Maharis and Martin Milner roamed ''Route 66'' in a new Corvette, looking for adventure, lending a hand to strangers in need and creating a desirable career goal -- having a cool car, but no permanent job or home address -- for countless young viewers.

GUTMANN--Marge Rosen, on October 22, 2011. Loving wife of Bill Gutmann. Beloved mother of Amy Rosen and Jason and Melanie Rosen. Cherished grandmother of Lindsey and Sydney. Marge was an advocate and lover of the arts and worked for over twenty years as the Cultural Arts Director for the Town of Hempstead. Donations may be made to cancercare.org or Metropolitan Jewish Hospice. Services 11:30am Monday from "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels" 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

LONDON may be brimming with private members' clubs, but its latest, the newly revamped Arts Club in Mayfair, is creating quite a stir. Founded in 1863 by a group of friends (including Charles Dickens), the formerly fusty establishment has reopened with Gwyneth Paltrow, an investor, as its creative director. The stylish Art Deco-inspired interior designed by David d'Almada features marble floors, cashmere walls and art by Tomas Saraceno, John Baldessari and George Condo. Cameron Diaz, the photographer Mario Testino and the shoe designer Charlotte Dellal have been spotted supping in the restaurant, and Ms. Paltrow is known to belt out a few tunes at Club Nouveau, the nightclub downstairs that's run by Mark Ronson. Also on the mic at times are Ronnie Wood, Mica Paris and Noel Gallagher. It costs £1,000 to join (about $1,575), the same fee applies each year and the first list closes on Oct. 31. Being famous and fabulous is not a requirement, but it doesn't hurt to be either, or both. 40 Dover Street; (011) 44 20 7499 8581; theartsclub.co.uk. JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

LORBER--Jerome Zachary; 93 years old, joined his beloved Bette on October 21, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Perlish Lorber and Bette Weintraub Lorber. Devoted father of Dan and Deborah Lorber, Henry and Elizabeth Lorber, Julia Benson, Carol and Lawrence Rizzolo. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Eric, Kathryn, Michael, Sarah, David, Gregory, Douglas, Trevor, and Cathy. Loving stepfather of Barbara and Stewart Sims, Richard and Patti Weintraub, Mark and Alice Weintraub. Proud grandfather and great-grandfather to Bette's grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Jerry was a proud graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. He was admitted to the Bar of the United States Supreme Court, but never practiced law. From 1941 to 1945, he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army General Staff In the Pacific theater, receiving a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. Coming home after the war, he married Ruth Frank. He became President of Woodside Savings and Loan and began an illustrious real estate career, housing many returning veterans of the Korean War in Queens. He became President of Temple Sinai in Roslyn and was active in numerous Jewish organizations. Jerry was an active philanthropist, generously donating to many, many charitable organizations. He was a believer in education and funded an important medical education initiative at Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he was a life trustee. He was an avid reader of history, political science, and philosophy, always ready to discuss these topics with great wisdom. He leaves a legacy of love and knowledge for generations to come. Donations in Jerry's memory can be made to the Bette and Jerome Lorber Center for the Advancement of Medical Education at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Services, Sunday October 23, 2011 at 1:30pm; Temple Beth-El of Great Neck.
POSEROW--Sylvia (Greenfield), mother to Jean Gerson Greer and John Gerson, grandmother, and stepmother, at 97.

DYER--Elisha, 79, of Washington, CT, passed away peacefully October 17 after a long illness. He was born in New York City to the late Katharine Whitaker Dyer and Elisha Dyer of Brookville, NY, where he spent his childhood. A graduate of St. George's School and Brown University he served in the US Army for two years. He worked at Clark Dodge and later at Hilliard Lyons on the American Stock Exchange. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years Natalie (Hubbard) and his three daughters: Lili Dyer (Nick Benson) of Washington, CT; Diana Knoblauch (Loring) of Bedford, NY; Lissy Heminway (Bill) of Shoreham, VT and seven adoring grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Grace Aarons of Woodbury, CT and his niece Katharine Slack and nephew Randall Slack. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to either St. John's Church, P.O. Box 1278, Washington, CT 06793 or to the Steep Rock Association, P.O. Box 270, Washington Depot, CT 06794. A memorial service will take place at 11am at St. John's Church, Washington, CT on November 19th.
