The Nevada Republican Party decided on Saturday to push back the date of its presidential caucuses to Feb. 4, a move that brings a sense of order to an otherwise chaotic primary calendar and keeps New Hampshire from scheduling its voting before the New Year. The Republican National Committee had implored Nevada to reconsider its decision to hold the caucuses on Jan. 14, and the Nevada Republican central committee agreed on Saturday.

KRANTZ--Harriet. We're saddened by the loss of our cousin Harriet. She was a dedicated college professor, a tireless volunteer and most of all a loving and caring family member. She will be sorely missed. Stanley, Barbara and Andrew Feingold.

The 36 Hours column on Oct. 9, about Ann Arbor, Mich., misstated the phone number for the Ann Arbor Farmers' Market. It is 734-794-6255. The column also misstated the name of the street that Bob Seger, who grew up in Ann Arbor, sings about in his song ''Mainstreet.'' It is Ann Street, near Main Street; it is not Main Street.

A report on Sept. 18 about the marriage of Amy Gallo and Timothy Ryan described incorrectly CVS Caremark, the company from which the bridegroom's father, Thomas Ryan, retired as chairman and chief executive. It oversees the entire CVS drugstore chain, not just mail-order prescriptions.

Last Saturday, I saw what I bet was the first reality fashion show of the 21st century at New York's first Tweed Run. The event was a bicycle ride in which participants dressed in the style of 1930s and '40s England: tweed jackets, caps and knickers; contrasting vests, argyle socks, luggage-colored shoes and bow ties. The Tweed Run, founded in London in 2009 by enthusiasts of vintage clothes and cycling, was transported from London to New York by Ralph Lauren, and many of the participants wore clothes from his Rugby shop on University Place. There, tables were set up on the sidewalk, and the tweedy gang sipped tea from china cups between rides. They even danced to the music of a combo. The riders became instant models, replacing the uninspired old runway presentation. Welcome to the new autumn in New York.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Wheldon, Indy 500 Winner, Dies After Las Vegas Crash,'' Oct. 17: Dan's Wheldon's death might have been avoided if Las Vegas Speedway would have used the formula instituted by the American Automobile Association starting with the 1912 Indianapolis 500: 400 feet per car for the length of the track. The Indianapolis 500 track is two and half miles, or 13,200 feet. Divide 13,200 feet by 400 feet, and that leaves room for 33 cars. That is why the Indy 500 allows 33 entrants. The formula was calculated when the cars were traveling only 75 miles per hour, not 220.

MESSENGER--Rae Schragis, suddenly at age 77. Devoted daughter of the late Fanny and Jack Schragis. Beloved and treasured wife of Bert, mother of Scott and Nancy, sister of Shirley and the late Seymour Gordon and Alvin and Carole Schragis. Cherished grandmother of Alison and Jake. Caring aunt, cousin and friend. A vibrant and selfless woman, she did so much for everyone. She touched our hearts and will remain there forever.

NORWOOD--John. 90, Sportsman and Publisher. John Norwood, 90, of Cobb Isle Road, Water Mill, died peacefully on October 14th at his home in Water Mill, New York. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, nee Havemeyer, and five children, his daughters Christopher Norwood of Sag Harbor and New York, Karen Hoover of Chicago, and Nanette Norwood of New York; and his sons John H. Norwood, Jr., and Marquis James Norwood, both of New York. He is also survived by three grandsons, Forrest and Hamilton Hoover and James Norwood as well five great-grandchildren and two nephews, William and Guy Mills. His first two marriages ended in divorce. He was the son of the late Dorothy Swarbrick and O.Guy Norwood, a descendent of a family that become prominent in Gloucestershire in the 1450's; the Norwood family was established in America in the late 1640's, in Virginia, after a cousin, Sir William Berkeley, became governor. A graduate of Lehigh University, he was a lieutenant in Naval Intelligence during Word War Two. He had a long career in magazine advertising and publishing, starting at Life Magazine and then becoming part of the original Time-Life team that launched Sports Illustrated. He later became publisher of Sport Magazine and, at his death, was still publishing and writing Motorsports America, an annual book covering American Motorsport racing. Mr. Norwood, himself, raced extensively at major sports car tracks, including Lime Rock, Daytona and Bridgehampton. In 1959, as Team Captain, he led Franklin Roosevelt Jr's 5-car Fiat-Aborth team to a 1-2-3 finish in every national race in its class. A member of the Meadow Club, River Club and Queens Club in London, he was also a skilled and dedicated tennis player who routinely won club championship. Viewing and services will be held from 6 to 8 on Friday the 21st at the Brockett Funeral Home at 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, New York. Donations would be welcome to Health People, a Bronx program for families affected by AIDS, founded by his daughter, Chris, or to the Southampton Fresh Air Fund.

Rockaway, NY), beloved husband to Barbara and the late Sylvia; brother to Marilyn, the late Charles, Carolyn and Michael; father of Richard, Gila and Yosi, Gary and Sheryl, Eric and Karen, and Gail and Neil; grandfather of 12. HAMMER--Beatrice, 98, passed away peacefully early Thursday morning. Bee was the beloved wife of the late Paul Hammer, daughter of the late David and Rose Brickman and sister of the late Jacob and Bernard Brickman. She is survived by her daughters Gail Hammer Gatti and Joan Davis, son-in-law Claudio Gatti and granddaughter Rebecca Davis and grandson Aaron Hammer Gatti. Throughout her life she was an inspiration to her family and friends for her courage and generous nature. She grew up in New York, raised her family and worked as a teacher in the Yonkers public schools. Her family was fortunate to have her in their lives for so long. Bee will be remembered by all for her beautiful smile, her youthful spirit and her devotion to her family.

IN 1920, Gaston Chevrolet, driving a car he and his brothers Louis and Arthur built, won the Indianapolis 500. But he wasn't in a Chevrolet. Louis had co-founded the Chevrolet Motor Car Company, but by 1915 he had left to start two other companies, including Frontenac. So the Chevrolet brothers raced Frontenacs.

CHANDLER--Marvin H.,90, of Delray Beach, FL and formerly New York City. Beloved husband of Eleanor, loving father of Kathy Falk and Alene Goodman, adoring grandfather of four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. We will all miss you.

KENNEDY--Thomas P.,90, died peacefully at home, October 21. Loved and loving husband of Valerie; father of Kathleen, Kevin, Joanne, and Jerry; stepfather of Benjamin Kelly; grandfather of Emily and Patrick Schroder, Timothy and Ashley Kennedy, Marine van Voorthuysen and Molly Kennedy-Svolos; adoring companion of Bonnie. Born in Tralee, Co. Kerry, Ireland and raised in Dublin, Ireland. Immigrated to The United States 1947. Lived the rest of his life in New York City. Public Relations/Advertising Manager of Aer Lingus 1959-84, East Coast Director of American Ireland Fund 1985-99. Devout Catholic, world traveler, staunch Democrat, supported of all things Irish. His life defined the word "gentleman". Beloved patriarch. Great friend to many. Much loved by family and countless friends. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9pm. Mass, Wednesday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 11:30am, Burial on Thursday in Redhook, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to Irish Repertory Theatre or American Ireland Fund.

An article on Oct. 9 about an Argentinian woman's grappling with revelations that her father, a lieutenant colonel, was not her father but instead was responsible for murdering her parents and taking her as his child during the country's ''dirty war,'' described a character in a feature film incorrectly. The film, ''The Official Story,'' was about a girl -- not a boy -- who was taken from her family.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Get Your World Series Programs Here!'' Oct. 19: In 1961, my father, home from work on a fall Friday afternoon, said he had special plans for us.

BOEHM--Werner W. Distinguished Social Work Scholar 19132011. Werner W. Boehm was born in Germany and was educated in France, receiving his first doctorate in law from the University of Dijon in 1937. That same year, he emigrated to the United States and worked in Alabama as a High School teacher of French, Latin and Social Studies. He attended Tulane University starting in 1939 and earned a Master's degree in Social Work in 1941. Before beginning his long and illustrious career in social work education, Boehm worked in social welfare agencies in Boston and New York, and also served in the U.S. Army. After WWII, he taught at the University of Wisconsin, the University of Minnesota, and came to Rutgers University where he served as Dean of the School of Social Work from 1963-1972. During his tenure as Dean, Dr. Boehm brought the School to national prominence by adding the bachelor and doctoral programs in Social Work. At the conclusion of his Deanship, he served as Director for the Center for International Cooperative Social Welfare at Rutgers University from 1973 to 1981. He continued to lecture in France and Germany through 1985, devoting his last professional activity to preparing Social Work for the challenges of the future. Dr. Boehm enjoyed a varied and highly respected career as a practitioner, academic administrator, and scholar, and for almost half a century he provided leadership to Social Work education. He is best known for having directed a landmark study on Social Work curriculum development for the Council on Social Work Education from 1955-1960. Many of the findings and recommendations of that Study have relevance for Social Work education in the new millennium. In addition to his books, monographs, and more than one hundred papers, Dr. Boehm served as Editor of the Journal of International Social Work and the Harper and Row Social Work series. He also served as a Social Work Specialist for the U.S. State Department, providing consultation to the United Nations in the U.S., Europe and South America. Dr. Boehm was the recipient of many awards and honors, including a Fulbright award (1969), the Rutgers Medal (1983), the National Association of Social Work's Social Worker of the Year (1983), an honorary doctorate from the Tulane University School of Social Work (1992) and the Council on Social Work Education's Significant Lifetime Achievement award (1995). Dr. Boehm is survived by his current wife Laurie H. Boehm of New Brunswick, NJ, his brother Dr. Eric Boehm of Santa Barbara, California, his nephews Ronald and Steven Boehm of Santa Barbara, California, and his cousins Harold and Millicent May of Englewood Cliffs, NJ and Hilde and Gunter Hahn of Sao Paulo, Brazil. His previous wife, Dr. Bernice Boehm, died in 1983 and their son, Andrew Boehm, died in 2010. Memorial donations may be sent to the Rutgers University School of Social Work--Boehm Scholarship Fund--New Brunswick, NJ.

Twitter serves many purposes -- meme manufacturing, revolution aggregation, troll facilitation -- but it also functions as a real-time discussion board for the things we see on television. And every time something major happens on a program that a lot of us love, the progression of tweets is predictable. First, the nonspecific expressions of shock. (''OMG BREAKING BAD :0.'') Then the rush to make a trenchant if vague joke. (''Gus sure was sporting a Harvey Dent look!'') Then the broader, spoiler-filled discussion of the twist. (''Someone better make a GIF of Gus straightening his tie before he falls down dead.'') Then, of course, the angry accusations of spoiler-mongering. A few years ago, in the pre-Twitter era, I wrote a long blog post outlining the etiquette of online spoilers. My argument was simple: if you love ''The Wire'' so much that you'd be angry to find out who died before the DVDs are released, then pony up for HBO. Twitter only solidified this rationale. You would not expect, for example, your friends to avoid tweeting about the death of Steve Jobs out of respect for the fact that you had not yet read the newspaper.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments about A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis's column on the continuing influence of the New Yorker film critic Pauline Kael. ''Kael's work got me excited, whether I agreed or disagreed with her, perhaps because she was excited as well. When she stopped being so, she quit. Rare and smart move. After reading her reviews I either wanted to see the film or to find her and argue with her, especially about De Palma. I found myself wanting to read her halfway though this article -- so I did, and felt excited again.''

CHESS has an intellectual pedigree, but as played on the streets of New York City by a small army of hustlers, it is a game unto itself -- a gritty pastime and a way to scratch out a living. Hustling chess has a long tradition in the city, but no one knows who started it. In the 1960s and '70s, a man named Bobby Haywood used to park his board on a garbage can at Eighth Avenue and 43rd Street and stand in front of it in a threadbare fur coat, taking on all comers. Many of the hustlers are black; some are immigrants. There are silent assassins who utter hardly a word as they dispatch their opponents, and there are boisterous, native New Yorkers, adept at the quick insult, who exult with each victory. Some players are genial, others project a slight air of menace. The players are cagey about just how much they win, but some will admit to taking home $50 to $75 a day.

LANCE--Sheldon V.,93, of Rye, New York and Waterford, CT. Founder of Defender Industries, Inc and loving husband and father died October 13, 2011 with his family by his side. Mr. Lance is survived by five children and ten grandchildren. His wife, Charlotte, died in 1987.

An article last Sunday about the divorce of Sid Bass and his second wife, Mercedes Bass, misstated the type of divorce law applicable in Texas when Mr. Bass divorced his first wife, Anne Hendricks Bass. Texas, the couple's home state, was (and remains) a community property state, not common property, a term that does not apply to divorce law.
EISENSTEIN--Alvin Gordon, 10/12/15 -10/26/87. Remembered these past 24 years and always, by his loving family and friends, as a caring and gracious man and to many an icon.

THINKING of fighting crime but don't know what to wear? The solution may be found at the spring 2012 collection for superheroes presented by the Brooklyn Supply Co. The event, on Monday at 9 p.m. at the Ace Hotel, is a benefit for 826NYC, a nonprofit literacy organization. The contributing designers -- Christian Joy, Opening Ceremony, United Bamboo, Matt Singer, Jack Spade, Renata Morales and Complex Geometries -- were asked to come up with crime-fighting attire, which left the possibilities just about endless. ''There's a lot of flexibility as to what a superhero will wear,'' said Joan Kim, the education director at 826NYC. ''The Incredible Hulk just wears shorts. Some wear different accessories, some wear capes.'' The seven outfits will be sold at silent auction. Other designers, including Marc Jacobs and Stella McCartney, have donated pieces for the silent auction and raffle ($20 a ticket). Tickets are $75 for general admission, or $150, which includes an 8 p.m. cocktail party and five raffle tickets. Go to 826nyc.org/fashion. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

Cruise lines are increasingly tying their appeal to branded amenities and celebrities of the film, television and culinary worlds. Carnival Cruise Lines hired the comedian George Lopez to help cast performers for the ships' comedy clubs. EA Sports, makers of video games like Madden NFL, will sponsor a 16-screen sports bar, and the Food Network host Guy Fieri will oversee Guy's Burger Joint (above), Burger Joint on Carnival's Fun Ship 2.0 both making their debut this month on the Carnival Liberty.

Meru National Park, Kenya, Sept. 7, 2011 My sister and I were on safari in Kenya -- our first safari and the trip of a lifetime. These giraffes seemed intent on coming together. It appeared as if a meeting had been called to order, and our presence was of little consequence. The giraffes moved with a grace that had an animated quality and it was quite beautiful. On the trip I was struck by many Kenyans' dedication to stewardship of their natural environment. BETSY RICH, Shelburne, Vt.

EPSTEIN--Robert Joseph, of Boulder, CO died suddenly on October 11th. Born in Fall River, MA on October 7, 1951, he was the beloved son of Muriel and the late Seymour Epstein of NYC. A graduate of Scarsdale High, he attended NYU. His deep love of art and music was realized early in his life. His heart and soul were in every piece of sculpture he made and every bar of music he played. Bob's sense of humor, quick wit and his amazing depth of knowledge were legendary, as were his compassion, generosity and love. He leaves his heart-broken mother, three wonderful and talented sons, Cass, Josh and Alex, their mother Marjorie, sisters Randy, Jane and Susan and their husbands Bruce, Edgar and Jeff, his life partner, Jackie Buckner and her daughter Cassidy, cousins, nieces, nephews, aunt and uncles. Bob's friends and family shared a beautiful memorial service led by his sons who played their original music to celebrate Bob's love of life. Donations in Bob's memory can be made to The Seva Foundation and The Coral Reef Alliance.

GENTLEMAN of varying persuasions of style are already familiar with the name Mark McNairy. Shoes from the designer's footwear collection, Mark McNairy New Amsterdam, and tailored pieces from the Ivy League-inspired outfitter J. Press, where Mr. McNairy was formerly the creative director, have made their way into an eclectic mix of closets, traditional and trendy. When it was announced this summer that Mr. McNairy would introduce a complete line of subversive-preppy clothes and accessories for men in the spring, all those fans cheered. And now, it's official: he's doing women's wear, too. Inspired by his daughter, Daisy, the 50-piece collection is charmingly boyish, but (very McNairy) sexily so, with oxford shirts paired with boyfriend boxers and rugby tanks over miniskirts. There are echoes of some of the men's line motifs: a daisy print, an exploded camouflage and a floral-on-plaid shirt. ''Basically, I make women's clothes from a guy's point of view,'' Mr. McNairy said. ''It has nothing to do with fashion.'' Mark McNairy New Amsterdam men's and women's collections will be available starting in mid-February at markmcnairy.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

CHEVROLET, which celebrates its 100th birthday next month, has woven itself deeply into the fabric of America. Its Impalas dropped us off at school. Its pickup trucks hauled our produce on the farm. Its Corvette sustained our sports car fantasies through the boredom of high school algebra class. Earlier than almost any other automotive brand, Chevy created a palette of vehicles that ranged from the small and thrifty to the sleek and sporty to the large and smartly trimmed. Once the model line expanded beyond the limited body selections of its first half-century, there was a Chevy for almost everyone. The brand's broad appeal resulted in a place atop the sales charts starting in the 1930s and continuing nearly uncontested for decades. By the mid-1960s Chevrolet sold nearly threemillion cars and light-duty trucks a year.But there's more to the story than commercial success. Although it occupied the first rung of Alfred P. Sloan's General Motors hierarchy, a ladder on which customers would move up to more expensive brands as they gained affluence, Chevy developed a following of fans whose devotion lasted a lifetime. After decades of decline, Chevrolet has lately had a resurgence with its Cruze and Malibu sedans, the reinvented Camaro and the Volt, the first mass-produced plug-in hybrid. The full Chevrolet story has filled volumes. Here are some ofthe highlights of the 100-year journey.

FREUDENBERGER--Joachim. We mourn the death of Joachim Freudenberger, son of Dr. Rudolf and Amalia. Survived by wife Shirley, children Michelle (Andy Dimond) and Ron (Emily), siblings Marion Freilich and Joseph, and grandchildren Eve and Max. He died from complications of Parkinson's disease in his home surrounded by his family on October 19, 2011. He was born November 1, 1924 and fled Nazi Germany in 1938 to NY where he studied at Brooklyn Technical High School and CCNY. He was a decorated Army veteran. He was a great person, teacher, husband, grandfather and father. He will be missed by all. Funeral services Sunday at 9:45am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

KANTER--Harriet Hirsch, age 96, died peacefully on Friday morning in New York City, the city of her birth. She lived a long, wonderful life full of happiness and joy. In 1937 she married Nat Kanter with whom she shared 57 blissful years, and raised and adored three children, Robert, Jane and Sam. Harriet was the devoted sister of the late Melba Stern, Ruth Stern, and her twin Eleanor Kletz, loving mother-in-law to Richard, Carol and Deborah, dedicated grandmother and "Meme" to Jennifer, Gary, Wayne, Pamela, Keith and Abraham, as well as the adoring greatgrandmother of, Alex, Amanda, Bo, Charlotte, Emily, Juliet, Madeline, Mia, Phoebe and Zoe. In 1972 Harriet and her twin sister Eleanor founded the boutique "Twins for Gifts", later named "Harriet's", which was an East Side fixture for over 25 years and whose customers stopped in just to talk, see her wonderful smile and enjoy her vivacious personality. Throughout her life Harriet Kanter was cherished by her family and friends for her elegance, beauty, her caring, warmth, optimism and love of life. She will always be remembered by those who were fortunate to have known her. Gravesite services at Riverside Cemetery (Saddle Brooke, NJ) at 1:00pm on Monday, October, 24, 2011. Shiva will be at the home of her daughter, Jane Weisglass, on Monday from 5:00-9:00pm and Tuesday from 2:00-8:00pm.

McDERMOTT--Kathleen, age 67, passed away peacefully on October 16, 2011 at her home in Manhattan, NY, surrounded by her loving family and friends. Born in the Bronx, NY, she was the daughter of Frank and Margaret McDermott. Kathleen received an RN Degree from St. Clare's Nursing School, New York (first in class), a B.A. from Lehman College, New York, Summa Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa and M.A. and PhD. from the University of California, Berkeley. Kathleen spent many years teaching and working in Hong Kong, Wales, Vermont, and England. She recently retired from Columbia University as Assistant Vice-President and Director of Global Programs. She spent over 21 years in different roles at Columbia, among them as Columbia College's first residential dean and as adviser for study abroad and fellowships. She was on the Community Impact Board from 1991 through 2006. Kathleen is predeceased by her parents, her son, Paul Grandpierre, and her nephew, Michael McDermott. She is survived by her loving children, Claire Grandpierre of New York and Caitlin Bell of Dorset, England; her granddaughter Charlotte Soubirous of New York, her sister Eileen McDermott of Los Angeles, CA; her brothers Gerry (Eleanore) McDermott of Roanoke, VA; Dan (Kathy) McDermott of Pearl River, NY, and Jim (Pam) of Newark, DE. Kathleen's compassion, kindness, gentleness and wisdom were an inspiration for many. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to either the Kathleen McDermott Scholarship Fund at Columbia College (c/o Eleanor Coufos, Columbia College Alumni Development, 622 West 113th Street - MC 4530, New York, NY 10025) or to the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Center, (Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Center, Office of Development, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY 10032). Memorial services will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia Campus on November 5, 2011, 1pm.

To the Editor: In ''Don't Give Me What I Want'' (Modern Love, Oct. 16), Terry Tom Brown writes that playing hard to get can end up being the strongest allure. Marcel Proust, in ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' advised women that ''such things as an absence, the refusal of an invitation, or an unintentional coldness accomplish more than all the cosmetics and fine clothes in the world.'' I wonder if that works for men as well. Les Dreyer

A few weeks ago, we celebrated the Rubik's Cube. One of the things that I find fascinating about the Rubik's Cube is that, even though a single move changes the position of 8 cubies, you can string together a series of moves such that you can change the orientations of exactly 2 cubies (the quarks and anti-quarks we mentioned), leaving the rest of the cube completely unchanged. Even though we move an ensemble of eight different cubies at a time, we are able to precisely cancel the motion of all of the other cubies we moved, and hone in with surgical precision on the two we are interested in. Using sledgehammer moves, we are able to create a scalpel!

In this week's Critics' Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Spike Lee's 2002 film "25th Hour." It stars Edward Norton as Monty Brogan, a man experiencing his last day of freedom before going to serve a long prison sentence. It tracks him as he says his goodbyes and takes care of some unfinished business. "25th Hour" features a strong ensemble cast, including Brian Cox, Barry Pepper, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Anna Paquin and Rosario Dawson as Monty's girlfriend. "But the real love interest," Mr. Scott says, "is New York City itself." The film takes in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks and "it captures, better than any other movie, the mood of raw shock and grief that blanketed the city in those months." Have you seen "25th Hour?" Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

In the fall of 2008, the photographer Noah Abrams came across a YouTube clip of a couple of Afghan kids skateboarding in Kabul. "It struck me as the most positive image I'd seen in a long time," he says. "I had to figure out a way to get over there." Abrams, a skater himself, made two trips the following year to photograph what turned out to be a small but thriving skating scene in the war-torn city, in part the work of Skateistan, a school started in 2007 by two Australian skaters. (A documentary film about the program, "Skateistan: To Live and Skate Kabul," had its premiere at Sundance this year.) Overcoming a lack of smooth roads and sidewalks, among other things, Kabul's skaters - girls included - find in skating a rare recreational outlet, Abrams says. "The mullahs have no problem with girls skating. They can't ride a bike, but they can skate. The girls just jump on it." Here, Abrams's diary of his weeks in Kabul, above, and a Times video on "Skateistan," below.

I promised myself (and staff) (and wife) that I would dedicate every waking (and sleeping) hour to the operation of the restaurant for exactly one year. And then, crash tutorial completed, I would back off from the day-to-day obligations, trusting that the right staff had been marshaled and the right culture inculcated, that my personal stamp would not be erased without leaving some readable palimpsest. Detachment would be healthy for all concerned -- no one likes the boss hanging around all the time, and the boss could concentrate on neglected parts of his restaurant (and his life).

Over the next several weeks, The Stone will feature a series of brief video interviews drawn from the work of Tyler Krupp and Rachel Stuart, two young students at work on a full-length documentary film on philosophy and philosophers. The interviews will feature contemporary working philosophers and others - beginning today with Raymond Geuss - answering questions on their work, lives and thought.I first came to know Tyler via e-mail, discussing nihilism and other sundry matters. Last December, he and Rachel came to my home in Brooklyn for a long and fascinating conversation. I was impressed by their integrity and energy and by their initiative to travel the world to talk to philosophers about issues that mattered to them, and that should matter to all of us. For Tyler and Rachel, philosophical problems are not just technical issues discussed among cognoscenti in academia, but matters of central importance to the human endeavor that are infused by existential commitment and passion. It warmed my heart to see these young people hungry for philosophy directly engage some of the most interesting thinkers of our time.

Ten years is the length of an average commercial lease, but it's also, as the designer Ted Muehling has discovered, the approximate life span of a neighborhood. Back in 2001, Muehling moved his storefront workshop from a formerly desolate block on Greene Street to Howard Street - at the time SoHo's final frontier. But when a Mondrian hotel went up nearby, so did Muehling's rent, and the designer moved on once again. His new store, on White Street in TriBeCa, is grander in proportion and there is more selling space, but also more space for Muehling to display the many things he collects and that inspire him, from natural wonders like seashells or insects to the work of his partner, the artist Mats Gustafson, or that of his friend Jan Baracz, who carves bellybuttons into large stones. And while his workrooms are smaller, for the first time Muehling has a little studio all his own - an "attic" tucked into a mezzanine under a skylight in the back. The timing could not have been better. With his product collaborations with Nymphenburg and Steuben winding down, Muehling is eager to get back to making jewelry. On a recent morning, a pair of canaries twittered joyfully, and an installation of monarch butterflies on a dried mullein stem was magically animated by a breeze from the air-conditioner. As with his previous store, this one is livened by sounds from behind the scenes - the bang of metal on metal, the murmur of NPR - evidence that this is a place where things are made and not just sold. It's the kind of neighborhood place, Muehling points out, where you can walk in and they'll make a new wire for your earring if you don't mind waiting 20 minutes.

In 1948, the architect and inventor Buckminster Fuller gathered a group of his students at Black Mountain College to build a life-size geodesic dome. The dome was a flop. It succeeded, however, in planting the seed for the sculptor Kenneth Snelson, a student of Fuller's, to develop the principle of tensegrity that would allow Fuller to build a dome for the United States Pavilion at Expo 67 in Montreal. For the Performa 11 biennial (11.performa-arts.org), the Los Angeles artist Liz Glynn will retrace Fuller's steps, pratfalls and all. Part 1 of her performance - a loosely choreographed re-enactment of Fuller's failed attempt - takes place on the first Sunday of the biennial in locations throughout New York City, including Times Square; for Part 2, 25 volunteers will assist in building a dome. Whether it will stand remains to be seen. But Glynn's cast-concrete dome sculptures (above), on view at the Performa Hub through Nov. 21, are objects of perfection of which even Fuller might have approved.

Here's a Dot Earth Postcard from Rhett Butler, the founder of the essential Mongabay.com blog tracking issues related to conserving forests and biological diversity worldwide. Butler took the images above while visiting a ranch in Colombia that is managed to accommodate both livestock and wildlife. Whether in South America, the Adirondacks, the Serengeti or Asia, there's enormous logic in finding ways to mesh human livelihoods and wildlife that don't involve fences. Could an Indian Army helicopter's accidental foray into Pakistani territory Sunday afternoon have an unexpected effect - the improvement of relations between the two nations? After questioning the four-member Indian crew for nearly five hours, Pakistani officials released them at about 6 p.m.(Hindustan Times). India's Ministry of External Affairs said it "greatly appreciates the manner in which Pakistan worked with us" (The Hindu). India's gratitude for the swift return will be "expressed at the highest levels" when Prime Minister Manmohan Singh meets his counterpart Yousaf Raza Gillani in the Maldives next month, says the Times of India.

(TCM) CLASSIC HORROR Turner Classic Movies celebrates Halloween this month with a 32-film festival, which picks up here with the long-overlooked ''Carnival of Souls'' (1962), starring Candace Hilligoss as Mary Henry, a free thinker who survives a car crash and goes on the run to save her life from the Man (Herk Harvey, who directed the film) and a conservative society intent on keeping women in their place. The evening continues with Francis Ford Coppola's ''Dementia 13'' (1963), about an Irish clan whose members are killed off by one of its own intent on inheriting the family fortune, at 10:30; William Castle's ''Strait-Jacket'' (1964), with Joan Crawford as an ax murderer trailed by carnage after returning home to her daughter (Diane Baker) from her stint in a mental hospital, at midnight; and a double bill directed by Roger Corman and starring Vincent Price, above, in ''The Pit and the Pendulum'' (1961), at 1:45 a.m., and ''The Masque of the Red Death'' (1964), at 3:15. ''The Devil's Bride'' (1968), Terence Fisher's tale about small-town Satanists who entice a pair of siblings into their coven, closes the lineup, at 5. 8 P.M. KENNEDY--Thomas P.,90, died peacefully at home, October 21. Loved and loving husband of Valerie; father of Kathleen, Kevin, Joanne, and Jerry; stepfather of Benjamin Kelly; grandfather of Emily and Patrick Schroder, Timothy and Ashley Kennedy, Martine van Voorthuysen and Molly Kennedy-Svolos; adoring companion of Bonnie. Born in Tralee, Co. Kerry, Ireland and raised in Dublin, Ireland. Immigrated to The United States 1947. Lived the rest of his life in New York City. Public Relations/Advertising Manager of Aer Lingus 1959-84, East Coast Director of American Ireland Fund 1985-99. Devout Catholic, world traveler, staunch Democrat, supporter of all things Irish. His life defined the word "gentleman". Beloved patriarch. Great friend to many. Much missed by family and countless friends. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9pm. Mass, Wednesday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 11:30am, Burial on Thursday in Red Hook, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to Irish Repertory Theatre or American Ireland Fund.

For two decades, a pair of Japanese bankers toiled away in relative anonymity on Wall Street, hopping from firm to firm. Now the two - Hajime Sagawa and Akio Nakagawa - are at the center of a growing firestorm over a mysterious $687 million payout by Olympus, the Japanese company that runs a lucrative medical equipment business and a less successful, if better known, digital camera business. The money has been described as a fee for advising Olympus on the 2008 takeover of a British company, the Gyrus Group.

In the early 1900s, John Wanamaker, a political figure and well-known merchant, coined one of the most famous quotes about advertising: ''Half the money I spend on advertising is wasted. The trouble is, I don't know which half.'' For the past century that observation has remained true, but that is slowly changing as online companies start delivering real-time analytics about Web surfers and the ads they see. It could be used for social networking advertising - an area that Google is poised to enter with its new social network, Google+.

CURRAN--John J. Jack, Jr.,79, of Heritage Hunt in Gainesville, Virginia, passed away peacefully at home on October 20, 2011. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Marlane; three sons, Michael, Christopher (wife Brooke) and John; a sister, Anne and five granddaughters; and was preceded in death by his son Jeffrey. Mr. Curran was born and raised in Whitestone, Queens, NY. He graduated from St. Augustine H.S., St. John's University (B.A.), Michigan State University (M.S.), and the University of Chicago (M.B.A.). He had a long and successful career in the flavor and fragrance industry in New York, Chicago and Minneapolis. He was extremely proficient with crossword puzzles, an excellent bridge player, a terrific bowler, an avid sports fan, a talented singer and a lousy golfer. He will be remembered by his family and friends as a loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather, and a good humored companion. He will be sorely missed by all. A private memorial service will be held in several weeks. Online condolences may be expressed to the family at www.foundandsons.com.

WOOD--Suzanne Cort, peacefully on October 19 at 95 years. Born in Manhattan to Margretta and Harry L. Cort, playwright and impresario, whose family owned the Cort Theater. Growing up in the theatrical world, she studied art and dance and acted professionally. In 1938 she married John W. Wood (Jack). Although from an old New York family, Jack was also a creative spirit and a gifted architect. After their marriage Suzanne continued to study art and to paint, brilliantly ranging across many styles. She also continued acting with such groups as the Amateur Comedy Club and the Snarks, of which she became president. She was an active member of St. James Church, co-chairman of Interfaith Neighbors and a director of the Social Register. Gentle, always cheerful and continually loving she will be greatly missed. She is survived by her children Michele Wood Ruhm and John Walter Wood, grandchildren Duncan Wood, Wendy and Thomas Ruhm, and great-grandchildren Adair and Lydia Wood. Funeral service at 11am, October 27 at Christ Church, Bronxville.

LinkedIn, the social network for businesspeople, is adding on to its biggest business: matching jobs to job seekers. The company is announcing an addition to its hiring solutions business called Talent Pipeline at a conference for 1,500 job recruiters and personnel executives in Las Vegas on Tuesday. Pipeline is an effort to centralize the way recruiters find, track and stay in touch with potential hires and promotions. The product is intended to be used with candidates internally and outside the company. Employees, the company says, can more easily find out about job openings for themselves or candidates they know.

For the celebrity chefs Emeril Lagasse and Wolfgang Puck, the kitchen counter is about to grow more crowded with a new set of culinary tools. On Monday, the Conde Nast magazine Bon Appetit will announce a partnership with the Home Shopping Network on a line of branded culinary products. They will include stainless steel cookware, small appliances and cutlery, and will be available for sale through HSN on television as well as HSN.com.

Manfred Gerlach, East Germany's last head of state and the first politician outside the ruling Communist Party to hold that position, died on Monday in Berlin. He was 83. His wife told German newspapers and the public television network MDR that he had died after a long illness.

An article on Thursday about Randi Zuckerberg, a sister of Mark Zuckerberg, a founder of Facebook, referred imprecisely to the circumstances under which Mr. Zuckerberg declined to comment for the article. After the reporter told Ms. Zuckerberg that her brother had declined to be interviewed, Ms. Zuckerberg said she would e-mail him. But while a representative of Ms. Zuckerberg acknowledges that she did e-mail Mr. Zuckerberg to tell him about the article, the e-mail did not explicitly request that her brother agree to an interview.

The American Academy of Pediatrics last week again urged parents to limit TV, video game and computer exposure -- even when a screen is on only in the background -- for children age 2 and younger because infants and toddlers learn through real interactions and by playing, not by watching programs. TV viewing is about 24 hours a week for children ages 2 to 11 -- an average of more than three hours every day. With a slight drop in usage for their older siblings (those ages 12 to 17 watch 22 hours, 24 minutes a week) and roughly the same for those ages 18 to 24 (24 hours, 17 minutes), viewing increases with age.

GIOVANNINI--Fred. Freddie passed away suddenly October 16th while enjoying one of his passions, cycling in the surrounding hills. He is survived by his loving wife and best friend of 20 years, Renni Lyn Burge; all who helped them celebrate their wedding cannot forget that day. Freddie is also survived by a multitude of family and friends. His smile and exuberant laughter will be sorely missed by all whom he touched. Freddie's Celebration of Life party will be held sometime in the next year. In lieu of flowers, please honor Freddie with a donation to his favorite charity, The Salvation Army.

GRUBE--Ernst J. (May 9, 1932 - June 12, 2011). In this late October of 2011 when, once again, The Metropolitan Museum of Art reopens its exhibition-galleries for the arts of the Islamic world, it is appropriate to recall that you were the Met's first Curator of the newly-formed Department of Islamic Art. Appointed to that position in 1965 by the then- Director and your great friend and mentor, the late James J. Rorimer--your remarkable acquisitions of the 1960's still command attention, even in this most encyclopedic collection. That you did not live to see the second reinstallation of the galleries you had begun to plan, toward the end of that decade, is an abiding sadness to the many colleagues and friends who knew, admired, worked with, and loved you, and who miss you on this signal occasion. "Your place is empty," as the Persian saying goes; your impact remains. The East-West Foundation

KEY PERFORMANCE Each successive solid game by receiver Jeremy Kerley makes it hard to believe he barely played the first month of the season. Eclipsed by the since-departed Derrick Mason in September, Kerley has emerged as a favorite target of Mark Sanchez, who found him twice on third down on the Jets' first scoring drive of the second half. Both conversions came with the Jets needing at least 5 yards for the first down. Kerley finished with a career-high four receptions for 29 yards. NOTABLE NUMBER Toward the end of the game, linebacker Calvin Pace glanced at the scoreboard and, reading Philip Rivers's passing statistics, knew the Jets' defense had clamped down. Rivers threw for only 179 yards, his fewest in 22 regular-season games since Jan. 3, 2010. The Jets had only one sack, in the first quarter, but their pass rush pressured Rivers for much of the game. Their secondary held Vincent Jackson, a dangerous receiver, without a catch in the second half.

Paul Leka, a songwriter and producer who worked with many recording stars but who was best known for writing the chanting chorus of ''Na Na Hey Hey (Kiss Him Goodbye),'' a No. 1 hit in 1969 that was reborn in the 1970s as a sports arena anthem, died on Oct. 12 in a hospice near his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 68. The cause was lung cancer, said his brother, George.

As a host of potential bidders circle Yahoo, several of Silicon Valley's biggest companies are considering whether to jump into the fray themselves. Microsoft and Google are both weighing whether to participate in the bidding. Each has its own business reasons for wanting to see the continued existence of Yahoo, which despite its financial struggles still has a monthly audience of almost 700 million unique visitors.

North American moviegoers were in the mood to be scared over the weekend, powering the micro-budgeted ''Paranormal Activity 3'' to a stronger-than-anticipated $54 million in ticket sales. That total, easily enough for No. 1, prompted Paramount Pictures, the studio behind this wildly successful horror franchise, to shriek with delight, or at least superlatives. (According to Paramount, the opening weekend total for ''Paranormal Activity 3,'' which cost just $5 million to make, is the biggest in history for a horror film -- not accounting for inflation.) The studio partly attributed strong sales to strikingly positive reviews, which helped draw more moviegoers in their 30s and 40s. ''Real Steel'' (DreamWorks) was second with about $11.3 million in ticket sales for a three-week total of $67 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. ''Footloose'' (Paramount) was third, taking in a solid $10.9 million in its second weekend for a new total of $30.9 million. A 3-D version of ''The Three Musketeers'' (Summit Entertainment) arrived with a thud in fourth place and $8.8 million in ticket sales. Summit, which acquired distribution rights to ''Musketeers'' from its financier, Constantin Film, came under fire on Twitter on Friday from Milla Jovovich, the film's female lead, for botching the marketing; Summit executives privately dismissed the notion but did not comment publicly. ''The Ides of March'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fifth, taking in about $4.9 million for a three-week total of $29.2 million.

McDERMOTT--Kathleen, age 67, passed away peacefully on October 16, 2011 at her home in Manhattan, NY, surrounded by her loving family and friends. Born in the Bronx, NY, she was the daughter of Frank and Margaret McDermott. Kathleen received an RN Degree from St. Clare's Nursing School, New York (first in class), a B.A. from Lehman College, New York, Summa Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa and M.A. and PhD. from the University of California, Berkeley. Kathleen spent many years teaching and working in Hong Kong, Wales, Vermont, and England. She recently retired from Columbia University as Assistant Vice-President and Director of Global Programs. She spent over 21 years in different roles at Columbia, among them as Columbia College's first residential dean and as adviser for study abroad and fellowships. She was on the Community Impact Board from 1991 through 2006. Kathleen is predeceased by her parents, her son, Paul Grandpierre, and her nephew, Michael McDermott. She is survived by her loving children, Claire Grandpierre of New York and Caitlin Bell of Dorset, England; her granddaughter Charlotte Soubirous of New York, her sister Eileen McDermott of Los Angeles, CA; her brothers Gerry (Eleanore) McDermott of Roanoke, VA; Dan (Kathy) McDermott of Pearl River, NY, and Jim (Pam) of Newark, DE. Kathleen's compassion, kindness, gentleness and wisdom were an inspiration for many. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to either the Kathleen McDermott Scholarship Fund at Columbia College (c/o Eleanor Coufos, Columbia College Alumni Development, 622 West 113th Street - MC 4530, New York, NY 10025) or to the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Center, (Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Center, Office of Development, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY 10032). Memorial services will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia Campus on November 5, 2011, 1pm.

Hakan Swahn and his partner, the chef Marcus Jernmark, have reconfigured their Nordic restaurant, Aquavit. What was the cafe area in the front is now the main restaurant, and though the furnishings include Swedish classics like Arne Jacobsen chairs, it is less formal than the previous dining room, which was in the back and is now for private parties. There are four- and seven-course prix-fixe menus for dinner, à la carte or three courses at lunch. Traditional Swedish specialties like herring dishes will now be served from late afternoon through evening in the bar and lounge.

The British design doyen Sir Terence Conran is showing signs of his 80 years. But don't make the mistake of assuming that his retrospective exhibition, "Terence Conran: The Way We Live Now," at the Design Museum in London from Nov. 16 through March 4, 2012, is a swan song.

What was Manhattan for the wildly ambitious, talented and tirelessly self-promoting 24-year-old Cecil Beaton, but a candy box of opportunities, just waiting to be picked? And pick them he did, over the course of some five decades, in a peripatetic career that saw him cross-pollinating the social and cultural elites of the Old and New Worlds, and applying his protean gifts to everything from fashion photography and portraiture to illustration to stage and costume design. "Cecil Beaton: The New York Years," curated by Donald Albrecht and opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, includes vintage fashion prints and a wide range of portraits, from Marilyn Monroe (cajoled into relaxation in Beaton's Ambassador Hotel suite) to the very young Mick Jagger to Wallis Simpson and the aging Greta Garbo (one of the photographer's rare heterosexual liaisons). Together with drawings, theatrical designs and other ephemera, they illuminate this English dandy's astonishingly productive and long-lasting engagement with the booming cultural metropolis that was Manhattan at midcentury.

After the close of the stock market Tuesday, Amazon.com will announce its third-quarter results. Analysts are predicting yet another revenue blowout, up 44 percent compared with last year. Amazon's torrid growth more than 15 years after its founding makes it an object of envy and fear across the retail world. It is now a $100 billion company, about 12 times the value of Sears.

It questioned the company's ability ever to turn a profit, argued that Amazon was spending far too much money on marketing and suggested that the company was using misleading accounting metrics.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Last week, I wrote that the monster passing numbers from the first five weeks took a serious body blow in Week 6, evidenced by a huge decline in passing touchdowns. The knockout punch was delivered in Week 7. After teams averaged over 240 passing yards per game through the first six weeks of the season, the 26 teams playing in Week 7 combined for only 4,997 passing yards this past weekend, a paltry 191 yards per game. Nowhere was this more evident -- on Sunday -- than in Cleveland, as the Seahawks and Browns put on a pitiful display. The Browns and Seahawks combined for 435 yards and 9 points. It was the worst display of offense in a game not affected by severe weather in over a decade. The Colt McCoy pass attempt watch marches on: he threw 35 passes in a game in which the Browns allowed only 137 yards and 3 points.

MULRY--Thomas C. 79, of Gulf Stream, FL died Sunday, October 23, 2011, surrounded by his wife of 51 years, Margaret Power Mulry, and his five children. Mr. Mulry was born in New York and educated at Chaminade High School and Seton Hall University. He served in the U.S. Army (1955-1957). He was the former President of Stone & Webster Securities (1972-1974) and Managing Director then Advisory Director of PaineWebber Inc. Investment Banking Division (1974-2000). He is survived by his children, Patricia Mulry of Lake Worth, FL; Thomas C. Mulry, Jr. of Boyce, VA; Sean F. Mulry, of Glen Cove, NY; Megan Huisinga of Delray Beach, FL; and Brooke Mulry, of Lake Worth, FL; and seven grandchildren, Hope, Cecilia, Maggie, Tommy, Katharine Mulry and Helen and Jeb Huisinga. He was a long-time resident of Locust Valley, NY, and retired to Gulf Stream in 2000. He was formerly a member of the Bond Club of New York, The Creek, Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club, and St. Andrew's. At the time of his death, he was an active member of The Brook, Millwood Country Club, Manalapan Yacht Club, The Pilgrims of the United States, The Little Club, and the Gulf Stream Bath and Tennis Club. Funeral services will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church in Delray Beach, FL, at 2:00pm on Thursday, October 27, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Bethesda Hospital Foundation, PO Box 243628, Boynton Beach, FL 33424.

Even in death, Harry Houdini has been hard to pin down. The Society of American Magicians, of which Houdini was president at the time of his death in 1926, then gave up trying to replace it.

Has the power of the mammogram been oversold? At a time when medical experts are rethinking screening guidelines for prostate and cervical cancer, many doctors say it's also time to set the record straight about mammography screening for breast cancer. While most agree that mammograms have a place in women's health care, many doctors say widespread ''Pink Ribbon'' campaigns and patient testimonials have imbued the mammogram with a kind of magic it doesn't have. Some patients are so committed to annual screenings they even begin to believe that regular mammograms actually prevent breast cancer, said Dr. Susan Love, a prominent women's health advocate. And women who skip a mammogram often beat themselves up for it.

CONCORD, N.H. - Mitt Romney officially became a Republican candidate for president on the New Hampshire ballot on Monday morning, stopping by the Statehouse in a well-choreographed visit to sign the necessary papers and joking that he was ''hoping that this time it will take.'' ''We're going to make sure New Hampshire remains first in the nation - it's a responsibility and an honor New Hampshire richly deserves, and I'm happy to be part of that process,'' Mr. Romney said, standing in the office of New Hampshire's secretary of state, William M. Gardner, who has recently been battling to keep the state's special role of holding the first primary.

An obituary on Saturday about John M. Blum, the presidential historian and author of an influential biography of Theodore Roosevelt, referred incorrectly to Roosevelt's family. His wife and mother died in 1884, but his daughter Alice, who was born that year, lived until 1980. Roosevelt did not lose ''his wife, newborn daughter and mother in the span of a few days in 1884.''

Plans to award a major construction contract for concrete work on the Guggenheim museum planned for Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi have been temporarily suspended, the Associated Press has reported. But officials from the Tourism Development and Investment Company, which is building the large cultural district in the Emirati capital that the Guggenheim will be part of, said another major museum there -- a branch of the Louvre -- is on track to open in late 2013. The developer told the A.P. that the Guggenheim delay was related to a review of its contracting process, which drew protest from artists. It did not say when it would again seek bids. ''This is a decision by TDIC relating to construction and does not affect the ongoing planning for the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi Museum,'' Eleanor R. Goldhar, a spokeswoman for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation said in an e-mail message on Monday. Tourism Development and Investment Company officials, responding to questions about projects on Saadiyat Island, stated: ''T.D.I.C. is moving forward as planned with all of its announced projects including all the projects on Saadiyat.''

John Mayer, the singer and songwriter, has undergone surgery to remove an inflamed growth on his vocal cords that forced him to cancel several concerts and postpone the release of a new album, he wrote on his Tumblr blog. He said he had surgery to remove the growth, known as a granuloma, last Thursday and had been told to rest his voice for at least a month. In September he canceled several concerts, including a Los Angeles performance with Tony Bennett, and said he would delay releasing a new album until 2012. On his blog, Mr. Mayer said that he had reached the decision to have surgery after two weeks of rest and other remedies failed to improve his condition. He has been spending his time working on guitar parts, he said. ''I should be frustrated but I can't seem to stop thinking about beautiful things,'' he wrote. ''I never thought I'd be wishing I could do what I love again; I stay in at night, picking guitar parts off of records and dreaming of playing on the big stage. The only difference between now and when I was 18 is that now I have this beautiful, meaningful record waiting for me when I can sing it.''

She announced her decision in an internal memorandum Monday morning and will explain it on the program on Monday afternoon. Mr. Johnson started on Monday as a senior adviser to the Obama campaign.

Audra McDonald's Carnegie Hall concert on Saturday evening had the feel of a homecoming celebration for a prodigal daughter: In an unbroken wave of adoration, all was forgiven. Ms. McDonald's crime, if there was one, was her temporary abandonment of musical theater for television. For four seasons, while playing Dr. Naomi Bennett in the ABC series ''Private Practice,'' she more or less disappeared from music. While Ms. McDonald is a more than capable actor, she is a one-of-a-kind musical supertalent whose temporary sabbatical robbed the world of her singular gift at a moment when her voice was in its prime. Any of dozens of actresses could have stepped into her television role, but as a singer she is an irreplaceable resource.

An illustration on Wednesday with coverage of the World Series erroneously included one program cover among those representing the World Series through the years. The cover showing a pirate promoting a World Series matchup between the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Yankees in 1938 was printed before the participants were known; it was not the official program for that year. (The Chicago Cubs passed the Pirates for the National League pennant in the final week of the 1938 season and went on to play the Yankees in the World Series.)

NEW STATION FOR THOMAS Mattel agreed on Monday to buy Hit Entertainment, owner of popular preschool toy brands like Thomas the Tank Engine, below, and Bob the Builder, for $680 million in cash from a group led by Apax Partners. The deal is one of Mattel's larger acquisitions, adding another popular stable of children's brands to a portfolio that already includes Barbie and Fisher Price. The deal will allow Hit to pay off its large debt load, put in place when the company was acquired by Apax in 2005 for £489.4 million. Last year, Hit reached an accord with its lenders to push debt maturities to next year, in exchange for higher interest rates. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

8 P.M. (ESPN) THE REAL ROCKY In 1975 Chuck Wepner, the 6-foot-5 boxer known as the Bayonne Bleeder for his New Jersey hometown and for the pummeling he sustained at the fists of Sonny Liston, went up against Muhammad Ali for the heavyweight title and a potential purse of $100,000. (Ali would win $1.5 million.) Wepner, above, knocked Ali down in the ninth round, stunning the crowd; in the remaining rounds Ali opened cuts above Wepner's eyes, broke his nose and, with 19 seconds remaining in the 15th round, knocked him down, winning the bout. Watching it all was a young Sylvester Stallone, who was inspired to write the script for, and eventually star in, ''Rocky'' (1976), which won three Academy Awards, including best picture. Jeff Feuerzeig (''The Devil and Daniel Johnston'') chronicles the life and times of Wepner, now a liquor salesman who drives a Cadillac with vanity plates that read ''Champ.'' 5:20 P.M. (Starz) THE YOUNG VICTORIA (2009) Emily Blunt portrays a decidedly unfrumpy Queen Victoria as a teenage monarch; Miranda Richardson is her mother, the Duchess of Kent, who would gladly pull the puppet strings; and Rupert Friend is Albert, Victoria's first cousin and the eventual love of her life. ''Despite the filmmakers' efforts to persuade us that 'The Young Victoria' is a serious work, and despite some tense moments and gunfire, the movie's pleasures are as light as its story,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this ''frivolously entertaining film,'' directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and written by Julian Fellowes. ''No matter. Albert may never rip Victoria's bodice, but he does eventually loosen it, to her delight and ours.''

Being overweight as a teenager carries a greater risk of being an overweight adult, along with an increased risk of dying of heart disease. But overweight adolescents who slim down in middle age may lower their risk, a new study shows. Previous studies have linked being overweight as a teenager or young adult to deadly consequences later in life, including an increased risk of heart disease. But it was unclear if the risk was higher simply because heavy teenagers become heavy adults, or because being overweight or obese as a young adult causes irreversible damage.

Weekly yoga classes relieve symptoms of low back pain about as well as intense, regular stretching sessions, a new study shows. The research found that yoga and stretching were equally effective in easing chronic back pain and improving function, but participants had to practice each regularly to see benefits. The subjects in both groups took weekly 75-minute classes and practiced yoga or deep stretching at home for about 20 minutes at a time at least three days a week.

The title of the article was ''Amazon.bomb.'' Back in 1999, Barron's memorably splashed that headline across its cover. He may have been Belgian, but the singer/songwriter Bobbejaan Schoepen, who died last year at the age of 85, was pure Nashville in style. A mega-star in his homeland and the founder of the Bobbejaan theme park in Lichtaart, Schoepen was the first non-British European to perform at the Grand Ole Opry. On stage, Schoepen favored rhinestone-encrusted suits from Nudie Cohn, whom he met on a visit to Los Angeles in the late 1960s and remained close with until Cohn's death in 1984. The heavily embroidered fruits of their relationship are showcased in "Dreamsuits," an exhibition of the clothes and accessories Cohn made for Schoepen and his wife, Josée, on view at the Mode Museum in Antwerp. (It's also the first time Cohn's designs have be shown in Europe.) "Nudie called Bobbejaan 'the cowboy from over there,'" says Mairi MacKenzie, who curated "Dreamsuits" with the designer Robert Cerimagic. "The first time they met, Nudie took him for a ride in one of his famous Nudiemobiles. When you started the engine, you heard the sound of horses' hooves and gunfire. Bobbejaan was so impressed that he got one to display at Bobbejaanland. He always said it was the most lucrative ride he ever had."

For most people, Diwali festivities are incomplete without the crackling of firecrackers. And almost everyone has a favorite, ranging from the innocuous "phooljhadi," or sparkler, to the rocket, which usually fails to live up to its name, hissing into the sky with fierce intensity only to fall flat on the ground within minutes. And then there is the pernicious-sounding "bomb," whose name says it all. They come in different shapes and sizes but the firecrackers have one thing in common: they unleash an ear-splitting bang when they are set ablaze.

An article on Monday about federal officials' plans to overhaul privacy rules that regulate research involving human subjects, and concerns raised by scholars, paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Linda Shopes, who helped draft a statement by historians about possible changes. She said that board members at a university (which she did not name) -- not board members at the University of Chicago -- suggested at one point that using recorded interviews deposited at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Library would have needed Reagan's specific approval when he was alive.

After a recent episode of ''The Walking Dead'' that vividly revealed the contents of a zombie's stomach, AMC has decided it still has a healthy appetite for that popular series about the survivors of an undead apocalypse. On Tuesday the cable channel said it was ordering a third season of ''The Walking Dead,'' which is adapted from the popular Image Comics series and has turned into - if you'll pardon the awful pun - a monster hit for the home of prestigious series like ''Mad Men'' and ''Breaking Bad.'' The second-season premiere of ''The Walking Dead,'' broadcast on Oct. 16, set a ratings record for AMC, drawing 7.3 million viewers in total and 4.8 million were ages 18 to 49, making it the highest-rated drama episode ever on cable in that age category. (Ratings for a new episode shown this past Sunday were down slightly but still strong.) AMC did not immediately say when production on new episodes of ''The Walking Dead'' would begin; it made no mention of which characters will survive to Season 3, or what would be left of them.

MULRY--Thomas C. 79, of Gulf Stream, FL died Sunday, October 23, 2011, surrounded by his wife of 51 years, Margaret Power Mulry, and his five children. Mr. Mulry was born in New York and educated at Chaminade High School and Seton Hall University. He served in the U.S. Army (1955-1957). He was the former President of Stone & Webster Securities (1972-1974) and Managing Director then Advisory Director of PaineWebber Inc. Investment Banking Division (1974-2000). He is survived by his children, Patricia Mulry of Lake Worth, FL; Thomas C. Mulry, Jr. of Boyce, VA; Sean F. Mulry, of Glen Cove, NY; Megan Huisinga of Delray Beach, FL; and Brooke Mulry, of Lake Worth, FL; and seven grandchildren, Hope, Cecilia, Maggie, Tommy, Katharine Mulry and Helen and Jeb Huisinga. He was a long-time resident of Locust Valley, NY, and retired to Gulf Stream in 2000. He was formerly a member of the Bond Club of New York, The Creek, Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club, and St. Andrew's. At the time of his death, he was an active member of The Brook, Millwood Country Club, Manalapan Yacht Club, The Pilgrims of the United States, The Little Club, and the Gulf Stream Bath and Tennis Club. Funeral services will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church in Delray Beach, FL, at 2:00pm on Thursday, October 27, 2011. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Bethesda Hospital Foundation, PO Box 243628, Boynton Beach, FL 33424.

BACKING OUT ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steel manufacturer, announced on Tuesday that it was pulling out of a $4.9 billion joint bid with Peabody Energy to acquire Macarthur Coal of Australia. The announcement came less than two days after the companies gained a majority stake in the mining company.

Eight current and former New York police officers were arrested on Tuesday and charged in federal court with accepting thousands of dollars in cash to drive a caravan of firearms into the state, an act of corruption that brazenly defied the city's strenuous efforts to get illegal guns off the streets. The officers -- five are still on the force, and three are retired -- and four other men were accused of transporting M-16 rifles and handguns, as well as what they believed to be stolen merchandise across state lines, according to a complaint filed in the case in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

Perhaps it's not Occupy Wall Street that the banks should fear, but their latest frothy financial product. Investment bankers are crisscrossing the nation peddling spinoffs. But given the weak stock prices of these banks, they may find themselves under pressure from their own investors to break up. Spinoffs are the deal du jour. Abbott Laboratories became the latest on the bandwagon, announcing last week a spinoff of its research-based pharmaceutical business. This year, 59 spinoffs have been completed, totaling about $98 billion, according to Dealogic. The dollar number is up almost 85 percent from the same period last year and does not include planned splits by Sara Lee, McGraw-Hill and Kraft Foods, among others.

An article on Monday about hearing loop technology, which eliminates background noise for wearers of hearing aids, misstated the name of an oratorio by the composer Richard Einhorn, who lost most of his hearing at age 57. It is ''Voices of Light,'' not ''Voice of Light.''

The winners of the Whiting Writers' Awards, given annually to authors ''of exceptional talent and promise in early career,'' were announced on Tuesday. The 2011 recipients include the fiction writers Scott Blackwood (''We Agreed to Meet Just Here''), Teddy Wayne (''Kapitoil''), Daniel Orozco (''Orientation'') and Ryan Call (''The Weather Stations''). The poetry winners are Don Mee Choi (''The Morning News is Exciting''), Eduardo C. Corral (''Slow Lightning''), Shane McCrae (''Mule'') and Kerri Webster (''We Do Not Eat Our Hearts Alone''). The nonfiction winner is Paul Clemens (''Made in Detroit''), and the playwright is Amy Herzog (''After the Revolution'').

LIBO--Andrew L.,54, of Mamaroneck, NY died peacefully at home on October 25, 2011 surrounded by family and friends. Born on October 6, 1957 to Dr. Hersh and Libby Libo, Andrew grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. He attended Poly Prep Country Day School where he was a star wrestler and from where he graduated in 1975. Andrew graduated cum laude with a B.A. in psychology and history from the University of Rochester in 1979 and earned his J.D. from George Washington School of Law in 1982. He was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1983. After gaining Associate experience at the Law Offices of F. Lee Bailey and Aaron J. Broder, Andrew became a founding member of the law firm of Gersowitz Libo & Korek, P.C. in 1984 where he embarked upon a career representing victims of corporate malfeasance and negligence. Dedicated to protecting the civil justice system, Andrew was a member of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, New York City Bar Association, Bronx County Bar Association and American Association for Justice. Andrew kept faith with his philanthropic philosophy by sponsoring the annual Gardiner Foundation basketball tournament which provides scholarships to college bound inner-city youth. Andrew was a loving and dedicated husband and father and took joy in coaching his sons' soccer and Little League games. He was an avid golfer and enjoyed rooting for the New York Yankees with his family. Andrew is survived by his loving wife of 18 years, Jean Meyerowitz and their three sons, Sanford (16) Matthew (14) and Ethan (12). Andrew is also survived by his parents, Dr. Hersh and Libby, his brother, David (Miriam) of Los Angeles, his sister, Sheryl (Max) of Playa del Carmen, Mexico, and his many nieces and nephews. Also surviving Andrew are the countless individuals and families whose lives he helped better over the course of his distinguished legal career. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Jewish Center on 175 Rockland Avenue in Mamaroneck, NY on Thursday, October 27, 2011 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Andrew's name to The Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center at Duke, DUMC Box 3624, Durham, NC 27710.

The Character Study last Sunday about Ed Shevlin, a New York City garbage collector who studies the Irish language and culture, misstated the name of a circular pin that shows the wearer speaks Irish. It is a fáinne, not a fáinna.

10 P.M. (Comedy Central) SOUTH PARK Randy develops an appreciation for Broadway and whisks Sharon to New York to see every musical, above, in an episode that reunites the creative team behind the Tony Award-winning ''Book of Mormon'': Robert Lopez and the ''South Park'' creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker. In a recent interview with Dave Itzkoff of The New York Times, Mr. Lopez talked about the team's creative process: ''To hear them say how they do it, they're always out of ideas, and they're always looking around for crumbs. And those crumbs turn into these great episodes. I'm really curious to watch that all happen, so I decided not to bring too much with me.'' 7:45 P.M. (Cinemax) WALL STREET (1987) Oliver Stone chronicles shifting fortunes in the financial world in this double bill, which begins with his drama about a young stockbroker (Charlie Sheen) willing to do anything to make it to the top, and his ruthless, corporation-raiding mentor, Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas). In its sequel, ''Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps'' (2010), at 10, Mr. Douglas returns as the reptilian Gekko, who, after serving an eight-year prison sentence, has landed in the public spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf is the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko's fans, and the live-in love of Gekko's estranged daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume. ''To the question 'What went wrong?' the film offers an answer that is both irrefutable and unsatisfying: human nature,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. And yet, he added, something vital here works. Mr. Stone ''is not the man to explain Wall Street, or to stoke public indignation at its crimes,'' he said. ''But no one else could turn it into a show like 'Wall Street.' ''

Rick Perry appears determined to make doubts about President Obama's birthplace an issue again in the Republican primary campaign even though Mr. Obama produced his long-form birth certificate months ago. In two interviews, Mr. Perry insisted that he was not certain that Mr. Obama was born in the United States, linking himself to the so-called birther movement, whose members question whether the president is occupying the White House legally.

The real-life Leonardo da Vinci had no extraordinary powers, other than a first-class intellect, unparalleled artistic skills and the ability to make millions of dollars for Dan Brown a few centuries down the road. But to the Starz cable channel Leonardo is enough of a champion to feature in a new series that was announced on Tuesday and which is being created for the channel by a writer with some serious superhero credentials. Starz said it had given the green light to a new adventure series called ''Da Vinci's Demons'' in which that original Renaissance man will be its central character and which will be written by David S. Goyer, whose film credits include the blockbusters ''Batman Begins'' and ''The Dark Knight,'' as well as a coming Superman movie, ''Man of Steel.''

The Books of The Times review on Saturday, about ''Steve Jobs,'' by Walter Isaacson, described ''Angry Birds,'' a popular iPhone game, incorrectly. Slingshots are used to launch birds to destroy pigs and their fortresses, not to shoot down the birds.

BARRON--Arthur R.,Former Paramount and Time Warner executive Arthur R. Barron died on October 22, 2011 at the age of 77. Art Barron was born July 12, 1934 and grew up around Lake Okoboji, Iowa. Following service in the U.S. Navy, he graduated from San Diego State University. He joined the international accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand where he became a CPA. In 1963 he went to work for Desilu Productions. Soon afterwards, Desilu was acquired by Gulf & Western, which recently had also had taken over Paramount Pictures. Arthur R. Barron assumed the leadership of Paramount Communications Inc.'s (formerly Gulf & Western's) leisure and entertainment businesses after Barry Diller and Michael Eisner exited Paramount Pictures in the early 1980s. He was President of PCI's Entertainment Group from 1984 to 1989, when he retired. Not long afterward, he was lured back to work for Time Warner by Steve Ross. Barron served as Chairman of Time Warner International from 1990 until his final retirement in 1995. Over the next quarter century Barron advanced through several executive positions in Paramount Pictures and its parent company Gulf & Western (subsequently named Paramount Communications Inc.). He was Paramount's Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer between 1967 and 1983. As President of PCI's Entertainment Group he led Paramount Pictures, Simon and Schuster, Madison Square Garden, the New York Knicks and New York Rangers, Famous Players theater chain, Famous Music, and the Group's interests in several international joint ventures. Frank Mancuso, ex-Chairman and CEO of Paramount Picture and MGM, said "I had the great privilege of working with Art Barron for 25 years at Paramount Pictures. He was an exceptional financial executive, a company builder, a devoted husband and father, and an exceptional friend. He will truly be missed by so many." The French Government appointed Barron a Commander of Arts & Letters in 1987. In 1998, San Diego State University awarded him an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters. The same year, Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications recognized Barron with its Minister's Commendation Award. Over the years Barron served on committees organized by the U.S. State Department and the Commerce Department. He was a Trustee of the Business Council for International Understanding; a member of the Advisory Committee for the Center for Strategic & International Studies and a director of the Russian American Chamber of Commerce. Barron was a Trustee of the American Museum of the Moving Image; its Education Program is named in honor of Barron and his wife, Joan. He also served on the Board of Trustees of the American Liver Foundation. Barron maintained a close relationship with his alma mater, San Diego State University. He was Founding Co-Chairman of the SDSU Japan-U.S. Telecommunications Research Institute. He was also the Founding Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the International Center for Communications. Earlier this year, The Joan & Art Barron Veterans Center was dedicated at SDSU. Barron was a director of the Southern Ocean County Hospital in Manahawkin, NJ. He was also a Trustee of the Southern Ocean Medical Center Foundation. Other organizations he served in various capacities included the Surflight Theatre Co., the Alliance for a Living Ocean (ALO), and the Montana Chapter of the Nature Conservancy. Art and Joan Barron maintained homes in Bonita Springs, FL, and Beach Haven, NJ. In addition to his wife, Joan, he is survived by his son Robert and his wife Maria, their children Brian, Sean, Tyler and Alanna, and his daughter Brenda and her children, Janaye and Ryan.
