GOLDSTEIN--Judy Ann. Beloved wife of Bob for 41 years, devoted mother of Loren Mortman and her husband Alex, adoring grandmother of Arielle and Mackenzie. Judy had an incomparable ability to care about other people. She demonstrated this compassion for others in her early career in social work and every day of her life. Judy was very young at heart and had a zest for living that was contagious. Everyone who knew Judy was affected by her special vitality. All who were fortunate enough to call her a friend know they were lucky. The world was a better place with Judy in it and she will be deeply, deeply missed. A Memorial Service will be held to honor Judy on Thursday, October 27, 2011, 10:30am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St., New York City.
Time: About 20 minutes

STEIN--Fred, 84, died October 24, beloved father, grandfather, uncle, and friend. Fred was known for his passion for investing, love and generosity toward his friends and family, and larger than life personality. After seven years in the Merchant Marines, Fred began his career writing price quotes by hand on the chalkboards of the Stock Exchange. He retired as one of the great money managers. Although he amassed considerable wealth along the way, his greatest gift was for making close friends. At his 80th birthday, a friend said: "If anyone who knows Fred were in trouble and could make just one call for help, he would call Fred." Another friend said: "The day was always better if one got to spend a part of it with Fred." He is survived by his four children and daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by all. Funeral services are at 12:30 today at the 92nd Street Y. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the UJA in Fred's honor would be greatly appreciated.

After missing last Thursday's latest must-win win against Philadelphia after receiving a red card in the previous game, Henry and the Red Bulls are preparing for Wednesday night's playoff opener against Dallas in Frisco, Tex.

A typical superhero throws punches, not paper clips. But a typical superhero is not also a New York City public school teacher. A new mobile game, The Teachers of New York City, changes that, turning public school teachers into heroes and heroines who can advance from one level to the next by opening closed schools and cleaning out Tweed Courthouse, the headquarters of the city's Education Department.

The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust had no apparent problems with Roland Emmerich's previous movies about genocidal space aliens, apocalyptic solar flares and life in prehistoric times. But when Mr. Emmerich messed with Shakespeare, that's where the trust drew the line - right through the name of the playwright it is set up to protect. The trust, a British charity organization that promotes the study and life of Shakespeare, is protesting the release of ''Anonymous,'' a film directed by Mr. Emmerich that questions the authorship of his works, by covering Shakespeare's name on several signs in Warwickshire, the British county that was the playwright's home.

FRANKFURT - As European officials struggle to find a solution to the sovereign debt crisis, two of the region's largest financial firms continue to deal with the fallout from the market turmoil. On Tuesday, Deutsche Bank exceeded quarterly profit expectations, but Germany's largest lender warned of jobs cuts in the investment bank, following a drop in trading revenue stemming from the market mess. Under similar pressure, the Swiss bank UBS, which also was hurt by a trading scandal that cost it $2.3 billion, reported that earnings fell 39 percent in the third quarter, from a year earlier.

An article on Tuesday about the failure of the Class Act, a federal long-term care insurance program, misstated one of the conditions that Joshua M. Wiener of the RTI International research group said could have made the program work. Mr. Wiener said the Class Act might have succeeded if it had restricted enrollment to the healthy, not if it had restricted benefits to the healthy.

Last week, I wrote that the monster passing numbers from the first five weeks took a serious body blow in Week 6, evidenced by a huge decline in passing touchdowns. The knockout punch was delivered in Week 7. After teams averaged over 240 passing yards per game through the first six weeks of the season, the 26 teams playing in Week 7 combined for only 4,997 passing yards this past weekend, a paltry 191 yards per game. Nowhere was this more evident -- on Sunday -- than in Cleveland, as the Seahawks and Browns put on a pitiful display. The Browns and Seahawks combined for 435 yards and 9 points. It was the worst display of offense in a game not affected by severe weather in over a decade. The Colt McCoypass attempt watch marches on: he threw 35 passes in a game in which the Browns allowed only 137 yards and 3 points. But Cleveland-Seattle was just an appetizer for ''Monday Night Football.'' Against Jacksonville, the Ravens' first 22 plays netted 6 yards. Baltimore had nine drives in the first half, and the Ravens never got close to getting a first down on any of them. Four of Jacksonville's first-half possessions gained negative yards; a fifth series ended in a fumble. After 30 minutes, the game featured five fumbles, four first downs and just 29 yards of passing. Baltimore got its first first down with five minutes left in the third quarter. The two teams combined for 185 passing yards, the fewest in any game this season. Joe Flacco threw for only 137 yards on 38 pass attempts; only Jesse Palmer, Bobby Hoying, Kent Graham, Carson Palmer and Tommy Maddox have gained fewer yards on so many attempts since 1970. The Jaguars rookie quarterback Blaine Gabbert wasn't any better -- the Jaguars gained 73 passing yards on 24 pass plays. Once again, don't write the obituary on pass defense just yet.

GOLDSTEIN--Judy. It's not supposed to happen but when it does, it's tragic that a wonderful friend, wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandparent, and daughter passes away in her early sixties.....leaving behind all whom she loved and cared about and who loved her as much! Sixty wonderful years with all of us and then a diagnosis of a serious cancer......and yet, Judy continued to love her family and friends and live life to the fullest without a complaint......and continued to ask all "how are you?".......because Judy cared about us even as she battled a deadly disease. The news of Judy's death on Monday stopped all of us in our tracks and we cried because we knew that we lost "the real deal!" We share the deepest sorrow with Bob G and the family and with Judy G's many dear friends. With the deepest sadness, Ronnie Rothstein, Mara Urshel, and Wayne Rogers

Ticket sales for straight plays on Broadway were notably strong last week, according to theater box office data released on Monday, with most of those non-musical productions making gains in their grosses in an otherwise flat week for Broadway. Indeed, money-wise, new straight plays are poised to have one of their best fall seasons on Broadway in recent years. Usually Broadway has two, maybe three breakout hits among plays each fall, in large part because of the popular appeal of well-known actors in the cast. Last year the hits were ''The Merchant of Venice'' (starring Al Pacino) and ''Driving Miss Daisy'' (Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones), and in 2009 they were ''A Steady Rain'' (Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig), ''God of Carnage'' (James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden) and ''Hamlet'' (Jude Law).

Hauptman--Herbert. The City College of New York mourns the passing of its distinguished alumnus, Dr. Herbert Hauptman, Class of 1937. Together with a classmate, Dr. Jerome Karle, Dr. Hauptman, a math major at CCNY, shared the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for their "outstanding achievements in the development of direct methods for the determination of crystal structures." Over the years, Dr. Hauptman retained strong bonds with his alma mater. He returned to campus in 2005, along with Dr. Karle and two other of CCNY's nine Nobel Prize-winning alumni, to participate in a conference commemorating the centennial of the Einstein Papers. He also collaborated on two math books with Dr. Alfred Posamentier, former dean of education. On behalf of our faculty, students and staff, I extend condolences to his family. Lisa S. Coico, President

An article on Thursday about state jobless benefits programs misstated unemployment insurance law in a suggestion to business owners seeking to contain their insurance rates. Business owners cannot persuade employees to quit ''by offering a severance package in exchange for a written agreement to forgo unemployment.'' It is not the case that this is an option they have for handling poor employees. (The tactic is not allowed under federal law, Labor Department regulations and the law in most states.)

"My Lord, I can touch a bell on my right hand, and order the arrest of a citizen in Ohio. I can touch the bell again, and order the arrest of a citizen in New York. Can the Queen of England, in her dominions, do as much?" William Henry Seward's boast to Lord Lyons, Britain's envoy to the United States for much of the Civil War - and a diplomat with whom Lincoln's secretary of state enjoyed an often fractious relationship - is almost certainly an apocryphal invention of administration critics. But it nevertheless illustrates a higher truth: Seward's early and aggressive involvement with the wartime suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, one of the most controversial actions of the Lincoln administration.

The town of Dhobley, Somalia, sits at the gateway of hell.  Just west of Dhobley is the border with Kenya, and the road to Dadaab, which hosts a giant complex of refugee camps; Dhobley has become the last stop in Somalia for a growing stream of desperate, starving people in flight from famine.  In Dhobley, as well, drought has ruined crops and felled cows.   There is no government to help.  The town is a battleground; control of Dhobley has teetered between the Shabaab Islamist militant group and government forces.  Shabaab has blocked food aid from entering Dhobley and burned a food truck, but soldiers from all sides have stolen food meant for the destitute.   The usual street life of an African village - children playing, women laughing together - has vanished.   Gunshots are a constant background noise - "like birds singing," said Tracy Stover, the emergency coordinator in Dadaab for the humanitarian group World Concern.

Chances are you weren't ready to buy a winter coat when the first of them started arriving in stores in August, pre-Labor Day, while temperatures still neared 90 degrees. But it's officially fall now, the recent summer's record-breaking heat has long been forgotten, and it's time to start thinking seriously about buying a coat, of which there are many warm and woolly options. Long is the trend, and contemporary labels like Theyskens' Theory and 3.1 Philip Lim deliver it in full. Capes are making a comeback - the fall runways showed versions in everything from mohair to wool -- and cropped peacoats (see Miu Miu and Burberry) are in attendance, too. And then there are parkas, like those from Altuzarra and Valentino's Red Label, that look as good with slip dresses as they do with wool suits, and are versatile enough if you just add layers in January. Coat, check!

Fresh out of the Yale School of Drama in 1975, Meryl Streep was 90 minutes late for her first audition with Joseph Papp, the artistic director of the Public Theater and the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park. Her train from New Haven had been delayed, and there were, of course, no cellphones or e-mail then. She arrived to find Papp sitting in one of his signature white suits, his impatience conveyed with a grimace and twitchy crossed-leg kicks. Yet a few minutes later, the potential of a great actress had transformed his mood, and soon he was offering a small role to Ms. Streep in what would be her Broadway debut: "Trelawny of the 'Wells'" at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, in an era when acting work in New York was hard to find.

Dominique Ansel, who was the pastry chef at Daniel for six years and worked at Fauchon in Paris before that, is opening his own pastry shop and café on Wednesday. And in addition to croissants, macarons and éclairs, he is baking a few specialties that are not everyday indulgences in New York. Among them are a tall, fluted cake, the gâteau battu, which comes from Mr. Ansel's native Picardy, northeast of Paris, and is halfway between brioche and pound cake but lighter than either one. He sells the whole cake and slices, excellent with soft butter and jam. He is also baking kouign amann, a flaky, crispy little Breton pastry, which a few American chefs are starting to feature on their menus. And his take on the Paris-Brest, a filled ring of cream puff pastry, is called Paris-New York and has caramel, peanuts and chocolate. His menu also includes savory items like sandwiches, quiches, soups and salads. The narrow space with an open kitchen has a few seats and a marble counter, an all-weather greenhouse for seating in the back, and a garden.

A group of art forgers who sold falsely attributed oil paintings to art collectors, and whose victims included the comedian Steve Martin, were sentenced on Thursday by a court in Cologne, Germany, Bloomberg News reported. Wolfgang Beltracchi, the leader of the ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Léger and Max Ernst, was given a six-year sentence; his wife, Helene, was sentenced to four years while her sister, Jeanette, received a 21-month suspended sentence. Otto Schulte-Kellinghaus, a fourth member of the ring, was sentenced to five years.

Print may be dying, but not in the design world. The exhibition "Archizines," at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London from Nov. 5 through Dec. 14, features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries. The show's curator, Elias Redstone, who writes the London Underground column for T's blog, The Moment, collected the publications on his travels, compiling them first as an online project (archizines.com), with art direction by Folch Studio in Barcelona. But an exhibition of the print versions makes perfect sense: the power of the Internet notwithstanding, it's more fun to turn real pages than digital ones.

On Oct. 27, 1904, the first rapid transit subway, the Interborough Rapid Transit (I.R.T.), opened in New York City. The line ran approximately nine miles from City Hall north to Grand Central Station, then west to Times Square and up the West Side to 145th Street.The New York Times described the excitement among city dwellers for the subway's opening: "For the first time in his life Father Knickerbocker went underground yesterday; went underground, he and his children, to the number of 150,000, amid the tooting of whistles and the firing of salutes, for a first ride in a subway which for years had been scoffed at as an impossibility."

In 1912, the 24-year-old Eugene O'Neill tried to kill himself with an overdose of Veronal, but botched the job and was found unconscious by friends. He later wrote about the experience in an autobiographical one-act play, ''Exorcism,'' which ends with the O'Neill character, Ned Malloy, experiencing a kind of resurrection. ''The Past is finally cremated,'' he says. ''I feel reborn, I tell you.'' ''Exorcism'' premiered at the Provincetown Playhouse in March, 1920, but O'Neill then abruptly withdrew the play and destroyed what were believed to be all the copies. What scholars knew of the work came from mostly the details in a review in The New York Times by Alexander Woollcott, who wrote that ''Exorcism'' was ''uncommonly good.''

Charles Hamm, who helped establish the field of American popular music history with two books that have become standard texts, died on Oct. 16 in Lebanon, N. H. He was 86. The cause was pneumonia, his son Stuart said.

FITZGERALD--Pamela, January 8, 1952 - October 23, 2011. Beloved wife of John, loving and devoted mother of John and Hadley, who will remember her forever. Pamela grew up in New York City and New Jersey with her sisters Patricia Walsh and Marylou Cook, and their parents, Lourdes and the late Bill Walsh, and was a graduate of Georgian Court College (BA, English) and Fordham University (MSW). She possessed a keen intellect, a sharp sense of humor, and great beauty. She valiantly fought against the breast cancer that took her life too soon. Visitation at the Leonardis Memorial Home, 210 Ridgedale Ave., Florham Park, NJ, Friday from 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday at 11am at the Church of the Holy Family in Florham Park. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about John McCarthy, a computer scientist, misspelled the given name of one founder of Apple, who had been a member of the Homebrew Computer Club, a hobbyist group that Dr. McCarthy invited to meet at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. He is Stephen Wozniak, not Steven.

Will this be the year that Marta will be dethroned as the winner of FIFA's women's world player of the year? Marta, a skillful Brazilian, has won the award for the past five years and was among the 10 players nominated Wednesday for this year's award. The United States has three players on the list (which, for some reason, the rest of the world refers to as shortlisted), all of whom played for the United States at last summer's Women's World Cup in Germany and all of whom (including Marta) played last season in Women's Professional Soccer. The three Americans are Alex Morgan, Hope Solo and Abby Wambach.

8:30 P.M. (HBO) THE EDUCATION OF DEE DEE RICKS (2011) In 2008 Ms. Ricks, above, a hedge-fund millionaire and single mother of two sons who described herself as vain, learned she had aggressive Stage 2 breast cancer. Insured and affluent, she could afford the best treatment -- in her case a double mastectomy and reconstructive surgery. But she was stunned to learn of the difficulties faced by uninsured women in the same situation, so she set out to do something about it. This documentary, directed by the newswoman Perri Peltz and released during National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, chronicles Ms. Ricks's efforts to recover and her transformation from successful businesswoman to advocate for impoverished patients. NOON (Flix) LOVESPELL (1981) Richard Burton portrays King Mark of Cornwall, Nicholas Clay is Tristan, and Kate Mulgrew is Isolt in this romantic fantasy about a love triangle, based on Arthurian legend and directed by Tom Donovan.

CARPENTER--Ruth C. A teacher, mentor, literary scholar and friend of unparalleled intellect and generosity, Ruth Corn Carpenter, of New Milford, Connecticut and New York City, passed away peacefully on the evening of October 23, 2011. Only child of Lorlene Johnson and Wilbur Graves Corn, Ruth grew up in Franklin, Tennessee, and attended The Harpeth Hall School, where she was valedictorian. She was graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1957 with a B.A. in English, first in her class and summa cum laude. Among other honors, she was awarded Marshall and Fulbright scholarships, and studied at Cambridge University in England, where she received an M.A. She also won Bryn Mawr's European Fellowship, the college's highest honor for a member of the graduating class. Ruth then began a 50-year career studying and teaching literature. Many of her students have described her as the most brilliant mind and greatest teacher they have ever encountered in any field at any institution. She taught briefly at Barnard College, and in South Korea at Ewha Women's University, but primarily lavished her great literary and pedagogical gifts on the girls of the Brearley School in New York City, where she taught for 40 years, and where she was the guiding star of an English department that rivaled any in the country. Ruth opened the minds of thousands of Brearley girls to the abiding value of literature. She taught everything from Malory to Jane Austen to Samuel Beckett to Langston Hughes, but Shakespeare was her first love, literally. At the age of 12, she saw a traveling production of Hamlet in Franklin, Tennessee, and suddenly she "was in love" -- simultaneously with the red headed actor playing the lead, with Hamlet and with Shakespeare. It was to Ruth's Shakespeare elective that the students of Brearley flocked every year, and it was to Shakespeare that she primarily devoted her luminous attention after retiring from the Brearley School in 2000. From 2000 through 2011, Ruth was the head of adult education at, and taught Shakespeare seminars for, the Shakespeare Society in New York City. Like generations of Brearley girls, Ruth's adult students became enthralled by Ruth's remarkable ability to deepen, complicate and expand their understanding of, and feeling for, the fully formed characters we meet in Shakespeare's plays. Ruth Carpenter offered to all her students, young and old, a new way of comprehending Shakespeare, the world and themselves. That is the essence of her legacy to us all. She would have us continue to regard Shakespeare with new eyes; and to those who protest they cannot do that without her she would say (quoting readily from The Winter's Tale), "It is required you do awake your faith." Ruth was a radiant spirit and a devout humanist who also firmly believed in the immortality of the soul. Her enormously generous heart, a lifetime devoted to seeing human beings fully, in life as in literature, and her linguistic brilliance made her at once a wise and compassionate friend, and a wonderfully witty one too. The entire English language was at her command, and her grip on it never failed. Moreover, the invariable elegance of her attire matched the elegance of her mind, and we will rarely see her like again for sartorial perfection. For Ruth, as for Shakespeare, "nothing human was alien to her," and her sheer love of life and her friends rivaled that of her beloved Falstaff. She also made friends with bats and snakes and blue jays and geese and all the denizens of her Connecticut gardens that were a source of endless pleasure. Ruth now joins her loving partner of 20 years, Dick Gershman, who died in 1998. Ruth is survived by the love of her best friends Alexa and Fred Aldridge, Ann McDonald and Ellie Rittman, and by the love and devotion of all the Aldridges, who are her godchildren and family: Mindy Aldridge and her daughter, Katharine, and Richard and Kris Aldridge, and their children Hank, Eliza, Bo and Evie. Ruth's funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held in New York City, the details of which will be announced. Ruth asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Shakespeare Society, 118-122 Baxter Street, Suite 705, New York, New York 10013.

Jack the Cat did not patronize the duty-free shops. He was never spotted near any of the drinking establishments. And if he bothered to sample the food court fare, his emaciated condition would register as a scathing critique. But when the 5-year-old Norwegian forest cat, with long orange hair and copper eyes, fell through the ceiling in the customs area in Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday night, he achieved what was starting to seem impossible: giving this tale of a natural disaster, missing-pet posters and airline bureaucracy a happy ending.

WHEN New Yorkers want Halloween costumes with sartorial flair, they forgo costume shops and drugstores and head to the Patricia Field boutique on the Bowery, where glitter wigs and bondage pants are the everyday garb of Ms. Field's regular customers. Best known as the costume designer for the ''Sex and the City'' television series and films, Ms. Field said that there's nothing wrong with buying a Halloween costume that comes in a box, but that her shop has become a destination for out-of-the-box, high-fashion getups. Think geisha wigs, peacock feathers, and devil headbands made of rhinestones.

LIBO--Andrew L.,54, of Mamaroneck, NY died peacefully at home on October 25, 2011 surrounded by family and friends. Born on October 6, 1957 to Dr. Hersh and Libby Libo, Andrew grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. He attended Poly Prep Country Day School where he was a star wrestler and from where he graduated in 1975. Andrew graduated cum laude with a B.A. in psychology and history from the University of Rochester in 1979 and earned his J.D. from George Washington School of Law in 1982. He was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1983. After gaining Associate experience at the Law Offices of F. Lee Bailey and Aaron J. Broder, Andrew became a founding member of the law firm of Gersowitz Libo & Korek, P.C. in 1984 where he embarked upon a career representing victims of corporate malfeasance and negligence. Dedicated to protecting the civil justice system, Andrew was a member of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, New York City Bar Association, Bronx County Bar Association and American Association for Justice. Andrew kept faith with his philanthropic philosophy by sponsoring the annual Gardiner Foundation basketball tournament which provides scholarships to college bound inner-city youth. Andrew was a loving and dedicated husband and father and took joy in coaching his sons' soccer and Little League games. He was an avid golfer and enjoyed rooting for the New York Yankees with his family. Andrew is survived by his loving wife of 18 years, Jean Meyerowitz and their three sons, Sanford (16) Matthew (14) and Ethan (12). Andrew is also survived by his parents, Dr. Hersh and Libby Libo, his brother, David (Miriam) of Los Angeles, his sister, Sheryl (Max) of Playa del Carmen, Mexico, and his many nieces and nephews. Also surviving Andrew are the countless individuals and families whose lives he helped better over the course of his distinguished legal career. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Jewish Center on 175 Rockland Avenue in Mamaroneck, NY on Thursday, October 27, 2011 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Andrew's name to The Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center at Duke, DUMC Box 3624, Durham, NC 27710 or the Cancer Support Team, 875 Mamaroneck Avenue, Suite 204, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

Orange alert! The Department of Homeland Security may have retired its color-coded terrorism alert system, but the pervading sense of paranoia that it represented isn't going away, and neither is Showtime's hit series, ''Homeland.'' On Wednesday that cable channel said it had ordered a second season of ''Homeland,'' its serialized thriller about a dogged if possibly paranoid C.I.A. officer (played by Claire Danes), a recently released American prisoner of war (Damian Lewis) who may be a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda, and Mandy Patinkin's epic beard. (O.K., the beard is not as crucial to the story, but some of us still find it fascinating.) The series, which is adapted from Gideon Raff's Israeli television program ''Prisoners of War'' and is produced by Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa (both of ''24''), has been Showtime's highest-rated first-year drama series since making its debut earlier this month, and is drawing about 1 million viewers for each new broadcast. Showtime said that production on a new 12-episode season of ''Homeland'' would begin next spring, giving Ms. Danes's character plenty of time to refill her illicit supply of Klonopin.

THOSE graphic geometric sweaters that popped up on several fall runways turned a lot of fashionable heads. ''It's like a graphic T-shirt for grown-ups,'' the stylist Laurie Trott said. ''But much more chic because it's a knit.'' At Céline, a chevron-pattern pullover was styled with a white turtleneck and leather-trimmed pants -- incredibly chic. At Chloé, a patchwork sweater was shown with loose-fitting leather pants (wide-leg jeans or trousers would look cool, too). And at Altuzarra, an argyle pullover read dressed-up/casual with a military-inflected pencil skirt and puffy jacket. Some of the runway styles would set you back more than $1,500, but you'll find nifty knits at all prices. Check out this selection. Top, from left: Central Saint Martins for Pringle of Scotland argyle sweater, $550 at Saks Fifth Avenue. Balenciaga geometric pullover, $875 at Barneys New York. Versace diamond-print pullover, $1,575 at net-a-porter.com. Diamond-print cardigan, $76 at Topshop, 478 Broadway; topshop.com. Phillip Lim cable sweater, $550 at lagarconne.com.

Spain's Mediterranean coast is, for now, home to the top team in La Liga -- and it is not named Barcelona. After spending fewer than 24 hours in second place after Barca's 1-0 win at Granada on Tuesday, Levante vaulted back into the top spot on Wednesday courtesy of a goal by Ruben Suarez in injury time that enabled the small club from Valencia to score another big victory, 3-2, against Real Sociedad. It was Levante's seventh consecutive win.

SINCE the sleeper hit ''Drive'' opened in September, Dorothy Gaspar has had more inquiries about her work than she did after any of the more than 70 other films for which she designed gloves, ''Titanic'' and three ''X-Men'' costume dramas included. Attribute this to Ryan Gosling (left), darkly cool as the stunt driver who moonlights as a wheelman for burglars, but fashion designers had already put their spin on driving gloves for women. At Louis Vuitton, Marc Jacobs sent a smoking Kate Moss down the runway in fetish-style patent leather gloves. Phillip Lim now has three versions in stores, including the two-tone perforated pair here. Rag & Bone has quilted styles, even plaid ones to match the season's collection. For men or women, for driving a getaway car or just keeping your digits warm, having a signature style to call your own is a good look. Clockwise from top left: Leather driving gloves with zip detail, $135 at Mackage, 123 Mercer Street; (212) 925-1455. Leopard gloves, $500 at Agent Provocateur, 675 Madison Avenue; (212) 840-2436.Patent leather fetish gloves, $760 at Louis Vuitton. Rag & Bone quilted gloves, $275 at Barneys New York. Phillip Lim black-and-blue gloves, $250 at Pas de Deux, 328 East 11th Street; (212) 475-0075.

Jon S. Corzine's return to Wall Street has run into a wall of turbulence. Shares of his firm, the commodities and derivatives brokerage house MF Global, have plummeted 54 percent so far this week amid concerns about the firm's exposure to European sovereign debt. On Wednesday, the price of its five-year bonds slumped to 66.5 cents on the dollar, and the upfront premium of insuring $10 million of its debt annually climbed to $4.7 million, from about $3.9 million on Tuesday.

When the Goddess of Liberty was given to the United States, its donor's agenda was to burnish France's republican roots after the oppressive reign of Napoleon III and to celebrate the two nations' commitment to the principles of liberty. The only immigrants mentioned at the dedication in 1886 were the ''illustrious descendants of the French nobility'' who fought on behalf of the United States against Britain during the American Revolution.

Matthew G. Martinez, a former representative from the Los Angeles area who drew attention in 2000 when, as a party-line Democrat, he angrily switched to the Republican Party for his last months in office after being defeated in a primary, died Oct. 15 at his home in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 82. The cause was congestive heart failure, said his wife, Maxine.

Toby Keith has mellowed somewhat since the turbulent days after Sept. 11, 2001, when he became most known for his songs supporting the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. On subsequent albums he shied away from such material in favor of soulful ballads, along with the songs he has always produced about drinking, chasing girls and living hard. But the lead track on his new album, ''Clancy's Tavern'' (Show Dog/Capitol), is a full-throated throwback to that earlier style. That song, ''Made in America,'' describes an older farmer and his wife, who will buy only American products; are disgusted by the influx of foreign goods, from cars to cotton; and raised their family ''on King James and Uncle Sam.''

Adele continued to dominate the music charts with what is far and away the most popular album of the year as her ''21'' (XL/Columbia) album rose once again to the No. 1 slot on the Billboard album chart. The British soul singer has now spent 13 weeks this year on top of the chart and sold more than 4.1 million records, more than double the next best-selling album, Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way,''according to Nielsen SoundScan. No album has had more than four million sales in one year since 2005, when Mariah Carey's ''Emancipation of Mimi'' sold 4.97 million copies. Adele's feat overshadowed a strong debut showing for Casting Crowns, a Christian rock act that had been projected to do well with its new album ''Come to the Well.''(Provident) But in the end, people bought 99,000 copies of the Casting Crown recording over the last week and the group had to settle for runner-up. The band's last album, ''Until the Whole World Hears,'' sold 167,000 units in its debut in 2009.

Five of the 25 new shows on network television couldn't cut it: viewers didn't take to angels or agents, and couldn't find viewing time for bunnies or so-called gentlemen. ''Charlie's Angels'' on ABC, ''Free Agents'' and ''The Playboy Club'' on NBC, ''How to Be a Gentleman'' on CBS and CW's ''H8R'' were all canceled; none made it more than four episodes. The shows that have found the largest audiences appear to be going strong, and they're led by two young women who, to borrow from the title of their show, don't have much else going for them. The CBS sitcom ''2 Broke Girls'' leads all new shows that have had at least three episodes in average viewers and ratings in the pivotal demographic of 18-to- 49-year-olds. That show, staring Kat Dennings and Beth Behrs, has garnered an average of 12.7 million total viewers through six episodes.

We all loved him and will miss him very, very much. The Saltzman Family

Q.Ever since I upgraded my Mac to OS X Lion, it's been correcting my spelling on its own in e-mail and Web posts. How can I turn this off before it does something embarrassing that I don't notice ahead of time? A. As it does on its iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad devices, Apple includes an automatic correction feature on Macs that can sometimes make less-than-desirable changes. Fortunately, this feature can be turned off.

DAITCH--Herbert B.,97, passed away peacefully at his home in Rye Brook, NY on October 24th 2011. Beloved husband of the late Hilda F. Daitch for 75 years. Stalwart and loving husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and father-in-law to Hilda, Sandra, Larry, Susan, Jimmy, Meinar and Murray. A giant of the food industry, he was, at various times, President, Vice-Chairman, Chairman and CEO of Daitch Crystal Dairies, Daitch Supermarkets, Daitch-Shopwell Supermarkets and Food Emporium Supermarkets. The Company, which had stores throughout the Metropolitan New York area, was founded in 1919 by his father Louis Daitch. It was sold in 1986 to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Herbert Daitch, who was listed in Who's Who, was an early member of the Young Presidents Organization and the World Presidents Organization. He was a founding member of the Free Synagogue of Westchester and supported numerous charitable organizations both personally and through The Hilda and Herbert Daitch Foundation. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, Friday October 28, 2011 at 12 noon. The family will be receiving at his home, 33 Doral Greens Drive, West, Rye Brook, NY, following the funeral service and also on Friday 7:00 to 9:00pm; Saturday 1:00 to 4:00pm and 7:00 to 9:00pm and Sunday 1:00 to 4:00pm.

Benjamin Millepied, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, has retired and plans to focus on his choreography, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Millepied, 34, originally from Bordeaux, France, and known to many non-balletomanes as the choreographer for the Oscar-nominated movie ''Black Swan,'' joined the company in 1995 after training at City Ballet's affiliated School of American Ballet. He was promoted to principal in 2002 and originated roles in ballets by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins, Christopher Wheeldon, Alexei Ratmansky and others. As a choreographer, Mr. Millepied has created dances for numerous companies, including American Ballet Theater and the Paris Opera Ballet. His works for City Ballet include ''Quasi Una Fantasia,'' ''Why am I not where you are?'' and ''Plainspoken.'' For the company's 2012 spring season, Mr. Millepied will create a world premiere ballet to a commissioned score by Nico Muhly, which will have its premiere on May 10, at the company's spring gala. He's also working on the choreography for a new musical in development, ''Hands on a Hardbody,'' written with Trey Anastasio of Phish.

Video in 3-D may be all the rage, but there is an inexpensive new video tool that I think has greater potential to change the way you shoot video. It's from a company called EyeSee360, which makes lenses that put you in the middle of the action. It records in a complete circle (well, doughnut, really). The person watching the video can use a mouse to pan around and see what is happening all around the camera.

Samsung is offering a new camera that Narcissus might love almost as much as he loved himself. The MV800 takes a popular feature from other Samsung point-and-shoot cameras like the ST700, which is a front-facing LCD screen for self-portraits. Only the MV800 enlarges on the idea - literally.

WASHINGTON -- It would be hard for any lawyer to fathom a more riveting caseload than the one Paul D. Clement carried during his seven years in President George W. Bush's Justice Department. As solicitor general for three years and deputy solicitor for four, Mr. Clement appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, defended the administration's detention of terrorism suspects, fought off challenges to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law and validated the prosecution of medical marijuana growers in a landmark commerce case.

Always, Bruce, Mary Ann, Andrea, Nicholas, Lukas, Daniel, Bruce, Jr., Bryan & Ava Rose

A Sports of The Times column on Monday about the historically vexing relationship between the National Football League and African-Americans, and the role Al Davis had in confronting it as owner of the Oakland Raiders misstated the current number of black and minority head coaches in the 32-team league. There are eight (Carolina, Chicago, Cincinnati, Indianapolis, Minnesota, Oakland, Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay), not seven.

SEOUL, South Korea -- A civic activist and vocal critic of President Lee Myung-bak rode a growing call for political change to become mayor of the South Korean capital, Seoul, winning a poll widely seen as a bellwether for the presidential election in December next year. The activist, Park Won-soon, an independent candidate who was supported by the main opposition Democratic Party, clinched the mayoral race by winning 53.4 percent of the 4 million votes cast, according to the country's Central Election Management Committee.

An article on Wednesday about a proposed constitutional amendment in Mississippi that would declare a fertilized human egg to be a legal person misstated the surname of the president of the Center for Reproductive Rights, a legal advocacy group. She is Nancy Northup, not Northrup.

As the process of redrawing legislative boundaries heads to the courts in many other states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday said that he hoped to avoid that outcome in New York, warning that chaos would ensue if a judge was forced to sort out the state's redistricting procedures. Mr. Cuomo, who has proposed creating an independent commission to redraw the state's political map, reiterated that he would veto the district lines that are currently being drafted by the State Legislature. He urged legislators to reconsider their resistance to creating an outside body to handle the process.

An article on Tuesday about the cracking of an 18th-century code known as the Copiale Cipher misspelled the surname of the mathematician to whom Warren Weaver, a pioneer in automated language translation, wrote a letter in 1947 that suggested applying code-breaking techniques to the challenge of translating a foreign language. He is Norbert Wiener, not Weiner.
STEIN--Fred. With sincerest sympathy to all his family, Paul, Stuart and David mourn the loss of their great friend, mentor, a giant of a man, bigger than life, Fred Stein. He will be sorely missed.

An article on Saturday about Verizon's quarterly earnings misidentified the company executive who predicted a robust fourth quarter. It was Francis J. Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Amazon.com's quarterly earnings misstated the middle initial for the company's chief executive. He is Jeffrey P. Bezos, not Jeffrey A.

A SALVAGED shipping container may seem an unpromising showcase for cutting-edge style. But not to Hekima Hapa (bottom left), who set up shop in one of the rectangular spaces scattered throughout the Dekalb Market in Brooklyn on Saturday. She deftly exploited her cramped quarters as an intimate backdrop for her African-themed, Brooklyn-sewn designs. Ms. Hapa and her retail partner, Alicia Piller (top left), a jewelry designer, were participating in the Afrika21 Mixtape Project, part of the market conceived as a platform for emerging African artists of every stripe.

GOLDSTEIN--Judy Ann. The employees of The Equity Group Inc. are deeply saddened because a wonderful life, that of Judy Ann Goldstein, the wife of Robert Goldstein, our firm's founder, has come to a premature end. Judy exuded kindness and warmth as well as style and taste. She was the go-to gal when advice and wisdom were needed and she was an extraordinary hostess who made guests feel at ease and very special. Many of us at The Equity Group knew of Judy's thoughtfulness and goodness first hand and over decades. Our hearts are with Bob, Loren, Ada, Alex, Arielle, Mackenzie and all of Judy's family and friends.

STEIN--Fred, 84, died October 24, beloved father, grandfather, uncle, and friend. Fred was known for his passion for investing, love and generosity toward his friends and family, and larger than life personality. After seven years in the Merchant Marines, Fred began his career writing price quotes by hand on the chalkboards of the Stock Exchange. He retired as one of the great money managers. Although he amassed considerable wealth along the way, his greatest gift was for making close friends. At his 80th birthday, a friend said: "If anyone who knows Fred were in trouble and could make just one call for help, he would call Fred." Another friend said: "The day was always better if one got to spend a part of it with Fred." He is survived by his four children and daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by all. Funeral services were held at the 92nd Street Y. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the UJA in Fred's honor would be greatly appreciated.

ZACHS--Louise Wildred Silverman, 108, of West Hartford, CT, died October 25, 2011. Widow of William Zachs. Mother of Henry M. Zachs of Farmington, CT; mother-in-law of Judith Zachs; grandmother of Eric Zachs (Jessica) of West Hartford, CT, William Zachs (Martin Adam) of Edinburgh, Scotland; and four great- grandchildren. Funeral October 27, 2011 at 11:30am, Beth El Temple, West Hartford, Connecticut.

BRUCKMAN--Margaret, on October 25, 2011. Beloved mother to Josette and Barry Baime; grandmother to Daniel and Stacey Baime, Lauren and Alexander Crane; great-grandmother to Sophie, Samuel, and Jackson.

AT Carine Roitfeld's bal des vampires in Paris this month for her book, ''Irreverent,'' the hostess and guests like the model Anja Rubik, above, in a gothic lace-up velvet number, showed that high-fashion vamp calls for skillfully smudged eyes. ''Start by lining inside and underneath the lash line, then the entire lid with black pencil,'' the makeup artist Kristin Hilton advises. Next, she suggests adding shadow to the lid with a MAC 224 blending brush, and under the eye with a 219 pencil brush, building and brushing away excess. ''The vampire look needs to be shaded, not raccoonlike,'' Ms. Hilton said.

GOLDSTEIN--Judy. It's not supposed to happen but when it does, it's tragic that a wonderful friend, wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandparent, and daughter passes away in her early sixties.....leaving behind all whom she loved and cared about and who loved her as much! Sixty wonderful years with all of us and then a diagnosis of a serious cancer......and yet, Judy continued to love her family and friends and live life to the fullest without a complaint......and continued to ask all "how are you?".......because Judy cared about us even as she battled a deadly disease. The news of Judy's death on Monday stopped all of us in our tracks and we cried because we knew that we lost "the real deal!" We share the deepest sorrow with Bob G and the family and with Judy G's many dear friends. With the deepest sadness, Ronnie Rothstein, Mara Urshel, and Wayne Rogers

POP-UPS The PATRIK ERVELL pop-up at Boffo Building Fashion at 57 Walker Street looks more like a construction site than a high-end shop. This is the third Boffo project, a continuing collaboration of artists and designers. Amid crumbling walls and clothing displays made from rubble, the temporary shop, designed by the British architect Graham Hudson, is stocked with men's items like waxed cotton bomber jackets, $640, and embroidered sweaters, $340. Open until next Wednesday, it also has women's flower-print jeans, $430, and tuxedo blazers with hand-painted silk lapels, $1,450. Information: boffo-ny.org. ... If you look at our cover this week and think maybe you have enough worries in your life without adding anthrax back to the list, I completely understand. I feel that way myself sometimes. But I urge you to at least read the first section of Wil Hylton's story about the state of bioterrorism preparedness - it's only 400 words - and I'll be surprised if you don't feel compelled to keep going. Yes, you'll be a little freaked. Maybe a lot freaked. But Wil's reporting isn't just about the nightmarish scenarios that could befall us. It's about what exactly the U.S. government has been up to since the anthrax attacks in the wake of 9/11, and the shocking extent to which we have wasted precious time and billions of dollars on poorly defined policy objectives and bureaucratic logjams. This is not merely bad news. This an exposé that ought to inspire a rethinking of the entire program.

Corn season is waning, so if you can't find decent ears of corn to make the Colombian chicken, short rib, and potato stew featured in "A Good Appetite," feel free to substitute frozen corn. I've seen it sold on the cob in large supermarkets, and that is ideal here. But if you can find only kernels, just use about a cup of them in place of the cobs, stirring them in during the last few minutes of cooking. Also something to note: The corn used in Colombia, I've read, has larger kernels and is less sweet than what we typically get. But the sweet corn tastes wonderful, authenticity aside.

What would we do without citrus fruits? Our cooking would be dull without them. But unless we live in temperate climates, for the most part we depend on their availability to be shipped from citrus-growing zones. So much for locavore leanings: sometimes we just need stuff from elsewhere. We need to be able to add a big squeeze of lime, or the grated zest of lemon or orange, to so many dishes, sweet or savory.

43 Magazine, a new, independent bimonthly skateboard title was introduced on Thursday night at the Recess gallery in SoHo. Founded by Allen Ying, a longtime skate enthusiast and photographer, the magazine fixes to recapture some of the energy of the skate mags that Ying used to feverishly consume growing up in White Plains. "Nothing I've seen recently is as inspirational as what I used to read," Ying said, citing late-'90s monthlies like Transworld Skateboarding. "I wanted to create that."

Is any form of traditional media under more assault than the book? For half a millennium, it was happily contained between covers: easily understood by a child, disposable, nearly indestructible, demanding minimal energy, a triumph of economy and form. The Internet has upended all that, of course. Yet the strongest impression from several of the sessions at the Books in Browsers conference in San Francisco over the last two days is that while the off-line book might be dying, the online book has yet to be born.

Our paperback list has the perfect book for this trick-or-treating season. "Batman: The Long Halloween," at No. 9, is a new edition of one of Batman's greatest adventures, with extra pages previously available only in a hardcover version. The story, written by Jeph Loeb and illustrated by Tim Sale, is set in the early days of Batman's career. Gotham City is overrun with mobsters, and the colorful freaks that make up the hero's rogues gallery are just starting to emerge. The mystery, originally told over 13 issues, centers around a murderer named Holiday, who strikes on a special day each month - whether it's Christmas, Mother's Day or Independence Day. He does not get a lot of panel time, but one of the creepiest moments comes from Calendar Man, who is housed in Arkham Asylum and does not enjoy the fact that another villain is stealing his motif of date-based crimes.

An interesting commentary published in Nature this week explores what it would take to achieve California's ambitious plan to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. It is worth exploring here because it holds lessons that apply far beyond that state.

It will have a small takeout counter in the front, seats at the bar (a full bar this time), and tables for 30 in back.

Thursday night was the Fashion Group's annual party, at Cipriani Wall Street, a journey of 1,000 miles (it seemed). It isn't every day that Tel Aviv gets a piece of architecture worth writing home about. In fact, one of the easiest arguments to win in the Middle East might be that Tel Aviv's urban core has not sprouted a truly remarkable structure in the more than half a century since the Bauhaus inkwell - which left its curvilinear imprint on hundreds of buildings in "The White City" - began to dry up. But with the completion of the Herta and Paul Amir Building at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, opening on Wednesday, things are set to get noticeably whiter and brighter. The new wing, designed by the Cambridge, Mass.-based architect Preston Scott Cohen (who is also chairman of the architecture department at Harvard University), looks a bit like an elongated Rubik's Cube doused with bleach. The gleaming white parabolas of the facade are composed of 465 flat, interlocking, precast concrete panels of different shapes and sizes. The building's three floors are linked to two more below grade by an 87-foot-high, top-lit atrium, a "lightfall" that will shine on the world's largest collection of Israeli art. The building's confident yet supple geometries provide a nifty counterpoint to the museum's main building, a 1971 Brutalist number by the Israeli architect Dan Eytan (who also designed Israel's decidedly unfussy Dimona nuclear reactor). Next to that chunky monkey, Cohen's creation is pure pizazz. Fittingly, in honor of the building's inauguration later this month, the city of Tel Aviv has declared 2012 to be Art Year, culminating in a four-day blowout Art Weekend March 21-24.

Beginning with the 2012 Breeders' Cup, 2-year-olds will not be administered medication hours before they race for the first time in decades. The regulators of racing have seen the light from the horse and rider perspective. Extensive studies clearly indicate that drugs cause more trouble for racehorses and their riders than they alleviate. Lasix jurisdictions have significantly more breakdowns than jurisdictions where Lasix is not allowed. No prerace Lasix means no attending veterinarians with loaded syringes in the stall injecting the horses with drugs hours before they run. The dangerous and dubious charade of medicating racehorses before they compete is coming to a welcome end.

An article on Monday about some competitive New York City high schools that are working to address student stress by assigning less homework misidentified, in some editions, a high school that is offering homework holidays and misstated that school's relationship with Hunter College. It is Hunter College High School, not Manhattan Hunter Science High School. And it is administered by Hunter College; it is not a ''public-school partnership with Hunter College.''

The musician Lance Bass is aiming a new play, ''The Fabulous Lies of Hollywood Whores,'' for Broadway in spring 2012, with the television celebrity Kirstie Alley in negotiations to play a demanding diva who uses a Los Angeles department store as cover for her high-end escort service, an executive involved with the production said on Wednesday. Mr. Bass and fellow producers Jamie Kennedy, Beverley Mitchell and Matt Seifnia have scheduled Actors' Equity auditions in late November for the play, and are looking to start rehearsals in February in advance of a spring opening. Written by Dean-Anthony Joseph Delgado Bradford, the eight-character ensemble production is described in an audition notice as a ''cold, hard, broad'' and ''dirty'' comedy about ''the pimp'' (Ms. Alley's character) and her coterie of assistants, escorts, and others.

An article on the Itineraries page on Tuesday about a growing trend in the funeral industry to transport bodies for burial misstated part of the name of a funeral business whose chief executive, Neil O'Connor, commented on the trend, and misidentified the city in which it is based. It is the O'Connor Mortuary, not O'Connor Funeral Home, and it is based in Laguna Hills, Calif., not in nearby Laguna Beach.

CARPENTER--Ruth C. The Brearley School community deeply mourns the passing of Ruth C. Carpenter, a master teacher at the School who was a member of the English Department from 1960 to 2000 and its Head from 1965 to 1978 and from 1982 to 1988. Ruth was a brilliant teacher who passed onto generations of Brearley girls her passion for English literature. Her extraordinary ability, unaided by notes, to weave great swaths of Donne, Shakespeare and Milton into her lectures convinced students of the beauty of language and the glamour of literature. Many went into the world thinking of Donne or Hamlet as an elegantly dressed, animated woman with a slightly southern accent, as was Ruth. As a colleague and mentor to younger members of the department, Ruth was always interested, kind and generous. Her great gifts live on in both how and what we teach in the English Department. Brearley joins in sending sincere condolences to Ruth's many loving friends.

Throughout a creative career whose highlights included organizing the seminal punk-rock band Sex Pistols, and which ended with his being buried in a coffin that read, ''Too Fast to Live, Too Young to Die,'' Malcolm McLaren was not necessarily concerned with how future generations - or current ones, for that matter - might regard him. But now the name of Mr. McLaren, the artist, provocateur and sloganeer who died last year, will belong to the ages, or at least to Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial, whose organizers announced on Thursday that they would present its first-ever Malcolm Award at its grand finale on Nov. 21.

The Sports of The Times column on Oct. 10, about the Jets' cutting into the Giants' dominance in the New York market, referred incorrectly to the Giants' competition in the New York market before the Titans, who later became the Jets, arrived in 1960. While the Giants were the most successful professional football team in New York after Tim Mara bought the franchise in 1925, they were not the exclusive professional football team of the area. Before the Titans in 1960, there were several short-lived teams in the National Football League and the All-America Football Conference. (Included among the several teams were the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees.)

An article on Oct. 17 about the restoration of the Civil War painting ''Return of the 69th (Irish) Regiment, N.Y.S.M. From the Seat of War,'' which will be on display at the New-York Historical Society, referred incorrectly at one point to the unit depicted in the painting. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it is the 69th (Irish) Regiment, which was returning from the First Battle of Bull Run -- not the ''Irish brigade.''

ROME -- The European Union pledged 105 million euros (about $148 million) Wednesday toward the safeguarding of Pompeii, one of the world's largest and most fragile open-air archaeological sites. The money will finance a four-year project aiming to preserve and monitor the site, which is vulnerable both to the elements and to the wear-and-tear caused by some 2.5 million annual visitors. Heavy rains last week led to the collapse of a support wall, setting off widespread alarm even though the eight-meter section that fell had been built in the last century. Critics have repeatedly blamed the Italian government for not doing enough to protect the ancient town, which was buried by Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D.

Two independent investment banks, Lazard and Evercore Partners, appear to be weathering the slowdown in deal-making, even as the financial markets remain volatile. Lazard reported Thursday that revenue from its mergers and acquisitions advisory business rose 24 percent in the third quarter, to $199.1 million. And Evercore reported that its investment banking revenue rose 38 percent in the quarter, to $138.4 million.

LOS ANGELES - The Walt Disney Company on Thursday said it had completed a deal to introduce a nationally broadcast version of the Disney Channel in Russia, one of the world's last big untapped entertainment markets. Disney, which has aggressively tried to crack Russia for years with only modest success, said it would acquire 49 percent of Seven TV, a broadcast channel that reaches about 40 million households, or more than 75 percent of Russia's measured television audience. Seven TV will remain majority owned by UTH Russia, a fast-growing media company.

Among the close-knit fraternity of defense lawyers, federal judges and government prosecutors in white-collar law, Gary P. Naftalis is an elder statesman. In his more than 40-year career, Mr. Naftalis has been called on to defend embattled chieftains, troubled multibillion-dollar banks and even the former owner of the New York disco Studio 54. He is now representing Rajat K. Gupta, the former director of Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble who is accused of leaking company secrets to a billionaire hedge fund manager.

A group of art forgers who sold falsely attributed oil paintings to art collectors, and whose victims included the comedian Steve Martin, were sentenced on Thursday by a court in Cologne, Germany, Bloomberg News reported. Wolfgang Beltracchi, the leader of the ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Leger and Max Ernst, was given a six-year sentence; his wife, Helene, was sentenced to four years while her sister, Jeanette, received a 21-month suspended sentence. Otto Schulte-Kellinghaus, a fourth member of the ring, was sentenced to five years. In 2004 the Cazeau-Beraudiere gallery in Paris sold Mr. Martin a painting called ''Landschaft mit Pferden'' or ''Landscape With Horses'' and attributed to Campendonk, for 700,000 euros (about $850,000 then) after it was authenticated by an expert. Mr. Martin sold the work at a loss in a 2006 Christie's auction, where it was purchased for 500,000 euros by a Swiss businesswoman.

GOLDSTEIN--Judy Ann. The employees of The Equity Group Inc. are deeply saddened because a wonderful life, that of Judy Ann Goldstein, the wife of Robert Goldstein, our firm's founder, has come to a premature end. Judy exuded kindness and warmth as well as style and taste. She was the go-to gal when advice and wisdom were needed and she was an extraordinary hostess who made guests feel at ease and very special. Many of us at The Equity Group knew of Judy's thoughtfulness and goodness first hand and over decades. Our hearts are with Bob, Loren, Ada, Alex, Arielle, Mackenzie and all of Judy's family and friends.

ALLON--Agnes, on October 26th, 2011. Passed away peacefully, surrounded by her family. She was truly a saint to the many who knew and loved her. She came to New York in 1956, with her beloved husband Victor, after the Holocaust took most of their families, and began anew on the Upper West Side, where she raised two sons, Richard and Tom, and was a fashion boutique owner with her dear sister, Eva. She was the embodiment of class, elegance and warm-heartedness and she lit up every room she entered. One of her greatest joys was hosting holiday meals for her extended family. She did this with her Hungarian culinary grace and her kitchen was her castle. She also tended to her many fashion customers with her wit and style so that they not only looked stylish but also got her dose of life wisdom while they were being fitted. Her family was her truest pride and joy, and she has enriched all our lives: sons Richard and Tom, daughters-in-law Hope and Janet, and her three beloved grandchildren: Jonah, Tess and Lena. To see them grow up within four blocks of her apartment was like Moses' glimpse of the promised land: all that she and Victor struggled thru after WWII will live on thru her whole family and her passion for life and for family and for deep friendships has inspired all of us to continue in her shining example. She knew how to have fun, tell a great dirty joke and loved to swim each day at the Y, her elixir for 85 years. A celebration of her life and love will take place Friday, October 28th at 11am at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam and the family will sit shiva in her home.

Representative Connie Mack, Republican of Florida and the son of a former Florida senator, has decided to challenge Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, in the 2012 race. This comes as a direct reversal from a surprise announcement in March, when Mr. Mack decided not to enter the crowded Republican field, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family. The field has since thinned.

A film review on Thursday about the Bollywood movie ''Ra.One'' used an outdated name for the main railroad station in Mumbai, India, in describing a scene. It is the Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus; it is no longer called Victoria Terminus.

World financial markets powered higher on Thursday in the giddy hope that Europe's plan to solve its sovereign debt crisis would finally lift the uncertainty over the global economy and markets. In the United States, a sharp jump in stocks continued what has become the biggest monthly rally in 47 years. But even as stock markets from Paris to New York joined in the euphoria, some bond and credit market rates barely flinched, especially in Italy. That suggests doubts that the agreement will be a long-term solution for Europe's mountainous debt problem or the pressing challenge of restoring growth to the Continent's moribund economies.

FUNK--Howard L.,81, died October 25, 2011, beloved husband of Elisabeth (Paling), father of Helene (the late Bruce Braverman) and Rhoda Fry (William), brother of Barbara Lindeman (Philip), and grandfather of Derek Willem Braverman and Justin William Fry. A graduate of Washington University with a BS in Electrical Engineering, Howard had a 40-year career with IBM in the US and abroad, which brought him numerous awards and citations from professional societies and the corporation, including an outstanding contribution award for his proposal to open IBM's access to the Internet, implemented in 1990. Upon his retirement from IBM at Armonk in 1993, Howard opened H. L. Funk Consulting, a technical consulting business serving a wide variety of clients, including the Town of Lewisboro, whose web site earned the citation of best in state in 2005. Services will be held at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, on Sunday, October 30, 2011, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the New Netherland Institute, P.O. Box 2536, ESP Station, Albany, NY, 12220-0536. Those who knew Howard will know the depth of our loss.

8 P.M. (NBC) CHUCK Season 5 finds Chuck (Zachary Levi, above right, with Adam Baldwin and Yvonne Strahovski) adjusting to life as a spy for hire. Now Chuck and his team -- Col. John Casey (Mr. Baldwin); Chuck's best friend, Morgan Grimes (Joshua Gomez); and Sarah Walker (Ms. Strahovski), once the C.I.A.'s top agent and now Chuck's wife -- are operating as a private security company under the cover of the Buy More electronics store. But life has suddenly become more dangerous, as the group takes on a wealthy thief (Mark Hamill) and a conniving investor (Craig Kilborn), who have stolen money from some of the world's worst bad guys. In ''Grimm,'' a new drama inspired by Grimm's fairy tales, at 9, Nick Burckhardt (David Giuntoli), an Oregon homicide detective, discovers he has descended from a line of hunters charged with keeping a balance between the human race and the mythological creatures that few -- among them, his fiancée, Juliette Silverton (Bitsie Tulloch), and his partner, Hank Griffin (Russell Hornsby) -- know exist. Kate Burton guest stars in this series premiere as Nick's fearsome aunt. NOON (Hallmark) MARTHA & FRIENDS In ''Halloween Horror Show,'' Little Martha (Martha Stewart, imagined as an animated 10-year-old) and her friends Lily and Hannah dress up as ''Glampires,'' inspiring Kevin to make his only monster movie. The episode also features do-it-yourself projects.

On Tuesday, after eight years of renovation, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open its new Islamic wing -- the Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia. Below, a tour of some of the collection's highlights. The Damascus Room The room, a nearly intact 18th-centuryreception chamber from a wealthy Syrian residence, has been reassembled at the Met. The walls are inscribed with a sequence of verses inspired by the 13th-century Egyptian poet al-Busiri.

One comedian derided the group of Occupy Wall Street protesters in the front row as Ivy League nerds. Another ridiculed the ''mic-check'' format of public speaking favored by protesters since they have been prohibited from using bullhorns. Even their nonviolent protest methods came under fire. ''You need a little knife in the gut once in a while,'' joked the comedian Danny Vitale, during a comedy night held for the protesters at the Yippie Museum Cafe on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village on Wednesday night.

Rapid Redux will never make it to the Breeders' Cup, but Thursday afternoon he has the opportunity to join one of its greatest performers in the record book: The 5-year-old gelding is trying to win his 19th consecutive race to tie the North American record held by the 2010 Horse of the Year Zenyatta and Peppers Pride.

DAITCH--Herbert B.,97, passed away peacefully at his home in Rye Brook, NY on October 24th 2011. Beloved husband of the late Hilda F. Daitch for 75 years. Stalwart and loving husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and father-in-law to Hilda, Sandra, Larry, Susan, Jimmy, Meinar and Murray. A giant of the food industry, he was, at various times, President, Vice-Chairman, Chairman and CEO of Daitch Crystal Dairies, Daitch Supermarkets, Daitch-Shopwell Supermarkets and Food Emporium Supermarkets. The Company, which had stores throughout the Metropolitan New York area, was founded in 1919 by his father Louis Daitch. It was sold in 1986 to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Herbert Daitch, who was listed in Who's Who, was an early member of the Young Presidents Organization and the World Presidents Organization. He was a founding member of the Free Synagogue of Westchester and supported numerous charitable organizations both personally and through The Hilda and Herbert Daitch Foundation. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, Friday October 28, 2011 at 12 noon. Federal authorities are intensifying an investigation into the large fees that the Japanese company Olympus paid to an obscure American brokerage firm. The Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulators have now begun their own inquiries into the $687 million payout, according to people briefed on the inquiries. The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened the case only two weeks ago, but the inquiry has now grown to touch nearly every corner of the federal law enforcement arsenal. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have jumped on the case, while the S.E.C. has begun an examination of the now-defunct brokerage firm, Axes America.

LONDON -- He has turned his hand to ''Swan Lake,'' ''The Nutcracker,'' ''La Sylphide'' and ''Cinderella,'' but Matthew Bourne isn't done yet rethinking the ballet classics. At a news conference at Sadler's Wells on Wednesday, he announced that he would create a new ''Sleeping Beauty'' for Christmas 2012 as part of a yearlong celebration of the 25th anniversary of his company, New Adventures. Shocking die-hard ballet fans, he declared, ''I don't really buy the idea of love at first sight,'' and talked about some of his ideas for the ballet. ''Nothing much happens from a plot point of view after Aurora goes to sleep,'' he said. ''I think I've fixed that.'' Pointing out that in most productions of ''Sleeping Beauty,'' the 100-year gap is barely noticeable from a costume point of view, he plans to set the opening scene of Aurora's christening in 1890 (the year of the work's premiere at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg). ''I have taken this as a starting point, setting the Christening of Aurora in the year of the ballet's first performance; the height of the fin-de-siecle period when fairies, vampires and decadent opulence fed the Gothic imagination,'' he writes in the news release. For the awakening, we'll be in 2011, he said. ''Possibly the wedding will take place in 2012,'' he added, ''just to be completely up to date.'' Before ''Sleeping Beauty,'' Sadler's Wells will present three of Mr. Bourne's early works on a mixed bill in May, and his much-acclaimed ''Play Without Words.''

SCHMIDT--Michal W. January 8, 1957 October 22, 2011. Founder and President of Schmidt Artists International, Inc., Michal Schmidt died at New York Presbyterian Hospital of complications from breast cancer and rheumatoid arthritis. Born and raised in Tel Aviv, she showed an early aptitude and passion for classical music, and after completing her service in the Israeli army, she subsequently attended Tel Aviv University and graduated from New York University. In order to combine her deep love of music and exceptional interpersonal skills, she accepted a position with the classical artist management firm of Thea Dispeker, and was soon promoted to director of the Instrumentalists and Conductors Division. In 1993, she established Schmidt Artists International, which has since developed into one of the finest privately owned artist managements in the country. She is survived by her loving partner, Lee Ellen Hveem; her closest friend and business partner, Patricia Handy; her brother Ze'ev Schmidt and her cousin Laura Schor, as well as countless friends and colleagues whose lives have been touched by her vitality and generous spirit. Burial will take place in Tel Aviv; a memorial service will be celebrated for her in the near future in New York.

NEW DELHI - Sebastian Vettel continued his domination of qualifying sessions this year by scoring his 13th pole position of the season at the inaugural Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi on Saturday. Vettel joins Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna in the record books with the second largest number of pole positions in a season. Nigel Mansell holds the record of 14 pole positions, which he achieved in 1992 at Williams. With two races left in the season, Vettel has a chance to beat the record.

Mr. Lehman, who is suffering from a lingering virus, was himself a replacement for Ben Heppner, who early this year said he had decided not to sing the role. The Barrow Journal article on Oct. 17, about the fall subsistence whale hunt in Barrow, Alaska, misstated a greeting exchanged between the captain of a crew that killed a whale and a crowd onshore. They shouted ''aarigaa'' at each other -- an Inupiaq word meaning ''very good.'' The captain did not shout, and the crowd did not respond, ''Ah ah ha!''

Updated, 3:03 p.m. | Firefighters went into Zuccotti Park early Friday morning and removed six generators and 13 cans of gasoline, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on his weekly radio program. Protesters handed the materials over voluntarily, and there were no arrests. The mayor said that 30 or 40 firefighters went through the park and that there was a substantial police presence on hand as well. But the mayor, who said he had not been there but had spoken with both the fire and police commissioners, praised the protesters for being calm and cooperative.

NO. 11 OKLAHOMA AT NO. 10 KANSAS STATE 3:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Although it received no votes in the preseason top 25, Kansas State has emerged as a national title contender. Facing Oklahoma on Saturday, and Oklahoma State, Texas A&M and Texas in the next three weeks, the Wildcats will have a chance to make a statement. They will meet an Oklahoma team that ought to be extra ornery after being upset at home by Texas Tech. The Wildcats have been winning with great defense and special teams and a bruising running game that controls the clock. They have beaten Miami and Texas Tech on the road and handed Baylor its first loss of the season. Still, the speed of Oklahoma receivers Ryan Broyles, right, and Kenny Stills on the outside may pose problems. Despite its 7-0 record, Kansas State is a hefty underdog at home.

Some big retirement plans offer investors the chance to hire an independent adviser that can help them choose their investments. But your plan provider will soon be able to offer the advice itself, as long as it meets rules issued recently by the Department of Labor. Before the new regulations, which are effective Dec. 27, 401(k), individual retirement plan providers were required to hire an independent adviser to provide advice. That's because the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, the law known as Erisa that governs retirement plans, prohibited advisers from recommending investments if they were paid for other services like administering the plans in the first place. This was to avoid conflicts of interest where the administrator would put its own mutual funds on the menu and push them on participants.

An article on Friday about a market rally after disclosure of Europe's plan to solve its sovereign debt crisis misstated the number of years since the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had had a monthly rally like October's. It was the biggest rally since 1974, or 37 years -- not 47 years.

Administrators met with parents and teachers at Long Island City High School on Friday to try to address anger and frustrations over a snafu that left many students with entirely new schedules, two months into the school year. Both students and teachers are starting fresh in many classes, as school officials reshuffled schedules to balance class sizes, address gaps in teaching staff and provide crucial classes that students need to graduate.
NUSSBAUM--Dr. Jacob, 97, October 14, in Seattle. Loved by wife Sylvia, sons, granddaughters, family, friends.

A federal judge has given final approval to a $1.25 billion settlement by the Agriculture Department for African-American farmers' longstanding claims of racial discrimination. The decision on Thursday by the judge, Paul L. Friedman, was expected and gives about 40,000 plaintiffs a second chance to have their complaints heard by a court-appointed neutral party. The farmers say that between 1981 and 1997, the Agriculture Department ignored their complaints about local officials who unfairly denied them farm loans and other aid. The settlement is an outgrowth of the Pigford case, named after a North Carolina farmer. Congress included $100 million for the claims in the 2008 farm bill and approved $1.15 billion in November.

In its most simplistic form, financial planning is the process of charting a course from where you are today to where you want to go. The first step is to become crystal clear about what I call your current reality, or where you stand now.

Updated, 3:32 p.m. | Two weeks into Occupy Wall Street's takeover of Zuccotti Park, a group of Bronx community organizers and friends rode the subway down to Lower Manhattan to check out a movement they supported in principle. When they got there, they recalled, they found what they had suspected: a largely white and middle-class crowd that claimed to represent ''the 99 percent'' but bore little resemblance to most of the people in the group's own community. That community, the South Bronx, is one of the poorest areas of the country and home almost exclusively to blacks and Hispanics.

It appears that investors are flocking to Groupon's forthcoming initial public offering like customers to one of the daily deal giant's coupons. That would value the online coupon pioneer at potentially more than $12 billion. The company's executives and bankers, led by Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse, have completed the first week of a multistate road show.
