COCKERILL--Dr. Claudia S.,accomplished clinical and school psychologist on Long Island, passed away on October 25, 2011. She graduated St. Joseph's College, Emmitsburg, MD, and obtained her PhD from St. John's University, Queens, NY. Claudia was a devoted patron of the opera and ballet, enjoyed antique shopping and long walks, and was a loyal New York Mets fan. She was very dedicated to her profession and to helping people live more satisfying lives. She is survived by her beloved family, Christine Brenner (daughter), Cohn Brenner (grandson), Alberta Toth (sister) and Rebecca Toth (niece). A wake will be held Sunday, October 30th from 2-4 and 7-9pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home Inc., 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station, NY; funeral mass: October 31st, 9:45am at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington, NY with burial immediately following at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Brentwood Union Free School District in Memory of Dr. Claudia S. Cockerill.

At a time when many museums in the United States and Europe have made cuts in the face of weakened endowments and dwindling public subsidies, the Prado in Madrid announced Thursday that it planned to increase its hours to remain open seven days a week. The museum will join several others in Europe and a few in the United States like the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, in staying open every day. (The Prado, which has a general entry fee of 10 euros (about $14), will remain open even on Good Friday, when it has traditionally been closed; it will be closed only three days a year, Jan. 1, May 1 and Dec. 25.) Prado officials said the decision was part of a plan to make more money from entry fees, with a goal of eventually generating 60 percent of its operating budget through such fees and other income to help offset reductions in government support as European economies sputter.

An article on Thursday about a power struggle over the future of the Iranian presidency misstated, in some copies, the accusations that opponents of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad have leveled against two of his close associates, including his chief of staff, Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei. The two associates have been accused of being linked to the lead suspect in a bank embezzlement scheme; they have not been accused of being the lead suspects themselves.

At a news conference on Friday in New Zealand Peter Jackson, the director of the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy and a coming two-part film adaptation of ''The Hobbit,'' said he was working with one of the recently released Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three to help get him exonerated of the crimes for which the three spent nearly 20 years in prison. Speaking from the ''Hobbit'' set in Waikato and accompanied by the New Zealand prime minister, John Key, Mr. Jackson said he had received an exemption from New Zealand law that would allow a visit by Damien Echols, one of the West Memphis Three convicts, The Associated Press reported.

8 P.M. (HBO) LOVE & OTHER DRUGS (2010) The year is 1996, and Jamie Randall (Jake Gyllenhaal), the underachieving son of a prominent Chicago doctor, has decided to sell pharmaceuticals. Flash forward to 1998, when Jamie's employer, Pfizer, begins marketing Viagra. And voilà! Jamie is on his way to fortune and a certain fame among his zealous clients. But somewhere in the midst of this sexual playground, he ogles the breasts of (and subsequently meets) Maggie (Anne Hathaway, above with Mr. Gyllenhaal), a free-wheeling, slightly cynical, commitment-shy artist with early-onset Parkinson's disease -- an illness Jamie and his arsenal of pills can't ward off. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film from Edward Zwick ''a sometimes intoxicating, sometimes headache-inducing cocktail: a sweet, libidinous love story; a candid comedy of bedroom and workplace manners; and, most bravely, if also most jarringly, a medical melodrama involving a chronic and very serious disease.'' Ms. Hathaway and Mr. Gyllenhaal ''are frequently delightful to watch, and their ease together is a rebuke to the self-conscious, emotionally cautious protocols of modern movie romance,'' he added. ''But there is an asymmetry in the way the characters are conceived that undermines the film's credibility.'' 10:30 A.M. Mitt Romney likes rules. The former governor of Massachusetts likes following the rules, explaining the rules and pointing out to others when they, heaven forbid, break the rules. At the most recent Republican debate in Las Vegas, Mr. Romney inadvertently cast himself as the Enforcer when he tried mightily to ensure that every candidate received their allotted response time. ''Rick, I'm speaking, I'm speaking, I'm speaking, I'm speaking. You get 30 seconds. The way the rules work here is that I get 60 seconds, and then you get 30 seconds to respond, right?'' Mr. Romney said, all while Gov. Rick Perry of Texas interrupted and talked over him.

Charlie Sheen will return to television next summer in an adaptation of the 2003 movie ''Anger Management,'' the FX cable channel announced Thursday. Adding to the interest was that the studio developing the comedy show, Revolution, hired the veteran comedy producer Bruce Helford (''The Drew Carey Show'') to run it.

Mark Lugo, the Hoboken, N.J., man who was charged this summer with stealing a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco art gallery - and whose lawyer said at the time that he planned to plead not guilty - has now pleaded guilty to grand theft, the BBC reported. Mr. Lugo was arrested at a hotel in Napa, Calif., shortly after the daytime theft at the Weinstein Gallery, and the drawing, ''Tete de Femme (Head of a Woman)'' from 1965, valued at $275,000, was found with him. A subsequent search of his apartment in Hoboken turned up other works stolen in Manhattan, including a photograph by Jean-Michel Basquiat from the Skot Foreman gallery, a Fernand Leger sketch from the Carlyle Hotel and another Picasso sketch, from the William Bennett Gallery.

Facing pressure to explain apparent irregularities with his campaign fund-raising practices, John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said Friday that he had hired a former state attorney general to review his books. Mr. Liu, whose elected office makes him the city's top fiscal watchdog, has been struggling to answer questions about his fund-raising in the wake of a report two weeks ago in The New York Times that found instances in which individuals listed as campaign donors said that they had never given money to Mr. Liu, or that money had been given in their names by an employer or other Liu supporter. In some cases, people named as donors could not be located, or were listed as employees of companies they did not work for.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Happy Halloween, everybody! Have you all purchased your candy to dole out to trick-or-treaters? Anyone dressing up in costume for the holiday? It would be hard to overstate the level of preposterousness that surrounds Jon Gnarr, the punk rocker-turned-comedic actor-turned mayor of Reykjavik, Iceland. DreamWorks Animation's "Puss in Boots," a spin-off of that studio's "Shrek" franchise, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $34 million. An unusually heavy autumn snowstorm in the Northeast may have kept some potential ticket buyers at home: Hollywood had been expecting a total closer to $40 million. But "Puss in Boots," which cost about $130 million to make and was distributed by Paramount Pictures, received strong critical reviews and an A-minus from audiences in exit polls, opening up the possibility of solid sales in weekends ahead.

The exhibition "Filippino Lippi and Sandro Botticelli in Florence in the 1400s," showing at the Scuderie del Quirinale (Via XXIV Maggio 16; english.scuderiequirinale.it) through Jan. 15, follows the lives and works of those two painters, with particular emphasis on Lippi's career, style and innovations. More than 40 of his works are juxtaposed with those of other masters, mainly Botticelli, whose supporting role in the exhibition serves to illuminate the character of the junior master.

Italy has much to entice the intrepid oenophile. Tuscany and the Piedmont tend to rule the roost when it comes to wine, but it is the German- and Italian-speaking region of Alto Adige that hosts one of Europe's most prestigious wine events: the Merano Wine Festival (meranowinefestival.com), which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year, Nov. 4 to 7. Founded in 1992 by Herman Köcher, the festival owes its allure -- beyond the craggy peaks of the Dolomites -- to its ability to elegantly combine wine with gastronomy. In partnership with the Gourmet Club of South Tyrol (also founded by Mr. Köcher), the festival will commemorate its anniversary with the Union des Grands Crus de Bordeaux's guest exhibition of 32 historic chateaux crus, a presentation on South Africa's evolving viticulture, and a tasting of participating vintners' oldest vintages held on the last day, all paired with the South Tyrol club's ''masters of flavor'' event featuring more than 100 artisanal products.

An article last Sunday about unmarked and unnoticed landmarks in baseball history misidentified the street on which a sign marking the site of Griffith Stadium was erected this month in Washington. It is on Georgia Avenue NW, not on Seventh Street NW. The article also misstated the surname of a past executive president of the Society for American Baseball Research, who traveled to the University of Southern California campus to find the position of home plate at Bovard Field, where on March 26, 1951, the rookie Mickey Mantle drove in seven runs. He is Morris Eckhouse, not Eckstein.

The ''Block by Block'' column on Oct. 16, about Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, described incorrectly Au Pied de Cochon in Montreal, the restaurant that Hugue Dufour worked in before opening M. Wells near Vernon Boulevard. It does not in fact have a Michelin star.

An article last Sunday about the discovery that the Russian abstractionist Wassily Kandinsky had painted a picture over one believed to have been done by his girlfriend, Gabriele Münter, misstated the year of Kandinsky's death. It was 1944, not 1924. (He was born in 1866.)

HILLMAN--James, 1926-2011, nominee for the Pulitzer prize for Revisioning Psychology, awarded the Presidents Medal of Honor, Florence, Italy, and radical founder of Archetypal Psychology, died at his home in Thompson, CT from complications of cancer. Dr. Hillman was 85 years old, alternately holding court with friends and colleagues and deep in exchange with his beloved wife, artist Margot McLean. Born in Atlantic City, Hillman resided in Europe for more than three decades. He is the author of more than twenty books translated into twenty five languages including a number one best seller, "The Soul's Code," and his opus, "A Terrible Love of War." A ten volume Uniform Edition of Hillman's uncollected published works is in progress, with six titles currently in print. James' stunning wit, generosity of mind and heart, brilliant conversation, and joy in the daily round will be terribly missed. He leaves behind a used pair of tap shoes, a yard full of exotic chickens, mornings in Thompson, nighttimes in New York, friends from all over the world, and most importantly his irrepressible collaborator in life and love, Margot. Predeceased by his first wife Catharina Kempe, remembered by his second wife Patricia Berry, Hillman is survived by his sisters Sue Becker and Sybil Pike, brother Joel, four children from his first marriage, Julia, Carola, Susanne, Laurence and five grandchildren. A Memorial Service in New York City will be announced at a later date. For those who wish, donations may be made to: Spring Publications, PO Box 230212 New York, NY 10023 in support of his Uniform Edition.
KAY--Stephanie Wilner. October 29, 1961. We miss you so much. We love you so much. XO Jody

The Practical Traveler column last Sunday, about safaris in Africa, misidentified one of the animals that make up the Big Five, which many visitors hope to see there. The Big Five consist of the elephant, rhinoceros, lion, leopard and the African, or Cape, buffalo -- not the water buffalo, which is not found in Africa. In addition, an accompanying illustration was published in error. It erroneously included a tiger, which is also not found in Africa.

To the Editor: In his essay Steven Johnson has fun (as he has in the past) with the prose style he developed in the semiotics program at Brown University. (He quotes from a paper he wrote ''at the age of 19'': ''The predicament of any tropological analysis of narrative always lies in its own effaced and circuitous recourse to a metaphoric mode of apprehending its object. . . . '') As a founder of the program, I remember Johnson, and he did write that way. But some semioticians wrote with clarity -- Tzvetan Todorov and Umberto Eco, for example -- and I rather think I did so myself. But students take what they want, or what they need at the time, and the good ones find ways to use or abuse what they learned -- or both.Robert Scholes

KINNAIRD--Dennis E.,one of California's leading trial lawyers, died at home in Los Angeles on Monday from complications of esophageal cancer. He was 75. He grew up in San Diego. After serving in the Army he graduated from San Diego State University in 1961, and received a J.D. from University of California, Boalt Hall, Order of the Coif in 1964. After a brief time at Keating & Sterling he joined the U.S. Attorneys' Office and became Head of Special Prosecutions where he was regarded as an honest and effective federal prosecutor, one of the first to prosecute economic crimes in Los Angeles. Dennis then distinguished himself at Munger, Tolles & Olson, as a partner who litigated high profile complex cases. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He retired in 2001. His colleagues and friends described him as fiercely loyal, wise, a gentleman, a true friend, and above all valued his quick wit that would fill your heart with laughter. More than his legal acknowledgments Dennis valued the love of his life, Connie McCreight. He is also survived by his sister Susan Gribble, brother Donald Kinnaird, nieces Stephanie Levy, Shelby Scott and Keli Emery; and nephew Tod Emery. Contributions in his honor can be made to the Samuel Oschin Comprehensive Cancer Institute at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, 8700 Beverly Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90048 or please visit: www.discoveringforlife.org/ Kinnaird

TAPOLCAI--Andras. Born February 8, 1965 in Budapest, Hungary. Died October 11, 2011 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved partner of Lynne Haney. Loving father to Tristan. A dedicated writer and teacher with a social conscience. Remembered with love. Rudy, Janice, Jessica Peritz.

Is ''Nothing Sacred'' the most heartless of great American comedies? It's got competition from the best of W. C. Fields and Robert Zemeckis's ''Used Cars,'' but its cheerfully wised-up sophistication is in a class of its own. Like Fields's work and Mr. Zemeckis's film, ''Nothing Sacred'' is about American suckerdom. The spiffy twist of Ben Hecht's screenplay (his uncredited collaborators are said to have included Moss Hart, George S. Kaufman, Ring Lardner Jr. and Budd Schulberg) is that the prize rubes dwell in the big city.
NUSSBAUM--Dr. Jacob, 97, October 14, in Seattle. Loved by wife Sylvia, sons, granddaughters, family, friends.

FLENDER--Richard. Richard Flender, a resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, NY passed away on October 26, 2011 at the age of 82. A native New Yorker, he attended The Buckley School, Milton Academy and graduated from Yale University, class of 52. He served in the U.S. Air Force as a first lieutenant before earning a law degree from The University of Virginia, class of 1957, and through all made lifelong friendships. "Dick" practiced law for a short time before becoming a banker with JP Morgan, a career that lasted 35 years. He is survived by beautiful and charming Norma, his wife, with whom he shared more than 50 years of happiness, son, Charles Flender, daughter, Sylvia Scott Flender, grandsons Richard and Gage, granddaughters Nina and Elizabeth (Zizi), brother, John Flender, sister Elizabeth (Cindy) Webber and several loving nieces and nephews. "Dick" was known for his kindness and generosity and served on the boards of numerous charitable organizations. He will be dearly missed for his humour, and joi de vie, his certain flair and lovely manner. He was an avid skier, a golfer, a traveler, a Ranger fan, chocolate-lover, a friend. So handsome and strong willed to the end, Richard Flender was loved and respected by all who knew him--in the truest sense, he was simply a delight. A Memorial will be held on Friday, November 4, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, NY at 1:00pm with a reception following.

There are medal tables and World Cup standings. There are world rankings for badminton, curling and korfball. But what about a truly universal pecking order, one that determines the planet's top nation across all sports? It sounds like a fine, even a commercial, idea, yet in an age that runneth over with sports statistics, no authoritative ranking is all-inclusive. The closest is an obscure Web site introduced by three friends in 2008: greatestsportingnation.com.

MITROVICA, Kosovo -- For three months, this gritty mining town has been a hot spot of Balkan ethnic tension ominous enough to prompt new deployments of armed NATO peacekeepers and action by the European Union to slow Serbia's long-sought bid for membership. In a long siege at makeshift gravel barricades, ethnic Serbs hurled rocks toward ethnic Albanians on the other side of the Ibar River, and this summer, hooded men in shorts and sneakers firebombed a border-control station, stoking fears among Western powers that ethnic clashes could spin out of control in northern Kosovo.

Behavioral scientists have long known that humans, whether in the schoolyard or in a dimly lighted bar, have a tendency to subconsciously mimic the sounds, style and movement of others. Recent research, however, shows that this mimicry also extends to how we speak and write. Even the least important words we choose can say a lot about us. In one unusual experiment, 187 men and women gathered on the Northwestern University campus to take part in several four-minute speed dates. The couples talked about their respective majors and where they grew up, but none of that interested the University of Texas at Austin psychologist James W. Pennebaker. Instead, his focus was on the barely noticed personal pronouns (I, you, me), articles (the, a), prepositions (for, of, on), conjunctions (but, and) and other small words. These commonly used so-called function words, about 180 in all, Pennebaker says, are processed rapidly and subconsciously. And our use of them can reveal, among other things, whether a romance will work out or how well two people work together.

Florence Parry Heide, who wrote dozens of books of prose and poetry for children -- often enhanced with drawings by famed illustrators -- that enthralled the youngest readers (and those who read to them), has died at her home in Kenosha, Wis. She was 92. She died in her sleep either Sunday night, Oct. 23, or early Monday, said her daughter Roxanne Heide Pierce.

A chart on Oct. 23 about the European debt crisis misstated the effect that the introduction of the euro in 1999 had on central banks of individual European nations. Such banks were reconstituted to work with the European Central Bank; the central banks did not cease to exist.

NURKIN--Harry. With great sadness we honor Harry Nurkin, Ph.D. and all that he contributed to the Milbank Memorial Fund. Dr. Nurkin joined the Board of Directors in 2008 and was immediately engaged in the work of the Fund. He brought to discussions about the Fund's program his firsthand knowledge of managing complex health care systems and his dedication to caring for members of underserved populations. Over a period of 21 years, he led the development of the Carolinas HealthCare System from a single public hospital to the third largest public healthcare system in the U.S. In addition to his insightful comments, the board and staff also remember his warmth, good humor and unfailing courtesy. We will miss him. Samuel L. "Tony" Milbank, Chairman Carmen Hooker Odom, President Milbank Memorial Fund

IN fall 2008, the photographer Noah Abrams came across a YouTube clip of a couple of Afghan teenagers skateboarding in Kabul. ''It struck me as the most positive image I'd seen in a long time,'' he said. ''I had to figure out a way to get over there.'' Mr. Abrams, a skater himself, made two trips the following year to photograph what turned out to be a small but thriving skating scene in the war-torn city, in part the work of Skateistan, a school started in 2007 by two Australian skaters. (A documentary about the program, ''Skateistan: To Live and Skate Kabul,'' had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival this year.) Overcoming a lack of smooth roads and sidewalks, among other things, Kabul's skaters (girls included) find in skating a rare recreational outlet, Mr. Abrams said. ''The mullahs have no problem with girls skating,'' he said. ''They can't ride a bike, but they can skate. The girls just jump on it.'' ABBY AGUIRRE
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

The Consumer Reports Annual Auto Reliability Survey, released on Tuesday afternoon, is intended to provide shoppers with a sense of the projected reliability of new models. But as the sales of some new cars indicate, a poor showing in the study does not translate to poor performance in the marketplace. The Chevrolet Cruze, equipped with either the 1.4-liter or 1.8-liter engine, received the worst rating of any small car in the survey. Through September, however, Chevy had delivered 187,524 Cruzes in the United States, making it the highest-selling car in its segment, according to data provided by J.D. Power & Associates.
Bay Ridge, Brooklyn March 13, 2011

BURKE--Daniel B. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Daniel B. Burke, Chairman Emeritus of the NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Board of Trustees. A beloved member of our Hospital community for 20 years, Mr. Burke served in leadership positions on the Board of The Presbyterian Hospital and as Co-Chairman of the Board of the merged NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital. In recognition of his service, particularly his crucial role in making the merger a success, he was named Chairman Emeritus in 2000. His vision and support, including gifts toward the construction of Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital and the modernization of Presbyterian Hospital, leave a lasting legacy. Remembered for his extraordinary intelligence, integrity and sense of humor, Mr. Burke will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Harriet S. (Bunny); four children (Stephen, Bill and Frank Burke, and Sally McNamara); brother, James; sister, Phyllis B. Davis; and fourteen grandchildren. John J. Mack, Chairman Frank A. Bennack Jr., Vice Chair Charlotte M. Ford, Vice Chair Peter A. Georgescu, Vice Chair Herbert Pardes, M.D., Executive Vice Chair Jerry I. Speyer, Vice Chair Board of Trustees Steven J. Corwin, M.D., Chief Executive Officer NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

CHANCES are you weren't ready to buy a winter coat when the first of them began arriving in stores last August, before Labor Day, while temperatures hovered near 90 degrees. But it's officially fall now. Summer heat has long been forgotten, and it's time to start thinking seriously about buying a coat, of which there are many warm and woolly options. Long is the trend, and Theyskens' Theory delivers it in elegant burgundy. From Valentino's Red label, a hooded lace-trimmed parka is versatile enough. Just add layers in January. And from Carven, a ladylike take on the trench comes belted in camel-colored wool. Coat, check! From left, Theyskens' Theory coat, $1,395, at net-a-porter.com; Red Valentino parka, $850, at saksfifthavenue.com; Carven cocoon coat, $970, at net-a-porter.com. MADISON SHIMODA

Anarchy rarely hits the screen with the rigor of Seijun Suzuki's gangster films. Criterion is rereleasing, this time in Blu-ray editions, ''Tokyo Drifter'' and ''Branded to Kill,'' two of the dozens of movies that Mr. Suzuki made for the Japanese studio Nikaatsu between 1956 and 1967, when the unconventionality of ''Branded to Kill'' got him fired and unable to find directing work for the next 10 years. The plots are standard pulp premises. But the pleasure of watching a Suzuki has less to do with following the cryptic stories than the shuffle of his abrupt cutting, the sudden shifts in time and place, and the sensibility, which might be called black-humored modernist baroque. (Above, Tetsuya Watari, left, and Tamio Kawaji in a scene.)

An article last Sunday about Rhode Island pension funds referred incorrectly to the recent history of the Providence Public Library system. It did not close branches in 2009; city funding for all but the central library went instead to a nonprofit, the Providence Community Library, which has kept them open. (The central library did shorten its hours.) And because of an editing error, the article misstated the middle initial of the City Council president in Woonsocket. He is John F. Ward, not John W.

BRAVO--Lucia Hobart. Lucia Hobart Bravo, of Vero Beach, FL, passed away on Tuesday, October 25, 2011 at her home on the shores of the Indian River, FL. Lucia is survived by her daughters, Hylton B. Hard, Elizabeth B. Benson, Sylvia B. Larsen and sons Stephen Logan Bravo and Alexandre Hobart Bravo; 12 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Her son Jonathan Cahill Bravo preceded her in death in 2009. Lucia's lifelong love of rivers led to her choice of living on the Indian River, and so it was appropriate that she passed from this life while looking out over the estuary and its ever-changing weather and teeming wildlife, all enacted under sunny skies, huge thunder clouds, or a blanket of stars. Those who knew and loved Lucia will celebrate her life in the knowledge that she lived by her belief in the philosophy of leaving her communities, country and the world a better place. There will be a memorial service at 3:00 on Saturday, November 19, 2011 at Trinity Episcopal Church, Troy, OH. The date will be announced later for a memorial service at Trinity Episcopal Church in Vero Beach, FL. The family would like to express their sincere appreciation for all of her special caregivers during her last few years. An online guestbook is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com

In Metropolitan's cover article last week, ''Lunch, Landfills and What I Tossed,'' Mireya Navarro explored the limits of recycling in New York City. Readers wrote to NYTimes.com with a variety of solutions. They also debated Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, which argued that New York is not the melting pot it often claims to be. ''There's nothing I can do,'' bemoans one subject about their plastic waste stream. There's plenty you can do, buddy, but you have to want to. Bring lunches from home in containers. (Even Tupperware is better than throwaway receptacles.) Carry your own utensils. Refuse plastic.

Patriots (5-1) at Steelers (5-2) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Patriots by 3. In a world where the Colts lose by 55 points, the Jaguars can beat the Ravens without scoring a touchdown and games are becoming so boring that they have become upstaged by the postgame handshakes, it is heartening to know that we can still count on the Steelers' defense. Unfortunately, we cannot still count on the Steelers' defense. The Steelers have intercepted just two passes this season, an amazingly low figure when you run down the quarterbacks they have faced: Tarvaris Jackson, Blaine Gabbert, Kevin Kolb, Kerry Collins, Curtis Painter. Ten of the Steelers' 17 sacks came against Gabbert and Jackson, the standard-bearers in that cavalcade of regret. While Warren Sapp's ''old and slow'' estimation of the Steelers' defense after Week 1 was premature and slightly exaggerated, the Steel Curtain now has a higher-than-advertised aluminum content. The Steelers compensate for their declining defense with one of the best passing attacks in the league: they rank fifth in net passing yards per game and eighth in yards per attempt. And while the Patriots' offense is better than Pittsburgh's, their defense is far worse, allowing a league-high 423 yards per game. So get ready for a back-and-forth, high-scoring offensive battle. After last week's games, you deserve it. Pick: Steelers.

There is nothing spooky about Halloween in the city. Two weeks ago, more than 100,000 young people got an early start at ComicCon at the Javits Center, a third of them in costume relating to their favorite superheroes and supergoblins. This extravaganza of fantasy dressing brought to mind the September fashion collection of Gareth Pugh, with modernist skeletal clothes and Kenny Scharf-style pointed heads. All over the city, the urge to decorate with simulated cobwebs stretched over jack-o'-lanterns and over the entrances of Victorian brownstones. At the Union Square Greenmarket, children did what came naturally, climbing over and through the pumpkin patch.

CARPENTER--Ruth C. A teacher, mentor, literary scholar and friend of unparalleled intellect and generosity, Ruth Corn Carpenter, of New Milford, Connecticut and New York City, passed away peacefully on the evening of October 23, 2011. Only child of Lorlene Johnson and Wilbur Graves Corn, Ruth grew up in Franklin, Tennessee, and attended The Harpeth Hall School, where she was valedictorian. She was graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1957 with a B.A. in English, first in her class and summa cum laude. Among other honors, she was awarded Marshall and Fulbright scholarships, and studied at Cambridge University in England, where she received an M.A. She also won Bryn Mawr's European Fellowship, the college's highest honor for a member of the graduating class. Ruth then began a 50-year career studying and teaching literature. Many of her students have described her as the most brilliant mind and greatest teacher they have ever encountered in any field at any institution. She taught briefly at Barnard College, and in South Korea at Ewha Women's University, but primarily lavished her great literary and pedagogical gifts on the girls of the Brearley School in New York City, where she taught for 40 years, and where she was the guiding star of an English department that rivaled any in the country. Ruth opened the minds of thousands of Brearley girls to the abiding value of literature. She taught everything from Malory to Jane Austen to Samuel Beckett to Langston Hughes, but Shakespeare was her first love, literally. At the age of 12, she saw a traveling production of Hamlet in Franklin, Tennessee, and suddenly she "was in love" -- simultaneously with the red headed actor playing the lead, with Hamlet and with Shakespeare. It was to Ruth's Shakespeare elective that the students of Brearley flocked every year, and it was to Shakespeare that she primarily devoted her luminous attention after retiring from the Brearley School in 2000. From 2000 through 2011, Ruth was the head of adult education at, and taught Shakespeare seminars for, the Shakespeare Society in New York City. Like generations of Brearley girls, Ruth's adult students became enthralled by Ruth's remarkable ability to deepen, complicate and expand their understanding of, and feeling for, the fully formed characters we meet in Shakespeare's plays. Ruth Carpenter offered to all her students, young and old, a new way of comprehending Shakespeare, the world and themselves. That is the essence of her legacy to us all. She would have us continue to regard Shakespeare with new eyes; and to those who protest they cannot do that without her she would say (quoting readily from The Winter's Tale), "It is required you do awake your faith." Ruth was a radiant spirit and a devout humanist who also firmly believed in the immortality of the soul. Her enormously generous heart, a lifetime devoted to seeing human beings fully, in life as in literature, and her linguistic brilliance made her at once a wise and compassionate friend, and a wonderfully witty one too. The entire English language was at her command, and her grip on it never failed. Moreover, the invariable elegance of her attire matched the elegance of her mind, and we will rarely see her like again for sartorial perfection. For Ruth, as for Shakespeare, "nothing human was alien to her," and her sheer love of life and her friends rivaled that of her beloved Falstaff. She also made friends with bats and snakes and blue jays and geese and all the denizens of her Connecticut gardens that were a source of endless pleasure. Ruth now joins her loving partner of 20 years, Dick Gershman, who died in 1998. Ruth is survived by the love of her best friends Alexa and Fred Aldridge, Ann McDonald and Ellie Rittman, and by the love and devotion of all the Aldridges, who are her godchildren and family: Mindy Aldridge and her daughter, Katharine, and Richard and Kris Aldridge, and their children Hank, Eliza, Bo and Evie. Ruth's funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held in New York City, the details of which will be announced. Ruth asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Shakespeare Society, 118-122 Baxter Street, Suite 705, New York, New York 10013.

The New York City Department of Education released report cards for high schools last week with a new measure: college readiness, determined by the number of students who could qualify to avoid remedial courses in city colleges. At most schools, even many with stellar graduation rates, fewer than half made the grade.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports for Oct. 21 to 27. 1. A LEADING PIONEER Julia Chase-Brand ran the Manchester Road Race in Connecticut 50 years ago in an act of civil disobedience that became a pioneering moment in female distance running in the United States.

For decades, all those competing at the highest levels of North American racing have commenced each new year with their sights set on winning the same three races - the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes. Victories in these classics significantly raise the stature of horses, jockeys, trainers and owners alike and have a lasting impact on one's legacy, often tipping the scales in one's favor when it's time to be considered for the Hall of Fame. Today, and for much of the last two-plus decades, these same competitors have circled a fourth race on their calendars at the start of each year, the Breeders' Cup Classic. Trainers with Classic contenders plot their race schedule for the year based on the timing of the Classic, and winning the Classic has proven to deliver all the spoils that Triple Crown races do - a massive payday, Eclipse awards and lucrative breeding potential. Which is why we're calling the Classic thoroughbred racing's fourth major.

The late 1970s and early 1980s - when buildings were burning, fiscal crises were raging and the Dead Boys were playing at CBGB - were a macabre time in New York City's history, a period when it could be said that the city resembled a haunted house. The photographer John Conn, 62, spent those years documenting the subway system, what was then the dungeon of the city's haunted house. His images from underground include a bat-wielding man in a hunchback costume, a nun absorbed in a tabloid newspaper with a front-page headline about an attack on the pope and a disembodied arm brandishing a switchblade through an open subway window. The images have a quality of ghoulishness: fear and madness, as if seen through the eyes of a frightened child on a never-ending Halloween night.

A new online rating tool to help people with disabilities evaluate the accessibility of restaurants, hotels and other sites was released this month by the Rick Hansen Foundation. The Global Accessibility Map (rickhansenglobalaccessibilitymap.com) was designed as an easy-to-use source for people with mobility, sight and hearing impairments. (Visually impaired users can access it using standard software programs that convert text into audible content.) Users can sort through reviews by geographic location, kind of place, name, rating level or type of impairment, or any combination, and post reviews and comments. ''Often there is a disconnect between the venue owner's perception and the consumer's assessment of reality,'' said Daryl Rock, chairman of the Global Accessibility Map steering committee. Mr. Rock, a wheelchair user, said he recently stayed at a hotel in New York that described itself as fully accessible, but steps at the entrance prevented easy access.

Few pictures are as evanescent as Jean Renoir's ''Rules of the Game.'' Set on the eve of World War II, this story of Parisian aristocrats both misbehaving and tentatively reckoning with their own suffering holds so many shifts of tone, color and mood that watching it is like being dazzled by an intricately cut crystal: it reinvents itself not just with each viewing but within each viewing. No wonder that François Truffaut said of the movie that it makes us feel as if we were there as it was being made, instead of simply watching a finished product. ''For an instant,'' he wrote in ''The Films in My Life,'' ''we think to ourselves, 'I'll come back tomorrow and see if it all turns out the same way.' ''

WASHINGTON - Two months before the first votes are to be cast in the Republican presidential nominating contest, Herman Cain and Mitt Romney have the strongest support among party activists who plan to participate in the Iowa caucuses, according to a poll released on Saturday evening. The Iowa Poll in The Des Moines Sunday Register provides the clearest snapshot yet of how candidates stand in the Republican presidential race. The leaders were Mr. Cain, with 23 percent of support among Republican voters, and Mr. Romney, with 22 percent - a difference that is statistically insignificant.

If you have heard it once, you have heard it hundreds of times. ''The United States spends too much on health care.'' This is not a partisan point. You can hear this from Republicans as well as Democrats. ''We know that our families, our economy and our nation itself will not succeed in the 21st century if we continue to be held down by the weight of rapidly rising health care costs,'' President Obama said in 2009. Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, agrees: ''There is no serious dispute - on either side of the aisle.'' Unfortunately, few people really understand how much we spend on health care, how much we need to spend to provide quality care, and the difference between the two. Do we spend too much? Would cutting costs require rationing, or worse, death panels?

MONTGOMERY--Robert Quin died on October 12, 2011 in Leesburg, Virginia. Robert was born on December 29, 1955 in Norfolk, Virginia. He attended Rumson Country Day School, Lawrenceville, and Denison University. He began his insurance brokerage career at Marsh and McLennan. He also worked at Johnson and Higgins, then at Sedgwick, and later, at Armfield, Harrison and Thomas. Robert is survived by his loving companion, Tammy Morrison Lucas and daughter, Zoe Alexander Lucas, his mother, Harriett Giordano Chaney, his sister, Chloe Smeed and her husband David, and predeceased by his father, S. Phelps Montgomery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to an animal shelter of your choice. Robert will be greatly missed by all his family and friends. Condolences may be sent to colonialfuneralhome.com.

IT'S hard not to feel naughty when ordering a 10-inch pizza. Sure, it packs at least three food groups, but that crust is awfully thick, there has to be extra sugar in that red sauce, and (ugh) can someone pass the napkins? The Day-Glo orange grease drips all over. Enter Naked Pizza, a microchain started by a Louisiana man looking for healthier food options for his diabetic daughter. After succeeding in the South, the chain has finally made its way to New York. Though some of the menu (barbecue pizza, cheesy breadsticks) is a little suspicious, most of the guilt is gone. There's no added sugar in the tomato sauce; the mozzarella is light on grease; the toppings are hormone-free. And the nutty-tasting dough is made with 10 grains, including quinoa, and contains probiotics. How virtuous is that! Naked Pizza, 954 Third Avenue; (212) 759-3500; nakedpizza.biz. BRIAN NICHOLS

A free ride and a friendly driver aren't necessarily what taxi riders expect. But that's exactly what the author and television personality Leon Logothetis will be offering for the next couple of weeks, as he continues his cross-country road trip that began in New York City on Oct. 24. When Mr. Logothetis traversed the country in 2007 on a budget of just $5 a day for his TV reality show, ''Amazing Adventures of a Nobody,'' he relied on the kindness of strangers for necessities like food and shelter. Now, he said, it's time to give something back. So he's offering free rides in a vintage English taxi, appropriately known as the Kindness Cab (kindnesscab.com).

CAUBISENS--Henri P.,Pete to his friends and family, died on the 27th of October, 2011, just shy of 80 years old. He was a proud member of the New York State and Virginia Bar for over 50 years. He was truly a gentleman and a scholar, with a wide-ranging intellect and vast stores of knowledge on subjects ranging from the Civil War to aviation and baseball. He had a charming wit and a wry sense of humor. Pete courageously and gracefully battled Parkinson's disease for 17 years. He will be enormously missed by his adoring wife of 28 years, Beth Shapiro, his sister, Denise Aubuchon, his daughters Renee, Denise and Nicole, his stepchildren Andrew and Rachel, their respective spouses, his 10 grandchildren, whom he wished to see grow up, and his many friends. There will be a celebration of his life held at his home in New York City on Saturday, November 5, 2011 at 3:00pm.

Mark Messier is best known around New York as the captain of the Rangers when they won the Stanley Cup in 1994, their first championship in 54 years. But next Sunday, he will trade skates for running shoes and hit the streets for the New York City Marathon. Messier, 50, will represent the New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund and Tomorrow's Children's Fund in the race. He maintains ties to the Rangers as the special assistant to Glen Sather, the team's president and general manager, and oversees the Messier Project, an initiative to address concussions in hockey, particularly at the youth level, by raising awareness and working to change priorities in the sport.

To the Editor: Having taught at Brown for 16 years, including a course on Charles Sanders Peirce, the modern founder of sign theory, I found Steven Johnson's essay to be a depressingly accurate characterization of the academic times during his college years. However, readers should know that his identification of semiotics as a field of study by linking it with Peirce, an American philosopher, and the Swiss linguist Ferdinand de Saussure is a serious, albeit common, misconception. Saussure's version is defective next to Peirce's, and not curable by patch-up. That it was Saussure's ideas about signs, and not Peirce's, that gave rise to the Continental form Jacques Derrida and others propagated -- and gullible American academics swallowed whole -- should not be so glibly elided. Peirce is the greatest intellect the Americas ever produced, and it is his whole philosophy, including his semeiotic (note the spelling and the singular number) that now bids fair to prevail as doctrine.

WALTON--Eileen Drexler, passed on at the age of 93 on Sunday, October 23, 2011 in Arlington Heights, Illinois. She is survived by her daughter Patricia Walton Silver (husband David) of Sag Harbor and New York City and Mike Walton (wife Linda) of Deerfield, Illinois and her three grandchildren Steve, Julie, and Geige. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband of 57 years, Elmer Walton, former Mayor of Decatur, Illinois. One of her proudest accomplishments was winning the Illinois State Spelling Championship in 1932, representing Illinois at the Championships in Washington, D.C. and meeting then President Herbert Hoover. She was an energetic, strong woman totally devoted to her family while working full time at Millikin University in Decatur and volunteering in many organizations. She was an avid bridge player , an enthusiastic gardener and traveler (particularly to New York to visit her family) and spent many afternoons and evenings at Busch Stadium with Elmer cheering for her favorite Cardinals. She will be dearly missed by her children and grandchildren and greatgrandchildren who loved her for so many years and always appreciated her sense of humor and delightful smile. A beautiful woman in every way. Services to celebrate Eileen's life will be held at 11am on Monday, November 7 at First Presbyterian Church in Decatur, Illinois.

WOOD--Suzanne Cort, peacefully on October 19 at 95 years. Born in Manhattan to Margretta and Harry L. Cort, playwright and impresario, whose family owned the Cort Theater. Growing up in the theatrical world, she studied art and dance and acted professionally. In 1938 she married John W. Wood (Jack). Although from an old New York family, Jack was also a creative spirit and a gifted architect. After their marriage Suzanne continued to study art and to paint, brilliantly ranging across many styles. She also continued acting with such groups as the Amateur Comedy Club and the Snarks, of which she became president. She was an active member of St. James Church, co-chairman of Interfaith Neighbors and a director of the Social Register. Gentle, always cheerful and continually loving she will be greatly missed. She is survived by her children Michele Wood Ruhm and John Walter Wood, grandchildren Duncan Wood, Wendy and Thomas Ruhm, and great-grandchildren Adair and Lydia Wood. Funeral service at 11am, October 27 at Christ Church, Bronxville.

No one, in the 21st century, would have thought we needed, or even could use, another Winnie the Pooh film. For Pooh purists, those who have always taken delight in A. A. Milne's mischievous wordplay and E. H. Shepard's delicate yet robust pen-and-ink illustrations, the 1966 Disney short ''Winnie the Pooh and the Honey Tree'' was quite enough, thank you, and its numerous follow-ups only added insult to injury. But the 2011 ''Winnie the Pooh'' represents a bridge -- a Poohsticks bridge, if you will -- between those who hold Milne's works sacred and those who are perfectly O.K. with putting a red T-shirt on a once-gloriously unadorned mohair bear. In this new ''Winnie the Pooh'' -- directed by Stephen J. Anderson and Don Hall and narrated by John Cleese -- our Bear of Very Little Brain and the usual suspects (including Piglet, Rabbit, Owl and Tigger) reassemble for an important mission: to find the missing tail of the endearingly morose Eeyore. From there the story winds its way along a graceful, curving arc that introduces (and, if you watch through the end of the credits, beautifully resolves) the story of a new character, a terrible, horned beastie known as the Backson, who destroys everything -- books, toys, teacups -- that children and their stuffed animals hold dear. (The Backson, of course, doesn't exist, but is merely the result of Owl's misinterpretation of a note from Christopher Robin, in which he writes that he'll be ''back soon.'')

STILLMAN--Gerald I.,the former Director of Research and Development of the Power Authority for the State of New York, died on Friday, October 28, 2011. He worked on development of new sources of wind, solar and water energy. He was a loving husband and father, an avid bike rider and a self-taught cellist. After his retirement in 1991, he devoted himself to translating Yiddish literature into English. He also served on the Editorial Board of "Jewish Currents." Among his published translations are works by Mendele Mokher Sforim, Fishke the Lame, The Little Man in an anthology called The Three Classic Writers of Modern Yiddish Literature, vol. I, and a work by I.L. Peretz in vol. III of the same series. In May 2011, he was celebrated as Man of the Year by a peace organization, New Jersey Peace Action. He is survived by his wife, Mira Stillman, his sons, Sandy, Joshua, Ezra, and grandchildren, Sarah, Emma, Jonah, Abraham and Molly. The service will be held on Sunday, October 30th at 1pm, at Menorah Chapels Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Vaux Hall, NJ 908-964-1500

SPRINGER--John, died in NYC on October 30, 2001 at the age of 85. He is lovingly remembered by his wife June; children Gary, Alicia, and Cynthia; grandchildren Nicholas, Olivia, Anthony, Zora and Zachary; and his many friends and associates. Springer was one of the leading entertainment PR representatives in the world for decades, from his WWII service helping Marlene Dietrich entertain the troops, to the heyday of the Hollywood star system, to the new cinema and theater of the 70s and 80s. He represented a galaxy of film, theater and television stars, producers, directors, festivals and events from New York to Los Angeles to Europe. As a noted film historian, he had an encyclopedic memory for facts about Hollywood. In his introduction to Mr. Springer's book "All Talking! All Singing! All Dancing!" (1966), Gene Kelly said, "John Springer knows as much about movies as anyone I've met." His other books include "The Fondas: Henry, Jane and Peter;" "They Had Faces Then;" and "Forgotten Films to Remember." This only scratches the surface of John Springer's story!

SAALBURG--Mary Faulconer, died peacefully at home on June 19, 2011. She was a respected and talented artist, stamp designer, teacher, photographer and storyteller. She will be greatly missed and remembered forever.

To the Editor: Steven Johnson's essay ''I Was an Under-Age Semiotician'' (Oct. 16) paints an all-too-familiar portrait of semiotics as jargon-laden and ridiculous. But there's one saving grace: He and several peers apparently found a ''secret layer of meaning'' and developed ''conceptual antennas'' sufficient enough to secure ''influential careers in the media and the creative arts.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Missed Bullpen Calls Lead to an Interesting Game of Telephone,'' Oct. 26: St. Louis Manager Tony La Russa was unable to communicate to his bullpen coach that he also wanted Jason Motte warming up in the eighth inning of World Series Game 5, which the Cardinals subsequently lost.

As a teenager, I was delighted to discover on the map of Tolkien's Middle-earth the name of the city where I was born. Not the same town, of course, but another, fantastical place with the same name. Nevertheless, the map gave me options. I could be a native of Bree, a small, unremarkable town in northeastern Belgium. Or I could hail from that other Bree, equally small and unremarkable, but at least located in a world brimming with magic, danger and adventure. In contrast, my home province of Limburg, in Belgium's northeast, is generally flat, and on the whole bereft of elves, orcs, hobbits and wizards. So I spent many hours exploring Tolkien's world, dreaming up adventures of my own in the far corners of that map. I soon discovered that the cartography of the real-world version of Bree had one critical advantage over its Middle-earth counterpart: it had borders. Bree's corner of northwestern Europe was dotted with a tangle of boundaries, indicating the multitude of countries, cultures and languages jostling for their place on the map.

An article on Oct. 16 about a writer's returning to Sardinia, which she had known as a child, misstated the location of the town of Porto Cervo on the island's coast. As shown correctly on an accompanying map, the town is on Sardinia's northern, not southeastern, coast.

With the Occupy Wall Street protests now in their second month, there has been an enduring conversation in the city concerning what has come to be known as the 99 Percent. In shrewder quarters, there has also been a collateral conversation about the richer and remaining 1 percent. Of course, in New York, as in the nation as a whole, the truly well-to-do represent a fraction of the fraction. Affluence, by nature, is a separating element, and the city's wealthiest residents -- its financiers and industrialists -- can be comfortably said to existwithin a small percentage of even that 1 percent.

The Vows column last Sunday about the wedding of Evan Wolfson and Cheng He misstated the given name of Mr. Wolfson's mother. She is Joan Colter Wolfson, not Jean. The column also described the couple's suits incorrectly. They were black, not brown.

An article last Sunday about exhibits in Washington misspelled the middle name of one artist whose work is on display in the Great American Hall of Wonders at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. He was Charles Willson Peale, not Wilson.

Q. For our birthdays, my very generous parents surprised my three sisters and me with a ''bonding'' vacation and carte blanche to travel anywhere to do so. We are living across the country from D.C. to San Francisco, range in age from 27 to 21 and with varied interests and athletic abilities. We're looking for a place that will provide some quality down time, but also some activities to accommodate both a medical student and an adventurous trail runner. We're hoping to travel during the Christmas holiday. Does such a place even exist?

The Yankees exercised their one-year, $10.25 million option on right fielder Nick Swisher's contract Saturday. They also picked up the $14 million option on Robinson Cano's contract. Swisher, 31, batted .260 with 23 home runs, 85 runs batted in and 95 walks. (He has averaged 28 home runs, 89 R.B.I. and 90 walks per 162 games over his eight years in the majors, and has a career average of .254.) While playing through a sore left elbow, Swisher struggled in the final month of the season, batting .205 with only 2 home runs and 8 R.B.I., and he had another disappointing postseason. He went 4 for 19 with one home run in five games in the Yankees' division-series loss to the Tigers.
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the clothing designer Charlotte Ronson misstated the first name of one of her half-sisters. She is Henrietta Ronson, not Harriet.

STEIN--Fred. The headline we saw on Bloomberg News in Oman while we were reminiscing about Fred almost said it all: Fred Stein: "Investing Legend." But he was so much more--he was a legend in life. Fred's favorite word in investments was dimension." "Did the company have dimension?" he would ask. Well, no one had more dimension than Fred-avid reader; lover of opera, movies, theatre; travel; and most of all, people. No one was loved more, either-and for good reason. Fred was so loving and giving of himself. He spared no one his attention, his warmth, his kindness. And what a prodigious memory he had! He would regale us with stories from as far back as the 50s. We feel so very fortunate to have spent so much time with him on vacations with our families, including Christmases together for many years. Our lives are more blessed because we have known him so well. Fred was a godfather to Alexandra and Ben, and mentor to Scott and so many others he came into contact with, including me for over 40 years. Fred, our guest room in East Hampton is forever yours. We will miss you. Love, Leila and Mickey

Devoted brother of Marianne, David, Stuart and the late Ethel, Joan and Bobby. Longtime fighter for social justice; union organizer and WWII Veteran. His quick wit and loving personality endeared him to all.

Dolphins (0-6) at Giants (4-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Giants CB Corey Webster vs. Dolphins WR Brandon Marshall Marshall has made plenty of headlines this season for things he has said (predicting he would be ejected for fighting against the Jets; guaranteeing a victory against the Giants). But he is an undeniable talent, and Webster will be chasing him. Two weeks ago, the Giants' secondary gave up early big plays to the Buffalo Bills but excelled late in a dramatic victory. Can Webster lead a more complete effort against Marshall and the winless Dolphins?

Richard Katris: My mom raised cats when I was a child, so I'm very attuned to them. I've taken at least 800,000 cat pictures over 35 years. That's basically what I do for a living. Right now I am working this cat into position with a toy to take a photo before the Santa Monica Cat Club Cat Show. I'm trying to make the cat realize that nothing bad is going to happen to him. I've got a stick and a toy in one hand, and I've got a camera in the other, and I'm trying to get him interested in playing with cat toys. I'm trying to get him happy enough -- and then get him in the play mode so he forgets where he is and becomes a feral hunter. When that instinct takes over, the fear goes away.

To the Sports Editor: The players and the owners could save more than the season by agreeing to escrow the amount of money in dispute, and proceeding with the season now based on the amount of money not in dispute. For example, if one side is at 48 percent and the other is at 52 percent, 4 percent is in dispute but 96 percent is not.

HILLMAN--James, 1926-2011, nominee for the Pulitzer prize for Revisioning Psychology, awarded the Presidents Medal of Honor, Florence, Italy, and radical founder of Archetypal Psychology, died at his home in Thompson, CT from complications of cancer. Dr. Hillman was 85 years old, alternately holding court with friends and colleagues and deep in exchange with his beloved wife, artist Margot McLean. Born in Atlantic City, Hillman resided in Europe for more than three decades. He is the author of more than twenty books translated into twenty five languages including a number one best seller, "The Soul's Code," and his opus, "A Terrible Love of War." A ten volume Uniform Edition of Hillman's uncollected published works is in progress, with six titles currently in print. James' stunning wit, generosity of mind and heart, brilliant conversation, and joy in the daily round will be terribly missed. He leaves behind a used pair of tap shoes, a yard full of exotic chickens, mornings in Thompson, nighttimes in New York, friends from all over the world, and most importantly his irrepressible collaborator in life and love, Margot. Predeceased by his first wife Catharina Kempe, remembered by his second wife Patricia Berry, Hillman is survived by his sisters Sue Becker and Sybil Pike, brother Joel, four children from his first marriage, Julia, Carola, Susanne, Laurence and five grandchildren. A Memorial Service in New York City will be announced at a later date. Vincente Minnelli's ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' was not, of course, shot in St. Louis, or even on a Hollywood soundstage. It was filmed right in the middle of Candy Land, or so it seems, given the movie's Technicolor palette of pistachio greens, gumdrop reds and butter-cream yellows. There are many reasons to love ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' among them the movie's cheerful, postcard vision of small-city family life in the early-20th century. But if you look more closely, you see it really is a musical of extremes, a version of nostalgia in overdrive.

Anyone under the illusion that movies have grown more sophisticated about sex as society has become (allegedly) more open should take a look at ''Design for Living.'' Coming toward the end of that brief, disreputable era before Joseph Breen and the Motion Picture Production Code instituted the moralizing that has dogged movies ever since, Ernst Lubitsch and Ben Hecht's loose adaptation of Noël Coward's great play is, like ''Shampoo'' or ''Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice,'' an American comedy that is utterly grown up about sex and speaks to its audience on those terms. The young, impossibly sexy Gary Cooper and the sleek Fredric March play American bohemians in Paris, a painter and a playwright, who meet another American, a commercial artist named Gilda (Miriam Hopkins, above with March, left, and Cooper), and each decides that he wants her. Gilda decides she wants both, and -- except for a brief respite with the peerless Edward Everett Horton as a smitten ad executive who can give her security and not much else -- she pinballs languidly between the two.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week. Blue is a color not often seen in nature. It is rare to find a truly blue wildflower or bird. A T its zenith in the early 20th century, Jackson Ward, in Richmond, Va., was a thriving, multicultural quarter known as the Harlem of the South, with the likes of Duke Ellington and the native son Bill Robinson, known as Bojangles, headlining at the Hippodrome Theater. In the 1950s, the construction of Interstate 95 split the neighborhood, and Jackson Ward fell into decline. Vacant storefronts still blemish some of the historic district's 40 square blocks, but thanks to plucky restaurateurs, gallery owners and shopkeepers, there's a scent of promise mingling with the magnolias. So far it's more of a daytime and early evening scene -- but night life is coming back too: the long-empty Hippodrome has been restored and is scheduled to reopen in November, combined with a bistro and speakeasy-type bar. Italianate houses with cast-iron porches, the Black History Museum and the fascinating museum dedicated to the entrepreneur Maggie L. Walker are further reasons to stroll these brick sidewalks. JULIE BESONEN

We'll chalk it up to pure coincidence and nothing more sinister that FX waited until Monday - Halloween - to announce that it is ordering a second season of its macabre series "American Horror Story" from creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk. The show, which stars Dylan McDermott and Connie Britton as a struggling married couple living in a haunted Los Angeles mansion where people can't seem to stop dying, has been a hit for the cable network, drawing nearly 3.2 million viewers for its Oct. 5 debut and averaging about 2.8 million for each new installment. FX said that, through four episodes, "American Horror Story" was on track to become the highest-rated first season of any series it has broadcast, surpassing Mr. Murphy's plastic-surgery drama "Nip/Tuck," which began in 2003. The second season of "American Horror Story" will run 13 episodes; no debut was immediately announced, though it will likely run in the fall, at which point we'll know whether it's more or less terrifying than Charlie Sheen's new FX series, "Anger Management."

The New York artist Sue de Beer has long established herself as an aesthetic interlocutor of teens and the occult, so Halloween provides an apt occasion for her to unveil a new work. De Beer's practice first took root through domestically appointed video installations that channeled deep, dark, suburban, subcultural angst. She has steadily drifted toward explorations of the paranormal, conjuring Puritan New England for her 2007 horror film, "The Quickening," and more recently - and more minimally - evoking the inherent eeriness of spaces through structures inspired by Brion Gysin's "Dream Machine" or corporate entities like the Seagram Building. "Haunt Room," which opened over the weekend on the 14th Street passageway of the High Line, is a 15-foot-wide frosted plexiglass tetradecagon outfitted with powerful infrasound speakers that pump low-frequency tones outside the range of human hearing. According to experiments conducted by Goldsmiths College, these vibrations are capable, in theory, of producing a "haunted" feeling - or at the very least the perception of strange smells and physiological hallucinations like dizziness. Visitors may enter and judge for themselves how easily their sensory perceptions are smeared. "This is a New York 'haunted house'" de Beer says. "New York City architecture doesn't have gabled roofs or spooky parlors. It has office buildings, apartment buildings. And the only empty buildings here are either condemned or in the financial district."

I was utterly taken with Susan Gregory Thomas's article on "The Good Divorce" in the Sunday Styles section. My parents are rounding the bend on 61 years of marriage, but I well remember the nuclear effect that divorce had on my best friend's life. Her parents split when she was 11. They went on to poison every holiday, every birthday, every milestone event for decades. The first time I can recall them ever being in a (large) room together without tearing it down was at my friend's wedding, when we were 30.

Two hundred years ago it was illegal to drive over four miles per hour on the streets of England, and cars had to be preceded by a man on foot waving a red flag. Luckily, in 1896, the speed limit was raised to 14 miles per hour and cars no longer had to have someone walk ahead of them -- the red flag requirement having been eliminated in 1878. In the fall of 1896, motorists celebrated their newfound freedom by driving an "Emancipation Run" from London to the seaside town of Sussex. Today, a re-enactment of the event, now called the Brighton Veteran Car Run, takes place annually with a procession of pre-1905 cars driving from London to Brighton, about 60 miles away, this year from Nov. 4 to 6.

READ--William Augustus, Jr. of Palm Beach, Florida and Cody, Wyoming was the eldest of nine children. He was born on Beacon Street in Boston, Massachusetts, May 16, 1918 to Admiral William A. Read and Edith Fabyan Read. Mr. Read grew up in Purchase, N.Y. and was educated in New England, attending St. Paul's School and the Hun School. He married Kathleen Cushman Spence and they had one daughter, Edith Fabyan Read (Wey). A divorce occurred subsequent to his missing-in-action status during WWII. After Pearl Harbor, he joined the Navy, graduating from the Navy Aerial Gunnery Instructors School in Pensacola, Florida. He was Range Officer at the Navy Border Field Machine Gun Range in San Diego, California and became the Gunnery Officer for the Navy Patrol Squadron 101 in the South West Pacific on the Navy version of the B24 Liberator. He was shot down on his twenty fifth combat mission as Bow Turret Gunner for the Commanding Officer of the Squadron. He and some of the surviving crew were able to swim to an island in the Sulu Sea near Palawan Island within Japanese territory, where they lived on coconuts. He was wounded again in a second crash in which a Japanese plane was shot down and landed on some of the surviving members of the crew, killing two of them and further wounding the others. He was missing-in-action for two months. They were rescued by the submarine, Gunnell. His decorations include two Air Medals, two Purple Hearts, and the Navy Cross. Lieutenant William Read had flown 25 combat missions without flight pay. After the war, he became a partner with Phelps, Fenn and Company, a municipal bonds firm in New York City. In 1959, he married Isabel Uppercu Collier and they subsequently moved to Florida. They had been married just short of 50 years at her death in 2008. His skill in shooting has led to his qualification for the Navy Pistol and Rifle Expert. Mr. Read won the gold medal in the Olympics in the International Skeet Veterans Class. He is also in the Trap Shooting Hall of Fame, has won and successfully defended the Pennsylvania 50 Bird Challenge Cup, and defended it for a year. He has achieved his 100,000 target American Trap Shooting Association Pin. After his retirement, he became a licensed alligator trapper in South West Florida, near the family ranch in Immokalee, priding himself on filling his quota of 160 alligators annually with 160 shots. He was past president of the Palm Beach Skeet and Trap Club, a member of the Philadelphia Gun Club, and the Campfire Club of America; as well as the Cody Shooting Complex in Cody, Wyoming. He was also a member of the Bath and Tennis Club, the Everglades Club, and the Sailfish Club all in Palm Beach, Florida and the Brook Club in New York. He was the originator of Okeechobee Shooting Sports in Okeechobee, FL. Mr. Read is survived by his daughter Edith Read Wey, and two grandsons, Thomas Alexander (Lisa) Wey, Jr. and David Read (Claudia) Wey and three great-grandsons, Nicholas, Gianluca, and Gunnar Wey. He also leaves his three stepsons: Inglis Collier, Miles (Parker) Collier, Barron (Tami) Collier II, and his three step grandchildren Laura Collier, Barron Collier V, and Charlotte Collier, along with one sister, Jean Read Knox, and two brothers, Peter Read and Donald Read. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Isabel Collier Read, and five brothers: Curtis, David, Alexander, Roderick, and Frederick. The Family will receive friends from 11:00a until Noon on Thursday, November 3, 2011 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL, 33401. Graveside Services with Military Honors will be held Immediateely following at Hillcrest Memorial Park, West Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Naval Institute Foundation, 291 Wood Road, Annapolis, Maryland 21402-9987.

NURKIN--Harry. With great sadness we honor Harry Nurkin, Ph.D. and all that he contributed to the Milbank Memorial Fund. Dr. Nurkin joined the Board of Directors in 2008 and was immediately engaged in the work of the Fund. He brought to discussions about the Fund's program his firsthand knowledge of managing complex health care systems and his dedication to caring for members of underserved populations. Over a period of 21 years, he led the development of the Carolinas HealthCare System from a single public hospital to the third largest public healthcare system in the U.S. In addition to his insightful comments, the board and staff also remember his warmth, good humor and unfailing courtesy. We will miss him. Samuel L. "Tony" Milbank, Chairman Carmen Hooker Odom, President Milbank Memorial Fund

On Wednesday, Mayor Michael Bloomberg went to Union Square to welcome Yelp, the latest Silicon Valley company to put down roots in Manhattan. ''This is the latest proof that New York is on its way to becoming a Number One digital hub,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, during a press conference held at the Yelp offices. Yelp follows in the footsteps of Accel Partners, a noted venture capital firm, and Twitter, which opened its New York offices earlier this month. Facebook and Google already have well-established presences in Manhattan.

LEE--Dr. William Franklin, III, aka Bill Lee, 82 died October 23, 2011 in New Smyrna Beach, FL. Born February 20, 1929, in Galveston, TX, Dr. Lee was a jazz pianist, composer, arranger, author, and music educator renowned for pioneering comprehensive music education. Lee served on the faculties of St. Mary's University, The University of Texas, Sam Houston State University, Florida International University and is most known for having led the University of Miami School of Music to international influence across several music genres, particularly jazz, as Dean of the School of Music, Composer-in-Residence and Distinguished Professor of Music. Dr. Lee also served as Vice-President and Provost at The University of Miami and was one of the founding members, Past President and Executive Director of the International Association of Jazz Educators (IAJE). Lee was playing trumpet professionally at age 12 and performing with the Houston Symphony at 15. He was pianist with several big bands and jazz greats, including Gene Krupa, Artie Shaw, Charlie Parker, Red Rodney and Gerry Mulligan. As a professional composer-arranger, Lee won more than 20 ASCAP awards. His musical composition, Eight Vignettes for a Festive Occasion was nominated for a Pulitzer Prize and he is in the Songwriters Hall of Fame. Dr. Lee published over 100 books and received Grammy nominations for his compositions and recordings as well as two Deems Taylor Awards for his books People In Jazz and the biography of Stan Kenton, Artistry in Rhythm. He was also biographer for Maynard Ferguson, Billy Taylor and wrote comprehensive libraries of instructional and biographical music publications. Bill moved to New Smyrna Beach in 2005 to be closer to his children. He settled into retirement and in recent years authored another dozen books outlining notable musicians and their contributions in a series of books chronicled by musical instrument. Bill was preceded in death by his first wife, Lois. He is survived by his children, William F. Lee IV (Will Lee) and wife Sandrine, Robert Lee and wife Karen, Patricia Lee McAllister, and Peggy Lee Wharton and husband Rick; grandchildren Leeann, Tanya, Jessica, Jacquelyn, Austin, and a great-grandson expected in March. He also left behind the love of his life and former wife, Jacqueline Tyler Lee. Bill was a pioneer and visionary who contributed immeasurably to the music world and its students and scholars. His love and respect for jazz and its roots were his lifelong passion. Bill will be deeply missed by all who knew him. A scholarship has been established at the University of Miami's Frost School of Music in the name of Dr. William F. Lee http://www.miami.edu/williamleescholarship. Donations may also be mailed to the The William F. Lee Scholarship, University of Miami, Frost School of Music, 1314 Miller Drive, Coral Gables, FL 32146. Bill would have been pleased to know his legacy will continue at the University of Miami through future students.

The two lead actresses in the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' who muddled through months of backstage drama and script changes last winter, will leave the show in November when their contracts expire, the producers said on Friday. Jennifer Damiano, who plays the romantic lead Mary Jane Watson, will give her final performance on Nov. 6 and be replaced by Rebecca Faulkenberry, who recently made her Broadway debut in ''Rock of Ages.'' Ms. Damiano, who received a Tony Award nomination in 2009 for ''Next to Normal,'' saw her ''Spider-Man'' role expand considerably during a major overhaul of the musical in April, a bid to appeal to audience members with a love story involving Mary Jane and the main character, Peter Parker.

A book review on Tuesday about ''The Concussion Crisis,'' by Linda Carroll and David Rosner, misstated the role of Kevin Guskiewicz, a sports physiologist at the University of North Carolina, in studying head blows sustained by young athletes. Dr. Guskiewicz uses helmets fitted with accelerometers to measure the number and cumulative force of these impacts; he did not develop the helmet technology. (The developer was Simbex, a company in Lebanon, N.H.)

It would be hard to overstate the level of preposterousness that surrounds Jon Gnarr, the punk rocker-turned-comedic actor-turned mayor of Reykjavik, Iceland. Mr. Gnarr was elected in 2010 after he formed a quasi-satirical political party, the Best Party; his campaign promises included putting a polar bear in the city zoo and offering free towels in the swimming pools - as well as a promise to break all his campaign promises. Given that degree of personal absurdity, his appearance in New York on Saturday, to speak at a small conference dedicated to the future of radio, would qualify as merely unlikely. Mr. Gnarr was the keynote speaker of the first Radiovision Festival, a three-day conference put on by the radio station WFMU; other guests included representatives from Twitter, Kickstarter, the Web site Know Your Meme and Makerbot, which produces 3D-printers.

A week after a miserable performance in a loss at Jacksonville, Ray Rice rushed for a career-high three touchdowns in the Ravens' 30-27 win over the Cardinals. The Rams' defense held Drew Brees to a season-low 269 yards, sacked him six times and intercepted him twice in St. Louis' 31-21 victory. Chris Long had three sacks, Robert Quinn blocked a punt and Darian Stewart returned an interception for a touchdown with less than three minutes left to seal the win, the Rams' first this season.

The makers of ''America in Primetime,'' a four-week documentary series on PBS that began Sunday, produced more than the show itself: they also produced underwriting spots for Unilever's Dove brand that are helping to pay for the program. The 30-second spots, which run at the beginning and end of the hourlong episodes, are shot in a style similar to the program's. Both the spots and the show, made by the Documentary Group, feature interviews. For the series, the creators, writers and actors behind prime-time television shows are interviewed, while the interviews in the underwriting spots are with unnamed Dove marketing and public relations executives, who discuss how the brand tries to relate to changing consumers.

Alabama football had already established a rich tradition before Bryant arrived in 1958, but he took the program to an even-higher level of national prominence - and he did it while wearing a houndstooth hat.

An article on Wednesday about jobs in the solar power industry misidentified the source of some employment statistics. The figures of 24,000 people working in solar manufacturing and 52,500 working in solar installation came from a report by the Solar Foundation, not from Environment America. CARPENTER--Ruth C. The Shakespeare Society community is deeply saddened at the passing of our beloved colleague Ruth Carpenter. Since the founding of The Society, in a series of remarkable Shakespeare seminars, Ruth generously shared with us her penetrating insight, vast erudition, joyous wit and open heart. New York's theatrical community also benefited immeasurably from Ruth's enthusiasm and knowledge. Those theater artists lucky enough to have had Ruth as an adviser came away encouraged and enlightened. Ruth was a stellar teacher, a wise mentor and the best friend one could ever have. We mourn her passing, celebrate her life and offer our deepest sympathies to her family and wide circle of friends. Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies a lass uparallel'd. Antony & Cleopatra, V, ii.

DreamWorks Animation's ''Puss in Boots,'' a spin-off of that studio's ''Shrek'' franchise, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $34 million. An unusually heavy autumn snowstorm in the Northeast may have kept some potential ticket buyers at home: Hollywood had been expecting a total closer to $40 million. But ''Puss in Boots,'' which cost about $130 million to make and was distributed by Paramount Pictures, received strong critical reviews and an A-minus from audiences in exit polls, opening up the possibility of solid sales in weekends ahead. Paramount's ultra-low-budget ''Paranormal Activity 3'' was second, selling about $18.5 million in tickets for a two-week total of $81.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. ''In Time,'' a $40 million thriller from 20th Century Fox and New Regency, was a soft third, taking in about $12 million. ''Footloose'' (Paramount) was fourth, taking in $5.4 million for a three-week total of $38.4 million. In a rare misfire, Johnny Depp brought up the rear as his ''Rum Diary,'' financed at an estimated $50 million and released by FilmDistrict, placed fifth with about $5 million in ticket sales.
